DOC.HEAD: Florida Congressmen Ask Bush To Bar Drilling
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 3rd graf to delete extraneous words.
DOC.TEXT: Florida congressmen said after meeting with President Bush Thursday that they were optimistic Bush would bar new oil drilling off the South Florida coast. But Sen. Bob Graham, D-Fla., said the president made no commitments on the matter. ``His previous statements as well as statements he made today were indicative of a disinclination to proceed with further drilling,'' in the tract 116 off South Florida, Graham said after the 13 congressmen met with Bush at the White House. The lawmakers unanimously recommended against new drilling, Republican Sen. Connie Mack said. ``With respect to his attitude I don't think that anyone in this meeting came away with a feeling of disappointment. There was a feeling that the president is going to be ruling in a way that we're gong to be very happy,'' he said. Democratic Rep. Dante Fascell was less willing to assume the president would decide to block exploration and drilling, but said he, too, was ``optimistic the president will make the right decision.'' Bush is to announce, perhaps as early as next week, what his plans are for the oil lease area off southern Florida and two areas off Northern and Southern California. He held up any oil-exploration activity in the three regions last year and named a task force to study the prospects and impacts of drilling. The task force submitted its report in January, but Bush, a former Texas oil company executive, has yet to act. He met this week with task force members to discuss options and also has consulted with the California delegation. Bush indicated to the Florida lawmakers he felt there was not enough oil in the Florida waters to warrant the risk to the environment that oil exploration would cause, said Republican Rep. Porter Goss. ``He did not seem to feel that we had a whole lot of oil out there ... to really justify all this havoc,'' Goss said. But Joe Lastelic, spokesman for the American Petroleum Institute, said the government's 1989 estimates were that the South Florida basin could contain as much as 1.06 billion barrels of oil. Unocal Corp. has said it could be more than 2.5 billion barrels. That compares with an estimated 10 billion barrels of undiscovered oil off the coast of California, said Lastelic. There are 42 gallons in each barrel. Bush asked the congressmen what should be done about 73 existing leases, where activity has been held up, Fascell said. The congressman said he told Bush the government should reimburse the lease holders.

DOC.HEAD: Former Negotiator Advocates End to Nuclear Tests
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS 2nd graf to restore Smith's first name
DOC.TEXT: The handful of nations possessing nuclear weapons should halt all testing and deployments as a step toward slowing the spread of nuclear weapons technology, a former chief U.S. arms negotiator told Congress on Thursday. ``If the majority of nations are to be expected indefinitely to forgo (nuclear) arms ... should not nations already deploying them also accept some constraints, especially now that the Cold War is over?'' Gerard C. Smith told a House subcommittee.
DOC.HEAD: The Bush, 3rd graf
Accused Gunman Guilty in Bensonhurst Murder
DOC.NOTE: Eds: RECASTS lead, SUBS 18th graf, `Bailey, the...,' with 4 grafs to UPDATE with reax from Bensonhurst.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY48, NY52
DOC.TEXT: A jury Thursday found a 19-year-old white man guilty of second-degree murder in the killing of a black teen-ager in Bensonhurst, the most serious racial incident to polarize the city since the 1986 Howard Beach case. Joseph Fama of Brooklyn, accused of being the triggerman in the killing of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, faces a maximum sentence of 25 years to life in prison. Jury forewoman Tonya Bailey delivered the verdict shortly after 7 p.m. The decision followed 10 tension-wrought days of deliberations during which police lined the steps of Brooklyn state Supreme Court to quell occasional scuffles. Hawkins and three friends were attacked by a gang of whites last Aug. 23 after they ventured into the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn to look at a used car. The verdict, the first conviction in the case, was greeted with shouts of glee outside the courtroom by Hawkins' family and supporters, and chants of ``Yusuf! Yusuf!'' Mayor David N. Dinkins, in a statement, said the guilty verdict allows ``us to turn our attention to the process of healing.'' ``Yusuf Hawkins died of racism in the first degree. That is a crime far more common than most of us are willing to admit,'' the mayor said. Fama was found guilty on 13 of 15 counts, including second-degree murder by depraved indifference to human life, riot, unlawful imprisonment, menacing, discrimination, and criminal possession of a weapon in the third degree. The defendant was acquitted of second-degree intentional murder _ the equivalent in seriousness of the depraved indifference charge _ as well as criminal possession of a weapon in the second degree. The shooting of Hawkins shocked the city and is the most serious racial incident since the December 1986 attack in which a gang of whites in Howard Beach, Queens, chased a black man to his hit-and-run death on a highway. In the days after Hawkins' death, racial tensions in the city flared as chanting protesters marched through Bensonhurst, clashing with white residents who screamed obscenities and racial slurs. Fama sat impassively beside his lawyer as the verdict was read. Several jurors wiped tears from their eyes. Moses Stewart, the victim's father, let out a quick, ``Yeah,'' but then said nothing else as the other charges were read. Hawkins' family and friends, holding hands with their advisor, the Rev. Al Sharpton, walked silently out of the courtroom, saying nothing. Then they let out a shout. Quickly they were surrounded by about 150 supporters who shouted ``Yusuf! Yusuf!'' At one point, Stewart raised a clenched fist in the air and smiled. When someone handed him a bullhorn, he joined in the chant for his slain son. ``This is a victory for the people,'' said Dave Walker, an investigator for a Brooklyn civil rights group. ``The tension's high throughout the city, throughout the whole country. ... All communities needed the verdict.'' Meanwhile, Fama's family was in a third-floor corridor and not speaking to reporters. In Bensonhurst, the mood was defensive. ``I feel bad for Joey,'' said John Deliso, 21. ``It wasn't a fair trial. The judge and the media sort of practically forced the jury to come up with a guilty verdict.'' ``He was a good boy. I've known him 20 years,'' said his next door neighbor, a woman who refused to be identified. ``They didn't have enough evidence. Nobody saw him with a gun. Nobody picked him out of a lineup.'' Bailey, the jury forewoman, said she did not feel the evidence supported the prosecution's claim that Fama was the shooter. ``I personally had decided that he was the shooter but there was not enough evidence according to the law for me to convict him of that.'' Bailey, a college professor at Brooklyn Technical College, said the deliberations took so long because ``It was that we examined every single aspect of the law. ... We had differences of opinion in how we interpreted the law.'' The case had worried city and community leaders who feared increased racial strie because of the murder. ``We hope that this is the last time we ever have to try one of these cases,'' said prosecutor James Kohler. ``But something tells me that we'll be back here again trying another one of these cases, until people learn how to get along with one another. And stop all of this racial hatred.'' A second jury considering charges against co-defendant Keith Mondello ended its deliberations Thursday without reaching a verdict. David DePetris, Fama's lawyer, blamed the verdict on Judge Thaddeus Owens' instructions to the jury, which he called ``substantially one-sided.'' He said the prosecution theory focused on Fama as the shooter, and his defense focused on rebutting that charge, but the judge's instructions enabled the jury to convict Fama for participating, even if it found he did not fire the shot. ``I think the verdict pretty clearly demonstrates that this jury was following the judge's instructions as best as they could,'' DePetris said. ``But I think it also points up that the basis for their conviction was that Joe Fama was on 69th Street and nothing more.'' The Fama jury had begun deliberations at 5 p.m. last Monday. Co-defendant Mondello was tried in the same courtroom. The victim was slain on a warm evening when he and three friends, all black, went to the mostly white Bensonhurst neighborhood of Brooklyn to look at a used car. Fama fled after the shooting but surrendered a few days later and has been held without bail since. Six other young whites have been charged in the attack and still face trial. A mile-long demonstration march through downtown Brooklyn a week after the shooting ended in a violent confrontation as bottle-throwing protesters clashed with riot-equipped police officers on the approach to the Brooklyn Bridge. Prosecutors allege Mondello, also 19, assembled a gang of 30 or more of his friends from the neighborhood in south Brooklyn because he feared 25 black and Hispanic friends of a neighborhood girl, Gina Feliciano, were coming to beat him up. When Hawkins and his pals appeared on the street at about 9:20 p.m., the whites apparently mistook them for outside troublemakers. Several of the bat-wielding whites surrounded Hawkins and pinned the teen in a doorway, prosecutors said. Fama then pulled a .32-caliber automatic pistol and squeezed off four shots. Two of the bullets went through Hawkins' chest, ripping apart his heart. Another bullet hit his hand. The teen-ager tried to flee, but collapsed bleeding on the sidewalk and died. In his closing remarks to the jury, Assistant District Attorney Edward Boyar stared Fama straight in the face and shouted, ``Mr. Fama, you are responsible for the death of Yusuf Hawkins. You had the gun. You pulled the trigger. You are responsible.'' But defense lawyer David DePetris methodically went through what he called uncertainties and contradictions in the prosecution's case against his client. ``Yes, the death of Yusuf Hawkins was a tragedy,'' DePetris said. ``Yes, whoever shot, and whoever the prosecution proves shot Yusuf Hawkins should be punished.'' He argued prosecutors failed to prove beyond a reasonable doubt that Fama was the gunman.

DOC.HEAD: Jurors Not Convinced Fama Was the Shooter
With AM-Racial Slaying
DOC.TEXT: Jurors who convicted a young white man Thursday in the Bensonhurst racial slaying said prosecutors failed to prove their charge that the defendant was the one who shot a black 16-year-old. But jurors said they believed Joseph Fama's role as part of the white mob that attacked Yusuf Hawkins was enough to convict him of second-degree murder by depraved indifference to human life and of 12 of 14 other charges. ``I feel that he had the choice, if he knew what was going on, to leave the area,'' said jury forewoman Tonya Bailey. ``To act with a mob is depraved indifference to me. I've seen mobs, and it becomes one entity, as opposed to individuals.'' said Bailey, a professor at Brooklyn Technical College. ``I was personally convinced that he was the shooter, but there was not enough evidence for me to convict him of that,'' she added. Hawkins and three other friends were attacked Aug. 23 as they walked through the mostly white section of Bensonhurst in Brooklyn. Jurors convicted Fama, 19, after state Justice Thaddeus Owens told them the defendant could be found guilty of second-degree murder even if he only participated in the attack. ``He is just as liable if he contributed to the realization of the plan _ if he helped or made it possible,'' Owens told jurors late Wednesday. The last holdout on the jury, telephone company worker Steven Berquist, told reporters he agreed to vote guilty on the murder count Thursday morning as the panel began its 11th day of deliberations. ``If I had any reasonable doubt, I wouldn't have convicted,'' he said. Although the case was one of the most racially charged in New York, race played no role in the difficult deliberations, said Debbie Cose and Michele Gardner, two of the three black jurors on the 12-member panel. ``We put that aside in the jury room,'' said Cose, a secretary in an accounting firm. ``We were family for 11 days,'' said Gardner. As Bailey delivered her verdict just minutes after 7 p.m., several jurors wiped tears from their eyes. ``The sympathy that we feel for both families made it very difficult,'' said Kelley Freer, a young bank employee, her eyes still red from weeping.

DOC.HEAD: Cappiello Named Stamford Correspondent
DOC.TEXT: Janet Cappiello, special projects coordinator in Corporate Communications for The Associated Press, has been named the AP's correspondent in Stamford. The appointment was announced Wednesday by Hartford Chief of Bureau Mary Anne Rhyne. Cappiello, 26, succeeds Jill Arabas, who is transferring to Business News in New York. Cappiello joined the AP in Louisville, Ky., in 1985 and worked as a newswoman there until moving to Corporate Communications at AP headquarters in New York last May. As special projects coordinator, she edited the monthly AP People newsletter and Spectrum, an annual communications newsletter, and wrote for AP World magazine. A native of Stamford, she is a graduate of Boston University.

DOC.HEAD: Evangelicals Turned Tide for Fujimori
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Alberto Fujimori, the Roman Catholic son of Buddhist immigrants, counts on Protestant evangelicals to help him defeat novelist Mario Vargas Llosa, an agnostic, for the presidency of Peru. Fujimori's parents immigrated to this predominantly Catholic country from Japan in 1934. He finished a close second to Vargas Llosa in a field of nine candidates April 8 and a runoff between them is scheduled for June 3. Vargas Llosa, an advocate of free markets, was the favorite, but Fujimori surged late in the first campaign despite a shortage of advertising funds. Polls show the once-obscure agronomist leading his famous opponent less than three weeks before the runoff. Evangelical Christians, responding to Fujimori's message of work, thrift and honesty, carried his campaign to areas the poll-takers never penetrated. They spread the word in revival meetings, knocked on doors in Lima slums and the violent Peruvian countryside. Raul Gonzalez, a sociologist, attributed Fujimori's strong support in regions where leftist guerrillas are dominant to the grassroots work of evangelicals and the diminishing presence of the Catholic Church. ``The evangelicals have been working door to door, almost person to person,'' he said. ``That has been very important.'' Evangelical denominations have grown rapidly in Peru. Sociologists say they offer moral and social discipline in a nation being driven to anarchy by economic crisis and the leftist insurgency. About 1 million of Peru's 22 million people attend storefront Protestant churches and the number has doubled in five years, according to the churches. The largest denomination is the Assembly of God, which has 1,152 churches in Peru. The evangelical movement also has grown elsewhere in Latin America. Efrain Rios Montt, a retired army general and evangelist who led a Guatemalan military government in the early 1980s, is a leading candidate for president this year. Jaime Althaus, a Peruvian anthropologist and newspaper columnist, said the evangelicals reflect the conservatism of Change 90, embodying the ``values of work, effort, savings that are at the base of grassroots capitalism.'' Fujimori recruited Carlos Garcia, a Baptist preacher, in November as a candidate for one of the two vice presidencies. Garcia later was elected president of the National Evangelical Council, an organization of Protestant churches ranging from Methodists to Pentacostals. Evangelicals made up about one-fourth of the 200 congressional candidates for Change 90, Fujimori's party. Many young party workers belong to the movement. Change 90 won about 50 of the 240 congressional seats April 8, but the official results have not been announced. Fujimori got 30 percent of the vote for president, two points less than Vargas Llosa. ``The evangelicals like Fujimori because he is honest and he is the only truly independent candidate,'' said campaign worker Ricardo Massa, a born-again Christian. Massa's uncle, Alejandro Rojas, is an evangelical minister and general secretary of Change 90. Guillermo Yoshikawa, a Methodist minister and Change 90 congressional candidate, addressed a letter to the ``evangelical public'' urging churchgoers to support the party's candidates. ``No longer will we have to ask `favors','' it said. ``Our brothers in parliament will make sure that the rights granted us in the constitution become a reality for all evangelicals.'' Catholic church officials claim Change 90 supporters sent flyers to convents, monasteries and groups of Catholic mothers urging people to vote against Vargas Llosa because he is an agnostic. Cardinal Augusto Vargas Alzamora has said the church would not endorse a presidential candidate, but the Apostolic League of St. Pius X, a conservative Roman Catholic group, declared in its monthly newsletter: ``If the evangelicals come to power, sooner or later Peru will become Protestant. No more masses. No more processions. No more saints.'' Fujimori says attempts to portray Change 90 as a disguised religious crusade are unfounded. ``I'm not preoccupied by religion and I don't discriminate on grounds of religion,'' he said, but added, in an obvious reference to his opponent: ``I believe Catholic people would prefer a Catholic president.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans in Philippines Face Growing Security Fears
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Americans in the Philippines, long accustomed to deferential treatment in the country the United States once ruled, still live the good life here, but safety is a growing concern. Ordinary Americans often live in opulence undreamed of by poorer Filipinos. Many have homes in in plush residential districts guarded by private security firms, away from the noise, pollution and rundown conditions of even middle-class Manila neighborhoods. But in the past two weeks, three U.S. enlisted men have been slain by suspected Communist rebels, bringing to eight the number of Americans slain in politically motivated attacks since April 1989. There is no widespread panic in the 140,000-member American community, but there is a sense of unease. ``Everyone is aware of the threat,'' said Mark Blacker, president of the American Chamber of Commerce in the Philippines. ``We all live with a little bit of apprehension.'' Concern is greatest among American diplomats and military personnel, believed to be the rebels' primary targets. Senior diplomats now drive in cars without diplomatic license plates and vary their routes to work. Armed guards screen visitors at their homes. ``We used to drive up to Clark (Air Base) every week to shop in the commissary,'' said the wife of one American diplomat, who spoke on condition her name not be published. ``But no more. People think the area around the bases is just too risky.'' It was near Clark that two young airmen were slain Sunday. The U.S. military's Far East Network airs frequent security warnings, including advice against wearing uniforms off base. Children of officers assigned to the Joint U.S. Military Assistance Group are forbidden from giving their home addresses and telephone numbers, even to the staff of schools they attend. Security concerns of Americans were heightened by December's bloody attempt to topple the government of President Corazon Aquino. The coup bid was crushed with the help of U.S. jets. But fears were fueled by persistent rumors of a fresh coup attempt and continued threats from Communist rebels. ``We will not stop until all U.S. bases and all American occupational soldiers are kicked out of our country,'' said Communist rebels who claimed responsibility for Sunday's killings. The slayings came on the eve of U.S.-Philippine talks on the future of the six American military bases in the Philippines. Those talks have pumped up nationalist sentiment among the 60 million Filipinos, many of whom view the bases as a vestige of U.S. colonial rule. Many Filipinos believe the United States, which ruled the Philippines from 1898 until independence in 1946, still dominates their nation economically, culturally and politically. Some examples of that can be seen in everyday life. Americans are addressed as ``Sir'' or ``Ma'am'' while other foreigners generally are not. Police often ignore Americans' minor traffic violations. But such treatment does little to calm anxiety. After Sunday's killings, the off-base movements of 40,000 military personnel, civilian Defense Department employees and dependents were restricted. Such warnings are becoming common. Several American families said they had curtailed the nightlife of their teen-age children. They said they planned summer vacations in the United States after foreign schools close in June. The American Womens' Club has noted a sharp decline in attendance at social functions because British, Australian and New Zealand nationals have been advised by their embassies to stay away from places where Americans gather. ``We used to go somewhere every weekend,'' said the wife of one American businessman, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``Now, I just travel between my home and the supermarket.'' Last March, the commander of the rebel army, Romulo Kintanar, said the guerrillas would not target American civilians who had no links to the counterinsurgency. Officials acknowledge that if the rebels expanded their targets to civilians, guaranteeing their safety would be impossible. Maj. Gen. Rodolfo Biazon, chief of the National Capital Region Defense Command, pointed to the huge number of potential American targets. ``How can we protect them all?'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: At Real Southfork, Life's a Soap Opera These Days
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Southfork Ranch was spared the recent flooding in north Texas, but J.R. Ewing's home on ``Dallas'' hasn't exactly been left high and dry. In fact, recent events sound more like a soap opera than many of those shown this season on the TV series. The international symbol of Texas glitz and glamour as portrayed on the series filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, temporarily blocking the 41-acre tourist operation from being sold at auction. Employees also say: _ There have been two rounds of staff layoffs. _ Ranch house carpeting required replacement because pipes burst during a winter freeze. _ Two Texas Longhorns broke down part of a fence trying to get at a tourist who was irritating them by snapping photographs. _ And Buffie, the ranch buffalo, is pregnant. ``It's discouraging, but I think we'll remain open,'' said ranch tour guide Paul Smith, 23, of Garland. It's no secret any longer that times are tough on the ranch, filmed as the home of the fictional J.R., his mother Miss Ellie and the rest of his extended family. The ranch, 25 miles north of downtown Dallas, is the state's ninth most-visited tourist attraction. Its fortunes seem to have fallen, just as in real life the Texas oil industry's aura of invincibility evaporated. And its ties to the television series are all but cut. Even the neighbors have noticed. ``J.R. Ewing would be welcome out here, if he needs to move,'' joked Nelda Burge, manager of the Southfork Mobile Home Park just down the road. ``We have a J.R. Avenue and a Miss Ellie Lane.'' Owner Terry V. Trippet did not return several phone calls made over two weeks by The Associated Press. In August, Lorimar Distribution, producer of ``Dallas,'' filed a lawsuit to cut off sales at the ranch of any souvenirs or other items related to the series. Lorimar contends Trippet didn't renew a licensing agreement and even wants him to remove the encircled SF from the front gate. ``It is Lorimar Television's policy never to discuss pending litigation,'' said Lorimar spokesman David Stapf in Culver City, Calif., when asked the status of the lawsuit. Trippet, who like J.R. was once an oilman, bought the ranch in 1984 for $7 million in a heavily financed transaction. The ranch generates income from groups who rent it for private parties. ``We've had a couple proms already this year,'' Smith said. ``There are dinners maybe four nights a week.'' Although some first-time visitors are shocked at how small the ranchhouse really is _ ``It's amazing what a wide-angle lens can do,'' says Smith _ Southfork holds a special place in the hearts of ``Dallas'' fans worldwide. The show is broadcast in more than 100 countries and has been translated into more than 30 languages. On a recent afternoon, a family from Malaysia, a foursome from Great Britain and a Swedish man toured the ranch and snapped pictures. ``I'm interested to see the entire world, but especially this,'' said Hans Helgemar, 40, of Uppsala, Sweden. His only disappointment was the absence of the man he knows as ``Yay-Are.'' That is a constant disappointment for many other visitors. Stapf, the Lorimar spokesman, said the season that ended Friday was the first in 13 years in which no episodes were filmed in the Dallas area. Smith promised a group of tourists that the cast members would be back this summer for more filming. But Stapf said he does not know if that is so. Ms. Burge said many foreign tourists knock on her door, asking for directions. But Ms. Burge has wearied of the series herself. ``To be honest, I've quit watching it,'' she said. The series' contract with CBS has one more year. The network hasn't said if it would renew the contract. Last week's episode ranked 30th in the A.C. Nielsens Co. ratings.

DOC.HEAD: Puppeteer Henson Leaves A Legacy of Living Characters
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Obit-Henson
DOC.TEXT: With the death of puppeteer Jim Henson, creator and alter ego of Kermit the Frog and scores of other Muppet characters, it is like a room crowded with old friends has fallen suddenly silent. Kermit cut a heroic figure for this age, a bemused voice of reason in an absurd world. ``It's not easy being green,'' Kermit sang on the preschoolers' ``Sesame Street,'' but concluded that many nice things are green. Henson was tall, lean, bearded, with an unruly mane of graying brown hair and a scholar's slouch. The loudest thing about him were his sports coats. He always seemed a bit uncomfortable in front of the cameras. Exposed to this world, he would patiently explain the logic of his, where fluffy, furry, feathered critters had quirks and qualms like our own. On ``Sesame Street,'' Kermit would interview three little pigs about construction techniques; he'd cover the cow that jumped over the moon as if it were a NASA space shot. As emcee of the syndicated ``Muppet Show,'' Kermit brought dignity (and intense frustration) to the impossible task of mounting a variety show with dozens of Muppets and one live human, like Liza Minnelli or Paul Simon. There was no joke too ancient, no sight gag too skewed, no pun too awful that Henson and his collaborators could not dust it off and trot it out, usually with an elegant variation, for ``The Muppet Show.'' In one inspired bit, singer Della Reese sits in her dressing room surrounded by clattering shellfish. Don't ask why. ``Oh, clam up!'' she snaps. In another scene, Muppets horrifically collide on a ski slope to the ambling strains of ``Tumbling Tumbleweeds.'' Through it all, Kermit would cope, or try to, where others would give up. And Henson, even while presiding over a multimillion dollar Muppet empire, stayed with the frog. Like others of his generation, Henson's first exposure to puppets was Burr Tillstrom's TV show ``Kukla, Fran and Ollie,'' featuring hand puppets Kukla the clown and Oliver J. Dragon with their human friend Fran Allison. Henson saw that television and Muppets were made for each other. The little screen might turn humans into one-dimensional talking heads, but Muppets literally could fill the screen with action _ top, bottom and sides. Henson also took his puppets out of the traditional Punch and Judy proscenium, using sophisticated materials and technology to create them and put them through their paces. And what wonderful characters: _ Big Bird, a whopping, yellow bird on ``Sesame Street'' with the same cares and questions about the world as any 5-year-old. If a bird that big can have questions about things, maybe it's OK for a small person to wonder as well. _ Cookie Monster, blue and shaggy with quivering, crazy eyes, could devour non-food substances with impunity, but would lapse into hoarsely bellowing ``Cookie? Cookie? Cookie!'' at the prospect of eating one. _ Miss Piggy, a prima donna whose blond tresses, blue eyes and snout have graced pinup calendars, famed for her shrill battle cry and karate blows and her not-so-secret passion for Kermit _ who, of course, wanted nothing to do with her. Frog meets pig, frog loses pig ... _ Fozzie Bear, a perennially flop-sweated comedian who can't get a chuckle from a crowd with a tankful of laughing gas. _ Gonzo, a beakey creature whose passion is ... chickens. _ Rowlf, the gravel-voiced dog whose barrelhouse piano stylings showed off a strong left paw. And so on. Henson went into a class by himself when he moved his creations beyond television, putting the Muppets into three feature films, beginning with ``The Muppet Movie'' in 1979. In 1982, Henson directed ``The Dark Crystal,'' a fantasy adventure set in a never-world with no human characters. He followed its success with ``Labyrinth,'' another fantasy feature, in 1985. Henson's Creature Workshop also designed the figures of the ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles'' movie. Ultimately, Henson used computers, hydraulics, radio controls and other electronic hardware to make his puppets more lifelike. Henson lived his adult life doing exactly what he loved, and his work showed it. As the theme song of ``The Muppet Movie'' concluded about pursuing one's dreams, ``everyone needs a rainbow connection, the lover, the dreamer and me.''

DOC.HEAD: In Remembrance of Emily, The Pig
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Poor Emily. She was taken before her time. May her sweet pig's soul rest in peace. The 680-pound swine was led down the garden path and out to slaughter, the victim of man's brutish ways. ``They just sent her off to market without a fare-thee-well,'' said Karin Stoll, who raised the 4-week-old piglet to full-grown in the Martha's Vineyard town of West Tisbury only to see her end up in the hands of Jimmy Dean sausage makers. ``She had no business dying that way,'' the bereaved pet-owner said in a telephone interview Wednesday. Stoll, a longtime resident of Martha's Vineyard, shared her sad story with friends and neighbors on the summer resort island in an obituary for Emily published in The Vineyard Gazette. Two weeks ago, about 15 mourners held a vegetarian ``pignic'' in memory of Emily, who met her maker after a change of hands at the farm where she was boarded until last month. ``Everywhere I go, people give condolences,'' Stoll said. Emily was a well-loved fixture known to many as Stoll's pride and joy, but ``for 10 cents a pound the man who took her to auction chose to overlook who she was.'' She was a good pig, a gentle pig. Emily liked strawberries, leftovers from Fat Tony's restaurant, rolling around on her tummy and grunting along to favorite songs. But for all her talents, in the end Emily was just a pig like any other in the eyes of her new caretaker. ``He telephoned out of state to ask the old (farm) owner, who said, `The pig belongs to the farm. Do what you want.' And he did,'' wrote Stoll. The farm manager hired a man to haul Emily to auction in Seekonk, where she was eventually sold to Jimmy Dean, the sausage company owned by the country and western singer. ``It stinks,'' said Stoll, who has taken some solace from her two cats and two dogs. She never thought things would end this way when Emily grew to 400 pounds _ too big for Stoll's back yard. Her first adoptive home was with Steve Morgan, who boarded Emily with his pig, Helen. ``I arranged to pay for the corn and Steve took on the ``slop'' detail,'' wrote Stoll. ``Emily became a social sow as people went out of their way to visit `the girls' and of course, to feed them.'' But those golden days came all too quickly to an end. Steve Morgan moved away and Stoll found the pig a new farm, the last home she would know. ``Life seemed sweet for Em,'' Stoll remembered. ``Until ... I found her gate open and her pen empty.'' Stoll said she didn't believe the farm manager and others implicated in Emily's death acted out of malice. It was something worse, she said. ``After much investigation, the culprits seem to be apathy, greed and ultimately, cruelty,'' wrote Stoll, who did not identify the owners. ``How could such a thing happen, especially in this wonderful, safe place we call Martha's Vineyard?''

DOC.HEAD: Nicaraguan Police Loyalties on the Carpet
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Nicaragua, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The police force is not called the Sandinista Police anymore, but who really controls them is far from certain _ something made glaringly clear Tuesday and Wednesday in the strike of government workers. In other countries, strikers and police often fight with tear gas, rocks, firebombs and nightsticks. But practically nowhere is the police force still so closely identified with a political party that became the opposition only three weeks ago. ``It's the same ... people,'' said Joaquin Morales, a 40-year-old construction worker at Managua City Hall. ``Different name, but still the same.'' Supporters of the new government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro see the police as a Sandinista force; Sandinistas can't understand why the police obey a government they consider a class enemy. At the height of a standoff between the government and striking workers, Sandinista labor leader Lucio Jimenez said he didn't worry about police force breaking up the walkouts. ``We are going to give a fraternal embrace to police,'' he told reporters. Police are stationed in front of government buildings and facilities taken over by pro-Sandinista workers. At the telephone company, striking workers took food and ice water to police officers outside the main building. Officers took naps under trees, sitting next to strikers who left the main building for a cooler spot. At the Foreign Ministry, the only site of violence, police made what looked like a half-hearted attempt on Tuesday at pushing through a human barricade blocking the main gate. When a mob rushed the foreign minister and a dozen diplomats standing across the ministry parking lot, only three police officers stood guard outside the gates of a restaurant. The officials ducked inside in a hurry. People in the mob yelled at the officers: ``What are you doing guarding them? You should be protecting us, you should be on our side!'' The Chamorro government wants to appear in control of the police. La Prensa, Mrs. Chamorro's family newspaper, on Tuesday night published glowing accounts of the police action at the Foreign Ministry, calling its behavior ``diplomatic'' and running a headline saying: ``Police Obey Order from Minister Hurtado.'' Carlos Hurtado took over from Commander of the Revolution Tomas Borge, whose Interior Ministry was renamed Government Ministry when Mrs. Chamorro assumed power. The ministry includes the police, immigration and other public order departments. It was Borge's pride, a force commanded by Sandinista militants, where paramilitary discipline was as important as party discipline. But the police situation remains such that when negotiations to end the strike began Tuesday night between Mrs. Chamorro and Sandinista labor leaders, Police Chief Rene Vivas, a committed Sandinista, sat in as an ``impartial witness.''

DOC.HEAD: Politics Rules the Latvian Airwaves
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Thursday AMs report.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Latvians, who poured into the streets to sing their traditional anthem when their leaders declared independence, are doing more listening these days. Strollers in Riga, the capital, clutch small transistor radios pressed closely to one ear. People at bus stops hold out radios so others can hear. The attraction is not a sporting event or a concert of Latvia's beloved folk songs. Latvians now have their ears pricked to the internal politics of independence. They are riveted to the live debate in the republic's parliament as it forms a new government. Wednesday's session was not highly dramatic. It included, for instance, the confirmation hearing for the next state arbitrator. Latvians listened nevertheless. ``Everyone is interested of late, when such crucial questions are being considered,'' said Indra Grube, a teacher who is also a member of a private dance group. ``People are devoting some of their free time to politics, especially nowadays,'' she said. Miss Grube, dressed in a traditional white folk-dancing costume and gold headband, spoke in a small central park where Riga Television was taping performers in preparation for the annual summer song-and-dance festival. Next to the park, about three dozen people were mixing the twin passions of song and politics, joining in an impromptu chorus of a patriotic melody beneath a white stone obelisk topped by the statue of Mother Latvia. Someone in the crowd waved a flag of the neighboring Baltic republic of Lithuania as the group sang ``On the Shores of the Daugava,'' a traditional song of Latvian unity. Latvia declared the beginning of a transition to independence on May 4, and Lithuania proclaimed outright independence on March 11. Someone in the crowd Wednesday shouted, ``Why are you waving a Lithuanian flag?'' Another person replied, ``Because we need solidarity.'' (Late Wednesday, Lithuania's Parliament offered to suspend laws it enacted since declaring that republic's independence if Moscow agrees to negotiate an end to their tense impasse.) The site, known as the Freedom Monument, often has been compared to London's Speaker's Corner, where all manner of people voice their opinions to anyone who'll listen. On Wednesday, Max Sikka, 60, proudly displayed his Estonian passport that predated the Soviet annexation of the Baltic republics in 1940. Others standing near the monument, which was decorated with hundreds of lilacs, carnations, and tulips, spoke of a hopeful mood in Latvia. ``We are not afraid of economic difficulties _ our shops are empty anyway, because Moscow has spoiled our economy,'' said Raitis Jansons, a member of the pro-independence People's Front. ``We are afraid of arms, tanks, and such military shows of force as in Lithuania now,'' he said. Asked if Latvian independence would come at the cost of peace with the Russians who live in the republic, Jansons said, ``I know very many Russians who support independence. It is possible that there will be a good economic situation after independence, and that will bring peace.'' At the other end of Riga's central Lenin Street stood a massive statue of Soviet founder Vladimir I. Lenin. The statue, standing deserted, was caked with grime from the passing traffic.

DOC.HEAD: Love-Triangle Murder, Grant's Menagerie: Lafayette Square Saw it All
DOC.TEXT: Tourists admiring the grassy serenity of Lafayette Square little suspect that it once was the site of a love-triangle murder, Helen Hayes' stage debut and a makeshift zoo where Ulysses S. Grant kept a menagerie of deer and prairie dogs. Some of the ``secrets of Lafayette Square,'' both amusing and tragic, were disclosed Wednesday during a historical tour of the seven-acre park opposite the White House. The tour was sponsored by the National Trust for Historic Preservation. According to tour guide Sarah Shaffer, the square that is inhabited today by homeless vagrants and anti-nuclear demonstrators once was surrounded by elegant hotels and clubs and the homes of prominent Washington figures. The square is no stranger to scandal. More than a century before the Watergate scandal engulfed the Nixon White House, a lurid sex scandal resulted in the death of the son of Francis Scott Key, who wrote ``The Star-Spangled Banner.'' Phillip Barton Key was fond of crossing the square from his boarding house to visit the wife of Daniel Sickles, a New York congressman, when she waved an all-clear signal from her bedroom window. Sickles, enraged at the discovery of his wife's infidelity, killed Key with a shotgun blast in 1859. On the east side of the square lived Dolley Madison, the destitute widow of James Madison, who had to mortgage her house before Henry Clay persuaded Congress to give her $20,000 to pay off her debt to John Jacob Astor. Nearby is the site of the old Belasco Theater, a vaudeville palace where actress Helen Hayes made her first stage appearance as a 5-year-old singer. On the northeastern edge of the square, where the Department of Veterans Affairs has its headquarters, stood the posh Arlington Hotel, where industrialist Andrew Carnegie once spent $10,000 on a dinner party for his friends. The park originally contained a private farmhouse, apple orchard and graveyard before it was bought in 1791 to help create the capital city envisioned by George Washington. It served as the unkempt front lawn of the executive mansion for a while, until Thomas Jefferson ordered Pennsylvania Avenue built right through the middle. It was a military campground in the War of 1812 and again during the Civil War, when President Lincoln crossed the street to visit troops guarding the White House. The President's Park was renamed Lafayette Square during the French military hero's visit to the United States in 1824. But it is Andrew Jackson _ not Lafayette _ who is honored with an equestrian statue in the center of the park. The statue was cast at a local foundry from melted-down British cannons seized in the War of 1812. It was unveiled in 1853 and celebrated by spectators who toasted ``Old Hickory'' from open kegs of rum and whiskey. The square was haunted by tragedy, too. Conspirators in Lincoln's assassination in 1865 bungled an attempt to kill Secretary of State William Seward in his home on Lafayette Square. Although Seward survived, his wife and daughter died of ``nervous prostration'' shortly after the attack. In a home on the present site of the Hay-Adams Hotel on the northern edge of the square, Clover Adams, daughter-in-law of John Quincy Adams, committed suicide by drinking chemicals from her rooftop photography lab. Long before the square was beautified with fountains and floral gardens, President Grant had the park drained and landscaped, removed a Civil War cemetery and installed his pet deer and prairie dogs. Grant's zoo was closed when the neighbors complained of the noise and stench. The tour was part of local observances of National Historic Preservation Week, an annual event sponsored by the non-profit National Trust to encourage public support of efforts to preserve buildings, objects and sites of historic significance.

DOC.HEAD: French Train Sets New World Record
DOC.TEXT: One of France's high-speed trains broke its own world speed record, traveling at 317.4 mph. The new record set Wednesday was one-tenth of a mile an hour better than the previous record of 317.3 mph, set last week by the same train. The records were set during a series of trial runs by the government-owned railroad to test new equipment, materials and track. Last week's record marked the first time any train has traveled faster than 300 mph. The tests are taking place on a stretch of track near Tours in central France. On regular passenger runs, the high-speed trains normally travel at a maximum of 180 mph.

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Drug czar William J. Bennett, who is on a crusade against crack dealers, took a swipe at a celluloid bad boy _ Bart Simpson. During a tour Wednesday of the Foundation for Abraxas drug-treatment center, Bennett spied a poster of the cartoon miscreant and told recovering addicts they shouldn't follow Bart's lead as an underachiever. ``You guys aren't watching `The Simpsons,' are you? That's not going to help you any,'' said Bennett, director of the national drug policy office. Bart is the spike-haired son on ``The Simpsons,'' the Fox network's highly rated cartoon sitcom featuring the adventures of a bug-eyed family of five. ``We have great respect for Mr. Bennett's task and responsibility,'' said Brad Turell, a spokesman for the show. ``But I am not aware of any one TV program that will help teen-agers kick the drug habit.''

Kelsey Grammer, who plays the uptight Dr. Frasier Crane on ``Cheers,'' was given 30 days in jail for violating his probation from a 1988 drunken driving arrest. Municipal Court Commissioner Patricia Schwartz on Wednesday told the 35-year-old actor to report to jail May 24 and enroll in a 90-day alcohol rehabilitation program. The actor had violated terms of his probation by missing a court appearance to report on his progress. Grammer's co-star Kirstie Alley pleaded unsuccessfully with Ms. Schwartz to spare the actor jail and instead enroll him in a strict alcohol and drug abuse program.

Anita Bryant, the former Florida orange juice woman and campaigner against gay rights, calls herself a ``walking miracle'' for having survived a nervous breakdown, pill addiction and divorce. Bryant, a pop singer in the 1960s, moved to Nashville from Selma, Ala., in August to get back into the business. She just finished an album called ``With Love'' and is working on her 11th inspirational book. ``I know that I am a walking miracle,'' she said in an interview published Wednesday in The Tennessean. ``You know how you read about the `points' you get if you have trauma in your life? I've got enough trauma points to have died and resurrected about three times. So I know I'm here by God's grace.'' Bryan said she had suffered a breakdown, financial woes woes and addiction to pills. In 1977, she took part in a campaign to block a Miami ordinance that would have prevented job discrimination against homosexuals. When her marriage ended in divorce 10 years ago, the same people who had applauded her crusade against homosexuals condemned her, she said. ``I was the darling of a lot of people. They waved their palms and then the same ones next time were saying, `Crucify her, crucify her,''' she said. ``Divorce is not God's perfect plan. But thank God it's forgivable.''

Geraldine Ferarro told a gathering of Korean women to fight to enter politics, saying women's voices are essential to good government. ``That's not necessarily because we are more caring or more effective, but because we bring another dimension to the political process,'' the former vice presidential candidate said at the meeting Wednesday at the National Assembly. ``Instead of engaging in confrontation, women are more apt to negotiate.'' Mrs. Park Young-sook, a vice president of the opposition party, said Ferraro was invited to speak as a role model. There are six women in South Korea's 299-member parliament, but all are appointed by their parties, not elected. The former congresswoman ran with Democrat Walter Mondale in 1984. She said she would decide next year whether to run for the Senate.

City Council gave landmark status to the studios where two Polish immigrants launched urban rock 'n' roll by recording the likes of Chuck Berry, Muddy Waters and Bo Diddley. The council voted unanimously Wednesday to honor Chess Studios, the two-story, brick and terra cotta building at 2120 S. Michigan Ave. where Berry recorded ``Johnny B. Goode,'' Howlin' Wolf cut ``Spoonful'' and Waters laid down ``I'm Your Hoochie Coochie Man.'' ``I think it's one of the greatest honors bestowed upon us,'' Phil Chess said in a telephone interview from his Tucson, Ariz., home. ``I just wish my brother was around to accept the honor, really, but that's life.'' Phil and Leonard Chess created the label in 1950, and in 1957 moved the studios to Michigan Avenue, across the street from the old Lexington Hotel, gangster Al Capone's one-time headquarters. Chess' urban blues and rock 'n' roll made its way across the Atlantic and came back transformed by British rock groups. The Rolling Stones took their name from Waters' 1950 Chess record ``Rolling Stone.'' In 1964, they recorded cuts for their ``12 x 5'' album at Chess, including the song ``2120 South Michigan Avenue.'' Chess flourished until 1969, when the family sold the operation. Leonard Chess died that year. The Chess catalog is now owned by MCA Records.

It was ``deja vu all over again'' for Joe Garagiola, the once and future co-host of the ``Today'' show. Garagiola and another new hire, former CBS anchorwoman Faith Daniels, will make their debut on ``Today'' June 4. They will appear with Deborah Norville and Bryant Gumbel. The announcement this week had the 64-year-old Garagiola quoting another former catcher, Yogi Berra: ``I said, `Hey, Yogi's right. It's deja vu all over again.''' Garagiola was ``Today'' co-host with Hugh Downs and Barbara Walters, and later Frank McGee, from 1969 to 1973. He left NBC in 1988 and has been doing play-by-play coverage of California Angels' games for cable's SportsChannel.

DOC.HEAD: Hatch Says Wide Approval Vote Will Affect Bush Budget Decision
DOC.TEXT: The overwhelming Senate vote for a nearly $3 billion bill to help states and cities cope with AIDS expenses will encourage President Bush to find room for the spending in the federal budget, a key Republican backer says. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said he believe White House officials will drop any reservations about the bill's cost when they hold budget deliberations with congressional leaders, in part because of the breadth of the Senate's 95-4 vote Wednesday. ``I think basically they wanted to see how the bill would ultimately sift out. They now know, at least from the Senate standpoint,'' Hatch said. ``We're very hopeful ... that the White House will see the merits of it and will help to include it in the summit agreement. And I have no doubt that they will,'' he said. Hatch, a leading conservative, joined with liberal Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., in sponsoring the AIDS bill. The measure now goes to the House, where a similar but bigger version awaits floor action. Lobbyists for AIDS groups were optimistic about its chances there. The Senate's bill would provide $600 million a year in the 1991 and 1992 fiscal years to cities and states to deal with AIDS patients overburdening many public hospitals. Half the money would go to 13 big cities that have reported 2,000 or more cases of AIDS. It would authorize spending ``such sums as may be necessary'' for three more years, through fiscal 1995. The Congressional Budget Office estimated the bill would increase federal outlays by $2.9 billion over five years. The bill was approved after three days of debate and a long series of amendments. It was vigorously opposed by Sen. Jesse Helms, R-N.C., who charged money was being diverted from other diseases and that the bill would encourage homosexual practices, which he termed immoral. Joining Helms to vote against the bill were Sens. Gordon Humphrey, R-N.H.; William Roth, R-Del., and Malcolm Wallop, R-Wyo. Not voting was Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa. The Senate accepted an amendment establishing 150 new Food and Drug Administration inspectors as a step to ensure the blood supply used by hospitals is free of the AIDS virus. It also approved another amendment barring local governments from using any federal money provided by the bill for needle distribution to users of illegal drugs. A stronger Helms amendment, to bar cities or states from distributing either needles or syringe-cleaning bleach, was defeated. The Senate rejected, 52-47, another Helms amendment that would have made it a federal crime to knowingly donate blood tainted by the AIDS virus, or for intravenous drug users or prostitutes to give blood. It accepted a milder version, requiring that states have laws ``adequate to prosecute'' anyone who knowingly and intentionally tries to donate tainted blood. The AIDS virus is transmitted through blood and other body fluids, and homosexual contact and illegal intravenous drug use are primary transmitters. The National Commission on AIDS, whose members are appointed by Congress and the president, said in a statement that it ``endorses the principles and objectives'' of the Senate's bill. A spokesman, Thomas Brandt, said the commission similarly supported the House bill. The 13 big cities are to receive half the money in the first year, and $150 million of that in the first 60 days after enactment. Those cities, and congressional estimates of their first-round allocation, are: Atlanta, $4.7 million; Boston, $3.5 million; Chicago $5 million; Dallas, $3.8 million; Houston, $6.6 million; Los Angeles, $15.8 million; Miami, $6.8 million; New York, $56.3 million; Newark, N.J., $7.7 million; Philadelphia, $4.4 million; San Francisco, $23.5 million; San Juan, Puerto Rico, $5.8 million; and Washington D.C., $6.4 million. Those cities will be eligible to apply for a second round of $150 million later in the first year of the bill. The other half of the bill's money would go to states. The money would be used to care for AIDS patients and to provide community-based services and support programs.

DOC.HEAD: WHO Urges Stepped Up Anti-Smoking Campaign
DOC.TEXT: The annual assembly of the World Health Organization warned there could be up to 3 million tobacco-related deaths per year during the 1990s and called for a stepped-up anti-smoking campaign. The resolution, adopted on Wednesday without a vote, suggested raising taxes on tobacco among proposals to discourage smoking. It also urged ``concerted action to eliminate eventually all direct and indirect advertising, promotion and sponsorship concerning tobacco.'' Member nations, including the United States, also were urged to consider measures to protect non-smokers exposed to smoke in public. The resolution said unless current smoking rates decrease, there will be 3 million tobacco-related deaths per year during the 1990's. It did not give the current rate. An increasing number of Americans have kicked the habit, but smoking is still on the rise especially in many developing countries. The resolution was initiated by New Zealand and had 23 co-sponsors.

DOC.HEAD: US Weighs Plans to Help Feed Contras
DOC.NOTE: EDS: House-Senate negotiations resume 10 a.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration, worried that 14,000 Nicaraguan Contras may run out of food, has come up with a contingency plan to feed the rebels for a month, U.S. officials say. The administration had hoped that Congress would have approved by now a $300 million Nicaragua aid proposal that includes food supplies for the Contras, and President Bush complained on Wednesday about ``procedural gridlock'' on Capitol Hill. As a stopgap measure, the administration is expected to take between $1 million and $1.5 million from aid programs to other countries in order to help feed the Contras, said the U.S. officials, who asked not to be identified. Democrats indicated Wednesday that it was unlikely the aid requested by the administration would be passed before the end of next week when Congress is scheduled to begin its Memorial Day recess. But at a news conference, Bush urged lawmakers to stay through the holiday weekend to complete the bill. The package also includes $420 million for Panama's five-month-old government. Bush blasted Congress for piling on scores of domestic spending proposals ``that have nothing to do with Panama and Nicaragua.'' One of the most controversial amendments would approve use of local tax dollars for abortions in the District of Columbia. The president said he would veto any bill including such a provision. House and Senate negotiators are trying to resolve differing versions of the bill passed by their chambers. Democrats said Bush was using the aid package as a foil to divert attention from problems facing his administration, such as looming budget deficits. ``He should be concerned with his deficits'' as he is with aid for Central America, said Rep. David Bonior, D-Mich. Health care, education, taxes and budget were the pressing issues in his district _ not foreign aid, Bonior said. As part of an elaborate peace plan, the Contras have assembled in five security zones that are off-limits to soldiers of the Sandinista army of Nicaragua. About $30 million of the $300 million would be used for humanitarian aid for the Contras and resettling them back to their home towns. But officials of the Organization of American States who are assisting in the resettlement process report that only a few days' supply of food remain. The officials declined to say which countries would be affected by the proposed transfer, known as ``reprogramming'' in diplomatic jargon. State Department lawyers were attempting to determine whether it would be legal for the administration to give back the funds to the countries originally earmarked for the aid once Congress approves the aid package. What worries the administration is that the food problem facing the Contras could unravel the Nicaraguan peace process. The administration has said that the Contras, if they are deprived of food, might leave the security zones in search of fresh supplies, raising the possibility that they could come in contact with the Sandinista Army. Even though political power in Nicaragua has passed from the leftist Sandinista government to U.S.-backed President Violeta Chamorro, the loyalties of the Sandinista army remain uncertain. The hostility between the Sandinistas and the Contras remains strong after 10 years of warfare, and officials are worried about renewed armed conflict if the rebels leave the safety of the security zones. Bush said he has exhausted all administrative avenues for providing aid to Nicaragua and cannot legally grant Mrs. Chamorro's request for an emergency $40 million loan. The Treasury Department cannot make such loans without assurance Nicaragua would get U.S. aid or other revenues to pay it back. Democrats said conservative Republicans were the villains in the tangled legislative web because they had rejected a compromise on strings attached to military aid to El Salvador measure, even though the State Department was willing to negotiate. As a result, the Democrats have attached the El Salvador measure to an aid authorization bill, setting the stage for a floor fight when the measure comes before the full House next Monday. Democrats are insisting that the authorization bill be passed before any money flows to Nicaragua and Panama. Along with that measure, lawmakers would have to pass an appropriations bill providing the actual dollars. The El Salvador proposal would condition aid to the U.S.-backed government of President Alfredo Cristiani in an attempt to encourage his government and leftist rebels to negotiate peace in the Central American country. The measure would hold back 50 percent of the 1990 military aid, which totals $85 million. It would do the same for military aid in 1991.

DOC.HEAD: N.J. Chief Justice Sued Over His Ban on `Bonfire of Vanities' Filming
DOC.TEXT: Tom Wolfe's novel ``The Bonfire of the Vanities'' includes headline-grabbing politicians, zealous journalists and an unyielding judge. Life imitated art on Wednesday, when Essex County Executive Nicholas Amato announced at a packed news conference that the county is suing New Jersey Chief Justice Robert N. Wilentz. Wilentz barred film crews from the county courthouse because he said the script for the movie version of ``Bonfire'' called for a scene that showed blacks acting in ``a riotous, lawless and life-threatening manner.'' Angry over the loss of $250,000 in filming fees, Amato sued. The American Civil Liberties Union joined the lawsuit, contending that the chief justice is interfering in the moviemakers' First Amendment right of free expression. ``He's violating the First Amendment,'' Amato said. ``He's also costing the taxpayers in Essex County a lot of money, and for what?'' Carl Golden, a spokesman for the state courts, said Wilentz has not seen the lawsuit and could not comment on it. ``His position hasn't changed, though,'' Golden said. ``It's important to remember that the chief justice is not saying you can't make a move. He's saying is he won't allow a courtroom for this particular scene.'' Warner Bros. has no part in the lawsuit. The movie studio said it doesn't have the time to wait for the matter to be settled to complete the scene. ``The suit's not something that's going to make the filming of the movie any easier, and that's what we want to do, make a movie,'' said Warner spokesman Rob Harris. The movie is based on the Wolfe novel about a white Wall Street bond salesman, Sherman McCoy, who is thrust into the New York City's Bronx court system after he accidentally kills a black youth in an auto accident. Wilentz objects to a scene that shows a metal gate being slammed in the faces of a black mob after the charges against McCoy are dismissed. ``What the scene depicts is rage over the outcome,'' said Harris. ``The judge seemed to think that that rage could be conveyed through two people engaged in dialogue. ``If he really thinks that, I wouldn't want to see any movie he would direct.'' The lawsuit says Wilentz is ``unlawfully seeking to censor, restrict and regulate the content of the movie.'' It asks that Wilentz be barred from prohibiting use of the courthouse and seeks unspecified damages. Earlier this month, Bronx Borough President Fernando Ferrer objected to the New York courthouse being used for filming, complaining that the movie painted the area as dangerous. In response, Warner Bros. offered to run a statement at the end of the movie saying it was based on fiction. Back in New Jersey, the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People defended Wilentz's actions, saying it's ``reprehensible'' for public property to be ``party to perpetuating racist stereotypes.''

DOC.BYLINE: Exposure to Light May Ease Depression and Other Disorders, Studies Suggest ^By MALCOLM RITTER
DOC.TEXT: A treatment with bright lights that can ease wintertime depression is showing promise for nonseasonal depression too, although why it works is a mystery, a scientist says. It may work by adjusting the timing of internal body activities or by replacing the sunlight missed by people who spend most of the day indoors, said Dr. Daniel Kripke. He discussed the topic Wednesday in a news conference at the annual meeting of the American Psychiatric Association. Other speakers reported preliminary success in using light therapy for premenstrual syndrome and for chronic inability to fall asleep at a reasonable hour. Kripke, of the University of California, San Diego, and other researchers tested light therapy on 51 veterans who were hospitalized for depression. Twenty-five patients were exposed to bright white light, usually from 8 p.m. to 11 p.m., every night for a week. The 26 others received a placebo treatment of dim red light for those hours. At the end of the week, patients who received the experimental treatment showed significant lessening of depression, while those on the placebo did not improve, Kripke said. The benefit was probably better than a medication could do in a week, he said. Drugs require several weeks to reach full effectiveness, and it is not yet clear how light therapy would compare in a longer-term study, he said. Still, ``I think there's a real effect here,'' said Norman Rosenthal of the National Institute of Mental Health. It will take more work to tell how useful light therapy could be, he said, but in treating depression, ``you take anything you can get.'' Light treatment was in the news earlier this month when researchers announced it could help night-shift workers avoid daytime insomnia and on-the-job sleepiness. One study presented Wednesday suggests light treatment may also help people whose sleep troubles are caused not by their jobs, but by an internal abnormality. People with ``delayed sleep phase syndrome'' are chronically unable to fall asleep when they want to at night, which makes them groggy the next morning at work or school, said Dr. Jean Joseph-Vanderpool of the mental health institute. Some may stay awake until 5 a.m. or so, he said. They may drink four or five cups of coffee a day to stay awake in the morning, and may abuse medications or alcohol in their attempts to fall asleep sooner at night, he said. Children with the disorder may be considered lazy or irresponsible by their parents, he said. Nobody knows how common the disorder is, although one study found it in 7 percent of a group of New York high school students, he said. Joseph-Vanderpool and colleagues tried light treatment in 20 patients. Each was exposed daily for two weeks to bright light from 7 a.m. to 9 a.m. and wore dark goggles from 4 p.m. to dusk. The experimental treatment helped the subjects fall asleep about two hours earlier and feel more alert between 9 a.m. and 11 a.m., Joseph-Vanderpool said. The approach is ``a very reasonable thing to try to do,'' said sleep expert Merrill Mitler of the Scripps Clinic and Research Foundation in La Jolla, Calif. The basic cause of the sleep abnormality is not known for sure, he said in a telephone interview. In another study, Dr. Barbara Perry of the University of California, San Diego, said light therapy showed promise in relieving depressive symptoms of pre-menstrual disorder. The condition can also include such symptoms as sudden mood shifts, irritability, difficulty concentrating and decreased interest in one's usual activities. Symptoms appear in the week before menstruation. Perhaps 5 percent of women with menstrual cycles have symptoms severe enough to interfere with their daily lives, Parry said. In her study, six patients were treated with bright light in the morning for two hours daily for a week during their premenstrual phase. They showed significant improvement in depressive symptoms, she said. She cautioned that the work must be repeated to better assess its promise. But the approach may someday replace or add to medications for some people with the disorder, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Zumwalt Backs Compensation for Vets With Agent Orange-Related Illness
DOC.TEXT: Vietnam veterans who suffered cancer and other diseases after exposure to Agent Orange should receive disability payments, says a government adviser who had ordered spraying of the herbicide. Retired Adm. Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr. told a Department of Veterans Affairs advisory panel that he believed 27 cases of illness, mostly cancers, could be sufficiently linked to Agent Orange exposure to justify compensation. Zumwalt spoke to the Environmental Hazards Advisory Committee as its newest member and as a personal adviser to Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski Jr. The committee on Wednesday began reviewing scientific evidence on the health effects of Agent Orange. Zumwalt speaks from a unique perspective: as commander of naval forces in Vietnam, he ordered the spraying of the dioxin-contaminated herbicide, which was used to deny jungle cover to the enemy. In addition, Zumwalt's son, who served in Vietnam, died of a cancer linked to Agent Orange exposure, and a grandson has birth defects linked to exposure. Zumwalt urged the panel to take a fresh look at the scientific evidence on Agent Orange. He also said a study he conducted for Derwinski parallels the work of an independent group of scientists hired by three veterans' groups. That group, the Agent Orange Task Force, said this month there was enough evidence to justify compensation for eight diseases or ailments that have been linked to exposure. The panel said there were 13 other health problems, mostly cancers, for which there is sound evidence of connection but not yet enough evidence to justify compensation. ``I suggest to you that any objective review by knowledgeable experts in the field would predictably lead to much the same conclusion,'' Zumwalt said. He contended the VA panel lcked a systematic approach or epidemiological perspective. Zumwalt went further, saying he believes 27 ailments, mostly cancers, could be compensated using VA criteria that were adopted as the result of a court order last year. The main diseases cited by the task force, Zumwalt and others are non-Hodgkin's lymphoma, Hodgkin's disease, soft tissue sarcoma, chloracne and other skin disorders, liver disorders, a metabolic disorder known as porphyria cutanea tarda and birth defects. Zumwalt's list includes 13 kinds of cancer in addition to those already cited. The VA has said it will come up with final rules this year on compensation. Derwinski must make the decision based on the recommendations of the 15-member advisory committee, a panel of scientists and lay people. The VA decided in March to award compensation for 1,800 Vietnam veterans with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma. That decision was based on a Centers for Disease Control study that found an increased risk of the disease among Vietnam veterans as a whole. The study was inconclusive on Agent Orange exposure. About 36,000 claimants have been denied compensation despite their contention that Agent Orange exposure caused their health problems. About 240,000 say they have been exposed to the herbicide. The Zumwalt statement heartened congressional Vietnam-era veterans who have pushed for legislation to award compensation. ``The evidence is there,'' said Sen. Tom Daschle, D-S.D. ``The only question left is whether or not the federal government is willing to accept its responsibility.''

DOC.HEAD: Brewers Weaken Beer, Avoiding Possible Higher Taxes
DOC.TEXT: Sweden's leading brewers say they will lower the alcohol level in their beer, after the government said it may increase taxes on alcohol and link them to the potency of the brew. But the brewers insist their decision is because of taste, not taxes. The five main brewers said they will reduce the alcohol content in their strongest beer from 4.5 to 4 percent. ``The taste is better at a lower level,'' said Katrin Andersson at the Swedish Brewers' Association. Authorities said the proposed tax increase would cut alcohol consumption by 10 percent. The government backs World Health Organization's goal to cut consumption by 25 percent before the year 2000. Swedes can buy beer in three strengths. The two weaker beers are available in supermarkets. The strongest beer is sold in state stores at government-set prices.

DOC.HEAD: Pact Reached by Workers, Gov't to End Nicaraguan Strikes
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 15th grafs to UPDATE with union officials saying why they accepted lower rate than gov't counteroffer. Pickup 16th pvs, `Both sides...' Minor editing thereafter to tighten.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA2
DOC.TEXT: A paralyzing strike by public employees ened Wednesday night when the new government agreed to double workers' salaries and promised not to fire those who walked off the job. The agreement included a 100 percent pay raise beginning next month to workers belonging to Sandinista unions. The workers went on strike Friday, demanding a 200 percent pay raise and restoration of a law under the former leftist Sandinista government that protected public employees from being fired. The walkout virtually shut down Managua and much of this Central American nation of 3.5 million residents, three weeks after the Sandinistas turned over power to conservative President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro on April 25. Labor Minister Francisco Rosales read the agreement to reporters Wednesday night. Other details of the accord were not immediately available. Earlier Wednesday, the beleaguered Chamorro government reached tentative accord with Sandinista labor leaders to end some of the crippling strikes by government employees. But most of her 3-week-old administration remained frozen by the walkouts, and suffered a further blow when President Bush said Wednesday that legally his administration cannot provide $40 million she sought in emergency loans. Cardinal Miguel Obando y Bravo had described the situation as ``very difficult.'' He met Wednesday with former President Daniel Ortega. Ortega later told reporters Obando agreed to his request to intercede with the government so negotiations do not break down, and would also ask that talks be held between the government and Sandinistas to discuss other issues, such as demobilization of the rebels, known as Contras, and agrarian reform. Obando said he agreed because, ``We must seek a climate of reconciliation.'' ``The national panorama is very tense because of the strike, and the pot could explode if more wood is fed into the fire,'' Obando told reporters. Most government workers are Sandinista holdovers of the Ortega government. Bush told a news conference in Washington that Nicaragua is ``absolutely bankrupt'' and asked Congress to act quickly on pending legislation providing $300 million in aid to the U.S.-backed government. But he said of Mrs. Chamorro's request for a loan to get her through the immediate financial crisis: ``I can't provide that, because the Nicaraguans have no assured means of repayment.'' In earlier talks, strike leaders reduced their demand for salary increases from 200 to 180 percent and the government responded by doubling its offer to 120 percent. Union leaders said they accepted the lower 100 percent figure to do their part to fight raging inflation. Both sides agreed to review labor contracts and other pending issues and work together to reform a job-protection civil service law the Sandinistas enacted shortly before leaving office last month after nearly 11 years in power. Mrs. Chamorro then proposed to rehire labor leaders fired last week and rescind an order declaring the strike illegal. Mrs. Chamorro, Labor Minister Francisco Rosales and their advisers worked out the tentative accord with leaders Lucio Jimenez and Jose Angel Bermudez of the Sandinista-dominated General Federation of State Employees, federation spokesman Douglas Diaz told The Associated Press. Nicaraguan and U.S. government officials have accused the Sandinistas, who were defeated in Feb. 25 elections, of trying to undermine the conservative Chamorro administration. Until Wednesday, Ortega and other Sandinista Front leaders were conspicuously quiet about the strike. Railroad workers on Wednesday resumed supplying crude oil to refineries to prevent a fuel shortage, but the rest of the administration continued to be at a virtual standstill. Managua's international airport, schools and banks remained closed. Public transportation was next to nothing and thousands of people were stranded. About 20 buses were running in the capital. Public hospitals were open but at least one limited treatment to the very old or young, pregnant women and emergency cases. In messaging Bush on May 11 to ask for emergency aid, Mrs. Chamorro said, ``My country is bankrupt,'' and that inflation was running at 70 percent monthly. Administration officials said they inherited an economy ravaged by years of Sandinista rule and U.S. economic sanctions, with only $3 million left in the treasury, and an $11 billion foreign debt. A municipal construction worker makes about $10 a month at the parallel market exchange rate, a secretary $70, a technician $140 and the deputy manager of a state-owned bank $350 a month. The parallel rate is the one most people use to buy and sell dollars. The official rate is a preferential rate used for key imports and exports.

DOC.HEAD: Yun's Town: Movie Shows Koreans as Second-Class People in Japan
An AP Extra
DOC.TEXT: A movie shows a spirited 16-year-old high school student being raped and beaten by teenage thugs hired by the younger sister of her boyfriend. Why? She's a Korean in Japan. The victim is the heroine of ``Yun's Town,'' directed by Kim U-son, a lifelong Korean resident of Japan. Although the attack is fictional, Kim says it symbolizes the discrimination against the nearly 700,000 Koreans who live in Japan. Acrimony between Japan and its neighbors on the Korean peninsula dates back centuries, and scars are still visible from the 1910-45 era when Japan ruled Korea as a colony. Many of the Koreans who live in Japan today are either those brought over as forced laborers or their descendants. The bitterness has emerged in a series of events preceding the May 23 state visit of Roh Tas-woo _ only the second such trip to Japan by a South Korean president. On Tuesday, Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu said he will apologize for Japan's colonial rule, but some Koreans want the apology to come from Emperor Akihito _ a demand resisted by Japan's governing party. Under Japanese rule, Koreans were told to worship the emperor's father, the late Emperor Hirohito, and they were forced to learn Japanese in school. Some were drafted into the Japanese army, and many died during the war. In South Korea, opposition parties and others have urged Roh to stay at home. Last month, under pressure from Roh, Japan agreed to throw out a fingerprinting requirement for the most recent generation of Koreans in Japan. But the decision affects only four infants _ the grandchildren of those who registered as residents as of 1971. Fingerprinting is just one of many measures that put ethnic Koreans at a disadvantage in Japan's homogenous society. Many ethnic Koreans are lifelong Japanese residents, but they cannot vote or apply for civil service jobs. They face deportation if they commit serious crimes, and find it almost impossible to obtain jobs as public school teachers. Like other foreigners in Japan, they are forced to register as aliens and cannot become citizens without adopting Japanese names. Outside the South Korean Embassy in Tokyo, radical rightist groups regularly jeer ``Koreans Go Home!'' through loudspeakers. As in the movie ``Yun's Town'' there are many cases of Korean junior high and high school students being bullied. Ironically for those who see the movie as an indictment of a racist culture, Kim says he made ``Yun's Town'' to show a brighter side of the Korean people. ``The stereotypes about Koreans in Japan are that they feel nothing but bitterness and hatred toward Japanese because they are objects of discrimination,'' said the 37-year-old director. ``I wanted to make a movie that showed flesh-and-blood people, Koreans who can delight in life and communicate on an equal footing with Japanese,'' said Kim, who shot the movie in a Korean ghetto in Osaka, where he was born. While planning the $760,000 movie, Kim went to major Japanese studios, but all refused financing. This says as much about self-censorship within the movie industry as it does about discrimination against Koreans, Kim maintains. Koreans are not the only film taboos, Kim says. Films on atom bomb victims are also off limits. ``To make such movies is to point a finger at Emperor Hirohito, and film makers and studios fear this,'' Kim says. What they fear is attacks on their theaters by radical rightists who revere the imperial family. Kim finally got the funds he needed from Korean investors in Japan and from a group of Japanese artists and actors.
