Despite applause from the critics, Kim encountered difficulties in getting the movie distributed. It was shown in only a dozen theaters. Nonetheless, Kim won the new director's award last year from the Japan Film Directors Association _ the first time it had ever gone to a non-Japanese. The government Culture Agency also gave the director a $63,000 grant. ``Yun's Town'' was shown at the Cannes film festival in France last year and at several other major festivals, including the Hawaii International Film Festival, where it was one of five nominees for the top award. ``Japanese nowadays say it's an international era in Japan, but I don't think there's internationalization here at all. There are Koreans, Chinese, Filipinos living here, but Japanese treat us as if we don't exist,'' Kim says.

DOC.HEAD: Group Promoting Safety Device to Prevent Scaldings
DOC.TEXT: A children's advocacy organization says it will help low-income households install safety devices on their sinks, bathtubs and showers that will shut off the water when it gets hot enough to burn a small child. The change in plumbing fixtures is urged in a program begun Wednesday by the National Safe Kids Campaign to help prevent instances that daily send 100 children to hospital emergency rooms nationwide for treatment of scald burns. The coalition also said it would work to amend local plumbing and construction codes to include stricter regulations for fixtures that control water temperatures and regulate water pressure. ``In less than the time it takes you to answer the telephone in an adjoining room,'' a child can be suffer a serious disfiguring burn from tap water, hot beverages or food when left unattended, Dr. C. Everett Koop, Safe Kids chairman and former U.S. surgeon general, said in announcing the program. ``It happens all the time. Every day 100 children are taken to emergency rooms with scald burns in this country,'' Koop said. This year ``37,000 children, under the age of 14, will be injured by a scald burn severely enough to receive emergency medical treatment.'' ``What gives us a little red mark can give a small child a first- or second-degree burn,'' said Ann Parsons, a nurse in the burn unit at Children's National Medical Center here. Safe Kids will help provide anti-scald spring-activated safety valves for plumbing fixtures in low-income homes with children under five at a cost of $5 each. The program will include installations in 200 units at Washington's Highland Terrace public housing development in Washington, D.C. Low-income residents can contact Safe Kids at 202-939-4993. Children from low-income homes, especially those living on the lower floors of public housing or multiple-family dwellings, are often scald burn victims because the water temperature is raised to extremely high levels to provide adequate hot water to upper floors. The safety devices, produced solely by Connecticut-based Memry Corp., operate on a spring device that automatically shuts off the flow of water to individual fixtures when the temperature reaches 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Other consumers can order the devices by telephone from Memry at 1-800-782-7840. The average cost for retrofitting fixtures in older homes is $13 per sink, $17 per shower and $40 per bathtub.

DOC.HEAD: New Book Alleges Unreported Deaths Linked to Nuclear Power
DOC.TEXT: Radiation releases from nuclear plants and bomb tests may have contributed to the deaths of millions more Americans than acknowledged by the government, say the authors of a new book. A spokeswoman for the commercial nuclear industry called the assertion ``hysterical fear-mongering.'' Some independent scientists dismissed the book as invalid. ``It just doesn't make any sense scientifically,'' said Bernard L. Cohen, a professor of physics and radiation health at the University of Pittsburgh. Benjamin A. Goldman and Jay M. Gould, authors of ``Deadly Deceit,'' said Wednesday that government mortality and radiation statistics showed that death rates for infants and the elderly rose significantly after accidental radiation releases at nuclear plants in South Carolina, Connecticut and Pennsylvania in the 1970s. Goldman, a researcher and author, and Gould, a statistician, also claim that radioactive fallout from the explosion of the Chernobyl nuclear power plant in the Soviet Union in April 1986 accelerated the deaths of about 40,000 Americans during the summer of 1986. As the basis for this claim, the authors cited government statistics that showed a 5.3 percent increase in reported U.S. deaths in May 1986 compared with May 1985. They said this was the biggest May increase in 50 years and that the odds of this being a chance event unrelated to Chernobyl were less than one in 1,000. The book also contends that deaths related to fallout from above-ground nuclear tests, which were banned in 1963, may be far in excess of any previous estimates. The authors reached this conclusion on the basis of national mortality tables that showed a steady decline in death rates in the United States until the 1950s, when the rate flattened out. The rate resumed falling after the early 1960s. This 10-year period of little or no improvement in the death rate coincided with the height of the U.S. and Soviet atmospheric nuclear testing programs. ``We have estimated that this mid-century mortality failure could have been measured as equivalent to 9 million `excess' deaths, as the difference between the observed number and what would be expected on the basis of pre-1950s trends,'' Gould said at a news conference. The authors said they could not be entirely sure of the accuracy of their conclusions since they were formed on the basis of ``statistical anomalies'' and not scientific investigation of links between radiation doses and human health. ``If it is not low-level radiation that caused this, then it is up to the scientific community to explain what in God's name accounted for this,'' Gould said. Cathy Roche, a spokeswoman for the U.S. Council for Energy Awareness, a nuclear industry trade group, said the assertions by Gould and Goldman had been made previously and debunked by state and federal health authorities. She said the authors have an anti-nuclear bias that skewed their analysis. Dr. Henry Wagner of the Division of Nuclear Medicine and Radiation Health Sciences at Johns Hopkins Medical Institution in Baltimore said the analysis by Gould and Goldman was incorrect because it did not account for other factors that affect mortality rates, such as poverty. ``I think the book is totally invalid,'' Wagner said.

DOC.HEAD: House Takes Up Rights Bill for Disabled
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Lead prospects uncertain
DOC.TEXT: Legislation guaranteeing the civil rights of at least 43 million disabled Americans was up for House action today. Hailed widely as the most significant civil rights legislation since the 1960s, the Americans With Disabilities Act was considered certain to pass. The bill handily cleared all four House committees that have jurisdiction over it. The Senate passed the measure last September by a 76-8 vote. More recently, President Bush urged its quick passage, although the administration objects to a key proposal _ how to punish employers violate the law. One section of the bill could make it possible for employers to be sued for damages. ``Disabled citizens have waited long enough for equality,'' Bush said earlier this month. The bill that emerged from negotiations last year with the White House prohibits discrimination in employment and guarantees access to business and professional services. It requires that buses, trains and other mass transit be made accessible to disabled people, including those in wheelchairs. Telephone service also would have to be made available for people who are hearing- or speech-impaired. To soften the economic impact, the bill includes a number of timetables and exemptions. For example, businesses with fewer than 15 employees would be exempt from the job protection provisions. Those provisions take effect after two years for businesses with 25 or more employees, after four years for those with 15 to 24 workers. Modifications to accommodate disabled employees could not cause an ``undue hardship.'' Also, adjustments to existing buildings or offices to make them accessible to disabled patrons or clients would have to be ``easily accomplishable without much difficulty or expense.'' Amendments may be introduced that are aimed at giving more breaks to small businesses. Other amendments could focus on the definition of disability, which by case law includes people with infectious diseases, including AIDS. Rep. Jim Chapman, D-Texas, wants employers in the food service industry to be able to reassign workers with a contagious disease so they won't be handling food. Such amendments would cover AIDS along with other diseases, even though AIDS is not transmitted by such casual contact. But Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Texas, said in a Rules Committee hearing Tuesday, restaurants would lose customers because of the misperceptions surrounding HIV infection. He said the proposed amendment ``resolves a very practical and difficult question of equities.''

DOC.HEAD: US, Arabs Unable to Agree on Anti-Israeli Resolution
DOC.TEXT: The United States and Arab countries are suspending efforts to negotiate a United Nations resolution criticizing Israeli settlements in occupied territory as a violation of international law, U.S. officials say. The Arab nations were hoping to come up with a Security Council resolution that would criticize Israel and not be vetoed by the United States. But the effort was abandoned partly because the Arab diplomats were unable to overcome differences over wording with U.S. negotiators, American officials, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Wednesday. Israel had protested the joint U.S.-Arab efforts. The New York-based Conference of Presidents of Major Jewish Organizations issued a statement saying it was gratified at the outcome. The Arab countries are concerned about the increasing flow of Soviet Jewish refugees to Israel and the prospect that many would be resettled in territory seized by Israel in the 1967 war. This would make it harder to fulfill the Arab goal of establishing a Palestinian state in those areas. But Israel has said that only a tiny fraction of the refugees have been resettled in the West Bank or Gaza Strip or in East Jerusalem. The State Department has generally sided with the Arab position that Soviet Jews must not be settled in the occupied territories. Officials have said that a request for $400 million in U.S. aid to house the Soviet emigres would be jeopardized if Soviet Jews are resettled in these areas. The Bush administration has expressed opposition to all settlement activities in the territories, but it has stopped short of saying they are illegal. Israel felt that the United States, by trying to cooperate with the Arab countries on the issue, was going along with what it called an Arab effort to block the flow of Soviet Jews to Israel. The settlement issue is one of several on which the United States and Israel disagree, but the administration maintains that it continues to view Israel as a close ally.

DOC.HEAD: Baker Gifts Include Religious Picture From Soviet Counterpart
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III received a religious picture worth $175 as a gift last year from Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze. The gift was duly noted by Baker in his annual financial disclosure form which also noted the receipt of a hunk of the Berlin Wall, picture frames, photo albums, pottery, a handpainted egg, a watercolor, a silver letter opener and books, all presents from foreign officials. The picture, which was not further described, was presented to Baker by Shevardnadze last September as the two met at Baker's ranch near Jackson Hole, Wyo. The Baker gift list for 1989 also includes a leather hat valued at $100 from Gareth Evans, foreign minister of Australia; a piece of the Berlin Wall valued at $75 from Walter Momper, mayor of West Berlin; a malachite horse valued at $150 from Sir David Wilson, governor general of Hong Kong; and a mezuzah, a Jewish religious object intended to be placed on the doorpost of one's home, from Israeli prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir. The financial disclosure form, obtained Wednesday under the Freedom of Information Act, shows that Baker kept a promise made last February to sell his holdings in a New York bank and all his other publicly traded stock. The move was prompted by questions from President Bush's ethics chief about potential conflicts of interest. Announcing his decision in February 1990, Baker said it went ``well beyond'' what was required by law or had been recommended to him by government lawyers. The controversy revolved primarily around Baker's holdings in Chemical New York Corp., which had lent $4.5 billion to Third World nations. Third World debt is an issue routinely faced by secretaries of state. The disclosure form shows that on March 7, 1989 Baker sold 1,100 shares of Chemical New York preferred stock, valued for reporting purposes at $15,000 to $50,000 and thousands of other types of Chemical Corp. stock valued at a range of $26,000 to $75,000. Baker also sold hundreds of shares of the stock of other companies, valued in all at a range of $35,000 to $120,000. The publicly traded companies included Exxon Corp., Houston Industries Inc., Trinity Petroleum Trust, Commonwealth Edison, Property Capital Trust, Salomon Inc., Schlumberger Inc., United Technologies Corp., and Residential Resources Mortgage Investments Corp. The disclosure form shows also that on Dec. 15, 1989 Baker purchased 1,222 shares of a Merrill Lynch municipal bond fund valued at a range of $5,000 to $15,000. Baker's stock holdings are in a qualified blind trust. A trustee controls the stocks and tells Baker annually of the general nature of the holdings. The current financial disclosure form, filed with the Office of Government Ethics, and the one Baker filed last year, both put a value of more than $250,000 on the assets held in the secretary's qualified blind trust. Both forms show that the secretary received more than $100,000 a year in income from the trust during the time covered, January through August of 1988 and 1989. The 1989 disclosure places the value of the ranches Baker owns in Texas and Wyoming at more than $250,000 each.

DOC.HEAD: On The Light Side
DOC.TEXT: The rivalry between Sonoma Valley and Napa Valley, the nation's premier wine regions, took a theatrical turn when caped crusaders in black masks ordered tourists on the Napa Valley Wine Train to ``throw that Napa stuff out the window.'' The tourists instead were served Sonoma Valley wine. The caped crusaders' antics Tuesday, which included a daring leap off the moving train into the Robert Mondavi Winery, were reported to the sheriff's office. But deputies decided against making a federal case out of it. ``Throw that Napa stuff out the window and take some of this Sonoma Valley wine,'' the raiders, revealing their true identity as the Sonoma Valley Wine Patrol. At first, the travelers didn't know what to think, but soon decided delight rather than fright was appropriate, especially when they got to sip wines in the $10-$20 class for free. ``When I saw those black capes I thought they were some religious cult,'' passenger Milli Minicelli of Oakland. Then she joined in the fun. The patrol's membership includes winemakers and others dedicated to unfettered promotion of wine from Sonoma Valley. Over the years, a hot competition has developed between the adjoining valleys.

Max, the 2-year-old feline from Augusta who received an invitation to a $1,500-a-plate political dinner, may get to join the Republican fat cats in Washington after all. Radio station WBLM began soliciting contributions Wednesday to buy Max a ticket to the June 12 dinner with President Bush. By midday, the staion had received $400 in pledges. The station launched its ``Maxathon'' after receiving a call from the cat's owner, Brian Woodbury, who was intrigued by the idea of having Max dine with GOP muckety-mucks. Liz Hamel of the National Republican Congressional Committee, which coordinates the annual dinner, said earlier this week that invitations are sent to GOP contributors. ``Either Mr. Woodbury's cat is on a mailing list, or somebody's playing a joke,'' Ms. Hamel said. ``If Max wants to attend, he can,'' she said, provided he comes up with the $1,500. Woodbury and his wife, Jennifer, said they had no idea why their feline was invited to the dinner, especially since they are Democrats who have never contributed to a political party. Woodbury said he had decided to let the matter drop but changed his mind Tuesday and called the rock station to suggest a fund drive. ``I know they do some really wild stuff,'' said Woodbury, a 24-year-old accounting student and part-time employee of Central Maine Power Co. Captain Herb Ivy, the WBLM morning disc jockey, said contributors who send in $5 or more would receive pictures of Barbara Bush in a bathing suit. ``If we don't raise all of the $1,500, we'll probably give the money to the humane society,'' Ivy said.

Ginger is in the dog house with the police department these days. That's because the Lhasa apso twice managed to place 911 emergency calls from an Arlington house on Wednesday. At least, police can think of no other explanation for the calls. Police said they found the dog beside a telephone when they entered the place after receiving the second call. No one else was home. Ginger's owner, Jane Shumaker, said she hadn't programmed 911 into her telephone's automatic dialing system, and she finds it hard to believe her pet made the call. But she added, ``I'm beginning to think she's smarter than I thought. Maybe she was lonesome.''

DOC.HEAD: Senate Democrats Propose 1 Percent Boost in Some Target Prices
DOC.TEXT: The Democratic majority on the Senate Agriculture Committee is proposing a 1 percent increase in target prices for wheat, feed grains and cotton. The proposal by the 10 Democrats was placed before the nine Republicans on the committee Wednesday and could come up for a vote by next week, staff aiders said. The price support program would cost about $10.6 billion a year and is higher than the Bush administration is seeking. The proposal would increase the target prices in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1, and maintain the increase for the other four years of the five-year farm bill. A rise in the consumer price index would automatically trigger additional target price increases, but the agriculture secretary would have the option of then reducing the increase by four percentage points. In an effort to dramatize the need for government involvement in agriculture, Sen. Kent Conrad, D-N.D., sent bags of groceries to the other members of the Senate on Wednesday. ``This bag of groceries would cost you about $14.41 at a grocery store,'' he said in an enclosed note. ``Just $1.40 of that will find its way back to the farmer.'' He said a loaf of bread contains 7 cents worth of wheat, a chocolate bar 1 cent worth of sugar, soft drinks just 2 cents worth of corn sweetener. ``Over the past 10 years, we've seen a steady disinvestment in agriculture,'' he said. ``Net farm income has plummeted. ... Unless we restore some income security to agriculture, there will be very few farmers to raise the crops of the new century, and very few people in rural America to support American agriculture.''

The rural poor cannot eat nutritionally using food stamps, says a report from a consumer group. ``Our study shows that the food stamp program is failing to provide adequate assistance to this vulnerable population because it does not consider the high costs faced by shoppers in poor rural America,'' said Ellen Haas, executive director of Public Voice for Food & Health Policy. The organization surveyed 33 rural counties last summer that were considered representative of the 269 persistently poor rural counties nationwide. They found: _Nearly one-third of the food stamps were redeemed at smaller stores where prices were higher. _In three out of four supermarkets the food that the government expects a family of four to buy for $75 cost on average $81. _Limited availability of fresh fruit, vegetables and meats in the stores that redeemed food stamps. _Only 30 percent of the competitively priced supermarkets are located in rural areas. The House Agriculture Committee on Tuesday approved a section of the farm bill on food stamps that attempts to respond to problems facing the rural poor.

Imported fruits and vegetables are likely to be contaminated by illegal pesticides, according to data from the Food and Drug Administration. The information was released Wednesday by Sen. Patrick Leahy, D-Vt., chairman of the Senate Agriculture Committee, before the upcoming vote on his bill to ban U.S. companies from selling chemicals abroad are kept off the market here for health reasons. Overall, 5 percent of the imported produce examined by FDA inspectors during the last two years was found to contain residue from pesticides that are not allowed to be sold to farmers in the United States. The contamination rate may be even higher, because the FDA does not screen for all the possible pesticides that are used in foreign countries, said Leahy. ``Although FDA is responsible for inspecting almost all imported food, it only samples a minuscule 1 percent to 2 percent of the food entering this country,'' said Leahy. ``The rest is simply waived through at the wharf.'' About 25 percent of the fruits and vegetables eaten by Americans come from other countries. Data on domestically grown produce showed little or no pesticides residues. Here is the extent by percentage to which 12 tested fruits and vegetables were found to be contaminated, based on inspections between Oct. 1, 1988 and April 13, 1990: Peas, 10.3. Eggplant 9.4. Cabbage 8.9. Pears, 8. Peppers, 7.4. Squash, 4.5. Carrots, 2.3. Broccoli, 1.7. Tangerines, 7.1. Okra, 7.2. Blackberries, 8.9. Papayas, 4.1.

DOC.HEAD: Bill to Improve Nutrition Information Moving Through Congress
DOC.TEXT: Consumers would have more uniform and accurate nutrition information on the food they buy under legislation making progress in Congress. The House Energy and Commerce Committee on Wednesday approved a labeling bill similar to a measure adopted last month by the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee. The House and Senate floors are the respective next steps for each. Rep. Henry Waxman, D-Calif., the primary author of the House legislation, said it is intended to ``make sense of the confusing array of nutritional labels that now confront consumers each time they enter the supermarket.'' Through uniform standards to be developed by the Food and Drug Administration, the legislation also would regulate health and nutrition claims such as ``light,'' ``low'' or ``lean'' on packages and assertions of their role in preventing cancer or heart disease. Current labeling practices have ``turned the grocery store aisle into a veritable minefield of false and misleading claims,'' said Bruce Silverglade of the Center for Science in the Public Interest, a consumer activist group. The legislation would pre-empt state food labeling laws on nutrition but not food safety, such has health warnings, or consumer economic issues, such as freshness dating or unit pricing. Meat, poultry and egg products are specifically exempted. Labels on processed foods and posted signs and brochures for fresh produce and fish would be required to uniformly specify the amount of total fat, saturated fat, cholesterol, sodium, total carbohydrates, complex carbohydrates, sugars, dietary fiber and total protein for each serving. The bill was sent to the full House on a voice vote after the Energy and Commerce Committee's chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., rejected industry-led efforts to pre-empt state laws requiring labels to also contain warnings about chemical contaminants and carcinogens. Also rejected by a 24-19 vote was an amendment to exempt fresh fruit, vegetables and fish from the nutrition reporting requirements entirely. Supporters of the amendment said extending the requirements beyond processed and pre-packaged foods puts too much of a burden on grocery stores and is unneeded since most consumers already are aware of the nutritional value of fresh fruits, vegetables and fish. ``If any yuppies in America want to know how much fat is in an avocado, they can find that out by going through journals in a library,'' said Rep. W.J. ``Billy'' Tauzin, D-La. But proponents of the requirement said it would be nonsensical to exempt the very kinds of foods that people are most likely to eat if they are diet-conscious. The pre-emption issue has divided both the Congress and the Bush administration. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan, for example, has sided against the food industry in directing that new labeling requirements being developed by the FDA should not pre-empt tougher state laws. Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter, who has jurisdiction over label requirements on meat, poultry and egg products, has taken the opposite tack. He says state-by-state labeling only drives costs up for consumers and sets a bad example for international trade. Dingell refused Wednesday to allow votes on extending the federal pre-emption over state laws to potentially hazardous food ingredients, ruling they were not germane to the nutrition issue. Sought by 16 food industry trade associations, the amendments were focused particularly at pre-empting a California law that requires food labels to list any possible cancer-causing ingredients.

DOC.HEAD: Builders Say They're Being Cut Off From Credit Markets
DOC.TEXT: Home builders and some congressmen are mounting a campaign against a ``credit crunch'' they say is crippling the construction industry and threatening the loss of 200,000 jobs. Coinciding with a Commerce Department report Wednesday about the smallest number of housing starts since the last recession, the National Association of Home Builders called a news conference to announce the details of their latest industry survey. Association President Martin Perlman said the survey showed that ``builders are being indiscriminately cut off from the credit markets. Production is dropping. People are losing their jobs and businesses. The disruptions in the housing delivery system are far more severe than anyone anticipated.'' The Commerce report said housing starts had dropped 5.8 percent to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.25 million units, the lowest level since 1.17 million units were started at an annual rate in October 1982. At issue, the home builders said, is the new savings and loan bailout law that limits the amount of loans to an individual and tightens requirements for loans by commercial banks. However, other housing industry observers say steep mortgage rates, overbuilding and the high cost of new homes also contribute to the downturn in construction. The S&L reform law limits to 15 percent the amount of capital that a thrift institution can lend to one borrower. Before the law was enacted last August, thrifts could lend as much as 100 percent of their funds to a single builder. Rep. Peter Hoagland, D-Neb., told the news conference that 68 congressmen have joined him in sponsoring a bill that would remedy the problem by permitting a transition period during which builders could find alternative sources of construction funds. Hoagland said he believes the bill will reach the House floor within two weeks. A similar bill has been introduced in the Senate by Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala. ``Further complicating the situation is the fact that commercial banks have not been able to pick up the slack and are tightening their lending requirements due to a February bulletin from the Comptroller of the Currency warning commercial banks about the dangers of real estate lending and urging bank examiners to look closely at all of the real estate loans in the banks under their jurisdiction,'' Perlman said. ``This is having an inhibiting effect on housing finance that is clearly reflected in our survey results,'' he added. He welcomed a statement last week by bank regulators saying that banks should keep making loans to qualified customers. ``Hopefully that message will get out to the bank examiners,'' Perlman said. Meanwhile, he said, the credit crunch has caused the builders group to revise its 1990 housing starts forecast downward from 1.42 million units to 1.28 million. ``This decrease of 140,000 housing starts translates into the loss of 200,000 jobs for an entire year, $6 billion in wages and $2 billion in taxes at all levels,'' Perlman said.

DOC.HEAD: Talks on Finance Reform Move Behind Closed Doors
DOC.TEXT: Senate leaders are moving their efforts to find a compromise on campaign finance reform behind closed doors after staking out widely divergent party opening positions in public. Majority Leader George Mitchell, D-Maine, and Republican leader Bob Dole of Kansas on Wednesday each named five senators from their parties to begin what is expected to be long and arduous weeks of negotiations. ``I remain optimistic, but no one should expect any miracles,'' Dole said. ``Obviously, there are many different points of view and many areas of disagreement.'' Dole appointed Sen. Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, one of the most vehement opponents of campaign spending ceilings that are the key feature of the Democratic bill, to head the Republican team. Other members include Sens. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., Bob Packwood, R-Ore., and Don Nickles, R-Okla., with Sen. Ted Stevens of Alaska, the ranking Republican on the Senate Rules Committee, serving as an adviser. Sen. David Boren of Oklahoma, the primary author of the Democratic measure, was named to head his party's team. Other members are Sens. John Kerry, D-Mass., John Breaux, D-La., and Thomas Daschle, D-S.D. Mitchell said he and Sen. Wendell Ford, D-Ky., chairman of the Senate Rules Committee, will ``monitor and guide'' the discussions from the Democratic side. ``None of us have any illusions about the difficulty of this process,'' Mitchell said. ``Democrats and Republicans have tended to see this issue from vastly different perspectives.'' Mitchell and Dole last week brought widely contrasting bills to the Senate floor on behalf of their parties last week. Each, in the name of reform, basically seeks to rein in the current advantages held by the other party. Democrats would establish voluntary ceilings on how much candidates can spend equal to about two-thirds of what was spent on the last election and outlaw contributions by political action committees directly to candidates. Compliance would be encouraged through a public finance scheme in which voluntary contribution of up to $3 a year through income tax returns would pick up about half of a candidate's combined primary and general election campaign costs. Republicans are calling for a total abolition of PACs and are seeking to sharply curtail Democrats' historic reliance upon labor unions for grassroots get-out-the-vote efforts. Both parties claim their bills plug current loopholes of the type that allowed savings and loan entrepreneur Charles H. Keating Jr. to pour $1.3 million into the election campaigns of five senators now under investigation for alleged ethical misconduct.

DOC.HEAD: Senator Meets With Ethics Panel on Accusations
DOC.TEXT: Sen. David Durenberger, R-Minn., held his first private talks with the Senate Ethics Committee since the panel found ``substantial credible evidence'' that he violated federal law and Senate rules. Sen. Warren Rudman, R-N.H., committee vice chairman, told reporters that Wednesday's meeting with Durenburger did not resolve the case, which is set for hearings beginning June 12. Any meetings before the trial-like hearings could be significant, because Durenberger said earlier this month that he believed the committee was pushing him to negotiate a settlement of the case. Durenberger's spokeswoman, Lois West, confirmed this was the first time the senator had met with the panel since it filed allegations of wrongdoing involving his financial dealings. But she would not comment on the substance of the talks. When the committee scheduled the hearings, Durenberger said, ``It's a matter of wanting to bring this to a head. Whether the hearing is going to be necessary, we'll have to wait until early June to make a decision.'' Those comments were made before the committee significantly expanded the allegations last week, making Durenberger's defense more difficult. Last week, the panel found ``substantial credible evidence'' of financial wrongdoing, misrepresentations to the Senate and improper administration of Durenberger's blind trust. Those allegations, covering August 1983 to November 1989, all are related to transactions involving a Minneapolis condominium that Durenberger partly owned while collecting Senate reimbursements for his stays there. He has been a senator since November 1978. Last week's announcement also said the ethics committee had found ``substantial cause'' to conclude that Durenberger had ``misused United States Senate funds through a pattern of improper conduct which has brought discredit upon the United States Senate.'' In February, the committee found ``substantial credible evidence'' that the law and Senate rules were violated on two other matters: a book deal under which Durenberger made speeches and accepted fees to promote two books he wrote; and his acceptance of free limousine service for personal trips in the Boston area. These allegations covered events in 1985-86.

DOC.HEAD: Thornburgh Aide Won't be Disciplined in News Leak
DOC.TEXT: Solicitor General Kenneth Starr supports Attorney General Dick Thornburgh's decision not to discipline his chief spokesman for confirming the existence of a criminal investigation involving a congressman. But Starr, who had been asked to review the matter by Thornburgh, said in a statement Wednesday night that he identified certain ``concerns of an administrative nature'' that prompted the attorney general to make procedural changes. Starr reviewed the issue after Thornburgh confirmed that his chief spokesman, David Runkel, had been a ``secondary source'' of the story that the FBI was investigating financial irregularities in the office of Rep. William H. Gray III, D-Pa. Runkel and Thornburgh's chief of staff, Robert S. Ross Jr., who were both questioned and given lie-detector tests during an investigation of the leak, were reassigned to other duties Monday in a move officials said was unrelated to the Gray case. Both men showed evidence of deception during polygraph tests, said sources, who spoke on condition of anonymity. But the sources stressed that the evidence of deception occurred during responses to tangential questions. The investigation determined that Ross was not a source of the information contained in the CBS story, officials said. The Gray story was aired last spring while the congressman was running for House majority whip. It proved politically embarrassing for Thornburgh, who has made plugging unauthorized news leaks a hallmark of his stormy tenure at the Justice Department. Democratic lawmakers charged the leak was politically inspired. The Justice Department then took the unusual step of issuing a statement that Gray was not a target of the investigation. Thornburgh also ordered the massive leak investigation, which subsequently failed to identify the original source of the information. In his statement, Starr said he concurred with the earlier finding that there was ``no basis for criminal prosecution'' involving the leak. Starr agreed that ``there is no evidence'' that any official in the Justice Department's headquarters or the U.S. attorney's office in Philadelphia ``was the source of the original unauthorized disclosure.'' Runkel and Ross were reassigned to other duties Monday in an attempt by Thornburgh to correct the public image that he runs the Justice Department through a tight circle of politically loyal aides. Department spokesman Daniel Eramian said Starr's findings were ``totally unrelated to the personnel changes that took place this week.'' He declined to describe the procedural changes that Thornburgh ordered to correct the administrative concerns identified by Starr. Starr said he didn't recommend ``that any disciplinary action be taken against any Department of Justice official'' and concluded ``it was appropriately within the discretion of the attorney general to determine that no disciplinary action ... is warranted.'' Starr said he concluded that ``the matter may be appropriately closed.'' Thornburgh last month had defended Runkel's handling of the episode, saying the spokesman was following standing orders not to mislead reporters. Thornburgh had said Runkel did not steer CBS reporter Rita Braver off information that she had obtained from other sources. Starr noted several of the 10 people who were given lie-detector tests ``experienced difficulties on some aspects of their polygraph examinations,'' although he said there was no evidence the original leak came from the Justice headquarters or U.S. attorney's office in Philadelphia. Runkel, who had been accused by reporters of giving them misleading and incorrect information on numerous occasions, was appointed communications director and will no longer act as the department's spokesman. A search for a new director of the Office of Public Affairs is under way. Ross, who is planning to return to private law practice in two or three months, was assigned to organize a new office of international operations.

DOC.HEAD: Washington Mayor's Lawyer Asks For Dismissal Of Charges
DOC.TEXT: Mayor Marion Barry's lawyer is seeking dismissal of the half dozen new drug and conspiracy charges against his client. R. Kenneth Mundy filed the motion for dismissal Wednesday after Barry pleaded innocent a day earlier to six additional charges brought against him. Mundy complained that the new charges would not allow the mayor's defense team to prepare adequately for the trial scheduled to begin in U.S. District Court in Washington on June 4. The lawyer maintains that the six new charges are ``vindictive and an undue burden'' because they were brought just three weeks before the trial date. The new charges accuse Barry of five misdemeanor counts of cocaine possession and one misdemeanor count of conspiracy. The mayor took drugs as far back as 1984, the new indictment alleges. Barry previously pleaded innocent to eight charges brought Feb. 15 alleging that he lied to a federal grand jury and that he possessed cocaine on five occasions.

DOC.HEAD: Octogenarians Face Off in Dominican Presidential Election
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with initial returns. Pickup 7th graf `The turnout...'
DOC.TEXT: Dominicans crowded polling stations Wednesday to pick a president in an election pitting conservative incumbent Joaquin Balaguer, who is 83 and blind, against an 80-year-old Marxist rival. Leftist former President Juan Bosch took an early lead in initial, sketchy returns. With only 324 of the 6,663, or 5 percent, of the polling stations reporting, Bosch had 24,907 votes to Balaguer's 20,967, the Electoral Board said. About 3.2 million people were registered to vote. The board announced the first results on television at 1:15 a.m. Thursday, more than one hour behind schedule. Board president Froilan Tavares apologized for the delay but gave no explanation. Earlier, Tavares said there were some insignificant voting irregularities. But he said they were not serious enough to affect the outcome. Both Bosch and Balaguer, a five-time president, said they were confident of victory in their fifth matchup to lead this Caribbean nation of 7 million people. ``I will accept the voting results whatever they may be,'' said Balaguer, who was blinded by glaucoma, after casting his vote. ``But I trust Dominicans will ... re-elect me for another four years.'' Bosch, voting earlier at the same polling station in the capital of Santo Domingo, said: ``I am not optimistic or pessimistic. I am realistic because everyone knows we won this election a long time ago.'' The turnout appeared heavy in the normally bustling capital, which ground to a virtual standstill. Lines formed for blocks at some polling stations. Soldiers stood on street corners, but no disturbances were reported. Most shops and offices were closed in the city of 2 million. Alcohol sales were banned for the day. Former President Jimmy Carter, accompanied by his wife Rosalynn, joined about 30 international observers monitoring the vote to ensure against ballot fraud. Police said at least six people were injured outside the capital Monday night in clashes between opposing political supporters. Bosch, leader of the Dominican Liberation Party, describes himself as a Marxist _ but not a Communist. He has moderated his stands in recent years, and during this campaign pledged to work for good relations with the United States and to promote capitalism. He has written more than 40 books, novels, short stories, poems and Latin American and Caribbean histories. He was nominated last year for the Nobel Prize in Literature. Bosch's party has been claiming Balaguer organizers prepared 300,000 phony ballots to rig the vote, a charge denied by Balaguer's party. Balaguer, leader of the Social Christian Reformist Party, pinned his hopes largely on a $2 billion public-works project to transform centuries-old Santo Domingo. The project was planned in part to coincide with 1992 celebrations of the 500th anniversary of Columbus' arrival in the New World. The president, a lawyer and himself the author of more than 20 books, ran under the slogan, ``Balaguer, a road without danger.'' He portrayed Bosch as a dangerous Marxist. Balaguer's public-works project has created thousands of new jobs, but his popularity has slumped as the country's economic problems deepened. Dominicans have contended with chronic electricity blackouts and water shortages. Bosch had been leading in opinion polls by 10 points the past year. But some observers believe he may be hurt by his criticism last week of a 1954 agreement with the Vatican providing all army chaplains be Roman Catholic. This nation, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, is overwhelmingly Catholic. In 1963, Bosch became the country's first democratically elected president after the assassination of dictator Gen. Rafael Trujillo two years earlier. Only seven months into office, he was ousted in a military coup. An attempt by rebel soldiers to restore Bosch to the presidency led to civil war in 1965 and prompted President Lyndon Johnson to send in 23,000 U.S. Marines to prevent a leftist takeover. Balaguer rose to power under the 31-year Trujillo dictatorship, serving briefly as the general's figurehead president. He was first elected president in his own right in 1966 and served three consecutive four-year terms before losing in 1978. He returned to power in 1986. Other candidates for president were Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, 52, a former mayor of Santo Domingo and civil war hero who leads the socialist Dominican Revolutionary Party; and Jacobo Majluta, 55, leader of the center-left Independent Revolutionary Party. Voters also chose a vice president, 30 senators, 120 congressional deputies and more than 100 mayors.

DOC.HEAD: Undocumented Workers Complain of Threats, Harassment
With PM-Japan-Korean, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Officials are violating the human rights of illegal foreign workers by threatening them with prison and fines under a law taking effect June 1, a Pakistani worker says. ``They treat us like jungle animals,'' Shahab Ammed, one of an estimated 100,000 undocumented foreign workers in Japan, told a news conference Wednesday. ``We are bound here _ like we are living in a zoo.'' Ammed, wearing dark glasses, spoke in halting English to about 100 reporters with the Rev. Hidetoshi Watanabe, who is chairman of an association that helps foreign workers. Watanabe, a United Church of Christ minister, said the Justice Ministry's immigration bureau is deliberately misleading illegal workers by implying they face up to three years in prison or fines of about $13,000 under the new immigration law. In fact, he said, the new law applies only to employers and brokers who hire illegal workers after June 1. ``My guess is they are trying to scare all the undocumented workers out of the country,'' Watanabe said. Thousands of illegal workers are rushing to turn themselves in and be deported before the law takes effect, officials say. Justice Ministry spokesman Takashi Nakamura said he had heard no reports of harassment of foreign workers. He said punishment under the new law applies only to employers or brokers but the workers themselves may be jailed, fined or deported as under the current law. In 1989, 16,608 people were convicted of working illegally in Japan, the ministry says. But few workers have been punished, Watanabe said. Unlike many developed countries, Japan does not allow foreigners to come in as unskilled laborers. But thousands of foreigners enter on tourist or student visas, then stay on to work in low-paying factory or construction jobs after their visas expire. Women from the Philippines, South Korea and Thailand work illegally in Japan's massive sex industry, and many Americans without the proper documentation are teaching English. Although the number of illegal workers is officially estimated at 108,000, the number may be as high as 300,000, Watanabe said. Ammed said he earns about $1,777 a month doing clerical work for a plastics company. He said unskilled foreign workers generally earn about $4.60 an hour and many work 12 hours a day. Many Japanese companies would fail without the illegal foreign labor, he said. ``The new generation in Japan has no interest in this low and hard work,'' said Ammed. He suggested that since Japan needs the workers, it should pardon them and establish procedures for admitting more, as other industrialized countries have done. But the problem is compounded by Japan's wariness of foreigners, especially those with darker skin. Ammed said that even when he was in Japan legally, he was hounded by police angrily demanding to see his passport and accusing him of lying. Ammed gave Watanabe a letter signed by 190 illegal workers appealing for an immigration law that would help foreign workers. Watanabe said he would present it Friday to the Justice Ministry. Ammed said he faced the risk of arrest by coming forward but was willing to sacrifice himself to improve the lot of illegal workers. ``We will fight in favor of human rights until we die,'' he said. ``If the police arrest me, a second will come. They can't arrest us all.''

DOC.HEAD: Entertainment World Remembers Sammy Davis Jr. For Warmth, Generosity
With PM-Davis-Career-List
LaserPhotos NY6, NY7, NY8
DOC.TEXT: Hollywood's stars shed tears for Sammy Davis Jr., the exuberant song-and-dance man who started as a vaudevillian in white face and battled to the glittery top of the entertainment world. The man who joked he was the nation's only ``black, one-eyed, Jewish entertainer'' died early Wednesday of throat cancer at age 64. ``A heaven with his magic gives me warmth,'' said Frank Sinatra. ``Sam was the best friend a man could have. He was a class act and I will miss him forever.'' Davis died at his Beverly Hills home, his wife, Altovise, and three of his four children at his side. He was diagnosed with throat cancer eight months ago and had returned home from the hospital March 13 after a two-month stay. Davis _ actor, singer, dancer and impressionist _ performed on stage, on television and in the movies, a powerhouse packed into a bantam, 5-foot-6 frame. His gold chains, heavy rings and gaudy bracelets were as much a part of his personality as his chain smoking, his self-mocking hip patter of ``peace'' and ``love'' and his membership in Hollywood's Rat Pack along with Sinatra and others. His hit songs included ``Something's Gotta Give'' (1955), ``I've Gotta Be Me'' (1969) and ``The Candy Man'' (1972). His films included ``Porgy and Bess,'' ``Oceans 11'' ``Robin and the Seven Hoods'' and ``Sweet Charity.'' Davis began as a tap-dancing toddler in Harlem. In the vaudeville days, he danced bug-eyed with white paint on his face because that's what white producers wanted. Decades later, he couldn't gamble or rent a room in some of the Las Vegas hotels at which he played. In the 1960s, after he had made it, some black activists derided him as a sell-out. Others considered him a gilded Las Vegas drone. But he had millions of fans and was admired as an entertainer's entertainer. ``I would say that Sammy Davis Jr. was the greatest entertainer in show business,'' George Burns said. ``There wasn't anything Sammy Davis couldn't do.'' ``He was the entertainer we all strived to live up to,'' said Liza Minnelli, who toured with Davis and Sinatra last year. ``I never saw anyone give so much.'' Sinatra canceled the remainder of a weeklong concert series at Radio City Music Hall after learning of Davis' death. Davis' energetic performances and upbeat manner were therapy for a life scarred by bigotry, failed marriages, drug and alcohol abuse and crippling tax problems. He wrote two autobiographies, ``Yes, I Can'' in 1965, and ``Why Me?'' in 1989. In the latter, he described his all-night partying, endless drug use and womanizing _ the hallmark of the 1960s Rat Pack, which also included Joey Bishop, Peter Lawford, Dean Martin, and Shirley MacLaine. But friends said they remembered Davis for his warmth and generosity. ``As great an entertainer as Sammy was, he was an even greater friend, not only to me, but to anyone whose life he touched,'' said Martin. Jerry Lewis wept as he spoke about Davis. ``I lost a brother,'' Lewis said. ``The whole world is a lot less now than when we had him.'' Davis was active in many charitable causes, often appearing on Lewis' telethons for muscular dystrophy. His death brought tributes from former President Reagan and civil rights leader Benjamin L. Hooks. ``The world has lost not only an irreplaceable talent, but a humanitarian whose heart was so big, so filled with caring for others,'' said Hooks, executive director of the NAACP. Davis was born Dec. 8, 1925, the son of dancer Sammy Davis and chorus girl Elvera Sanchez Davis. When he was 4, his father and ``adopted uncle'' Will Mastin passed him off as a 44-year-old midget. Trained in tap dance by the legendary Bill ``Bojangles'' Robinson, Davis went on the vaudeville circuit and criss-crossed the country 23 times by age 15. ``From the time I can remember, I've been around grease paint,'' Davis once said. ``While other kids my age were playing with marbles and toys, I knew only about the backstage dressing rooms.'' When he was 18, Davis joined the Army and experienced prejudice that he would say gave him something to prove. His nose was broken in a fight with a white soldier. Others painted him white, to remind him that he wasn't. A triumphant first engagement in Hollywood in 1951 led to a signing by Decca Records. His first Broadway show, ``Mr. Wonderful,'' opened in 1955 and ran for 383 performances. By the 1960s, Davis had established himself as one of the most popular and richly compensated entertainers in the world. But emotional troubles continued to plague him until recent years. He married dancer Loray White in 1958; they divorced a year later. He wed Swedish actress Mai Britt in 1961, and they had a daughter and adopted two sons. They were divorced in 1968. He married Altovise Gore, a dancer in his nightclub act, in 1970, and they adopted a son. A funeral is planned for Friday at the 1,200-seat Hall of Liberty in the Hollywood Hills.

DOC.HEAD: Stocks Close Up
DOC.TEXT: The Nikkei Stock Average closed at 32,061.60, up 93.98 points, or 0.29 percent on the Tokyo Stock Exchange Thursday.

DOC.HEAD: Tunisia Says `No, Thanks' to Loan
DOC.TEXT: At a time when most Third World countries are clamoring for new money, Tunisia's government has said it does not want $92 million of a $275 million loan, the International Monetary Fund announced. Fund officials said on Wednesday they could not recall that happening before. The fund, which is owned by 152 governments, gives its loans on strict conditions and borrowing countries have been glad to take all they can get. President Zine El Abidine Ben Ali has been visiting President Bush and others in Washington. Seven months after he took power in a bloodless coup at the end of 1987, the fund offered him the loan, to be disbursed over three years. Tunisia has never drawn any of the money. Now the fund says Tunisia had asked for a ``reduction of access'' that would drop the total to $183 million. A fund official said that meant the Tunisian government would use some of the money, but not all. It already owes the fund $223 million. The country's total foreign debt reached $6.7 billion at the end of 1988, according to the World Bank. A senior administration official said Tunisia had one of the world's best records on debt repayment.
DOC.HEAD: Baby Rattles Being Recalled
DOC.TEXT: A California toy company is recalling 262 baby rattles with small parts it says could choke or cut young children. Small World Toys recalled its yellow plastic Spinflower Rattles because the toy may break apart when dropped, ``releasing small beads,'' the Consumer Product Safety Commission said Wednesday in announcing the recall. In addition, the federal agency said, the rattle's ``flower petals may also break off producing sharp points.'' The rattles, sold nationwide since January 1988, was packaged in a clear plastic carrying case with a label marked ``Fischerform.'' Both the commission and company said there had been no reports of injuries involving the product. Consumer may return the rattles to the store where purchased for a refund.
DOC.HEAD: Missourian Proposes Overhaul of National Arts Agency
DOC.TEXT: Rep. Tom Coleman, R-Mo., is proposing to revamp the National Endowment of Arts to give state arts groups a majority share of the agency's monies. Coleman and Rep. Steve Gunderson, R-Wis. unveiled the proposal Wednesday, saying it has the backing of the House GOP leadership. In a statement, Coleman said the proposal was designed to ``revitalize, restructure and redirect the focus'' of the endowment. The agency has come under sharp attack on Capitol Hill because of grants of federal money to support what critics say are obscene art exhibits. The proposal by Coleman would increase from 20 percent to 60 percent the amount of endowment monies that must go directly to state arts councils. ``Our proposal will demand accountability, by the endowment and those who receive grants through it, to taxpayers whose monies support NEA,'' Coleman said. ``Specifically, it is designed to ensure that the creative works, exhibitions and performances supported by NEA funding meet community obscenity standards.''

DOC.HEAD: Mississippi Adventure Turns Out Rougher Than Expected
LaserPhoto MX1
DOC.TEXT: Three retirees who set out on the Huck Finn adventure they missed in their youth got a little more than they bargained for on a nine-day trip. They found out why it's called the mighty Mississippi. ``It's not a trip for the faint of heart,'' said Irving Glazer, 70, who took on 900 miles of the Mississippi River with Alvin Levenson, 67, and Stanley Herman, 66, all of Indianapolis. The three set out from Cairo, Ill., aboard not a raft but a 24-foot pontoon boat, The Silver Fox. They ended up at Baton Rouge, La., weary from struggling against currents, sandbars and the giant workboats that ply the river. They had intended to continue on to New Orleans but took a look at the seagoing vessels docked at Baton Rouge and decided to finish the trip by car. In Mark Twain's 1884 novel, Huckleberry Finn and Jim jump off their raft just before it is run over by a paddlewheel steamer. The only steamboats the Indianapolis three saw were of the tourist variety, but they got their fill of barges. Mississippi barges carry up to 1,500 tons each, and the lower river is their workyard. That, with the logs and other debris in the water, made for tough maneuvering for the modern-day Huck Finns. ``It was like riding a bicycle on an interstate,'' Levenson said. The trip got off to a rough, wet start when the Fox left Cairo, at the confluence of the Ohio and Mississippi rivers, on May 2, fighting heavy head winds and pounding waves. ``None of us dreamed we would hit four-foot waves on a river, but we did,'' Levenson said. The second day out, the travelers ran into a sandbar between Hickman, Ky., and Memphis and radioed the Coast Guard for help. A rescue squad from Reelfoot Lake, Tenn., freed the boat and cleaned the sand out of its 60-horsepower outboard. ``They said they really appreciated us calling them because it was the first rescue they'd had this year,'' said Levenson. The Indianapolis three were retired businessmen expecting a leisurely trip. But they got little use out of the lawn chairs and battery-operated TV they had packed. The river current changed often and the water was full of debris. ``We had to keep a spotter up front the whole trip,'' Levenson said. The three spent four nights on the boat but found overnight accommodations ashore the rest of the time. Unlike Huck Finn, they never stumbled into a bloody feud between two families and never got mixed up in a con game. No one nearly drowned. Still, they found some of the same scenery Twain described in the 19th century. Levenson said it was lonely amid the thick woods lining the riverbanks. ``There wasn't a living soul for miles. There is nothing along that bank, no telephone poles or any sign of life,'' Levenson said. ``When we got to Memphis there were a few pleasure boats. Outside of that, there wasn't another pleasure boat on the whole trip.'' Below Memphis, the travelers hung up on another sandbar and this time no help was around. ``We took off our clothes and got into the water. There we were, three old guys in the Mississippi River pushing and pushing until we got back into the deep water,'' Levenson said. While the trip was rougher than expected, Glazer said he's ready to do it again. ``It's the most exciting thing I think I've ever done,'' he said. ``It was a challenge and there was an element of danger.''

DOC.HEAD: Henson's Death Means `A Lot Less Sunshine in the World'
LaserPhotos NY10, 11, 12
DOC.TEXT: The death of Jim Henson, whose warm and fuzzy Muppets like Kermit the Frog taught and delighted millions worldwide, shocked those who appreciated his art, but they said they're glad his work will live on. ``There's a lot less sunshine in the world today,'' opera singer Beverly Sills said after Henson's death at age 53 Wednesday of complications from pneumonia. Henson created the Muppets in 1954. Kermit and some of his pals made their debut on a Washington TV program, ``Sam and Friends,'' which won an Emmy in 1959. During the 1960s, Henson and his troupe appeared regularly on ``The Jimmy Dean Show'' and ``The Ed Sullivan Show.'' But the Muppets' popularity exploded into a worldwide phenomenon after they began appearing on ``Sesame Street'' in 1969. Millions of children in 80 countries grew up watching Kermit, Cookie Monster, Oscar the Grouch, Big Bird, Bert and Ernie cavorting on the show, which teaches basic English and math to preschoolers. ``He was our generation's Charlie Chaplin, Mae West, W.C. Fields and Marx Brothers, and he drew from all of them to create a new art form,'' said Joan Ganz Cooney, chairman and chief executive officer of Children's Television Workshop, which produces ``Sesame Street.'' ``He took our breath away as a talent and provided laughter and love as a friend. Fortunately for the children of the world, Jim Henson's work will live on.'' Opera singer Placido Domingo, actor Danny DeVito and singer Lena Horne were among the real-life stars who performed with the Muppets. Miss Horne said Henson was absent Tuesday from a gathering of the ``Sesame Street'' cast and friends. But she had no idea he was near death. ``This has just overwhelmed me,'' said Miss Horne. In 1976, Henson introduced ``The Muppet Show,'' which starred the Mae West-style femme fatale Miss Piggy. The show won three Emmys during its five-year run and became the most widely seen TV program in the world. Some 235 million viewers in 100 countries watched it. The Muppets, in dark and macabre form, also appeared in the first year of ``Saturday Night Live'' in 1975. Henson's puppets moved to the big screen in 1979 with ``The Muppet Movie'' followed by ``The Great Muppet Caper'' in 1981 and ``The Muppets Take Manhattan'' in 1984. His magic touch was evident again this year with his work on the box-office smash ``Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles.'' Henson, a rumpled figure with shaggy hair and a beard, said the word ``muppet'' was something he just made up, although to appease interviewers he would say it was a combination of ``marionette'' and ``puppet.'' Besides Kermit, he did the voices of Ernie and game-show host Guy Smiley. ``Puppets have the same sort of graceful aging that cartoon characters have,'' Henson said in 1986. ``I'm sure Kermit will stay younger a lot longer than I will.'' Henson's death was the third to strike ``Sesame Street'' in the past year. Joe Raposo, who wrote many of the songs for the popular children's series, died last year at age 52. Former cast member Northern Calloway also died recently. A ``Sesame Street'' spokeswoman said it was too soon to say how Henson's passing would affect the show. Dr. David M. Gelmont, who treated Henson at New York Hospital, was asked by a reporter if Henson had AIDS. He said: ``He had pneumonia, definitely, absolutely, no AIDS.'' Henson had been admitted to the hospital early Tuesday with ``galloping pneumonia'' untreated for at least three days, Gelmont said. Asked why Henson failed to seek more aggressive treatment for his illness, Jim Henson Productions spokeswoman Susan Berry said: ``My guess is he's totally absorbed. He couldn't be bothered. He was very cavalier with his health.'' Henson was born in Greenville, Miss., in 1936. He married in 1959 and with his wife, Jane, had five children. They range in age from 19 to 30. He directed the fantasy films ``The Dark Crystal'' in 1982 and ``Labyrinth'' in 1986. Henson won a Peabody award for excellence in TV programming, a Grammy for a Muppet album, and four consecutive Emmys for outstanding animation for his Saturday morning cartoon, ``The Muppet Babies.''

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``We want to see negotiations or dialogue or whatever you call it _ discussions between Gorbachev and the Lithuanians get going. And then I'd like to see the release of that economic pressure on Lithuania. And that would clear the air fast.'' _ President Bush on how pressure by the Soviet Union on the republic of Lithuania has made the May 30-June 3 summit with Mikhail S. Gorbachev tense.

``We talk about this stuff in social studies all the time. ... It's not fair.'' _ Megan Engbert, 14, on record stores that have begun to ban sales of records with explicit material to people under the age of 18.

``People want to be appreciated and to be treated like human beings _ not like machines or peons. _ Ellen Bravo, associate director of 9to5, a support group for clerical workers, on what makes good and bad bosses.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Slightly Higher, Stocks Gain Modestly
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended marginally higher against the Japanese yen Thursday, while share prices on the Tokyo Stock Exchange rebounded moderately. The dollar closed at 152.00 yen, up 0.05 yen from Wednesday's close at 151.95 yen. The currency opened at 152.08 yen and ranged between 151.73 yen and 152.55 yen. The 225-share Nikkei Stock Average recouped 93.98 points, or 0.29 percent, ending at 32,061.60. It lost 29.42 points the previous day. Stocks opened mixed because of the yen's early slip but the Nikkei rose as market players started picking up issues of well-performing companies, said Masahiro Umemori, an analyst with Nomura Securities Co. ``The yen's lower opening did not discourage market players much, mainly because they think the currency's recent uptrend is not over yet,'' he said. Currency dealers said foreign securities firms and Japanese institutions such as life insurance firms bought the dollar for position adjustments after the currency's recent decline, while investment trust companies bought the yen. A dealer with a major Japanese commercial bank said the dollar is likely to fluctuate narrowly as many market players wait for the announcement later Thursday of the U.S. March trade figures. The price of benchmark No.119 10-year Japanese government bond fell to 87.80 from Wednesday's close of 87.90. That boosted the yield to 7.00 percent from 6.98 percent.

DOC.HEAD: Studies Tie Spermicide to Women's Yeast and Bladder Infections
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf pvs, `Previously, it ...' to CLARIFY earlier studies.
DOC.TEXT: A widely used spermicide hailed for its ability to prevent AIDS and venereal disease can cause bladder and yeast infections in women, some of whom should consider another method of birth control, scientists say. The spermicide, nonoxynol-9, is the active ingredient in most contraceptive foams, jellies and creams. Some condoms are packaged with the spermicide. The research provides the first evidence that nonoxynol-9 can trigger the uncomfortable urinary and vaginal infections even when the spermicide is used without a diaphragm, vaginal sponge or condom, said Dr. Thomas Hooton, who conducted two studies at the University of Washington in Seattle. Earlier studies suggested that diaphragms and sponges cause the infections. Spermicides had not been previously studied separately. Nonoxynol-9 has been hailed in recent years for its ability to prevent the spread of diseases such as AIDS. ``Nonoxynol-9 is an extremely effective agent against many sexually transmitted diseases, as well as sperm,'' said Jackie McGroarty, a Toronto General Hospital microbiologist who conducted a third study. But she said she wouldn't recommend a woman stop using it unless the woman suffered recurrent infections and was in a ``stable, monogamous relationship'' that put her at low risk of AIDS and other sexually transmitted diseases. McGroarty said bladder and yeast infections cause discomfort but aren't dangerous compared with sexually transmitted diseases or unwanted pregnancy. Birth control pills previously have been linked to yeast infections. Hooton said if women want to continue using spermicides despite infection, they can get antibiotics for the infection. McGroarty presented her findings Wednesday in Anaheim during the American Society for Microbiology's annual meeting. Hooton's research has been submitted for publication in medical journals. Dr. Amy Pollack, associate medical director of the Planned Parenthood Federation of America, said she hadn't seen the studies, but ``what she (Ms. McGroarty) is saying makes sense.'' Phyliss Barber, regulatory affairs manager for spermicide-maker Schmid Laboratories Inc., said she was surprised by the studies and hadn't seen them. ``We definitely will be taking a look,'' she said by telephone from Little Falls, N.J. Representatives of Ortho Pharmaceutical Corp. and Schering Corp. had no immediate comment on the studies. McGroarty grew yeast and E. coli _ the bacteria responsible for most bladder infections _ in the laboratory with nonoxynol-9 and the kind of cells that line the vagina and urethra, or urine tube. In the presence of nonoxynol-9, the yeast and bacteria underwent changes that made them stick to the cells in great numbers, suggesting the spermicide helps the microbes colonize the vaginal and urinary tract. McGroarty also found nonoxynol-9 killed lactobacilli, harmless bacteria that grow in the vagina to protect against infections. The Seattle studies, which involved 130 women, found those who used spermicides alone or with diaphragms or condoms were more likely than other women to develop infections or to have high levels of E. coli bacteria. Bladder infection, or cystitis, occurs when bacteria travel up the urethra to the bladder. Yeast infections are vaginal overgrowths of a fungus. Both cause burning or stinging during urination and a frequent urge to urinate. Bladder infections produce strong-smelling and perhaps bloody urine, and sometimes discomfort and fever. Yeast infections cause itching, swelling, irritation, thick white discharge, and pain during intercourse.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Results of Nazi Human Experiments Scientifically Worthless
DOC.TEXT: Nazi medical experiments on concentration camp prisoners were more than brutal and unethical, a report today concludes. They were also bad science. Researchers and ethicists have been debating whether the results of German experiments conducted during World War II should be used by modern-day experts studying the effects of cold on the body. At the Dachau concentration camp, Nazi doctors plunged prisoners into icy water, often for hours at a time, so they could test various methods of rewarming them. Some experts have contended that regardless of their source, the data should still be used to help doctors treat hypothermia, or low body temperature. Others believe that no matter how valuable the information, it should be ignored because of the unacceptable methods used to obtain it. The latest report concludes that this long-running ethical debate should end, because the Nazi data has no value to anyone. ``The implication was that there was this great information, and we could save lives if only we could use it,'' said Dr. Robert L. Berger, a surgeon at New England Deaconess Hospital in Boston. After reviewing the original Nazi data, however, Berger discovered that the experiments were so poorly set up and carried out that the results cannot be believed. ``The data are useless,'' he said. ``It's not scientific. It should be rejected outright. There should be no ethical discussion over it. You don't discuss scientifically useless data. You discuss data that have scientific merit but were obtained in an unethical fashion.'' Berger presented his findings and conclusions in today's issue of the New England Journal of Medicine. In an accompanying editorial, Dr. Marcia Angell, the journal's executive editor, said, ``The notion that there exists a treasure trove of valid information on hypothermia, from which we are voluntarily and fastidiously holding ourselves aloof, seems to be baseless.'' Ethicist Arthur Caplan of the University of Minnesota, who organized a conference last year on Nazi science, said other Nazi research into such areas as genetics and anthropology has already been absorbed into the mainstream of science. ``Berger appears to give a persuasive argument that there is not much to argue about with respect to hypothermia,'' Caplan said. ``That doesn't mean the ethical debate about Nazi science and medicine should be dismissed out of hand.'' Dr. Robert Pozos of the University of Washington, who in the past has advocated use of the Nazi results, said after reading Berger's report that the experimenters' scientific methods were ``atrocious.'' He added, ``My opinion is that the data should not be referenced'' in other research papers. ``It should not be used.'' The experiments were intended to find the best way to treat victims of hypothermia, especially German fliers who were shot down over the cold North Sea. Male civilians of various religions and nationalities, as well as Russian prisoners of war, were forced to participate. The subjects were plunged into a tank of ice water, often naked, and then rewarmed with various methods. Some died after spending several hours in the tank. Others were killed by the rewarming, which included throwing the men into boiling water. Berger found that such basic details as the men's ages, nutritional status, general health and blood pressures were missing. Also frequently unrecorded were many particulars about the experiments and their results, such as water temperatures, length of time in the water and the survival rates after various rewarming methods. Some findings were so physiologically improbable that they were probably fabricated, Berger concluded. Among these was the conclusion that people die of hypothermia in the water only if their necks are submerged. He also noted that Dr. Sigmund Rascher, the chief experimenter, was accused of faking other experiments and had sold saddles, riding breeches and handbags made from human skin. Rascher was eventually executed by the Germans for kidnapping children. He had claimed that his wife had three babies in quick succession after age 48. The hoax was intended to please Heinrich Himmler, head of the German concentration camps, by proving that the growth of the Aryan people could be speeded up by extending women's childbearing years.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Plains Weren't Regulated When Texas Communities Were Built
DOC.TEXT: Some of the swamped communities along the Trinity River in Texas were built before zoning regulations prohibited construction in the flood plain, officials said. Torrential rains two weeks ago damaged about 400 homes in Rochester Park, a Dallas neighborhood. About 7,000 residents below Lake Livingston, north of Houston, were warned this week to evacuate subdivisions because of the worst flooding in 80 years. Both areas now have restrictions on flood plain development, but that wasn't always the case, officials said. Rochester Park, most of whose residents are black, has been flooded two years running. Its civic leaders say Dallas' failure to provide flood protection demonstrates a lack of interest in minority communities. City officials deny that. ``We recognized that they've been in the flood plain of the Trinity since Rochester Park was first developed,'' said Assistant City Manager Cliff Keheley. ``But at the time it developed, flood plain delineation wasn't the exact science that it is today.'' ``Today we have some strong requirements on development,'' said Tommie McPherson of the Dallas Public Works Department. ``The problem you have with places like Rochester Park is that you can't make new flood control policy retroactive. It's not like we can go in and move people out of their homes. '' McPherson said the Rochester Park area was developed in the 1920s and was annexed to Dallas in the early 1950s. It wasn't until 1964 that the city began flood development plans. New homes must be at least 3 feet above the 100-year flood plain. Keheley said cost requirements had slowed construction of a levee to protect the community. Officials say it will be built by 1993. ``In the contact that I had with the project, I didn't see any kind of intentional neglect, and I don't think it was racially based at all,'' Keheley said. At Lake Livingston, some 200 miles southeast of Dallas, the Trinity River Authority released water through the Lake Livingston Dam's floodgates at a record rate of 94,800 cubic feet per second Wednesday. A discharge rate of 100,000 cubic feet per second level was expected by Monday, and would last about a week, said Grady Manis, the authority's southern region manager. Barry Brock, assistant city manager in Liberty, Texas, which lies below the lake, said as much as 45 percent of city land lies in the flood plain. The city enacted an ordinance in 1974 saying that new development must be a foot above the 100-year flood plain, the highest level water has gotten in the state during a century. But that ordinance doesn't affect several homes built before 1974. ``We can't go back and make people rebuild,'' Brock said.

DOC.HEAD: Minister Says London Being Subjected To IRA Terror Campaign
DOC.TEXT: Following two Irish Republican Army bombings in London in three days, Britain's armed forces minister says he believes the capital is being subjected to a systematic terror campaign. The official, Archie Hamilton, said the bombings _ outside an army recruiting center Wednesday and at an army education office Monday _ marked the first time London had seen two attacks so close together. ``I think we are being subjected to a campaign of terror by them (the IRA),'' Hamilton said in an interview with Channel 4 television Wednesday night. ``This is a new situation and we must assume they will try elsewhere, possibly in the London area, in the near future.'' An army sergeant was killed and another injured in the bombing Wednesday in Wembley in north London. The IRA, fighting to end British rule in Northern Ireland, claimed responsibility for the bombing in a statement to news organizations in Dublin Wednesday night. ``While the British government persists in its continued occupation of the north of Ireland the IRA will persist in attacking the British government and its forces in England,'' the IRA said in a statement. The bomb exploded in a white unmarked army van parked behind an army careers information office run by the Territorial Army, Britain's part-time volunteer reserve force. Scotland Yard said the bomb exploded at just after Charles Chapman and another sergeant got into the vehicle. Chapman, 34, was killed. The other sergeant, who was sitting in the back of the van, suffered severe cuts, bruises and smoke inhalation. Two passers-by were treated for shock. The sergeants worked at the recruiting office, on a busy shopping street about a half mile from Wembley Stadium, one of Britain's top sports arenas. Before Wednesday's explosion, 12 people had been killed and one crippled in attacks in mainland Britain since August 1988. On Monday, a time bomb buried in a flower bed blew a hole in the building housing the Directorate of Army Education at Eltham in southeast London, injuring seven civilians. The IRA claimed responsibility. Security at the facilities at Eltham and Wembley was minimal. The IRA has targeted British military installations in Northern Ireland, mainland Britain and the rest of Europe since sectarian and political violence flared in the province in 1969. But it has repeatedly said that in terms of publicity, one bomb in mainland Britain is worth dozens in Northern Ireland. Ten of London's 12 newspapers today made the Wembley attack their main story. The mainly Roman Catholic IRA wants to unite the predominantly Protestant province with the 95 percent Catholic Republic of Ireland under socialist rule.

DOC.HEAD: Killers Executed in Missouri and Texas
DOC.TEXT: A man convicted of killing four people was executed in Missouri today after abandoning all appeals, while a Texas inmate who claimed to be brain damaged from sniffing glue and gasoline was put to death for murdering his brother-in-law. Both men died by injection shortly after 1 a.m. EDT. Leonard Laws, 40, was executed for the robbery and shotgun slayings of an elderly couple. He was the second Missouri inmate executed in the last six days and the third this year. Six inmates have been put to death in the United States this year. In Texas, 30-year-old Johnny Ray Anderson was executed for a 1981 slaying that was part of a scheme to collect $67,000 in insurance money. On Wednesday, the U.S. Supreme Court denied a last-minute stay. Today's executions bring to 127 the number of people put to death since the resumption of capital punishment in the United States in 1977. Texas has had 35 executions, more than any other state; Missouri has had four.
