The last time there were two executions on the same day was March 15, 1988, in Louisiana and Florida. ``Our government has carried out its duty,'' said Missouri Gov. John Ashcroft. ``Robbing and brutally killing elderly people for monetary gain will not be tolerated in the state of Missouri.'' Laws accepted his fate calmly, and indeed helped the process by abandoning further appeals. He died wearing blue jeans instead of gray prison pants, in accordance with one of his last requests. He had no last words. An appeal by his father was refused without comment on April 30 by the U.S. Supreme Court. Laws laughed when he was sentenced to death for killing Charles C. Williams, 83, and Lottie Williams, 72, in 1980 in rural St. Louis County. The gunman, George Gilmore, 43, also has been sentenced to death. According to trial testimony, Laws cut the telephone line and acted as a lookout, then set the couple's house on fire. Laws also was convicted of killing a 65-year-old disabled man and an 85-year-old woman, both in 1980. He was sentenced to life in prison for those slayings. Johnny Ray Anderson, a sixth-grade dropout who blamed his IQ of 70 on sniffing gasoline and glue from age 5, issued a final statement insisting he was not responsible for the fatal shooting of Ronald Gene Goode, a 22-year-old a soft drink salesman. In the statement typed by a fellow death row inmate and containing numerous misspellings, Anderson criticized the justice system as unfair and inconsiderate of ``the victum's family.'' He called himself ``the excape goat.'' ``You people out there don't understand any of this, either because you don't care enough to check, or you will have to wait until your the one on the table getting killed, then as always it will be to late, then you will understand how unfair the system really is for all parties involved,'' Anderson wrote. Texas Attorney General Jim Mattox, who witnessed the execution, dismissed Anderson's claims of innocence. ``Even if he was not the person who pulled the trigger, he would still be culpable for the murder,'' Mattox said. Anderson's lawyers contended in their appeals that his mental shortcomings were not considered by the jury that gave him the death sentence. The U.S. Supreme Court earlier this year ordered the Texas Court of Criminal Appeals to reconsider a similar case involving another condemned man, John Henry Selvage. Anderson's appeal was based on that case. Anderson's sister and Goode's wife, Laura Anderson Goode, and Delvin Johnson were convicted of murder, sentenced to life in prison and paroled last year. Anderson's mother, Rowena, was acquitted of capital murder in the case.

DOC.HEAD: Facts and Figures on Dominican Election
With Dominican-Election, Bjt
DOC.TEXT:
Here are facts and figures at a glance on Wednesday's general election in the Dominican Republic:
LEADING PRESIDENTIAL CANDIDATES:
JOAQUIN BALAGUER _ Rose to power under dictator Gen. Rafael Trujillo, serving briefly as his figurehead president. First elected president in 1966 and served three four-year terms before losing in 1978. Returned to office in 1986. Lawyer and author of about 20 books. Blind from glaucoma. 83 years old. Founder and leader of conservative Social Christian Reformist Party. JUAN BOSCH _ Self-educated intellectual and author of more than 40 books. Marxist philosophy moderated in recent years. First freely elected president, in 1963, after Trujillo assassination two years earlier. Overthrown after six months by military coup. A civil war, with one faction trying to restore Bosch presidency, led to U.S. invasion in 1965. Lost five elections after that. 80 years old. Leader of leftist Dominican Liberation Party. JOSE FRANCISCO PENA GOMEZ _ Onetime Bosch protege, civil war hero and former mayor of Santo Domingo. 52 years old. Leader of social democratic Dominican Revolutionary Party. JACOBO MAJLUTA _ Former vice president. President for 43 days in 1982 after President Antonio Guzman's suicide. Finished close second to Balaguer in 1986. Economist. Finance minister under Bosch. 55 years old. Leader of liberal Independent Revolutionary Party.
LAND, HISTORY AND PEOPLE:
The Dominican Republic shares eastern two-thirds of the Caribbean island of Hispaniola with Haiti. The Spanish-speaking country is roughly the size of Massachusetts. Columbus arrived in 1492. Ceded by Spain to France in 1697. Haiti held entire island from 1822 until 1844, when it gained independence. Annexed to Spain from 1861 to 1865. Long period of political upheaval, with 35 governments and 28 coups, ending with U.S. occupation in 1916. Dictatorship of Trujillo from 1930 until his assassination in 1961. Civil war led to second U.S. invasion in 1965. Estimated population is 7 million. About 75 percent of mixed race, 15 percent Caucasian and 10 percent black. Ninety-eight percent Roman Catholic.
GOVERNMENT:
Constitutional democracy on U.S. model. Executive power vested in the president, who is elected to a four-year term, with a vice president running on the same ticket. Congress consisting of Senate and House of Deputies elected every four years.
THE VOTING:
There are 3.2 million registered voters. Electing president, vice president, 30 senators, 120 deputies and 103 mayors.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: Separates for PMs as a0470 on Henson and as a0476 and on Davis.
DOC.TEXT: Sammy Davis Jr., the exuberant song-and-dance man who started as a goggle-eyed child vaudevillian and battled to the glittery top of the entertainment world, died Wednesday of throat cancer at age 64. Davis performed on stage, on television and in the movies as an actor, singer, dancer and impressionist _ a powerhouse packed into a bantam, 5-foot-6 frame. His hit songs included ``Something's Gotta Give'' (1955), ``I've Gotta Be Me'' (1969) and ``The Candy Man'' (1972). His films included ``Porgy and Bess,'' ``Oceans 11'' ``Robin and the Seven Hoods'' and ``Sweet Charity.'' Davis began as a tap-dancing toddler in Harlem. His energetic performances and upbeat manner were therapy for a life scarred by bigotry, failed marriages, drug and alcohol abuse and crippling tax problems. His last movie was 1989's ``Tap,'' in which he co-starred with Gregory Hines as an old-time hoofer.

Jim Henson, who gave his voice to Kermit the Frog and his creative spirit to a multitude of Muppets, died Wednesday of pneumonia at age 53. Henson created the Muppets in 1954. They made their debut on a Washington TV program and appeared regularly on ``The Ed Sullivan Show.'' But their popularity exploded after they began appearing on ``Sesame Street'' in 1969. Millions of children in 80 countries grew up watching Kermit, Cookie Monster, Oscar the Grouch, Big Bird, Bert and Ernie cavorting on the show, which teaches basic English and math to preschoolers. Later, Henson's ``The Muppet Show'' won three Emmys during its five-year run and became the most widely seen TV program in the world. Henson's puppets moved to the big screen in 1979 with ``The Muppet Movie,'' followed by ``The Great Muppet Caper'' and ``The Muppets Take Manhattan.'' He also won another Emmy for ``The Jim Henson Hour,'' a special on NBC. Henson also won a Peabody for excellence in TV programming and a Grammy for a Muppet album. His Saturday morning cartoon, ``The Muppet Babies,'' won four consecutive Emmys for outstanding animated program.

Casper J. Schoener, former City Hall reporter for The Associated Press in New York, died Wednesday of complications of anemia. He was 74. Schoener spent 39 years with AP and five years before that in the old City News Association, covering police, labor and politics. He began covering City Hall full time in 1966. Schoener was the AP's lead reporter on the newspaper strikes of the 1960s, the parade for astronaut John Glenn, the fiscal crisis of the 1970s and Mayor Edward I. Koch's blossoming as a celebrity. He is survived by his wife, Peggy, four children and four grandchildren.

John Richard Wright, a pitcher in the Negro leagues who in 1946 had a tryout with the Brooklyn Dodgers along with Jackie Robinson, died Thursday in Jackson, Miss., at age 72. The cause of death was not disclosed. Wright was a pitcher for the Homestead Grays in the old Negro National League before and after his tryout with the Dodgers. Robinson became the first black man to play in major-league baseball. Wright also pitched for the Newark Eagles, Toledo Crawfords and the New Orleans Zulus. While in the military, he pitched for the first All-Negro Navy team.

James Earl Mays, a newspaper photographer, columnist and executive, died Monday at age 65. Mays was nominated for a Pulitzer Prize in 1960 at The Virginian-Pilot in Norfolk for exposing illegal trapping of wild ducks on Virginia's coast. He also wrote scripts for 18 documentary and industrial films, including the official NASA films of John Glenn's orbital flight. In 1967, Mays was named news director of WTAR television and radio, a post he held until 1981 when Landmark Communications sold the TV station. Mays then became Landmark's director of communications, retiring in 1985.

Bob Kowalski, a dancer and choreographer who helped found the Works Contemporary Dance, died Tuesday of AIDS at age 37. Founded in 1983 by Kowalski and Ted Hershey, ``Works'' was known for its humorous, energetic and eclectic style, mixing jazz, modern and classical dance. Kowalski's final work as a choreographer, ``Shadows and Light,'' dealt with the AIDS epidemic and was presented last fall. Kowalski last danced on stage in November 1988.

DOC.HEAD: Alaska Airlines Flight Attendants Report Sickness
DOC.TEXT: About 100 flight attendants for Alaska Airlines have reported suffering nausea, headaches and other health problems during several dozen flights in the last eight months, the attendants' union said. The Association of Flight Attendants said some passengers also have complained of develping headaches or feeling strange. Some attendants said they think the problems are caused by bad air in the jets. In many cases, they said, the symptoms cleared up when they left the aircraft or were treated with oxygen. Airline President Bruce Kennedy suggested the fears were unfounded. He said Wednesday the company had received no formal complaints from passengers and had logged fewer than 50 from attendants. ``I think we need at this point to back up from the notion that air quality is the source of the problem,'' Kennedy said. ``I think that a strong case can be made for the notion that the power of suggestion is operating here.'' Bill Cox, a company vice president, said problems had been reported on about three dozen flights out of roughly 13,000 and often involved just one or two of the four attendants aboard. The union said symptoms have included dizziness, confusion, swollen lymph glands, blurred vision, vomiting, weakness and other problems _ some lasting for weeks. The first reports of illness came July 29, involving four flight attendants on a Seattle to Orange County, Calif., flight. They were unable to make the return flight; several did not work for a month or more. Airline officials were unable to find anything wrong with the plane, and doctors could not determine what made the attendants sick. After reports of health problems persisted, the Seattle-based airline sought help from University of Washington specialists and the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health. ``It's frustrating,'' Cox has said. ``We can't find any problems to fix.'' Cox said the complaints concerned about 15 of the airline's 57 aircraft. He said eight or so reports were linked to specific problems, such as a fuel leak in one plane and smoke from a galley oven in another plane. After the initial report in July and discussions with the Federal Aviation Administration, Alaska Airlines said it agreed to clear air grilles, place air-sample bottles on aircraft and analyze cargo aboard when problems occurred. ``Not one indication was given that there was any problem with the air quality aboard an airplane,'' said Ray Vecci, an executive vice president. Cox said cargo has since been ruled out as a source because there has been no hazardous material aboard the flights involved except for one. No pilots have complained of the symptoms.

DOC.HEAD: Former Prime Minister Suffering From Pneumonia
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin was in stable condition today after doctors determined he is suffering from pneumonia, hospital officials said. ``Everything is under control. It was recommended that he rest a little, and he is receiving antibiotics,'' said Orna Cohen, spokeswoman of Shaarei Tzedek Hospital. Begin, 76, who won a Nobel Peace Prize for his role in making peace with Egypt, was brought to Shaarei Tzedek on Wednesday by ambulance after complaining of weakness. He slept through the night after undergoing tests, Mrs. Cohen said. Begin's daughters Hasia and Leah and one of his granddaughters have been staying with him since he arrived at the hospital, the spokeswoman said. Begin's son, Benjamin, a member of parliament representing the right-wing Likud party which his father founded, is overseas. Begin, who became prime minister in 1977, abruptly resigned in September 1983 and has since lived in seclusion in Jerusalem. Aides said at the time that Begin was depressed over the death of his wife, Aliza, and because of Israel's unsuccessful war in Lebanon which cost 650 Israeli lives. While serving as prime minister, Begin suffered several heart attacks. In 1986 he underwent prostate surgery. He was briefly hospitalized in 1987 and in 1989 after complaining of weakness.

DOC.HEAD: Suspects in Jewish Cemetery Desecration Confess
DOC.TEXT: Two Jewish followers of a messianic cult acknowleged they desecrated more than 300 Jewish graves in hopes that Arabs would be suspected and Jews would then unite against perceived Arab hostility, police said today. The two men confessed Wednesday night after initially denying involvement, Haifa police official Yonah Shlomo said. The official said 41-year-old David Goldner admitted he spray-painted 303 graves at a cemetery in the northern port city on Sunday with anti-Semitic slogans in Hebrew such as ``Kill the Jews.'' Gershon Tannenbaum, 32, also agreed to cooperate with police, Shlomo said. The Davar newspaper quoted Tannenbaum as saying he watched the desecration but did not participate. Goldner recently quit his job as a computer scientist involved in weapons development and joined a messianic group, Israel media said. In the weeks prior to Sunday's desecration, Goldner lived at the graveyard, Israel radio quoted police as saying. Davar quoted Goldner as saying: ``I wanted to unite the nation of Israel which is involved in internal arguments while it faces danger from Arab nations.'' Goldner originally denied he carried out the vandalism, but when he was remanded in police custody for 15 days on Tuesday he told reporters: ``I was fulfilling a sacred mission.'' A Haifa court on Wednesday remanded Tannenbaum into custody for 12 days. Israel radio said Tannenbaum persuaded Goldner to join him in a group that practices a mystic form of Judaism based on the belief it can hasten the arrival of the messiah. National Police Commissioner Yaakov Turner said Goldner and Tannenbaum were probably inspired by the desecration last week of 34 graves in the French town of Carpentras where the body of an 81-year-old man was dug up and impaled on an umbrella. The Haifa desecration sparked anger among Haifa's Jewish residents and some accused Arabs of the vandalism. Moslem leaders immediately condemned the desecration.

DOC.HEAD: Russian Deputies Demand Report on State of the Republic
With PM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Radicals trying to elect populist Boris N. Yeltsin president of the Soviet Union's vast Russian republic won their first battle, forcing his opponent to defend his performance as premier. In balloting on procedural issues late Wednesday, delegates by a one-vote margin, 495-494, voted to delay the election of the republic's president, and then voted 551-442 to require a report from Premier Alexander V. Vlasov on the state of the republic. Stanislav Yelisiekin, a supporter of Yeltsin, said the move was intended to force Vlasov into giving an accounting of the republic's disastrous economic and social problems prior to balloting. Russia is the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, stretching from Leningrad on the Gulf of Finland to Moscow and on through Siberia to the Pacific Ocean. It contains 52 percent of the Soviet Union's 290 million people and three-quarters of its land mass. Many Russians feel their wealth is supporting the other 14 Soviet republics, and both Yeltsin and Vlasov have taken up the issue of sovereignty in their platforms. The official Soviet news agency Tass has said some Russian lawmakers are demanding independence, like the three Baltic republics and groups in Azerbaijan, Georgia and the Ukraine. Vlasov is supported by Mikhail S. Gorbachev against Yeltsin, the Soviet president's most popular rival who contends the Soviet leadership has made only half-hearted efforts to solve the country's problems. Gorbachev underscored the importance of the struggle by appearing on the balcony as an observer for the second day today to watch the parliament struggle slowly through largely procedural matters. The radicals are hoping to wrest control of the republic's affairs from the national government. Some are calling for Russian laws to take priority over national laws, and a few are even going so far as to demand that Russia to secede from the Soviet Union. The first stage of the struggle is the election of the parliament's chairman, or president. With Gorbachev watching, the deputies voted 650-243 to elect their president immediately after Vlasov's speech, without discussing any of the candidates. There was no immediate word on when Vlasov would speak, or when the election would be held. There are three lesser-known possible contenders for the job of the Russian presidency: Yuri Manayenkov, a national Communist Party secretary; Ivan Polozhkov, a hardline conservative opponent of market-oriented reforms; and Arkady Volsky, who from more than a year was the head of the committee trying to keep order in Nagorno-Karabakh region between Armenians and Azerbaijanis.

DOC.HEAD: Arizona Governor Signs King Day Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 2 grafs to ADD when holiday takes place; PICKS UP 3rd graf pvs, `Mrs. Mofford ...'
DOC.TEXT: Arizona has a new Martin Luther King holiday on the books, but the 15-year struggle that cost the state millions in lost convention business isn't over yet. Opponents of the holiday said their campaign to put the issue before the voters would begin today, one day after Gov. Rose Mofford signed a bill designating the third Monday in January as a paid holiday in King's memory for state employees. Mrs. Mofford cut short a trip to Tucson to fly back to Phoenix and sign the bill hours after it won final passage in the House. ``This is a great day for Arizona, an especially great day for Governor Mofford because my wish has come true,'' Mrs. Mofford said. The House passed the bill 35-25. The Senate passed it 16-14 on Tuesday. Passage was the culmination of a 15-year struggle to designate a King holiday. Controversy over it has dogged the state's politicians for years. Democratic Gov. Bruce Babbit declared a holiday by proclamation in 1986. His successor, Gov. Evan Mecham, rescinded it days before it would have taken effect. The ensuing uproar included marches, tourist boycotts and convention cancellations. The furor also fueled a recall drive against Mecham, but he was removed by impeachment on other grounds before the recall vote could be held. Opponents say an extra holiday would cost the state $500,000 to $3.5 million. Supporters contend conventions and meetings canceled over Arizona's failure to create a holiday cost the state about $25 million in 1987-88. Mrs. Mofford signed the bill in a conference room packed with political, religious and business leaders who had campaigned for passage. She also spoke by speakerphone with Coretta Scott King, widow of the civil rights leader. ``The people of Arizona now have a great opportunity to put aside the politics of polarization and use this holiday to promote interracial cooperation, healing and good will,'' Mrs. King told the governor. The measure repeals a bill passed in September that created a King holiday but eliminated the state's paid Columbus Day holiday. Opponents of the King-for-Columbus law collected enough signatures to get the measure placed on the ballot, and they said they would try to force a referendum on the new law as well. Julian Sanders, an architect who spearheaded the petition drive on the first bill, said the new campaign would begin today. Opponents have 90 days to collect the 43,350 signatures needed for a referendum. Mrs. Mofford said she was hopeful the referendum drive would fail. She said Arizona needs to put the issue to rest. ``Not only has it affected the economy, but it has hurt us nationally. We are considered a racist state,'' she said. During debate on the bill, state Rep. Brenda Burns, a Republican who had pushed for a public vote, said the issue is ``no longer just an issue of whether to support the Martin Luther King holiday.'' ``It has become an issue of whether or not we take away the people's right to vote,'' she said. Rep. Jim Skelly, a Republican, broke with his fellow conservatives in opposing a referendum. ``We are elected representatives and our job as elected representatives is to pass legislation,'' he said. Forty-seven other states have a holiday honoring King. The other states without official King holidays are Montana and New Hampshire.

DOC.HEAD: Gov't Orders End to Segregation in Hospitals
With PM-South Africa
DOC.TEXT: Reversing its decades-old policy of segregated health services, the government has declared public hospitals open to all races. The decision Wednesday was the latest in a series of reforms since President F.W. de Klerk took office in August. The anti-apartheid National Medical and Dental Association welcomed the change. ``We hope this example will be followed quickly in bringing about an end to other obstacles toward a free and democratic South Africa,'' the group said. Health Minister Rina Venter said the decision was effective immediately and that patients staying at overcrowded black hospitals now could be moved to underutilized white hospitals. Venter told Parliament in Cape Town that all hospitals must be available to all South Africans for the country's health system to run effectively. ``All hospitals are now accessible to all people in South Africa,'' Venter said in an interview after leaving Parliament. Asked if she was worried about the reaction from conservative whites, Venter said, ``No. I think (integrated hospitals) will be in the interests of all our people.'' Schools and neighborhoods now remain the main segregated institutions in South Africa. Also, the country's 28 million blacks have no voice in national affairs. De Klerk has pledged to dismantle apartheid and wants to negotiate a new constitution that will bring blacks into the national government. However, he opposes outright black majority rule. The decision to integrate health services should help alleviate overcrowding at many black hospitals. For example, Johannesburg General Hospital, which is for whites, has an occupancy rate of about 50 percent. In contrast, hundreds of black patients sleep on the floor at Baragwanath Hospital, the only hospital in the nearby black township of Soweto. Traditionally, white hospitals treated blacks in need of emergency or specialized care but transferred them to black hospitals as soon as it was feasible. The staff at public hospitals has been integrated for years. At many private hospitals, both patients and staff already are fully integrated. In other developments: _Defense Minister Magnus Malan told Parliament the military was considering integrating some army units. _Deputy Education Minister Piet Marais said the government was considering combining education departments separated along racial lines into a single bureaucracy. However, Marais gave no indication the government intended to integrate public schools.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Stable as Market Awaits U.S. Trade Figures, Gold Steady
DOC.TEXT: The dollar was stable in calm European trading today and traders said they expected little movement until after the U.S. trade figures for March were released later in the day. ``The trade figures will set the market tone for the rest of the session,'' one trader in Milan said. According to an Associated Press-Dow Jones survey of economists, the trade deficit was expected to have widened to $7.6 billion from $6.49 billion in February. On Wednesday, a lower-than-expected 0.2 percent rise in U.S. consumer prices in April took some of the steam out of the dollar on expectations that U.S. interest rates might decline. Gold remained largely unchanged as buillon dealers also awaited the U.S. merchandise trade figures. In Tokyo, where trading ends as Europe's business day begins, the dollar rose 0.05 yen to a closing 152 yen. Later, in London, it was quoted at a lower rate of 151.90 yen. Other dollar rates at midmorning compared with late Wednesday: _1.6360 West German marks, down from 1.6431 _1.3981 Swiss francs, down from 1.3990 _5.5228 French francs, up from 5.5410 _1.8420 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8505 _1204.65 Italian lire, down from 1208.50 _1.1730 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1756 In London, the dollar fell against the British pound, and was quoted at $1.6927, compared with $1.6805 late Wednesday. Gold opened in London at a bid price of $369.25 a troy ounce, down from $370 bid late Wednesday. At midmorning, the city's major bullion dealers fixed a recommended price of $369.10. In Zurich, the bid price was $369.35, down from $369.85 late Wednesday. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold fell 66 cents to close at a bid $370.15. Silver fell in London to a bid price of $5.03 a troy ounce, from Wednesday's $5.05.

DOC.HEAD: Nails on the Superhighway Slow Motorists
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of roofing nails were dropped on a stretch of superhighway and flars into the Houston economy since 1962, but only recently has its true impact on the area been recognized. Now the center is viewed as one of the cornerstones of the future health of the nation's fourth largest city. Slug BC-Space Money. By Business Writer John Bolt. Moving Thursday on FFF-level news wires for Sunday May 20. LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: TAKEOVER GONE GOOD: Long John Silver's Thrives After Debt-Financed Deal
DOC.TEXT: LEXINGTON, Ky. _ The enormous publicity over the downfall of junk bonds and debt-financed takeovers has obscured what might be a surprising fact: some companies bought with borrowed money are not only surviving but doing well. One of the most visible examples is Jerrico Inc., parent of seafood chain Long John Silver's, acquired in a $620 million buyout last September. Since then the company has cut millions of dollars in costs, sold unwanted assets and concentrated on making seafood competitive with burgers and pizza for America's convenience-minded palates. ``We get the energy released inside the company,'' one of the new owners says. ``We take the lid off.'' Slug BC-Long John Silver's. By Mike Embry. Moving Thursday on FFF-level news wires for Monday May 21. LaserPhoto.
DOC.BYLINE: FAREWELL TO ARMS: Spain's Weapons Industries Change with the Times
DOC.TEXT: MADRID, Spain _ The reduction in world tensions due to the political and economic changes in Communist bloc could have sent Spain's defense industry reeling. But officials say that while arms manufacturers in other Western nations are entering a slump, Spain's revamped defense industry is well along in the race for transformation to civilian technology and will make money. Slug BC-Spain-Arms Industry. By Francisco Conde. Moving Thursday on FFF-level news wires for Monday May 21.

DOC.HEAD: Chief Censor Raids Government TV After Airing Graphic Rape Scene
DOC.TEXT: The chief censor raided the government TV station and confiscated film after the network broadcast an American movie with a graphic rape scene, the official said today. Peoples Television broadcast the film ``The Silent Witness'' on Tuesday night, substituting it quickly when a championship basketball game was unexpectedly interrupted. The film includes a scene in which a woman is stripped and attacked by three men. Such scenes violate censorship regulations in this predominately Roman Catholic country. Manuel Morato, chairman of the censorship board, said irate viewers telephoned his office Tuesday to complain. He rushed to the station and confiscated the tape after the movie ended, he said. Morato said he had referred the case to his legal department for possible criminal charges. Station officials claimed they did not have time to screen the film after the unexpected interruption of the basketball game. ``I have to do my job, even if the government is an offender,'' Morato said.

DOC.HEAD: Alleged Contract Killer for Medellin Drug Cartel Brought to U.S.
DOC.TEXT: An alleged contract killer for the Medellin drug cartel was arrested in Honduras and flown to the United States, where he was charged in a gangland-style slaying here six years ago, police said. Guillermo Leon ``Chiruza'' Velasquez, 33, of Medellin, Colombia, is linked to at least seven murders in South Florida and to other drug-related killings in his homeland, police said Wednesday. He was ``considered an enforcer, an assassin'' for the Medellin drug cartel, said David Steele, a spokesman for Hollywood police. ``His main goal was to kill people on demand if they crossed the path of Blanco.'' Police said Velasquez worked for Griselda Blanco, known as the ``Black Widow'' while she headed one of Colombia's most powerful drug families. Blanco was convicted of conspiring to import cocaine in 1985 and is serving a 25-year prison sentence in New York. Velasquez was taken into custody in Tegucigalpa, the Honduran capital, by Hollywood, Fla., detectives on Tuesday, police said. Because Velasquez is a Colombian citizen, the Honduran government had no obligation to go through formal extradiction proceedings, they said. And the Colombian government would not let him back in that country because of his alleged ties to drug-related murders there, the Sun-Sentinel in Fort Lauderdale reported today. Velasquez, brought to the United States late Tuesday, is being held at the Broward County Jail, where he awaits arraignment and a bond hearing. He was charged with first-degree murder in the July 6, 1984, slaying of Rodrigo Atehortua, a Colombian who lived in Hollywood. Atehortua was shot 18 times when he opened the front door of his home, because of a drug debt to a Colombian drug czar, police said. A six-year investigation by the FBI, the federal Drug Enforcement Agency and Metro-Dade police tied Velasquez to a network of drug deals and ripoffs, police said. ``It involves the same kind of narco-terrorism that now has the Colombian government almost paralyzed,'' Hollywood Police Chief Richard Witt said. Velasquez is also suspected in the torture-slaying of Atehortua's 15-year-old stepson, John Henry Garcia, who was found blindfolded and shot once in the back of the head near Delray Beach a day after his stepfather was killed, police said.

DOC.HEAD: Clashes In 13 Cities On Eve Of Kwangju Uprising; Car Plant Strike Continues
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 14 grafs to UPDATE with anti-government protests. Pickup 7th graf `In the...'; EDITS thereafter to TRIM
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto KWG1
DOC.TEXT: Radical students hurling rocks and firebombs fought police about a dozen cities today on the eve of the 10th anniversary of a bloody 1980 anti-government uprising. Meanwhile, thousands of assembly workers at the nation's leading car plant remained off the job for a third day. The nation's entire police force of 130,000 was put on alert after a major dissident coalition called for nationwide protests this week to mark the anniversary of the May 18, 1980 rebellion in the southern city of Kwangju. The uprising, brutally put down by troops and tanks, left at least 200 people dead and seared the psyche of Koreans more than any other incident since the 1950 Korean War. The nationwide dissident group called the People's Alliance announced in Seoul Wednesday that it would organize a series of protests in Seoul and 16 other cities this week. The alliance was a major force behind the May 9 nationwide protests, the largest and most violent since 1987. Radicals and dissidents demand the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo, saying the merger of his governing party with two opposition groups into the new Democratic Liberal Party (DLP) earlier this year was a political coup and marks a return to dictatorial rule. The semiofficial Moonhwa Broadcasting Co. said about 20,000 students were involved in today's protests on about 50 campuses. Police reported arrests and injuries in today's clashes but gave no figures. In Kwangju, 150 miles south of Seoul, about 1,000 students clashed with riot police around Chonnam University, hurling rocks and firebombs. Police fired barrages of tear gas from two armored vans, sending clouds of the choking gas billowing over the school's main gate. Students threw hundreds of firebombs and rocks. ``Disband DLP!,'' students shouted as they charged police in drizzling rain. ``Drive out yankees!,'' they also screamed, claiming the United States masterminded the formation of Roh's gigantic party. Similar protests were reported in at least 13 cities, including Seoul, Taejon, Pusan, Chonju, Iri, Sunchon and Mokpo but details were unavailable. In Seoul, about 1,500 students formed a new radical group seeking alliance with workers and fought vicious battles with riot police in front of state-run Seoul National University. In the 10-day Kwangju rebellion of 1980, government documents show about 200 people were killed and more than 1,700 others injured or wounded when troops and tanks crushed the revolt. Dissidents claim the death toll was much higher. In the southeastern industrial town of Ulsan, 27,000 assembly workers of the Hyundai Motor Co. remained off their jobs after halting production at the nation's largest car marker on Tuesday. The plant, a subsidiary of the giant Hyundai group, makes 2,650 vehicles a day and sold 589,000 cars last year, including 200,000 in the United States and other nations. Hyundai workers went on strike after talks on a new contract failed to make progress. Union officials reported ``some progress'' in marathon talks but said both sides were still apart over some key issues, including a shorter work week and more benefits.

DOC.HEAD: Muppet Projects to Continue Despite Henson's Death
With PM-Obit-Henson
DOC.TEXT: Despite the death of Jim Henson, Ponce D. Lion and the other Muppets he created will still get a series on the Disney Television Channel, and a 3-D Muppet movie will be produced as planned, a Disney spokesman said. Henson, who sold rights to the immensely popular Muppets to Walt Disney Co. last year for a reported $150 million, died Wednesday at age 53. The long-term deal that brought Kermit and Miss Piggy to the Disney menagerie included Henson's creative services as well as the use of the Muppet characters, which are seen on TV in 100 countries. It was announced last August, but is still not final. Henson's office in New York declined comment on how the death would affect the agreement with Disney. But Disney spokesman Erwin Okun said, ``I've talked with the key people involved in the deal, and they expect everything will proceed as usual.'' ``He will be sorely missed, no question. But the Henson organization is great,'' Okun said. ``Even with a giant, as he was, it's not just a one-man organization.'' ``Jim would be the first to say, `The show must go on,''' said Dick Nunis, a Disney executive in Lake Buena Vista, Fla. Still, Henson's death added a note of uncertainty to future Disney projects, if not the ones under way. Henson's creations and talent were a key part of Disney Co. Chairman Michael Eisner's plans to cross-market characters worldwide through films, cable and network TV, retail stores, restaurants, home video, character licensing, theme parks and resorts. Analyst Jeff Logsdon at the Crowell Weedon & Co. brokerage in Los Angeles noted that the Muppets are probably second only to Disney in worldwide recognition. Eisner called the alliance a ``marriage made in family entertainment heaven.'' In an interview this year with The Associated Press, Henson said he was happy to see his characters frolicking in the Disney environments. ``I love the parks,'' Henson said. ``They have been among my favorite places for years. Now that I'm actually designing things for the parks, I'm having a lot of fun.'' ``Obviously he was a great creative spark and a genius, and his loss will be felt,'' said Harold Vogel, a Merrill Lynch entertainment analyst. ``He would have come up with lots of others things if he'd lived another 10 or 15 years.

DOC.HEAD: Extradition From Syria of Eichmann Deputy Requested
DOC.TEXT: East Germany has asked Syria to extradite the man considered the most important Nazi criminal still at large _ an aide to Adolf Eichmann convicted of sending more than 120,000 Jews to German death camps. Alois Brunner, 78, has been living in Damascus since 1955. Syria has consistently denied his presence although he has been photographed and interviewed at his heavily guarded home in the Syrian capital. The extradition request was presented Wednesday in Damascus by East German Ambassador Karl-Heinz Lugenheim, said Nazi hunter Serge Klarsfeld. An East German Foreign Ministry spokesman, who spoke on condition of anonymity, confirmed in East Berlin that Lugenheim had been instructed to request the extradition. The spokesman gave no further details. Brunner was sentenced to death in absentia twice in 1954, in Paris and Marseille, for taking part in the deportation of more than 120,000 Jews from France to German death camps. After 40 years of denial, East Germany recently admitted its responsibility in Nazi war crimes, formally apologizing to the world Jewish community and announcing it would pay reparations. East Germany joins France, Austria and West Germany in requesting Brunner's extradition. According to the World Jewish Congress, the Austrian-born Brunner is responsibe for the deaths of more than 125,000 Austrian, French, Greek and Czechoslovak Jews. Hitler made Eichmann the chief of the Gestapo Bureau for Jewish Affairs and assigned him to prepare ``The Final Solution,'' the extermination of European Jewry. Israel hanged Eichmann in 1962 for crimes against the Jews. After the war, Brunner was temporarily detained by American and British officials but kept his identity secret. He was tracked down in Syria under the name Georg Fischer in the late 1950s by Austrian Nazi hunter Simon Wiesenthal and officially identified by Klarsfeld and his wife, Beate, in 1982. The Klarsfelds have lobbied actively for Brunner's extradition. In January, Serge, a Paris lawyer, was expelled from Syria after planning a public debate on Brunner. Beate Klarsfeld has devoted her life to bringing war criminals to justice. In February, she met with East German prosecutor Horst Busse to discuss the Brunner affair. In 1985, he was photographed at his home by Bunte, a West German news magazine, and showed no remorse for his crimes. ``I'm not sorry I killed those vermin,'' he was quoted as telling interviewers. Two years later, he told an American newspaper in a telephone interview that the Jews deserved to be killed because they were agents of the devil. He said if he had to do it over again, he would. Mrs. Klarsfeld has said the Israeli secret services also found Brunner. She said they were probably behind the letter bombs that cost him an eye and several fingers.

DOC.HEAD: China Criticizes U.S., Amnesty International Over Human Rights
DOC.TEXT: China today accused the United States of engaging in a smear campaign over Beijing's human rights record and denied Amnesty International's charges of widespread violations. Foreign Ministry spokeswoman Li Jinhua, speaking at a weekly briefing, also said recent student demonstrations in Bulgaria, the Soviet Union and Hong Kong in support of pro-democracy students in China were ``inappropriate'' and based on ignorance. Ms. Li expressed China's strong protest over a proclamation signed Saturday by President Bush that named a national day in support of human rights. The proclamation called on the Chinese government to ``respond positively'' to the aspirations of the pro-democracy movement crushed by military force last year. Ms. Li said: ``We have all along been opposed to interfering in China's domestic affairs and smearing and attacking the Chinese government by the U.S. Congress on the pretext of freedom and human rights.'' She said China was resentful of the human rights proclamation and had expressed such feelings through diplomatic channels. The spokeswoman also said the report Wednesday of the human rights group Amnesty International chronicling the arrests of political activists in last year's demonstrations was ``totally unfounded and unreasonable.'' She said the arrest and trial of ``criminals'' was China's sovereign right and no country or organization had the right to interfere in China's internal affairs. Amnesty International, based in London, said it sent Premier Li Peng a list of 650 names of people arrested since the crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in June. The group asked for information on what had happened to them. China announced last week that it had released 211 people detained for nearly a year in connection with the demonstrations. It said 431 were still under investigation. Foreign and Chinese analysts believe the number still being held without charges or trial is in the thousands. Li said the quelling of what the government calls the ``counterrevolutionary rebellion'' last year ``has won the understanding and support of most other countries.'' Referring to recent demonstrations in Bulgaria, Soviet Union and Hong Kong in support of Chinese students, she said: ``We can only express our regret over the inappropriate actions taken by some people in some countries due to ignorance of the truth of the Tiananmen Square incident.'' China's human rights record has been the central issue in its deteriorating relations with the United States and other Western countries since the violent suppression of the democracy movement. Washington says China has made only minimal improvements in human rights since then, year, and some members of Congress are calling on Bush to show U.S. disapproval by ending most-favored nation status on Chinese imports. Bush, who has until June 3 to make a decision on whether to renew China's favored trading status, said Wednesday, ``I don't want to send a signal that we're happy with their (China's) human rights record. ... It isn't an easy call.''

DOC.HEAD: Actress Paulette Goddard Leaves NYU More Than $20 Million
DOC.TEXT: Actress Paulette Goddard left New York University more than $20 million and the papers of her late husband, novelist Erich Maria Remarque, the university said today. Miss Goddard, who died April 23 in Switzerland, endowed seven new professorships with $1.2 million each, NYU President John Brademas said. They are in film, urban planning, creative writing, literature, European studies, languages and political economy. In addition, her bequest provided three $1 million scholarships, $3 million to establish a fund to attract and assist junior faculty and $7 million for a special endowment, Brademas said. The university plans to name a residence hall for Miss Goddard.

DOC.HEAD: Court Rules Book Profits Must Go to State Crime Victims Board
DOC.TEXT: Profits from the autobiography of convicted murderer Jean Harris must be turned over to the State Crime Victims Board, a state appeals court held. Ms. Harris wanted the $90,000 in profits to go to a fund for the children of inmates at a Westchester County prison where the former private-school headmistress is serving 15 years to life for murdering her lover, diet book author Dr. Herman Tarnower. The Appellate Division of the state Supreme Court in Manhattan ruled Wednesday that the ``Son of Sam'' law applies in Ms. Harris' case. Under the law, known by a nickname of '70s serial killer David Berkowitz, profits that criminals make from recounting their crimes must go to their victims or victims' families _ in this case, Tarnower's survivors. Ms. Harris said she would appeal to the Court of Appeals, the state's highest court.

DOC.HEAD: Cease-Fire Appeals Ignored, Two Killed in Renewed Shelling
DOC.TEXT: A 2-year-old girl asleep in her bedroom was killed today by one of several artillery shells fired during a renewed exchange between rival Christian forces battling for control of their battered enclave. Police said a man was also killed and seven people wounded in the bombardment that followed a short-lived cease-fire called at 9 p.m. Wednesday by the Maronite Catholic church, which claims the warring commanders as members. The girl died when a shell pierced her bedroom in east Beirut's Sin el-Fil district. The wounded included four women in an underground shelter in Ashrafiyeh, the main stronghold of the Lebanese Forces militia. The latest casualties raised the overall toll to 1,031 dead and 2,769 wounded since the battle between troops of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun and the Lebanese Forces commander, Samir Geagea, broke out Jan. 30. Police said the shelling, which engulfed most of the 310-square-mile enclave, picked up only two hours after the cease-fire plea and continued to rage this morning. It was the second cease-fire appeal by the church in three days. Dozens of previous truce accords in the 4-month-old Christian war have collapsed. Shells shook Christian east Beirut as well as Kesrouan province and the pinewoods of Metn northeast of the capital as Aoun's gunners and Geagea's militiamen traded rocket and artillery fire. Both sides accused each other of starting the bombardment, which alternated between raging exchanges and sporadic fire. Police said fire engines were battling fires which broke out in several apartment buildings and gas stations in the enclave, covering the clear blue sky with palls of black smoke. Aoun's 19,000 army troops have failed to overpower Geagea's 6,000 street fighters, who control two-thirds of the enclave. Aoun holds the presidential palace in suburban Baabda. He has refused to hand it over to Syrian-backed President Elias Hrawi because he contends Hrawi's election by parliament on Nov. 24 was unconstitutional. Geagea supports Hrawi. The conflict, the worst inter-Christian confrontation in Lebanon's 15-year-old civil war, has forced more than 400,000 of the enclave's 1 million inhabitants to flee to safer, predominately Moslem areas or overseas havens. The Chamber of Commerce and Industry has estimated damage at more than $1 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Commission Calls on U.S. and Others to Help Refugees
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 4 grafs to CLARIFY that statement adopted by consensus, no vote will be taken until conference ends. Pickup 5th, ``U.S. and...''
DOC.TEXT: An international commission today urged nations that oppose the forced repatriation of Vietnamese boat people to establish and finance refugee centers on their own soil. One delegate said the call was aimed at countries such as the United States, which has condemned Hong Kong for sending back Vietnamese refugees. Thailand and Malaysia sponsored the statement, which was released at the opening session of a conference of the U.N. High Commissioner for Refugees committee on Indochinese refugees. The statement was endorsed by all delegations except the United States and Norway, which expressed reservations, conference sources said. No formal vote was taken because the conference was still under way. U.S. and Norwegian representatives felt the statement should have accentuated positive developments, such as a decrease in the numbers leaving Vietnam, said Herman Laurel, a member of the Philippine delegation. ``This is mostly directed at the U.S. and Vietnam,'' he said, adding that Asian nations ``took the initiative out of their frustration on the continuing problem'' of Indochinese who leave for economic and not political reasons. On Wednesday, the British government announced it had suggested that the United States take 9,000 Vietnamese boat people from Hong Kong and house them in a special camp, possibly on the American island of Guam. In Manila, U.S. delegates refused to comment on the issue until the conference ends Friday. Meanwhile, three boats carrying 222 Cambodians trying to reach Australia reached Indonesia, bringing to more than 400 the number of Cambodian boat people landing there in the last two weeks, a navy officer said today. In the statement, so-called ``countries of temporary refuge,'' those where boat people land first, urged Vietnam to take effective measures to prevent its people from leaving their homeland illegally. The statement said the repatriation of those not considered political refugees was needed to prevent Asian nations from being flooded with Indochinese who do not qualify for settlement in the United States or other third countries. ``There is an obligation on any country which opposes the repatriation of non-refugees who do not volunteer (to return home) to offer an effective intermediate solution, such as the setting up and financing on its own territory a regional holding center for all non-refugees,'' the statement said. It said that if no workable, intermediate solution can be agreed upon, ``temporary refuge countries must reserve the right to take such unilateral action as they deem necessary to safeguard their national interests.'' Vietnam expressed reservations about accepting people who dont' want to return. The 10 Asian countries participating were: Thailand, Malaysia, China, Brunei, Singapore, Japan, South Korea, Philippines, Vietnam and Indonesia. Others included United States, Britain, Soviet Union, Australia, Austria, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, Finland, France, West Germany, Vatican, Italy, Netherlands, New Zealand, Norway, Sweden, Switzerland.

DOC.HEAD: Aquino Suggests Medical, Other Supplies to Defer U.S. Bases `Debt'
DOC.NOTE: Eds: News throughout to UPDATE with talks extended; comment from both sides, new comment from Philippine senate president. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: President Corazon Aquino today suggested the United States could provide medical and other supplies to defer the $222 million that Manila claims Washington owes for use of its six military bases. U.S. and Philippine negotiators agreed to extend their talks into tonight after a fourth day of meetings on whether to extend the bases when their lease expires in September 1991. ``We are trying to hammer out differences,'' said Philippine spokesman Rafael Alunan. ``I believe that they are inching toward some sort of agreement'' on the debt issue. The alleged debt has emerged as a major stumbling block in the talks. Philippine delegates claim the United States had fallen behind by $222.6 million in aid promised in return for use of the bases. U.S. officials say Washington fell only $96 million short of its aid target. ``We have not conceded that there is a shortfall,'' Stanley Schrager, spokesman for the U.S. panel, said today. ``We have lived up to our commitment, and we have made our best effort.'' The chief U.S. delegate, Richard Armitage, was quoted Wednesday as saying he would not ``stand next to a cash register'' while trying to settle the question. President Bush said he would study alternative locations for the bases if the negotiations fail. The two sides also disagree on the termination date for the 1947 agreement on the bases. In 1966, the two governments shortened the lease period and agreed that either party could terminate the bases after 25 years with one year's notice. The Philippine panel maintains that its constitution, drafted by a committee appointed by Mrs. Aquino, bans foreign bases as of September 1991 unless a new treaty has been ratified. The United States says the bases should be allowed to remain for a year after that even if there is no new agreement. Schrager said the delegations agreed to talk all night if need be. ``We're still talking and ... will probably spend the rest of the night to come out with an arrangement,'' he said. Armitage planned to leave the Philippines on Friday but was to return if both sides decide to continue the talks. Some U.S. and Philippine officials have suggested the aid shortfall could be made up by delivering excess military equipment from American units in Western Europe. ``Perhaps these medical facilities could be included in our talks with the U.S. panel on the matter of the shortfall,'' Mrs. Aquino said during a speech at a veterans center today. Mrs. Aquino also said it was too early to say whether the panels had reached an impasse. A classified memorandum prepared in February by the American desk of the Department of Foreign Affairs said the U.S. Congress was reluctant to increase aid to the Philippines because of perceived weak leadership and mismanagement by the Aquino government. The memo, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press, suggested that the government publicly demand full U.S. funding for the bases as well as other aid programs. But the memo recommended Manila quietly lobby the United States to make up the shortfall for the bases on the private understanding that the Philippines would accept a lower figure in aid under the international aid program inaugurated last year. Any agreement on the bases would need the approval of the Philippine Senate, where opposition is running high. The current talks are considered exploratory, to determine whether the two governments will begin formal negotiations on a new agreement. The two sides could also decide to proceed to formal negotiations or simply end the talks and begin deliberations on a schedule for closing the installations, officials added.

DOC.HEAD: Report Accuses Army of Cruelty in Deaths of Palestinian Children
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 8 grafs to UPDATE with WHO resolution on health conditions in territories, edits for transition. Pickup 5th graf pvs, `We are...'
DOC.TEXT: A human rights report today urged international protection of Arab children and said 159 were killed by bullets, beatings and tear gas and up to 63,000 injured during the first two years of the Palestinian uprising. The study, sponsored by the Swedish Save the Children group, claimed that Israel's army practiced ``calculated cruelty'' in some cases. The findings were rejected by the office of Brig. Gen. Nachman Shai, the army spokesman, and criticized by Israeli human rights activists as one-sided. In another development, the World Health Organization's annual assembly today adopted a resolution that cited worsening health conditions of the Arab population in the Israeli-occupied territories. The vote in Geneva was 105-2, with only the United States and Israel voting against. Five countries abstained and another 55 nations were absent. The resolution, co-sponsored by 36 nations, expresses concern at the ``deterioration of health conditions'' and at Israeli's refusal to permit WHO experts to investigate the health situation in the territories. Israel said the health situation in the occupied territories had improved. Responding to the allegations by the Swedish group, an army spokesman, Maj. Moshe Fogel, said pro-PLO activists used children as shields during protests and were responsible for their injuries. ``We are faced with an uprising which turns its children into martyrs and actually encourages minors to participate in violent activities against Israeli soldiers, whether actively or passively,'' he said. Thomas Hammarberg, head of the Swedish group and a former secretary-general of Amnesty International, said Israeli leaders failed to investigate abuses adequately and gave soldiers the impression they could do as they liked. ``It could be the soldiers believe plastic and rubber-coated bullets are non-lethal,'' he said in an interview. ``But I think it begins to take the form of the intentional if they let it continue when they know the consequences.'' The report examined how children 16 and under suffered physical injuries and the effects of collective punishments such as school closures, curfews, house demolitions, raids and economic sanctions. It concluded: ``In view of the Palestinian community's difficulty in protecting its children and the inadequacy of safeguards dependent upon Israeli government enforcement, protection of Palestinian children ... becomes an urgent matter in need of immediate consideration by the international community.'' The report said 159 children, aged 16 and under, were killed in the first two years of the uprising against Israeli rule of the occupied lands. The uprising began in December 1987. The report said 106 of the 159 children were fatally shot. So far this year, 13 children have been shot to death, the report said. The army says 79 children under the age of 14 were fatally wounded in the last 29 months. It does not have a figure for victims 16 and under. The Israeli Information Center for Human Rights in the Occupied Territories says 148 children 16 and under had died through May 1. Spokeswoman Zahava Galon said tear gas deaths were excluded as too difficult to substantiate and that no reliable injury estimates were available. The army disputed the report's claim that ``the vast majority'' of soldiers were not punished for wrongdoing. Fogel said soldiers were court-martialed or disciplined for improper use of force in 25 percent of the fatality cases of children recorded by the army. He said army investigations were hampered because Palestinians often take bodies before autopsies can be performed and Arab witnesses refuse to cooperate with army investigators. The three-volume, 1,008-paged study was written by Anne Elizabeth Nixon, former deputy director of the American Save the Children program in Israel. It was funded by a Ford Foundation grant. Joshua Schoffman, an Israeli civil rights lawyer, said the study had ``serious flaws'' because it relied too heavily on Palestinian sources. ``Just as one has to treat army announcements with skepticism, you have to treat Palestinian testimony with skepticism and balance the two,'' he said. Among the findings: _52 percent of the children killed were not in the vicinity of a protest when they were fatally injured. _Children accounted for 21 percent of all deaths and 38 percent of all injuries and deaths combined. By AP count, 687 Palestinians have been killed along with 43 Israelis. _The average age of children killed was 10 years. _About one in every 15 to 20 children in the occupied lands was injured, totalling 50,000 to 63,000.

DOC.HEAD: Rain in Midwest; Tornado Watch in Parts of South
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 6th graf, `On Wednesday...' to add Kentucky wind damage, injuries.
DOC.TEXT: Rain fell across parts of the Midwest early today, and tornado watches were in effect over a four-state area in the South. Thunderstorms today soaked Louisville, Memphis, and Nashville, Tenn., and Pittsburgh. Rain also fell in Cleveland, Detroit, Chicago and Indianapolis. More rain was forecast for north and central Texas, where the release of rain-swollen reservoirs has caused heavy flooding, loss of life and widespread agricultural damage. Flood watches were posted for today over much of New York into Vermont. Skies were fair over much of the lower Eastern Seaboard. Western skies were patchy with clouds. On Wednesday, damaging tornadoes touched down southwest of Magnolia, Ark., and southeast Worth County in Georgia. Torrential rains and winds of up to 50 mph hammered Kentucky late Wedneday night, battering at least 15 homes at a trailer park outside Elizabethtown and injuring several residents. Flooding continued in parts of Illinois, Missouri and Louisiana. Baseball-size hail fell near Fouke, Ark., and hail the size of golfballs fell at Fairview, W. Va., and Sullivan and Villa Ridge, Mo. The nation's high on Wednesday was 103 degrees at Presidio and Lajitas, Texas. The low was 16 degrees at Casper, Wyo. DOC.HEAD: Mexican Police Aided Drug Traffickers, Witness Says
DOC.TEXT: Mexican police accepted payoffs from drug barons, delivered narcotics and provided arms to protect marijuana ranches, a prosecution witness said in a trial resulting from a U.S. drug agent's murder. Juan Fernandez testified in U.S. District Court Wednesday that in 1984 he helped manage marijuana ranches for Mexican drug lord Rafael Caro Quintero and hnded out bribes to officials from four Mexican law enforcement agencies. Fernandez was the first government witness to testify in the trial of four men charged with conspiracy in the 1985 torture and killing of U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration agent Enrique ``Kiki'' Camarena. The defendants are Juan Ramon Matta Ballesteros, a convicted Honduran drug kingpin; Ruben Zuno Arce, a brother-in-law of former Mexican President Luis Echeverria; Juan Bernabe Ramirez, a former Mexican policeman; and Javier Vasquez Velasco, accused of killing two U.S. tourists who were mistaken for DEA agents. Prosecutors allege that Camarena was killed in retaliation for raids on marijuana fields that cost Caro Quintero and other drug barons $5 billion. Speaking in Spanish, Fernandez said he had been paid more than $200,000 as a DEA informant over the past nine years and helped the agency on ``more than 80 investigations.'' He said he helped Camarena make an undercover heroin purchase from a Caro Quintero associate, Manuel Chavez, and that Camarena had instructed him to take a job helping run the ranches. Fernandez said the Guadalajara drug cartel led by Caro Quintero maintained about 40 marijuana ranches in Zacatecas state. The cartel employed up to 500 workers who lived in the fields under armed guard, Fernandez said. Chavez used a radio to keep in touch with Mexican federal, state and local police officials, Fernandez said. Chavez would make payoffs ``on a particular day ... the end of the month,'' Fernandez testified. Information obtained by Camarena led to the seizure of more than 10 tons of marijuana during raids on the ranches in May 1985, U.S. officials contend. Testimony at the 1988 trial of three other men in the case revealed that Camarena was abducted from a Guadalajara street in February 1985 and taken to a house, where he was tortured and interrogated, then slain. His body was found along with that of his Mexican pilot, Alfredo Zavala Avelar, on a ranch 65 miles outside Guadalajara. Former DEA agent James Kuykendall, who was in charge of the Guadalajara office where Camarena was assigned, testified Wednesday that U.S. agents used undercover ventures such as Camarena's heroin buy to convince officials in Washington that ``the problem was bigger than they believed it was.''

DOC.HEAD: PLO Realigning Its Military Ranks
DOC.TEXT: The Palestine Liberation Organization is consolidating its military forces throughout the Middle East under a new strategy to upgrade its combat potential, according to PLO officials and newspaper reports today. The Kuwaiti daily Al-Anbaa quoted PLO leader Yasser Arafat as saying that Israel was planning a large-scale attack on neighboring Arab states in autumn or the following spring. Arafat warned that Israel intended to occupy the Jordanian mountains from Salt to Karak on the advice of former Defense Minister Ariel Sharon, now trade minister, the newspaper said. The newspaper quoted Arafat as saying that Sharon recommended proceeding to the outskirts of Amman, Jordan, ``to impose its conditions on Jordan.'' Newspaper reports did not specify that the PLO was gearing up for war. Bassem Abu Sharif, an aide to Arafat, was quoted by Al-Anbaa as stressing that the military realignment was ``a strategic choice.'' Al-Anbaa quoted Palestinian sources in Tunis as saying the PLO leadership recently met in the Iraqi capital, Baghdad, and adopted ``a new Palestinian military strategy ... that provides for gathering all Palestinian forces to enable them to restore their combat abilities.'' It said that under the new plan all Palestinian forces have been shifted to two Arab countries, Iraq and Libya, from Algeria, Sudan, and the two Yemeni states, where the Palestinian guerrillas fled from Lebanon. The transfer was in line with the tasks to be assigned to these forces in the coming stage, the newspaper said. PLO military strength has usually been scattered in Arab countries, particularly since 8,000 PLO fighters were forced out of Beirut by the 1982 Israeli invasion of the Lebanese capital. A year later, 3,000 more fled the northern Lebanese town of Tripoli under Syrian pressure. Senior PLO figures say they have returned, with the organization's strength in Lebanon estimated at more than 11,000 fighters. Lebanon used to be a favored base for the PLO, which launched military operations against Israel starting in 1965 from neighboring Arab countries. Jordan, Egypt and Syria all cracked down on their operations, leaving only Lebanon.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Conservative Public Holding Back Reforms
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that a conservative Soviet public afraid of change is holding back his efforts at economic and political reform. ``Changing people's minds is the most difficult thing. Perestroika depends on public opinion, and it's conservative,'' he said. Gorbachev previously has blamed bureaucrats for bogging down perestroika, his program of restructuring Soviet society. This is the first time he has said the people might be at fault. ``In politics, the public doesn't accept pluralism, and it has complexes about ideological conceptions and cliches,'' Gorbachev told a crowd of reporters in a break at the Russian congress. Many hard-liners are unhappy with Gorbachev's recent moves to end the Communist Party's monopoly on power, legalize private ownership of factories and otherwise upset basic laws of Marxism. ``In economics, they say you must not touch this and you must not touch that,'' Gorbachev said. Turning to Premier Nikolai Ryzhkov, who gave a television interview last week on economic reform proposals, Gorbachev commented: ``Ryzhkov only said a few words and already there is great agitation in the country.'' ``Take any sphere, everywhere we are hindered by complexes,'' the Soviet leader said. Faced with public alarm, Gorbachev has repeatedly delayed a radical economic reform plan over the last two months. He backed off suggestions by his aides that he was planning Polish-style ``shock therapy,'' which brought sudden price rises and mass unemployment in that country, in hope of shortening the difficult period of transition from old-style Communism to a market economy. Instead, Gorbachev has promised the public that nothing would be decided without discussion. He also indicated that his presentation of the program to the national parliament will be delayed again, as he will not discuss it with his own Presidential Council of advisors until May 22. Gorbachev also used the brief encounter with reporters to reassure the Soviet populace that the country can handle the current intense political struggle and its economic crisis, which has left stores near empty. ``People are saying `Chaos, chaos, collapse, collapse.' When Lenin watched a similar revolutionary process, he said: `You know, this chaos will crystallize a new form of life.'' The Soviet leader was looking relaxed and healthy after a day and a half of watching the Congress of the Russian republic wrangle over its agenda. Newly elected radicals are trying to elect a Gorbachev rival, Boris Yeltsin, as president of Russia, and to wrest control of the republic's affairs away from the national government. Russia is the largest of 15 republics in the Soviet Union, with 52 percent of its people and three-quarters of its land mass. Gorbachev, who stands to lose considerable prestige if his candidate, Russian premier Alexander Vlasov, is defeated by Yeltsin, was off-hand when asked about the struggle. ``I see no drama in this,'' he said. ``This is all normal. The (Communist) party has given up its monopoly.'' ``Tomorrow or the next day, new parties will appear with their own platforms and proposals, and this will be a normal process.'' He also condemned the Soviet tradition of government-owned monopolies, which have been blamed for part of the nation's economic stagnation. He even joked about it. ``We fought against the capitalist monopoly for 70 years _ but the strongest monopoly is our own,'' he said. ``Right here we have the representative of our former monopoly, Uralmash,'' he said, gesturing at Ryzhkov. The premier previously served as director of the giant Uralmash factory, which makes earthmovers and other heavy-duty equipment. But when foreign correspondents pressed him on the crisis in the Baltics, where Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania are all demanding independence from the Soviet Union, he abruptly shut down the interview. Asked if he would meet with representatives of the Baltic, he looked the correspondent in the eye _ and then turned away, telling his guards, ``Let's move on.'' Another correspondent then asked if he would meet with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene, who was en route to Moscow this afternoon with a compromise proposal to put to Gorbachev. He said, ``I have received no such request,'' and moved away.

DOC.HEAD: Polhill Undergoing Cancer Surgery
DOC.NOTE: EDs: LEADS with 4 grafs Polhill in surgery; picks up 4th graf pvs, He said...
DOC.TEXT: Freed American hostage Robert Polhill underwent surgery today to remove his voice box because of a cancerous growth around his vocal cords. Ben Smith, spokesman for Walter Reed Medical Center, said the midmorning operation was expected to take about four hours. Polhill's doctors said Wednesday that such radical surgery might have been avoided if the tumor had been diagnosed sooner. ``If it had been discovered earlier, he probably wouldn't have to lose his voice box, provided he had the right radiation therapy,'' said Col. Russ Zajtchuk, deputy commander of clinical services at the Army hospital. He said the tumor is probably at least a year old, but that there is no evidence the cancer has spread. Nonetheless, Polhill's treatment will include radiation therapy, the doctor said. Polhill, 55, was held captive by Shiite Moslems in Lebanon for 39 months before being released April 22. ``We are going to overcome this ordeal. We are survivors, and we are definitely going to survive this ordeal,'' Ferial Polhill said at the news conference, which her husband did not attend. Polhill has told his doctors he was visited by physicians eight or 10 times during his captivity. ``I'm pretty sure they didn't examine his throat,'' Zajtchuk said. ``He's a smoker and this condition is related to smoking,'' Zajtchuk said, adding that Polhill told him his captors had kept him in cigarettes. ``The growth is involving both vocal cords. One vocal cord, the left, is paralyzed,'' Zajtchuk said. ``The tumor also extends below the vocal cords, so it is quite an extensive lesion.'' Polhill's weak, raspy voice prompted early discovery of the tumor. A full diagnosis was put off until Polhill, a diabetic who was 25 pounds underweight when he was released, gained enough stamina to undergo the general anesthesia necessary for a biopsy. Polhill was told after the biopsy last week that the growth was cancerous, and agreed to surgery. Public disclosure was postponed to give Polhill time to tell members of his family, Zajtchuk said. Mrs. Polhill said her husband's spirits were ``very high, very positive, strong.'' Polhill's mother, Ruth, nodded agreement. Zajtchuk said Polhill had begun working with a speech therapist to explore various methods for voice communication once the larynx is removed. One common method involves the use of an electronic device that emulates the voice box. Another technique involves swallowing air and regurgitating it in a way that forms words. A third possibility, one not favored for radiation patients, requires a tracheotomy _ the insertion of a breathing tube in the throat. ``His mental status is remarkable,'' Zajtchuk said. ``Imagine a fellow being locked up for 3{ years. And then he comes to Walter Reed, and he virtually gets locked up again. And then he can't communicate, because he's going to lose his voice box.'' Polhill is expected to spend about two weeks in the hospital after the surgery, then will undergo radiation treatments.

DOC.HEAD: Company Chairman Bought Van Gogh Painting, Paper Says
DOC.TEXT: A newspaper today identified the buyer of van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' as the honorary chairman of a major Japanese paper company and quoted him as saying he spent $33 million more than he intended. ``I am extremely pleased with the purchase,'' the 74-year-old businessman, Ryoei Saito, told Nihon Keizai, an economic newspaper. A representative of the Kobayashi Gallery of Tokyo paid $82.5 million for the world's most expensive painting at a Christie's auction in New York on Tuesday, but refused to identify its client. Nihon Keizai said Saito, president of Daishowa Paper from 1961 to 1982, was the anonymous buyer. Saito and officials of Daishowa Paper Manufacturing Co., Japan's second largest paper manufacturer, could not be reached for comment. Saito was quoted by the paper as saying,``I have been collecting paintings for 40 years, but I wanted to own this van Gogh painting. Therefore, I asked to make a successful bid no matter how expensive it was.'' The final price of the painting ``was 5 billion yen ($33 million) higher than what I expected,'' he was quoted as saying. Saito told the paper he borrowed the money from banks, using his property as security, the paper said. Asked about the possibility of displaying the painting, Saito said that for security reasons he would ``keep it at hand for the time being.'' He said eventually he would like to display the van Gogh at the Shizuoka Prefectural Art Museum.

DOC.HEAD: TV Networks, White House in Dispute Over Coverage Rules
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS new 5th graf, bgng, The White ... to UPDATE with no camera restrictions today
DOC.TEXT: The four major television networks say they will keep boycotting some White House events if President Bush's press secretary continues limiting the number of cameras. The networks bypassed two of Bush's meetings Wednesday to protest Marlin Fitzwater's experiment with limiting coverage of certain events to two pool cameras. CBS News bureau chief Barbara Cohen, who chairs the networks' own pool of bureau chiefs, said, ``We have all decided that if they continue to call for a travel pool for these events, we will continue to not come.'' She and the bureau chiefs at NBC, ABC and CNN were demanding a meeting with Fitzwater to discuss the coverage rules. The White House did not attempt to limit the number of cameras at any of today's events, including Bush's planned Oval Office meeting with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Radio networks, in a gesture of sympathy, also declined to send in a reporter to cover two Bush meetings Wednesday dealing with civil rights. ``They don't have to cover us if they don't want to,'' Fitzwater said in an interview. ``All we're doing is experimenting.'' Fitzwater said he wanted to reduce the crush of camera crews inside the Oval Office and other corners of the executive mansion at limited coverage events. All the networks covered the president's news conference on Wednesday. The White House earlier in the week twice limited coverage of presidential meetings, including the opening of Tuesday's budget summit with congressional leaders. A single network sent in two cameras to videotape the events and shared the tape afterward with competitors. ``It's not our fault that there are more independents sending camera crews in,'' said Cohen. ``We are competitors and we don't want to have our product homogenized by having one camera crew at all these events.'' ABC bureau chief George Watson said, ``If it's a question of congestion and decorum, that's something we can talk about.'' He said the networks might be open to restricting coverage to two cameras, in exchange for letting each network send in its own correspondent to ask questions. Currently only one broadcast correspondent is in such pool coverage.

DOC.HEAD: Marlo Brando's Son Arrested Following Shooting at Estate
DOC.TEXT: The son of actor Marlon Brando was arrested for investigation of murder in the shooting of a guest at the exclusive Bel-Air estate of his Oscar-winning father, police said today. Christian Brando, 32, is being held without bail, Lt. Ron Hall said. Officers called to the estate late Wednesday night found the body of Dag Dorlett, 26, who had been shot once in the head, said Officer Bill Frio. ``The dispute was over the victim's treatment of Cheyenne Brando, Marlon Brando's 20-year-old daughter,'' Hall said. ``It was a family matter.'' He did not elaborate. Marlon Brando, his wife and daughter were in another wing of the home and did not witness the shooting, Hall said. Officers recovered a handgun they said may have been used in the shooting and also seized four rifles from the home, Hall said. Christian is the son of the 66-year-old actor and his first wife, Anna Kashfi. The couple was divorced in 1959. Cheyenne is Brando's daughter by Tarita Teriipia, a Tahitian actress who played his sweetheart in 1962's ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' Marlon Brando won best actor Oscars in 1954 for ``On the Waterfront'' and in 1972 for ``The Godfather.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S.-Canada Forest Research Agreement Signed
DOC.TEXT: A memorandum of understanding was signed today by Agriculture Secretary Clayton Yeutter and Canadian Minister of Forestry Frank Oberle to improve cooperation in forest research and management. The agreement covers six areas of cooperation between the United States and Canada: _Fire behavior and emissions research, including joint investigations of the behavior, emissions and environmental effects of wildfires and prescribed fires. _An investigation of the decline in vigor and productivity of sugar maple stands in the northeastern United States and southeastern Canada. _Spruce budworms research to investigate outbreaks that have caused large losses in both countries. _An analysis of North American timber, an expansion of cooperation in forest inventory, resource and timber supply analysis, and an analysis of international trade and demand. _Mountain pine beetle management, including development of new ways of reducing losses from pine beetles in lodgepole pine forests. _Wood utilization research.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Defends Prayer Time Before His Sessions
DOC.TEXT: Five lawyers suing a county judge in federal court argue that his practice of opening sessions with a prayer forces his religious beliefs on a captive audience. For a year, Mecklenburg County District Judge Bill Constangy has recited a 67-word prayer he composed himself before he hears traffic and other lower court cases. ``A lot of people think the courts are involved in a lot of tricks and games,'' Constangy testified Wednesday. ``The prayer ... sets the proper tone... . It's not done as a religious exercise, it's done for a secular purpose.''
