The North Carolina Civil Liberties Union and five Charlotte lawyers are suing to bar the prayer under the U.S. Constitution's separation of church and state. ``This is an official prayer,'' said George Daly, attorney for the plaintiffs. ``It was composed by an official, read in an official setting, on company time.'' After hearing several hours of testimony, U.S. District Court Judge James McMillan said he would not rule before June 4. He gave attorneys on both sides until then to submit additional evidence. Constangy, a 47-year-old Charlotte native who attends a Roman Catholic church, was defended by the state attorney general's office, as well as attorneys from a Greensboro law firm and The Rutherford Institute in Charlottesville, Va. The institute is a non-profit legal and educational organization that specializes in litigation involving church-and-state constitutional issues, according to its executive director, Michael Patrick. One of the judge's attorneys, James T. Williams Jr., compared the prayer with those invoked before Congress and the inscription ``In God We Trust'' on U.S. currency. ``There's no difference on earth between the U.S. Congress opening its sessions with a prayer and this man opening court with a prayer,'' Williams said. But public defender Kathleen Arundell doesn't see it that way. ``The judge should avoid the appearance of impropriety,'' she testified. ``The people in the courtroom feel he has made a religious statement and he isn't impartial.'' Constangy recites this prayer: ``O Lord, our God, our Father in heaven, we pray this morning that you will place your divine guiding hand on this courtroom and that with your mighty outstretched arm you will protect the innocent, give justice to those who have been harmed and mercy to us all. ``Let truth be heard and wisdom be reflected in the light of your presence here with us today. Amen.''

DOC.HEAD: Tire Fire Burns Out of Control in Quebec
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd, ``Officials said...'' with 1 graf to UPDATE with fire about 50 miles from the U.S. border. Pickup 4th, `The smoke...'
DOC.TEXT: ST-AMABLE, Quebec (AP) _ A fire raged out of control in Quebec's largest tire dump today, spewing coal-black smoke, and the mayor of a nearby town said residents might have to be evacuated. The flames jumped a firebreak late Wednesday and quickly spread to almost all 3 million tires in the dump, which is the size of seven football fields. Officials said it was not immediately clear what caused the blaze, located about 1 mile outside St-Amable, a town of 5,000 people, and about 50 miles from the U.S. border. Billowing clouds of smoke drifted over nearby farm fields. The smoke funneled high and drifted northwest, away from St-Amable, where citizens for years have asked that the tires be moved or at least better protected. But officials said a change in winds could blow smoke toward the town today. They told residents that, while tests for toxic elements in the air so far turned up negative, an evacuation plan was ready. ``We are going to watch the toxicity of air and if it goes high we will evacuate,'' said Jacques Doyon, the mayor of St-Amable. The smoke was clearly visible over Montreal, 13 miles away. The fire, which began Wednesday afternoon, jumped a firebreak and raced to the end of the dump, where firefighters from a half dozen towns in the region held the flames at a 50-yard trench dug with heavy equipment. Doyon on Wednesday said fire crews were ``powerless'' to fight the blaze until the flames became less intense. Early today, a steady rain began to fall on the blazing tires. Doyon said fire crews started dumping dirt on the lower end of the tire pile in an attempt to snuff the flames. Smoke from burning tires is known to pose a health danger and can spoil crops. The burning tires also leave an oily residue that can contaminate underground and surface water. Last month, a fire at a dump in Ste-Anne-des-Plaines, 35 miles north of Montreal, was brought under control after 50,000 tires burned over 24 hours. Hagersville made headlines in February when arsonists started a fire at a dump holding 14 million tires. The fire, which burned for 17 days, was the largest tire blaze in North American history. The Quebec government said in March it would spend $3.5 million to increase security and put up fences at the province's seven largest tire dump sites.

DOC.HEAD: Aggressive Form of Pneumonia Killed Henson
With PM-Obit-Henson
DOC.TEXT: Muppet creator Jim Henson was killed by an unusually quick-spreading form of bacterial pneumonia, a doctor who treated him said. Dr. David M. Gelmont, director of intensive care at New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center in New York, said the 53-year-old puppeteer apparently was healthy until coming down with flulike symptoms Friday. Henson was examined by a doctor in North Carolina who did not find pneumonia, Gelmont said. Henson's condition worsened and he returned on Monday to New York, where he died Wednesday. When he arrived at the hospital early Tuesday, the bacterial infection that caused his pneumonia had spread from his lungs through his body, attacking other organs, doctors said. At that point, it could not be controlled with antibiotics, the usual therapy. Pneumonia is an inflammation of the lungs that is most often caused by streptococcus, the bacteria that killed Henson, but also can be caused by other forms of bacteria, as well as viruses. Pneumonia strikes about 2 million Americans each year and kills 40,000 to 70,000, many already ill with other serious diseases, such as heart disease or cancer. Pneumonia is primarily a hazard of the very young and very old and rarely kills people who are in otherwise good health. Among those at especially high risk of pneumonia's complications are people whose immune systems have been weakened by diseases such as AIDS or who are taking immune-suppressing medicines. As for Henson, Gelmont said, ``Categorically, he did not have AIDS.''

DOC.HEAD: Leftist Ex-President Holds Narrow Lead Over Incumbent in Early Returns
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Leads with 17 grafs to UPDATE with comment from Bosch's party, Carter quote, capital quiet. Pickup 14th graf, `Bosch, an author...' TRIMS.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY5
DOC.TEXT: Juan Bosch, a leftist ex-president once ousted in a military coup, took an early lead over conservative President Joaquin Balaguer in Dominican elections, according to initial returns today. Bosch, who has moderated his positions in promising to lead the nation out of an economic crisis, held a narrow lead with about 20 percent of the polling stations reporting, the Electoral Board said this morning. At the headquarters of Bosch's Dominican Liberation Party, Bosch's backers were celebrating early today. Lideo Cadet, the party's secretary-general, excitedly told reporters at dawn: ``We've won the elections.'' But he was not authorized to make a formal claim of victory on Bosch's behalf. Cadet said Bosch was being kept informed about Wednesday's election by the party leadership but would not comment yet. Neither Balaguer nor his party leaders commented publicly on the returns. Aides said Balaguer planned to keep to his usual schedule at his palace office. Vote-counting was being done by hand and was running far behind schedule. Balaguer, 83 and blind from glaucoma, and Bosch, 80, were locked in their fifth contest for the leadership of this Caribbean nation of 7 million people. With 1,364 of the 6,663 polling stations reporting, Bosch had 126,443 votes to Balaguer's 114,806, election officials said. A former socialist mayor of Santo Domingo, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, was third with 80,816 votes, and center-left candidate Jacobo Majluta had 22,559 votes, officials said. Bosch and the army hierarchy have been at odds since he was overthrown in a military coup 27 years ago. But military officers and Balaguer stated before the elections they would respect the outcome of the vote. About 30 international observers monitored the voting, including former President Jimmy Carter. He told reporters that talks with the four major candidates after the polls closed had convinced him the final results would be respected by all. Santo Domingo was quiet this morning, with no military patrols visible. Public and private offices and commercial establishments customariliy remain closed and Dominicans stay home from work the day after national elections, although it is not an official holiday. The Election Board remained in control of the nation's public and private radio and television stations, allowing only the broadcast of official election information. About 3.2 million people were registered to vote, but the officials did not announce the turnout or say what percentage of the vote had been counted. Bosch, an author and intellectual who describes himself as a Marxist but not a Communist, ran on a moderate platform. He pledged to work for good relations with the United States and endorsed capitalism as the best way to improve his country's economic plight. Balaguer, founder and leader of the Social Christian Reformist Party, pinned his hopes largely on a $2 billion public-works project to transform centuries-old Santo Domingo. He portrayed Bosch as a dangerous Marxist. Balaguer's public-works project has created thousands of new jobs, but his popularity has slumped as the country's economic problems deepened. Dominicans have contended with chronic electricity blackouts and water shortages. Bosch had been leading in opinion polls by 10 points, but some observers believe he may be hurt by his criticism last week of a 1954 agreement with the Vatican providing all army chaplains be Roman Catholic. This nation, which shares the island of Hispaniola with Haiti, is overwhelmingly Catholic.

DOC.HEAD: Judge: Open Stores, But Don't Sell Banned Items
DOC.TEXT: A judge has ruled that all businesses can open on Sundays in North Dakota, but has retained a list of 44 items that still cannot be sold on the Sabbath, including clothing and hardware. The law, which also lists 37 types of businesses that may open Sundays, including cold storage warehouses, libraries, bait shops and coin-operated laundries, was called ``arbitrary, haphazard and irrational'' by the judge. North Dakota malls, though, won't be opening for business Sunday. South Central District Judge Gerald Glaser temporarily blocked his own ruling from taking effect, anticipating an appeal that Attorney General Nicholas Spaeth later said he would pursue. The decision came Wednesday in a lawsuit filed by a group of North Dakota businesses seeking to overturn the state's Sunday closing law, which is recognized as the nation's strictest. The businesses, backed by the state chamber of commerce, contend the law is vague, unconstitutional and selectively enforced. Glaser's decision, which handed small victories to both Spaeth and North Dakota shopkeepers in the dispute, surprised the attorney general. Glaser ``has staked out a middle ground, and I don't think either side expected it,'' Spaeth said Wednesday. Glaser said the law was discriminatory, as well as ``arbitrary, haphazard and irrational.'' But its flaws did not warrant throwing it out entirely, the judge said. Glaser's ruling, in essence, does away with the list of businesses that may open, allowing any retailer to open on Sunday as long as the retailer does not sell the 44 prohibited items. John Olson, a Bismarck attorney for the business group, said the ruling ``further erodes Sunday closing restrictions in North Dakota. There's no doubt about that.'' ``It will probably increase retail business on Sunday,'' Olson said. ``But the opinion does not have the effect of going the whole nine yards and creating Sunday opening in this state.'' A large discount retailer could open on Sunday if it limited itself to selling shampoo, toothpaste and other items not specifically barred from Sunday sale. However, the store could not sell clothing _ except for work gloves and baby supplies _ or kitchenware, radios, clocks or linens. In Fargo, merchants at North Dakots's largest shopping mall said they were disappointed and somewhat confused. ``I wasn't expecting to completely do away with the law, but I was hoping we'd take a bigger bite out of it,'' said Mark Sinner, owner of Creative Kitchen in the West Acres Mall. Creative Kitchen sells kitchenware and kitchen utensils _ two of the 44 items barred for Sunday sale. ``I think it's idiotic,'' said Donna Haroldson of Fargo, who was shopping with a friend. ``I guess North Dakota always feels Sunday is a day of rest. I think that's dumb in this day and age.''

DOC.HEAD: Train Workers Stop Rail Traffic Nationwide in Warning Strikes
DOC.TEXT: East German transportation workers briefly halted train traffic nationwide today to demand higher wages and job protection, the latest strikes in a wave of worker unrest. The 30-minute strikes paralyzed main rail routes. Employees stopped work at switching yards, train stations and ticket offices, the East German government news service ADN said. Workers staged the warning strikes to protest what they called the failure of transportation officials and the government railroad company to meet their demands. Train traffic, a principal form of daily transportation for many East Germans, was interrupted in the cities of Magdeburg, Rostock, Gera, Schwerin and others, ADN said. At the main station in Rostock, workers demonstrated against ``the delay tactics of the traffic ministry,'' ADN said. Transportation and railroad officials rejected a wage demand on Wednesday, the news service said. The strikes were the latest among several worker demonstrations in recent weeks as frustration grows over the possible effects on jobs of unification with West Germany. The two nations are to combine their economies on July 2, when the West German mark is to become the currency of East Germany. Workers are seeking protection from joblessness and from the better-made Western imports already flooding the country. Many outmoded East German businesses are expected to fail in the first two years of economic unification. They also are demanding higher wages to cope with the price increases expected when Communist price controls are lifted and costs are set by the free market. The strikes were held during the weekly session of Parliament, which debated the draft of a constitution that will allow East Germany to unite with its western neighbor. The draft of the democratic charter would eliminate the guarantees of full unemployment under the old Socialist system, toppled by a peaceful revolt last year. Left-leaning Social Democrats say East Germans should have some job and social guarantees during a transition period to the free market. Conservatives say the increase in Western investment will eventually raise living standards and provide jobs.

DOC.HEAD: ``Today'' Still Second
DOC.TEXT: NBC's ``Today'' show, which will welcome Joe Garagiola back in June as its third co-host, still has the ratings blues. It was in second place last week for the 19th straight week, Nielsen estimates showed Thursday. ABC's ``Good Morning America'' remained first in ratings, averaging a 4.8. ``Today'' averaged a 3.2 and ``CBS This Morning'' a 2.6. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. The 19th week of bad news for ``Today'' came a day after it was twitted on local TV by WNYW-TV's ``Good Day New York'' show, which last week beat the slumping NBC show in local Nielsen ratings. The needling occurred Wednesday on the East River, where ``Today'' was broadcasting live from a 160-foot luxury yacht. Gordon Elliott, who normally barges into homes for live interviews on ``Good Day,'' dogged the ``Today'' broadcast in a rented cabin cruiser. NBC was not amused, said the puckish Elliott, whom viewers saw using a bullhorn to hail NBC's show, ask permission to board what he called the ``S.S. Today,'' and interview co-hosts Bryant Gumbel and Deborah Norville. NBC, though the Coast Guard, ``formally asked us to stay 100 yards from their vessel, which I thought was bad sportsmanship,'' he groused. ``I was going to make our show available to help them in the ratings.'' But Elliott can sympathize with ratings woes like those of ``Today.'' He once was a host of ``Good Morning Australia,'' which at one time also had ratings problems. ``It happens to every show,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Rafsanjani Predicts Cooling Of Iranian Revolution
DOC.TEXT: Iranian President Hashemi Rafsanjani today predicted a cooling of the radical revolution that swept Iran more than 11 years ago, and said his people will care more about the economy, Tehran radio reported. ``As the revolutionary conditions of the country are normalized, society's political sensitivity will decrease, and attraction to welfare and material issues will increase,'' he said, according to the radio monitored in Cyprus. Speaking to provincial officials in Tehran, he told them to ``move according to the conditions of the time and create an economic-political balance in society in accordance with the government's precise programs.'' Rafsanjani is trying to pull Iran out of the economic mess left by the chaotic 1979 revolution and a devastating eight-year war with Iraq. Sources in Tehran report growing public dissatisfaction with the economy. Iranians daily must contend with shortages of almost all consumer goods, runaway inflation and an artificially inflated currency that is all but worthless abroad. Since his election in July, Rafsanjani has tried to repair Iran's pariah international image by tempering the revolutionary hostility toward the West, from where he hopes to attract investment and advanced technology. As a result, he has been under attack by a rival anti-Western radical camp, led by former Interior Minister Ali Akbar Mohtashemi and Ahmad Khomeini, son of the late revolutionary patriarch, Ayatollah Ruhollah Khomeini. The radicals fear relations with the West would compromise the ``neither East nor West'' principle laid down by Khomeini to preserve Iran's neutrality vis-a-vis the superpowers, and spell the end of the revolution. Ahmad, who holds no official position in the government but wields considerable influence as the late Khomeini's only surviving son, on Wednesday urged the government to clarify its policy toward the West. He referred to the ``existence of two trends of thought in the country,'' and said this ``confused the population.'' In an apparent attack on Rafsanjani's administration for what the radicals see as compromises with the West, Khomeini said: ``The point of compromise or no compromise must be defined.'' Rafsanjani's rivals have accused him of giving in to the West by gaining the release of two American hostages last month from their pro-Iranian captors. They also are unhappy that Iran settled a financial dispute in which Americans who lost property in Iran after the revolution would be compensated. Ninety liberal Iranians, who were instrumental in the revolution that toppled Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi and paved the way for the Islamic republic, have reportedly written to Rafsanjani demanding the restoration of constitutional rights and condemning the government for trampling civil liberties. The letter, signed among others by Mehdi Bazargan, the now-estranged leader who became the Islamic Republic's first prime minister in 1979, reportedly has accused the government of mismanaging the economy and isolating Iran internationally. The letter was obtained by the British Broadcasting Corp. in London. ``What you have produced for the poor are slogans and empty stomachs,'' the letter said. Without referring to the letter, Rafsanjani said today that ``the liberals'' and other groups opposing the government were ``politically bankrupt.''

DOC.HEAD: Prosecutor: Father in Boston Hears Daughter's Rape on the Telephone
DOC.TEXT: A Boston man talking on the telephone with his 18-year-old daughter in Santa Fe listened helplessly while she struggled with a rapist, a prosecutor said. ``The telephone was off the hook and the victim's father could hear her screams,'' Assistant District Attorney Jim Hall said during a bail hearing Wednesday. Neighbors also heard the victim's screams and called police, who arrested Andrew Sisneros, 27, of Santa Fe. Sisneros was indicted by a Santa Fe County grand jury Monday on two counts of rape and one count of kidnapping in the May 7 attack. Hall urged District Judge Joe Castellano to maintain Sisneros' bail at $250,000 because of the seriousness of the crime and because he might be indicted on similar charges in another case. Castellano raised Sisneros' bail to $300,000. Sisneros allegedly followed the woman inside her apartment, locked the door, turned up the music and attacked the woman, Hall said. The father, whose name was withheld to protect the identity of the victim, could not hang up and call authorities because his daughter's telephone was off the hook.

DOC.HEAD: Hand Grenade Explodes At Panamanian Party Headquarters
DOC.TEXT: Unidentified attackers threw a hand grenade at President Guillermo Endara's party headquarters early today, and the explosion caused minor damage to buildings in the area but no injuries, witnesses said. ``It was an irresponsible, terrorist action that we must condemn,'' said Francisco Artola, a legislator from the Arnulfista Party. Apparently, it was thrown from a white Toyota automobile. It caused minor damage.'' Residents in the area said they heard a loud explosion at 2:30 a.m. and the area downtown was quickly surrounded by police. The party building is next to the National Lottery and near the Cuban Embassy. Police said they had no immediate clues on the identity of the attackers. No group claimed responsibility.

DOC.HEAD: Bush to Host Leaders of Colombia, Haiti, Greece
DOC.TEXT: President Bush will host the presidents of Colombia and Haiti and the prime minister of Greece in upcoming meetings, the White House announced today. Bush will see Colombia's President Virgilio Barco on June 5 during Barco's visit to the United States for commencement ceremonies at the Massachussetts Insitute of Technology. Bush last saw Barco in Cartagena, Colombia, for the one-day anti-drug meeting in February that also included the presidents of Peru and Bolivia. On May 24, Bush meets with Haiti's President Ertha Troullot, who will also see members of Congress and international financial executives. The White House, in a statement from press secretary Marlin Fitzwater, noted Bush's emphasis on the importance of relations with the countries of the western hemisphere. On June 6, Greek Prime Minister Constantine Mitsotakis will visit the White House for a meeting and lunch with Bush.

DOC.HEAD: Most Charges Against Leona Helmsley Dropped
DOC.TEXT: Most of the charges of a state tax evasion indictment against self-styled hotel queen Leona Helmsley were dropped today. State Supreme Court Justice John Bradley said he was dropping 180 of 188 counts on grounds of double jeopardy. The dropped charges, he said, are essentially the same as those on which Mrs. Helmsley was tried and convicted in federal court last August. She was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million. She is appealing the conviction and sentence. ``I'm very happy,'' Mrs. Helmsley said tearfully as she left court after hearing Bradley's ruling. The eight charges that remain are offering a false instrument for filing, a felony. Each is punishable by up to four years in prison. Leslie Gersing, a spokeswoman for the state attorney general's office, said one of the eight charges relate to Mrs. Helmsley's personal taxes and the others involve Helmsley businesses. Gersing said prosecutors were studying the decision and had not decided whether to appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Floods Could Continue Until September, Official Says
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 13 grafs to UPDATE with storms threat abated in Liberty, guardsmen helping feed cattle in Oklahoma. Picks up 13th graf, `Others may...'
DOC.TEXT: Rain-swollen Lake Livingston has released enough water in the last three weeks to fill the Astrodome 1,200 times, and thousands of acres downstream could be flooded until September, officials said. But there was some good news. Thunderstorms that dumped 2{ inches of rain west of Houston dispersed before hitting the area northeast of Houston where the rain-swollen Trinity River has swamped several subdivisions. ``It looks like Liberty County escapes this line of thunderstorms today,'' National Weather Service meteorologist Scott Kiser said. With about 100,000 cubic feet of water being released each second from Lake Livingston Dam, however, ``we're more concerned about the water down here right now,'' said county dispatcher Lin Pruitt. Elsewhere, heavy rain caused flooding that drove residents from their apartments in two housing projects in East St. Louis, Ill., along the Mississippi River. Fifteen families' homes were flooded in Danville, in northeastern Illinois. Prison officials evacuated 270 women Wednesday night from the Renz Correctional Center on the rising Missouri River near Jefferson City, Mo. They were taken to two nearby prisons. The Mississippi was expected to hit flood-stage at St. Louis this weekend. Meanwhile, the Red River pushed deeper into central Louisiana today, threatening 700,000 acres of prime cropland. One farmer began the delicate process of moving his 4,000-head alligator herd, threatened with submersion in the rising waters of a bayou. At least 360 people in Louisiana have been forced from their homes. Flooding in recent weeks has killed 13 people in Texas and one in Oklahoma. Oklahoma Gov. Henry Bellmon dispatched a helicopter and three National Guardsmen to southeastern Oklahoma today to help get feed to more than 200 stranded head of cattle. About 7,000 people on about 200 square miles downstream of Lake Livingston have been advised to evacuate, but only about two dozen people had gone to shelters by this morning. ``They're being stubborn,'' said emergency volunteer Frances Thornton. ``They're afraid of looting and they don't want to leave their homes.'' Others may have sought refuge with friends. The subdivisions downstream are scattered in the woods, making it difficult to know how many people have left. The dam will be releasing 100,000 cubic feet per second for at least the next week, and at least 50,000 feet per second through June, said Sam Scott, executive service manager for the Trinity River Authority. Between April 27 and Wednesday, the dam had released about 556 billion gallons of water, enough to fill the Astrodome 1,200 times. The previous record flow is 75,000 cubic feet per second, in 1973, Scott said. The dam was built in 1969. Just 20,000 feet per second is enough to cause flooding, ``and we could be releasing that amount into September,'' Scott said. That's assuming minimal rain. ``If we got 5 or 8 inches it could be catastrophic, depending on how fast it fell and where it fell,'' Scott said. The Red River crested Tuesday evening at Shreveport, Louisiana's second biggest city, and was expected to crest Sunday at Alexandria. A giant levee system should protect the central Louisiana city, officials said. After flying by helicopter from Alexandria northwest to Shreveport, a distance of 127 miles, Gov. Buddy Roemer said he would ask for federal aid. Bayous and other tributaries were backing up, and farmers in the Natchitoches area, midway between Shreveport and Alexandria, were building makeshift levees to protect homes and recently planted corn, milo, wheat and soybeans. Skeet Rogers parked four farm wagons on a mound and prepared to move his 4,000 alligators there from their pens. His men will wear chain-mail gloves to move the gators, which are raised for their meat and skins, he said. ``The last time we got to fooling with them, one man got 47 stitches,'' he said. ``We can't get behind them with horses and drive them to high ground.''

DOC.HEAD: Sisters Win Abuse Lawsuit Against Father
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS one graf after 5th graf, `The women...' to explain differing statutes of limitations on criminal charges and civil judgment.
DOC.TEXT: The adult daughters of a child abuse expert were awarded $1.2 million each from a jury that found the former FBI agent and prosecutor had sexually abused and beaten them when they were growing up. Susan Hammond, 44, and her sister, Sharon Simone, 45, called their lawsuit ``a terrible act of love'' to make Edward Rodgers, 72, accountable for years of abuse. ``I feel really good that I've gone public with this,'' Hammond said after the verdict Wednesday. ``My father did shameful and horrible things to me and my brothers and sisters. I don't believe he is a shameful and horrible man, but he has to be held accountable.'' The women sued their father, a former FBI agent, chief investigator for the El Paso County, Colo., District Attorney's office and a nationally known child abuse expert, for abuses suffered from 1944 through 1965. Rodgers cannot be criminally charged because the statute of limitations in Colorado for sexual assault on children is 10 years. The limit for a civil lawsuit is two years, but jurors determined that the sisters became aware of the nature and extent of their injury only within the past two years, during therapy. Neither Rodgers nor his attorney was present during the trial, and the proceedings were conducted by the sisters' female lawyers before an all-female jury picked by the women's attorneys. In a deposition, Rodgers admitted that he hit his wife and may have hit his children, but said he didn't remember doing so. He said he had fought alcoholism for years. He described himself as a domineering person ``who demanded strict obedience from my children.'' ``I'm sure that I was harsh with them, but I don't know that it rose to the level of criminal abuse,'' he said. The lawsuit deeply divided the Rodgers family. Two other daughters testified on their sisters' behalf, but their three brothers questioned the degree of abuse suffered by their sisters. Rodgers recently fired his attorney, Thomas D. Gresham, who said this week that he has been unable to locate his client since April 24. The jury awarded each sister $600,000 for economic and non-economic damages and $600,000 for punitive damages. Simone, of Boston, and Hammond, of Southern California, say they are unable to have intimate sexual relationships with their husbands. The other sisters did not take part in the lawsuit. Hammond testified that her mother sent her to a Catholic school because she feared Rodgers might kill her and that Rodgers raped her when she returned home from the school at age 19. Simone testified that she was often spared beatings because she made a constant effort to please him.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Present Medals to Bush Son, Grandson
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has presented medals to President Bush's son, Jeb Bush, and grandson, George P. Bush, for helping victims of the December 1988 earthquate in Armenia, the White House announced today. Medals and certificates of appreciation were given to the two Bushes by Soviet Ambassador Yuri Dubinin at the White House earlier this week. Jeb Bush, 37, and George P. Bush, 14, were among the volunteers who accompanied a relief airlift to Armenia two weeks after the quake. The airlift brought 100,000 pounds of medicine, clothing and other supplies to earthquake victims. The certificates accompanying the medals voice gratitude for ``the sincere sympathy you extended to the Armenian people during their recent misfortunes.'' The Armenian people ``will never forget this demonstration of human charity,'' the certificates say.

DOC.HEAD: Strike Ends As Nicaragua, Labor Reach Agreement
LaserPhoto MGA3
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with end of strike, vacating of buildings, info on how government will pay for raises. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MGA3
DOC.TEXT: Pro-Sandinista strikers ended a walkout today that had crippled the new pro-American government, but the country's cash crisis deepened while Washington officials haggled over an aid package. Under the settlement signed Wednesday night, public employees' salaries are doubled and the government promises not to fire those who walked off the job. Government buildings occupied for a week were vacated by morning and the country's estimated 150,000 government employees employees were returning to work normally. The bus system was returning to normal, but slowly, and long lines formed at bus stops. The international airport, closed since Tuesday, reopened. The agreement was a victory for the Sandinista unions, which virtually shut down Managua and much of this Central American nation of 3.5 million residents since the walkout began Friday. It was also a victory for the leftist Sandinista Front, which President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro's 3-week-old government accused of a behind-the-scenes role in the strike. ``We hope this experience will serve the government of Senora Violeta to think over our demands,'' labor leader Lucio Jimenez told a news conference. ``The main achievement (of the strike) is that the government will be able to do nothing without the active participation of the workers.'' The government, which had declared the strike illegal Monday and threatened massive firings, backed off on practically all points in contention. Central Bank President Francisco Mayorga said the strike, which had been stepped up daily since May 10, cost the government $10 million in lost production and revenues. That is a loss Nicaragua's battered economy could hardly withstand, especially after President Bush on Wednesday said he could not legally provide $40 million in emergency aid Mrs. Chamorro requested. Bush also complained that ``procedural gridlock'' in Congress was holding up a $300 million Nicaraguan aid plan. For years, Congress funded the Contras rebels in their war with the ruling Sandinistas and much of the nation's economic woes stem from the fihgting. Mayorga said the government budget had planned for eventual raises similar to those granted, but that because of the strike they had to be granted sooner than planned. He said his government is counting on the generosity of the Conference of Donors, a group of industrialized, mostly European nations, who help Third-World countries. The group is to meet in Rome June 6-7, where Nicaragua will present a case for aid. Nicaraguan officials say they inherited an economy ravaged by years of Sandinista rule and U.S. economic sanctions, with only $3 million left in the treasury and an $11 billion foreign debt. The striking workers initially demanded a 200 percent pay raise to keep up with inflation, which is galloping along at an estimated 70 percent a month. But they settled for 100 percent after the government offered 120 percent. ``We did not want to be responsible for hyperinflation,'' Jimenez said when asked about accepting the lower percentage. Mayorga said the labor unrest represented ``the loss of two valuable weeks'' in moving Nicaragua toward a free-market economy and trying to turn it around. Mayorga has devaluated the cordoba, Nicaragua's currency, twice in the last three weeks, something that has sent prices for staples soaring. Nicaraguan public workers earn as little as $10 a month, and salaries of $30-$40 are very common. A secretary can earn $70 a month; a technician $140; a middle-level bank administrator $350. Salaries more than $500 a month in the public sector are rare.

DOC.HEAD: Shamir Granted 21-day Extension to Form Coalition Government
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 7 grafs to update with Shamir receiving 21-day extension; Pickup 7th, `Israel has...'
DOC.TEXT: President Chaim Herzog today granted Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir a 21-day extension on his mandate to form a new government. Shamir had asked for extra time because of disputes with potential partners over the distribution of Cabinet posts, Avi Pazner, a spokesman for Shamir, said today. The previous mandate expires on Friday. ``Shamir came to the president and asked for 21 days. He got 21 days,'' said Herzog's spokesman, Giora Pordes. Shamir, head of the right-wing Likud bloc, has tentative agreements that would give him a majority in parliament. But he has been unable to sign pacts with three ultra-right parties and three Orthodox religious factions. ``The problem is who gets what, '' Cabinet post, Pazner said. Pazner said the prime minister was optimistic he would be able to present a government to the 120-member Knesset, or parliament, by next week. Under Israeli law, a legislator entrusted by the president with forming a government is initially given three weeks, and then may ask for an additional three weeks. No president has ever rejected a request for an extension. Israel has been governed by Shamir's 13-member transition Cabinet since March 15, when the left-leaning Labor Party toppled the Likud-Labor coalition because Shamir refused to accept U.S. proposals for an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo. Herzog first asked Shimon Peres of the center-left Labor Party to try to form a government. But Peres failed after five weeks and was forced to hand the mandate to Shamir on April 26. At the time, Likud signed a coalition agreement with a four-member faction headed by Yitzhak Modai, a former finance minister. The faction had vacillated between the two rival camps for weeks. A second agreement was signed with Eliezer Mizrahi, a defector from the Agudat Israel ultra-Orthodox party which backs Labor. Mizrahi's move to Likud robbed Peres of the majority he needed to form a government. Shamir still needs to pin down formal pledges of backing from three religious parties and three ultra-rightist factions to assure himself of a 61-seat majority.

DOC.HEAD: Apollo Remains May Go To Smithsonian
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 4th graf, `The Apollo ...,' to CORRECT time element to late last month, sted this month.
DOC.TEXT: The charred Apollo capsule in which three astronauts died 23 years ago will be given to the Smithsonian Institution if museum officials want the spacecraft and agree not to display it, NASA said today. ``We're concerned it not turn into a sideshow of any kind,'' said John Lawrence, chief of congressional affairs for NASA's Office of Space Flight. ``Of course, the Smithsonian doesn't operate like that.'' Remnants of the 1967 Apollo fire _ America's first space tragedy _ were to have been buried without fanfare this month in an abandoned missile silo at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station. The more than 17,600 pounds of material would have been placed on top of debris from the nation's only other space disaster, the 1986 Challenger explosion. The Apollo capsule and investigative material had been stored at NASA's Langley Research Center in Hampton, Va., for 23 years; the space agency wanted to find a final resting place for it. Some of the items were moved late last month to Kennedy Space Center awaiting burial. Smithsonian officials indicated this month they were interested in some of the pieces after turning down offers from the National Aeronautics and Space Administration late last year and in 1985, Lawrence said. Derek Elliott, curator for the National Air and Space Museum, part of the Smithsonian, has said he is interested in obtaining the capsule as a historic artifact, not a display item. ``That's one reason why we'd want it. It's a historically significant artifact,'' said Dom Pisano, a museum curator and chairman of the collections committee that will decide the matter. Smithsonian officials have assured NASA a decision will be made within the next month. ``Our clock is ticking. We're anxious to resolve this one way or another,'' Lawrence said. Astronauts Virgil ``Gus'' Grissom, Roger B. Chaffee and Edward H. White II died Jan. 27, 1967, when fire engulfed the capsule during a countdown rehearsal for the first manned Apollo mission. The fire, in a cabin filled with 100 percent oxygen, was triggered by a spark when a broken or bruised wire beneath Grissom's couch contacted metal.

DOC.HEAD: University Developing 6-Legged Walking Robot For NASA
DOC.TEXT: A six-legged, 12-foot-tall walking robot designed for NASA to explore rugged terrain on Mars and the moon took its first steps at Carnegie Mellon University, the school announced today. ``The body is propelled in a motion similar to cross-country skiing,'' said William L. Whittaker, chief of the project. ``A single leg reaches out in front of the others, places itself firmly on the ground like a ski pole and then pulls the machine forward.'' The aluminum robot named the Ambler has two sets of stacked legs, with three legs per stack. Work began in 1987 and a prototype took its first strides recently at the school's field robotics center. The multiple-leg array allows the robot to remain level on uneven ground. The design provides a stable platform for sensors, scientific equipment and sample-taking tools. The Ambler is one project being evaluated under the Planetary Rover program of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. The program is developing robotic and manned technology to explore hard-to-reach lunar and planetary surfaces. ``The intent for the vehicles ... is for them to be capable of operating on their own with just a very general set of directions,'' said David B. Lavery, manager of the NASA program. ``Robots are not susceptible to temperature changes or radiation exposure on the long flights required to reach the planets,'' Whittaker said. ``They can spend protracted time on a mission that would be impossible for an astronaut.''

DOC.HEAD: EDITORS:
DOC.TEXT:
President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev meet May 31-June 3 against the backdrop of a changing world. The Soviet empire is breaking apart, in Eastern Europe and around the world. Even within the Soviet borders, democracy is showing its face. In a four-part series for Monday through Thursday, May 21-24, Associated Press writers look at the changes within the Soviet empire and the impact on the Western alliance. Each story runs about 900 words. The package will be illustrated by graphics. Monday's story will move today as b0454. The remaining three stories will move Friday.
Here is a brief description of the stories:
Monday
WASHINGTON _ Communism's collapse in Eastern Europe last year gave the North Atlantic Treaty Organization the victory for freedom and democracy it had sought for four decades. But it also stole NATO's main reason for being _ leading some analysts to question where the alliance is headed. Slug BC-Summit '90-NATO. By Robert Burns.
Tuesday
WASHINGTON _ From Africa to Latin America to Eastern Europe, the Soviet empire is crumbling. Soviet troops are out of Afghanistan, the Marxist-linked Sandinista regime in Nicaragua is toppled, and the governments of Ethiopia and Mozambique are veering away from hardline Marxist ideologies. The disintegration of the empire has taken Mikhail Gorbachev by surprise and dramatically altered his stance as he heads into his Washington summit with President Bush. Slug BC-Summit '90-Soviet Empire. By W. Dale Nelson.
For Wednesday
MOSCOW _ Radicals control city councils in Moscow and Leningrad. Protesters call the president a dictator _ to his face. Forty-five thousand people daily pass through McDonald's golden arches blocks from the Kremlin. ``The nation is quite different from what it was in the early 1980s,'' Mikhail Gorbachev told the Soviet Congress last September. Indeed it is. Slug BC-Summit '90-Soviet Democracy. By Andrew Katell.
For Thursday
MOSCOW _ From the Baltics to Siberia to the southernmost republics, the Soviet Union is being pulled apart by ethnic strife and economic self-interest. Inspired by Mikhail Gorbachev's policy of glasnost, or openness, everyone seems to want something. Many of the demands are mutually exclusive. Slug BC-Summit '90-Soviet Disunion. By Mark J. Porubcansky
The AP

DOC.HEAD: Nothing Left to Chance When Emperor Leaves Palace
DOC.TEXT: When the emperor of Japan leaves his palace in Tokyo, nothing is left to chance. Determined to eliminate the element of surprise, officials in this scenic coastal city on the southern island of Kyushu have slaved for months over preparations for the arrival Friday of Emperor Akihito and Empress Michiko. Officials are particularly nervous because the emperor is to meet Mayor Hitoshi Motoshima, who was shot in the back by a rightist in January. The attacker was angry at Motoshima for saying the late Emperor Hirohito, Akihito's father, bore some responsibility for World War II. About 4,000 police officers were being mobilized to ensure the monarch's safety. Highlighting the emperor's four-day stay will be a visit to an atomic bomb memorial at Peace Park, and the 41st annual Arbor Day Festival on Sunday. The emperor, who is to plant a tree and give a short address, is scheduled to spend less than an hour at the festival, but officials reportedly are spending $50,000 to deodorize a nearby pig farm. They also are planning to hang a curtain to keep the farm out of the royal couple's sight, and have told media hoping to cover the event by helicopter not to create any ruckus that might disturb the animals. ``Sure, if the wind is right it could smell pretty bad at the festival,'' said Yoichi Tanaka, head of general affairs for the Nagasaki Prefectural Trade Union. ``But it's a pig farm, after all, and there really isn't any need to try to hide that.'' The strengthened police presence prompted a local newspaper, the Nagasaki Shimbun, to complain in an editorial Thursday that ``excessive security'' could dampen ``the Nagasaki people's natural desire to welcome their emperor.'' The editorial, however, acknowledged the need for tight security wherever the emperor goes. Leftist radicals strongly oppose the monarchy and often have used violence to gain publicity for their views. The same month that Motoshima was shot, leftists claimed responsibility for firing projectiles that slightly damaged the Tokyo home of the emperor's younger brother, Prince Hitachi. Public opinion polls indicate the overwhelming majority of Japanese support the monarchy, but there also are painful memories of World War II, when the emperor's name was used to inspire Japan's troops. After the war, Hirohito, whom the Japanese now call Emperor Showa, visited all of Japan's prefectures except Okinawa, a string of southern islands where some of the war's bloodiest battles were fought and where ill feelings toward Tokyo still linger. Radicals broke through security and hurled firebombs at Akihito and Michiko when they visited Okinawa in 1975. Akihito, then crown prince, and his wife narrowly escaped injury.

DOC.HEAD: Tribal Custom Banned to Help Prevent AIDS
DOC.TEXT: Tribal chiefs worried about the spread of AIDS have banned the ancient custom of widows and widowers having sex with a relative of their late spouse to ``cleanse'' themselves. Chiefs in Chikankata and Monze districts, about 80 miles south of Lusaka, ordered a halt to the practice after AIDS educators visited, a health ministry spokesman said Thursday. Under the custom, a widow would have sex with one of her husband's brothers, and a widower would arrange a sexual encounter with one of his late wife's relatives. The tradition contributed to the spread of AIDS, ``especially, of course, if a spouse died from AIDS,'' said the spokesman, who was not identified in keeping with standing practice. In Africa, AIDS is mainly spread by heterosexual contact and the use of contaminated blood or medical equipment. The problem is aggravated by poor health services in isolated areas. Acquired immune deficiency syndrome is caused by a virus that damages the body's immune system, leaving victims susceptible to infections and cancer. Zambia has one of the world's highest AIDS rates. Up to 20 percent of the population of 7.5 million people is believed infected with the virus that causes the disease. In March, the government told the World Health Organization that Zambia had 2,417 cases of AIDS.

DOC.HEAD: Former Congressman Says His Directions Led To Cabinet Post
DOC.TEXT: Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski told former House colleagues Thursday that pointing the way to a restroom could lead to a Cabinet post, just as it did for him. During an awards ceremony on the House floor, the former Illinois congressman described how 22 years ago, he ran into a ``freshman Republican congressman by the name of George Bush.'' ``I didn't know him, he didn't know me,'' Derwinski said. ``But he said, `By the way, where's the men's room?' '' Derwinski pointed the way, and Bush ``was forever grateful for that help.'' ``That's how you get to the Cabinet, fellows,'' said Derwinski, whose buttercup yellow blazer stood out in sharp contrast to a sea of blues, grays and pinstripes. Derwinski, who became the first veterans secretary when the Veterans Administration achieved Cabinet status last year, was given the distinguished service award from the Association of Former Members of Congress. Derwinski was introduced by former Rep. Abner J. Mikva, a fellow Illinoisian who is now a federal judge. Mikva mentioned Derwinski's ``skills, talents and color.'' Among those attending the ceremony were former House speakers Thomas P. ``Tip'' O'Neill of Massachusetts and Jim Wright of Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Ancient Fossil Missing Link in Ancestors of Mammals
DOC.TEXT: A long-misclassified fossil of a 280 million-year-old animal with three pairs of horns on its head is a missing link in the family tree of the ancient reptiles that were ancestors of the mammals, according to a report today. Researchers believe the creature, known as tetraceratops, represents an evolutionary step between the older, reptile-like animals called the pelycosaurs and the later therapsids that were forerunners of the mammals. The fossil skull was discovered around the turn of the century in Texas, but its evolutionary significance was not recognized because it was surrounded in rock that was hard to remove. The discovery of its place in evolution was made by Michel Laurin and Robert R. Reisz of the University of Toronto. They reported their work in the British journal Nature. ``As the most primitive known therapsid,'' they wrote, ``tetraceratops bridges the large morphological gap between primitive and advanced mammal-like reptiles.'' They based their analysis largely on the shape of the bones and teeth of the fossilized head. It combined primitive features of the pelycosaurs as well as hints of the more modern therapsids that came after them. Since only the creature's head was recovered, the scientists did not speculate about the size or shape of its body. The animals lived before the rise of the dinosaurs, which ruled the planet during the Mesozoic era, which began 225 million years ago. The first mammals were tiny, shrew-like animals that lived during the Jurassic period between 180 million and 130 million years ago.

DOC.HEAD: Prince Visits Capital For Environmental Events
DOC.TEXT: Britain's Prince Philip arrived in Washington Thursday for a three-day round of events connected with environmental causes. The queen's consort is president of the World Wide Fund for Nature International. He will visit President Bush at the White House on Friday, then deliver a luncheon speech on ``Perception and Belief'' at the National Press Club. The speech will be followed by a question-and-answer session with reporters. On the first day of his trip to the United States, the prince's schedule called for him to attend a board meeting of the World Wide Fund and a private dinner organized by the group. He will take part in a seminar on ``Conserving our Heritage'' at the Washington National Cathedral on Saturday, visit an ecology fair on the cathedral grounds and plant a tree using a spade used by the Prince of Wales in 1919 for a similar purpose. The visit ends Sunday when Prince Philip flies back to London.

DOC.HEAD: Wildfire Burns 10,000 Acres of Everglades
DOC.TEXT: A wildfire apparently sparked by a burning barn has scorched 10,000 acres of tinder-dry sawgrass in the Everglades, officials said Thursday. ``It's dry out there. It's like a tinderbox,'' said Peter Burke, spokesman for the state Division of Forestry, blaming Florida's 20-month-long drought for the rapid spread of the flames near the Dade-Broward county line. He said the fire broke out Wednesday and grew to 10,000 acres by Thursday morning. Gusts up to 20 mph complicated fightfighting efforts. Eight state firefighters were at the site Thursday, and crews planned to set backfires along canals to deprive the fire of fuel and prevent it from jumping the waterways, said Burke. There are no structures threatened in the uninhabited area, but a fishing camp was briefly evacuated Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Former Prime Minister Improving From Pneumonia
DOC.TEXT: Former Prime Minister Menachem Begin showed a ``marked improvement'' Thursday after being hospitalized and diagnosed as suffering from pneumonia, officials said. Dr. Motti Lifshitz, deputy director of Shaarei Tzedek Hospital in Jerusalem, said he hoped Begin would be released soon. ``Taking the general condition of the patient as an indicator of improvement ... there is a marked improvement,'' Lifshitz said on Israel army radio. Begin, 76, who won a Nobel Peace Prize for his role in making peace with Egypt, was brought to Shaarei Tzedek on Wednesday by ambulance after complaining of weakness. Begin slept through the night after undergoing tests, hospital spokeswoman Orna Cohen said. ``Everything is under control. It was recommended that he rest a little, and he is receiving antibiotics,'' Mrs. Cohen said. Begin's daughters, Hasia and Leah, and one of his granddaughters have been staying with him since he arrived at the hospital, the spokeswoman said. Begin's son, Benjamin, a member of parliament representing the right-wing Likud party which his father founded, is overseas. Yehiel Kadishai, a Begin aide who visited the former premier Thursday, said Begin read newspapers, focusing on reports about the difficulties faced by Likud in forming Israel's next government. ``He said `Let's hope it will be all right' but did not give any advice,'' Kadishai said. Begin has not received other visitors following the doctors' recommendation that he rest, and two private guards are posted outside his room, Mrs. Cohen said. Begin, who became prime minister in 1977, abruptly resigned in September 1983 and has since lived in seclusion in Jerusalem. Aides said at the time of his resignation that Begin was depressed over the death of his wife, Aliza, and over Israel's unsuccessful war in Lebanon. While serving as prime minister, Begin suffered several heart attacks. In 1986, he underwent prostate surgery. He was briefly hospitalized in 1987 and in 1989 after complaining of weakness.

DOC.HEAD: Floodwaters Threaten Alligator Farm
With AM-Floods, Bjt
LaserPhoto pursuing
DOC.TEXT: Walter ``Skeet'' Rogers put on metal gloves, grabbed a 3-foot-long alligator and slung it into a cotton wagon, moving it to high ground before flood waters got it. ``The last time we got to fooling with them, one man got 47 stitches,'' Rogers said, explaining the gloves. Rogers' 4,000 alligators were hatched from eggs gathered from wild nests and raised in double-decked ponds in four climate-controlled cinder-block buildings. Two more buildings are under construction at his Bayou Pierre Gator Farm, located on low land near the bayou for which it is named. About 200 square miles of Louisiana is flooded by water from the Red River and backwaters such as Bayou Pierre. Most of the land in a sparsely settled section of the state is for farming cotton, wheat, soybeans. Rogers' crop is different, though no less threatened. ``It's awful. The water keeps coming up,'' said Alice Hart, Rogers' mother. ``I've been right here for 12 years, and nothing like this has ever happened before. ``They'll drown. Skeet sold off some of the big ones, but the rest will just drown, if it keeps coming up.'' With hides bringing $35 a linear foot and demand for alligator meat high, alligator farming is a burgeoning industry in an economically depressed state. Louisiana has 92 licensed gator farms. Two-dozen license applications are pending. Three years ago, there were 13 alligator farms in Louisiana. Buddy Goatcher, an alligator biologist with the state Department of Wildlife and Fisheries, said it is possible gators could be drowned if trapped in deep water for a long time with no firm resting place. ``The farmer can't predict how long the waters will be up,'' Goatcher said. ``And you can't predict the force of the water. It could knock down the building and send gators spewing all over the place.'' ``The threat is not so much to the well-being of the gators. They'd love it,'' he said. ``The threat is losing the farm.'' Along with the buildings and the concrete ponds, special heaters are necessary to keep it warm enough for a good hatching rate and optimum growth. ``He doesn't want a lot of cold water coming in,'' Goatcher said. Rogers and two helpers, Roy Cheatwood and his son, Roy Jr., piled homemade sandbags around pumps, heaters and other immovable equipment, trying to protect them from the flood. The alligators were packed into four cotton wagons parked on a nearby mound. Each gator had to be moved by hand. ``We can't get behind them with horses and drive them to high ground,'' Rogers said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Will Reject Any Civil Rights Bill with Hiring Quotas
DOC.NOTE: EDs: INSERTS grafs 5-6, On Capitol Hill ..., to UPDATE with move by bill's supporters to meet White House objections; ADDS 3 grafs, bgng, The key ... to provide details.
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said today that civil rights laws ``should not be turned into some lawyers' bonanza'' and he will reject any legislation that he believes will result in hiring quotas. ``I want to sign a civil rights bill but I will not sign a quota bill,'' Bush told a Rose Garden audience in a ceremony to honor the newly reconstituted President's Commission on Civil Rights. The Justice Department has raised the possibility that Bush would veto civil rights legislation pending in Congress. The department contends it would establish unconsitutional minority quotas. Many Republicans have joined Democrats and the chairman of Bush's civil rights commission in contending it does not require quotas. Bush's press secretary, Marlin Fitzwater, earlier stopped short of saying the administration would veto the legislation. ``We are not repeating'' the veto threat, he said this week. On Capitol Hill, Senate supporters of the bill softened it somewhat today and immediately drew fresh support from two Republicans and six Democrats, bringing the total cosponsors to 47 in the 100-member Senate. ``There are several others who are very close and I think there are others who will be coming on board,'' Sen. John C. Danforth, R-Mo., said as he and Sen. John Heinz, R-Pa., added their names as cosponsors. Bush said today his goal is to make sure that ``affirmative action is not reduced to some empty slogan and that this principle of striking down all barriers to advancement has real, living meaning to all Americans.'' ``We will leave nothing to chance and no stone unturned as we work to advance America's civil rights agenda,'' he said to applause from the audience that included many civil rights leaders. ``This administration seeks equal opportunity and equal protection and equal protection under the law for all Americans,'' Bush said. He said he would ``enthusiastically support legislation'' that backs up the principles of removing employment barriers based on race, religion, sex, color or national origin; does not result in quota systems; promotes fairness in the legal system; and protection against harassment based on race, sex, religion or physical disability. ``Our civil rights laws, however, should not be turned into some lawyers' bonanza'' that could result from complaints of discrimination under the law, he said. Bush's remarks followed a series of meetings with civil rights leaders on the so-called Kennedy-Hawkins legislation, which is still awaiting final action in both the House and Senate. Although it does not call for quotas of minority applicants, critics contend that would be its result. The legislation would undo a Supreme Court decision that narrowed the ability of minorities to win monetary damages for job discrimnation, and would restore the burden of proof to defendants in cases where employers' hiring practices allegedly had a discriminatory impact. ``No one here today would want me to sign a bill whose unintended consequences are quotas. Because quotas are wrong and they violate the most basic principles of our civil rights tradition and the basic principles of the promise of democracy,'' Bush said. The key change made by senators today would alter a provision of the bill designed to undo the Supreme Court's 1989 Wards Cove decision, involving a fair-hiring case at an Alaskan salmon cannery. Under the decision, employers named in fair-hiring lawsuits must either end lopsided hiring practices or prove that they represent business necessity. As the bill initially went into the hopper, employers would have to prove that discrimination was ``essential'' to job performance. The new version would require only proof that such practices had a ``substantial and demonstrable relationship to effective job performance.''

DOC.HEAD: Court Says Missouri River Flow Should Not be Reduced
DOC.TEXT: An appeals court panel today upheld the power of the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers to regulate the flow of water from a 232-mile-long Missouri River reservoir. The three-judge panel overruled a district court decision that had ordered the corps last week to temporarily reduce by about one-third the discharge from the Oahe reservoir. The upper Missouri River basin states of South Dakota, North Dakota and Montana brought the suit in an effort to protect their sport fishing industry, which officials say is being decimated by the low river levels. The case has created controversy among seven Midwestern states. The downstream states of Nebraska, Iowa, Kansas and Missouri are aligned with the corps. The panel, which heard arguments in the case Wednesday, said it announced a decision today because of the urgency of the issue. It said it would release a formal opinion later. On Friday, the panel issued an emergency stay blocking the lower court order. Today, the panel said the district court erred in concluding that the corps was arbitrary and capricious in making its decision about water flow. The corps appealed the ruling issued last Wednesday by U.S. District Judge Patrick Comny in Bismarck, N.D., that the level of Lake Oahe be maintained until June 1, when the walleye hatch is completed. John Stahr, a Justice Department trial attorney representing the corps, said it was acutely aware of the harm to the tourism industry caused by drought in the area. However, to reduce the Oahe discharges by one-third would mean halting barge traffic between Sioux City, Iowa, and St. Louis, a 730-mile shipping channel, because the river level would be too low, Stahr said. Former Gov. William Janklow of South Dakota, a lawyer representing the Dakotas and Montana, argued that a temporary disruption in barge traffic must be balanced against the viability of the economy of central South Dakota, which relies heavily on Missouri River tourism. Lake Oahe stretches north from a dam just north of Pierre, S.D., to just south of Bismarck.

DOC.HEAD: Religious Broadcasters, Churches Cautioned About Mail Bombs
DOC.TEXT: Federal officials have warned religious broadcasters and churches around the country to screen mail because of last month's explosion of a package addressed to evangelist Pat Robertson. Cedric W. Lawrence Jr. of the U.S. Postal Inspection Service in Richmond said he sent letters to 185 religious broadcasters and groups, including such figures as the Revs. Billy Graham and Jerry Falwell. Thomas Love, an FBI agent in Norfolk, said the bureau notified all its offices after the bombing at Robertson's Christian Broadcasting Network headquarters. ``Individually, some of those offices have contacted churches to alert them to the information,'' Love said. On April 27, a bomb in small package exploded in the CBN mailroom in Virginia Beach after it was identified as suspicious and a guard attempted to open it. Scott Scheeper, 33, was hit in the leg by several pieces of shrapnel and was hospitalized for several days. The package was addressed to Robertson, founder and president of CBN and an unsuccessful candidate for the 1988 Republican presidential nomination. On Jan. 30, a mail bomb exploded at the church of the Rev. John Osteen in Houston. Osteen's daughter was slightly injured when she opened a shoebox-sized package. Both packages were mailed from small towns in Bladen County, N.C., investigators said. Postal inspectors have released two similar composite drawings of men suspected of mailing the packages. Robertson said the bombings ``could be part of pattern of attacks against evangelical Christians.'' Robertson also mentioned an April 17 arson at the offices of gospel singer Sandi Patti in Anderson, Ind. Ms. Patti and a fire department investigator said there were no indications of any connection between the arson and the bombings. The fire caused $650,000 in damage. An anonymous phone caller told a newspaper that a group called the Equal Religious Coalition started the fire because ``anyone who sells God or religion'' should be attacked. ``We have not yet identified that that organization does exist. Nor can we find any hint of a home base for that organization,'' said Terry King, the Anderson Fire Department's chief of investigation. ``Experts from the East Coast to the West Coast haven't heard of them.'' Television evangelists said they have been the target of hate mail in the past. ``We always have threats _ as many as eight or nine a month several years ago, but it's slowed down in the last few months,'' Robertson said. Mark DeMoss, a spokesman for Lynchburg-based Falwell, said the ``Old-Time Gospel Hour'' pastor also receives threats, but ``there have been years where we would receive more threats than we do today.'' Others haven't talked about threats. ``It really hadn't been discussed or even mentioned up until the bombing at CBN,'' said the Rev. Brandt Gustavson, president of the 825-member National Religious Broadcasters. ``We have supplied some names and addresses of our members to the postal inspectors.'' Osteen's Lakewood Church in Houston is taking added precautions. ``The only thing that we have done any different is that the U.S. marshal's office is scanning our mail on daily basis,'' said Renee Branson, a church spokeswoman. ``The post office takes our mail to the marshals who scan it before it is taken to the local post office for delivery to us. It takes a day or so longer, but nobody seems to mind.'' At CBN, spokeswoman Frankie Abourjilie said, ``After talking with postal inspectors it was obvious our system worked.'' But, she added, ``we're tightening things up.''

DOC.HEAD: Organizers Say Plans For Radio Ship Postponed Indefinitely
DOC.TEXT: Plans to beam pro-democracy messages to China from a radio ship have been postponed indefinitely, an organizer said Thursday, because Taiwan refused to allow a powerful transmitter through customs. ``We are anti-Communist but we cannot violate international law,'' government spokesman Shaw Yu-ming said. ``This government does not support the broadcasting plans and we cannot help them install the transmitters.'' Without the transmitter sent from France, it would be impossible to proceed with the broadcasts, said Christophe Nick, an organizer of the Goddess of Democracy ship. Nick refused to blame Taiwan, but Shaw said customs would not approve the transmitter. Although Taiwan's ruling Nationalist Party is the sworn enemy of the Beijing government, tensions between the two sides have eased in recent years and Taiwan wants to avoid angering Beijing. China has accused Taiwan of secretly helping the Goddess of Democracy and has refused to rule out the use of force to stop the broadcasts. The Nationalist government has denied involvement in the project and has said it opposed unauthorized broadcasts from international waters. The 1,200-ton vessel, which left France on March 17, arrived in the northern port of Keelung on Sunday to take on provisions before sailing into international waters to broadcast toward Communist China. Organizers originally planned to leave Keelung Thursday and begin broadcasts the following day. But the customs difficulties appear to have stymied the project. Organizers had hoped the Taiwanese government would look more favorably on the project, sponsored by a coalition of press organizations headed by the French magazine Actuel. ``The association will never stop trying to broadcast,'' Nick said. ``Never, never, never.'' The ship is named after the statue erected by demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing in May 1989. It was destroyed during the June 4 military crackdown that left hundreds, perhaps thousands, of civilians dead.

DOC.HEAD: Family, Friends Testify on Behalf of Panamanian
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 6 grafs to UPDATE with morning testimony. Picks up 6th graf, `Lakas reportedly...'
DOC.TEXT: A former Panamanian president says his son shouldn't be on trial for threatening to kill President Bush because ``that's the way we express ourselves'' in Panama. Demetrio B. Lakas, president of Panama from 1972-78, told jurors Wednesday that death threats are a way of life in the country where he lives and where his son, Otto Lakas, was born. ``My life was threatened thousands of times,'' the elder Lakas said. ``That's the way we express ourselves. Saying it and doing it are two different things.'' Otto Lakas is accused of making the threat in a discussion with the managers of a pawnshop where he was looking at a gun. In the U.S. District Court trial's second day today, family and friends continued testifying about the non-aggressive nature of Lakas, a 21-year-old architecture student at Lubbock Christian University. ``When Otto sees pain in others, he assumes the pain,'' his mother, Elizabeth Lakas said. ``I am very proud to have him for my son.'' Lakas reportedly said he had ``a bullet with Bush's name engraved on it,'' and if the president came to Lubbock he was ``going to blow his (expletive) head off.'' Family and friends have characterized the statements as a joke. But Secret Service agents took Lakas at his word and have jailed him without bond since April 17. If convicted, he faces a 5-year prison term or a $250,000 fine, or both. Lakas' attorney, Tommy Turner, told jury members the government would be unable to prove Lakas ``understood and meant'' what he was saying or that he ``knowingly and willfully intended to be taken seriously.'' Prosecutor Paulina Jacobo would not comment about what the government could prove. Stacy and Tracy Nichols, twin brothers who manage their parents' Exect Pawn Shop, said they talked to Otto Lakas on April 4 for almost three hours while Lakas considered buying a .357 Colt revolver. Stacy Nichols said Lakas told him he wanted the gun for protection. While discussing ``everything that 21-year-olds talk about,'' Stacy Nichols said Lakas voiced anger about the December invasion of Panama by U.S. troops. ``I have a .223-caliber rifle at home and a bullet with Bush's name engraved on it,'' Nichols quoted Lakas as saying in a Secret Service affidavit. Stacy Nichols said in an April 17 Secret Service affidavit that he was afraid to report Lakas' statements to authorities because he was ``afraid that Otto Lakas will retaliate.'' But Nichols testified Wednesday that Lakas' alleged threats were the only serious part of a three-hour conversation filled with jokes. Nichols said he liked Lakas and was never concerned for his own safety while Lakas was in the pawnshop. Despite the threats, Nichols said, he would have sold the revolver to Lakas if Lakas had produced the money. Nichols said the incident would never have been reported if they hadn't told a friend who is a police officer about the conversation. The officer told a Secret Service agent, John Steven Barker. Barker said a search of Lakas' apartment produced a .30-.30 caliber rifle. A box of bullets also was found, but none was engraved with Bush's name, Barker said.

DOC.HEAD: Mine Closure Following Racial Clash That Killed Two
DOC.TEXT: The country's largest mining company shut down part of a gold mine Thursday following a racial clash that left two whites dead and several blacks injured. The victims were among 12 people killed in nationwide violence Wednesday, police said Thursday. Heavily armed police and mine security officials for the Anglo-American Corp. sealed off part of the President Steyn gold mine near the central city of Welkom following Wednesday's fighting. Blacks attacked whites at the gold mine after security guards fired on black protesters with rubber bullets, wounding at least eight blacks. Two whites were killed and four hurt by the black workers, who were protesting the dismissal of 30 miners. Anglo-American, a huge mining conglomerate, said one mine shaft was closed because of the tense atmosphere and some 4,000 workers were sent home. Other shafts on the mine compound remained open. Welkom, 170 miles south of Johannesburg, has been the scene of repeated confrontations between blacks and right-wing whites in recent weeks. The neo-Nazi Afrikaner Resistance Movement said white miners should be allowed to take weapons underground to protect themselves. The said the current tension could only be defused through ``strong action by the government and its security forces.'' About 100 white right-wingers armed with shotguns, pistols, whips and knives demonstrated Wednesday night in Welkom to protest the deaths of the two whites. Right-wing leader Blikkies Blignaut, said, ``If we don't get joy, we will start action as a resistance movement and there will be hell on Earth.'' Extreme white right-wingers have formed paramilitary groups to ``control'' blacks in Welkom. Blacks, meanwhile, have boycotted white-owned businesses for almost two weeks. White and black leaders fear the growing threat of violence by extreme right-wingers could hamper political reform efforts. President F.W. de Klerk wants to negotiate a new constitution with black opposition groups, but he faces a growing backlash from conservative whites. In violence elsewhere: _Two black adults and two black girls were burned to death when their shack was set alight as they slept Wednesday night, police said. A man was arrested, but police said they had not determined a motive for the attack near the central city of Kroonstad. _A leader of the Inkatha political movement, Jerome Mncwabe, was gunned down Wednesday night at his home near Pietermaritzburg in Natal Province, police said. Inkatha, a conservative Zulu movement, has been fighting with militant black groups in Natal. _A white security guard was killed at a construction site near Durban when a group of blacks opened fire with pistols, police said. Another guard drove off the attackers with pistol fire, they said. _Four blacks were killed in other incidents, apparently clashes between rival black factions, but police gave no details. Hundreds of people have died in recent months in fighting between rival black factions.

DOC.HEAD: House Youth Service Bill Praised
DOC.TEXT: Community and state leaders voiced support Thursday for a youth service bill. ``Youth service tells young people they are needed, appeals to their desire to participate and gives them an opportunity to make a difference,'' said David Liederman, executive director of the Child Welfare League of America Inc. The support boosts efforts of the House Education and Labor Committee, which is preparing to consider legislation that puts it at odds with a Senate-passed bill tying youth community work with student financial aid. ``Our agencies are in complete agreement with you that service should be entirely voluntary and non-participation should not disqualify young Americans from any existing educational loans, grants or opportunities,'' Liederman said. The House bill would authorize $35 million for school-based programs that make community service an important element of learning; $25 million in grants to institutions of higher education to create or expand service opportunities for their students; $30 million to fund demonstration programs targeted to school dropouts and rural youth; and $93 million to establish three specific youth oriented demonstration programs. Liederman, who said his group is the oldest and largest membership organization of child and youth serving agencies with more than 650 members throughout North America, was among a host of community and state leaders who urged quick passage of the National Service Act of 1990 during the final hearing on the bill. The Senate passed its version in early March. Chairman Augustus Hawkins, D-Calif., said the House committee probably would consider the legislation before July and hoped floor action would follow soon after. The House measure rejects any link between service and student financial assistance. Hawkins said the House version was ``intended to build upon worthwhile local and state efforts and to enhance their potential for addressing unmet social needs.'' Liederman said the range of programs created by the bill should attract and make services available to every type of young person. The program, he said, shifts youths from being clients to ``community resources.'' ``Our youth are not unwilling to serve,'' said John Buchanan Jr., a former congressman who is chairman of People For the American Way Action Fund, a liberal group. ``The underlying principle of the National Service Act rightly assumes that American young people will embrace community service if the opportunities are presented to them. Involvement in service activities enables young people _ whether poor or affluent, residents of the inner cities or suburbs, achievers or at-risk children _ to realize that they have much to give to their community.'' Brian Holloway of the New York State Division for Youth said ``structured, dynamic programs'' were needed to ``expose youth to meaningful and practical experience, responsibility, participation, membership, through community service in schools and on a full-time basis.''

DOC.HEAD: Janet Jackson's Rhythm Nation Tour Strikes Chord in Japan
DOC.TEXT: Janet Jackson paraded her Rhythm Nation tour through Tokyo Dome on Thursday night, her thunderous waves of funk and choreography inspiring about 50,000 people to clap in unison and dance in their assigned seats. Teen-agers in miniskirts, families with children and men in business suits rose as one when the American pop star, silhouetted in colored smoke, was lifted to the massive stage on a platform and launched into ``Control.'' ``Want to get nasty?'' she yelled with two female and four male dancers behind her in various stages of undress as she strutted and rapped her way through ``Nasty.'' Fans roared politely in approval. It was the opening for Miss Jackson's five-night appearance in Japan on her first world tour. She travels next to the Japanese cities of Osaka and Yokohama, back to the United States and then on to Europe in September. The energy and enthusiasm of Miss Jackson and her 15-member troupe managed to punch through the cavernous expanse of Tokyo Dome, an indoor baseball stadium nicknamed the Big Egg.
