But fans in the middle and upper reaches had to depend on giant video screens showing the action far below, and the sound was out of sync with the action because it took so long to travel to their ears. Fiery explosions heralded ``The Knowledge,'' and the crowd shouted along with Miss Jackson and the onstage marquee lights as she chanted: ``Ignorance, no. Bigotry, no. Illiteracy, no.'' Dave Barry's searing guitar solo highlighted ``Black Cat,'' and Miss Jackson danced and sang atop the stage's second level as explosions and red and orange spotlights cut through the smoke. The sounds and flashes of a summer thunderstorm opened ``Come Back to Me,'' which allowed the sultry rock star to show a reflective, wistful side. She donned a paramilitary uniform with medals and billed hat _ a getup mimicked by many of her fans _ to close the show with ``Rhythm Nation,'' a song popularized by its use since January in Japan Airlines commercials.The choreography, a cross between break-dancing and military maneuvers, sent some spectators dancing into the aisles.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Cries `Uncle;' Cameras Back in Oval Office
DOC.TEXT: The White House press office dropped an experimental limit on cameras Thursday and the networks were back in the Oval Office covering President Bush. They gathered in full force to cover the outset of Bush's meeting with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl. ``Look who's back. Welcome back, gang,'' Bush said as the cameras rolled and a dozen boom microphones stretched for his every word. ``It's been very lonely without you fellows.'' The four networks boycotted coverage of two White House events Wednesday in protest of the experimental restrictions, first tried Monday. ``You win. I cave,'' White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater told reporters at another event. Fitzwater complained Wednesday that the networks were operating by ``horse-and-buggy rules'' in an era with space-age camera technology. George Watson, ABC-TV's Washington bureau chief, said he was ``pleasantly surprised'' at the about-face. The network chiefs still want a meeting with Fitzwater to discuss ``whatever problems concern him,'' Watson said. ``We have no interest in bopping people on the head with microphones or scratching antiques. We do want to maintain as much competition as we can at the White House,'' Watson said. A Fitzwater aide, John Herrick, said the networks mounted their protest so quickly, ``we felt it wasn't worth fighting them.'' ``For the time being we are reverting to the standard pool coverage,'' said Herrick, who arranges many of the news pools. The networks _ CBS, ABC, NBC and CNN _ skipped two Bush meetings with groups lobbying on a civil rights bill Wednesday. Earlier, they went along with the limited, two-camera pool coverage of other Bush meetings, including the start of the budget summit with congressional leaders Tuesday. Fitzwater argued that the networks and independent television stations alike could get more and better pictures if only two pool cameras were sent into the Oval Office and other parts of the White House with limited space. There is only one camera in the tight travel pool of reporters and crew members who accompany the president whenever he leaves the White House, including flights aboard Air Force One. Radio networks, in a gesture of sympathy, also declined to send in a reporter to cover the two Bush meetings Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Army Officer Knocked Unconscious by Deer During Exercise
DOC.TEXT: A company commander leading 400 soldiers on a conditioning run collided with a deer and was knocked unconscious, authorities said Thursday. Capt. Ian Erickson didn't know what hit him May 7 until he regained consciousness inside an Army ambulance and tasted deer fur in his mouth, said Capt. Pauline Geraci, a public affairs spokeswoman. ``He said the deer came crashing out of the woods _ just leaped at him,'' Ms. Geraci said. Other soldiers ``said it sort of sideswiped him and tumbled with him and then got up and ran off.'' Ericson was left with chipped teeth, smashed glasses, whiplash-like pain and a gash in the back of his head that required stitches, the spokeswoman said. He has returned to his base at Fort Clayton, Panama, she said.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Surges, But Good News Seen in Export Boost
DOC.TEXT: Record exports helped keep the U.S. trade deficit in March below its 1989 monthly average, the government reported Thursday, and analysts said the gap could narrow to less than $100 billion this year for the first time since 1983. The Commerce Department said the March deficit totaled $8.45 billion, down from the $9 billion monthly gap last year but a sharp 38.5 percent increase over February. The jump resulted in part from a 10 percent increase in imports to $41.72 billion, their highest level in five months. But economists said the advance was a rebound from an 8.1 percent decline in imports in February, which they called an aberration. The department said exports totaled $33.28 billion in March, up 4.6 percent from February and breaking the previous record of $31.9 billion set last January. The deficit is the difference between imports and exports. The economists called the increase in exports a bright sign for the overall economy. ``If they stay up, there's just almost no way we can have a recession,'' said Bruce Steinberg, senior economist with Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York, who forecasts a deficit of $95 billion or less this year. ``It's absolutely what we need for our economy to prosper.'' Rising exports mean a stronger economy because more jobs and profits are created as American factories produce more. That produces more taxes and helps close the gap between what the government receives and what it spends. But with rising imports, as reported for March, lead to a decline in U.S. production and a loss in jobs as Americans spend more on products made overseas. Howard Lewis, vice president of the National Association of Manufacturers, said exports are growing twice as fast as imports and represent ``30 to 40 percent of our economic growth over the past three years.'' Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher noted the $23.9 billion first-quarter imbalance was the smallest in more than six years and continued the downward trend in the deficit. ``Strong export growth was the key to these favorable results,'' he said. ``I expect that we will see the trade deficit break $100 billion this year.'' The deficit peaked at $152.12 billion in 1987 and then dropped to $118.53 billion the following year and to $109 billion last year. It has been above the $100 billion level since 1983 when it totaled $52.4 billion. The March exports represented ``nice increases in computers, electrical machinery, industrial machinery and scientific equipment,'' Steinberg said. Holding down the export number was a decline in aircraft shipments, which Robert Brusca, chief financial economist with Nikko Securities Co. in New York, said resulted from the recent Boeing Co. strike. ``When the Boeing strike ended at the end of last year,'' he said, ``aircraft shipments were running at abnormal levels. Now they are back down to more normal levels.'' Samuel D. Kahan, chief financial economist with Fuji Securities Inc., in Chicago, noted much of the import increase was concentrated in automobiles and other consumer goods which, to some extent, may be seasonal. Oil imports totaled 261 million barrels, up 7.4 percent from February. But prices fell from $19.39 to $18.18 a barrel in March, making the $4.7 billion import bill virtually the same as the previous month. As usual, the deficit with Japan was the largest of any country. It totaled $3.6 billion; followed by China and Taiwan, $600 million each; Mexico and Brazil, $300 million each; and Canada, $100 million. The United States posted a $700 million surplus with the countries of Western Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Tracey Ullman Leaves Fox Network
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts one graf after 4th graf, `The British ...,' to add that ``The Simpsons'' is a spin-off from Ullman's show. ^By DEBORAH HASTINGS
DOC.TEXT: Tracey Ullman, whose offbeat comedy show attracted a dedicated but small following and won Fox Broadcasting Co. its first Emmy, has quit the fledgling network. ``I have decided not to go on with `The Tracey Ullman Show' after four seasons in which I was constantly challenged and happily tortured by a unique group of people,'' Miss Ullman said Wednesday. ``I thank Fox for letting somebody no one ever heard of do a show on a network that didn't exist.'' Miss Ullman's Saturday night show featured an array of comedians and musical sketches and earned Fox four Emmys and 20 nominations. The British comic's seemingly endless lineup of characters and accents helped make her one of the best known new performers in the United States. ``The Simpsons'' originally appeared on the show in April 1987 and was spun off this year as its own program. Although critically acclaimed, the program never did well in the ratings, often finishing last in the Nielsens. The final show has been completed and is scheduled for May 26. Miss Ullman's departure came two days after her friend and executive producer, James L. Brooks, announced he was leaving Fox for Columbia Pictures Television. Miss Ullman leaves Fox four years into a five-year contract. ``I think it was probably mutually agreed upon,'' said Fox spokeswoman Antonia Coffman. ``The Tracey Ullman Show'' will go into syndication, she said. Miss Ullman co-stars with Kevin Kline in the recently released film ``I Love You to Death'' and is in New York rehearsing for a summer run of ``The Taming of the Shrew'' in Central Park with Oscar-winning actor Morgan Freeman.

DOC.HEAD: Professor Remembers Friend Who Named Kermit the Frog After Him
With AM-Henson-Sesame Street
DOC.TEXT: A Purdue University professor says it ain't easy being Kermit. But when you're the namesake of a famous frog, life isn't all bad. Kermit Scott was the grade-school friend of Muppets creator Jim Henson, who died Wednesday in New York of complications from bacterial pneumonia at age 53. Scott had not heard from his friend since he was 14. That's when the Henson family left Leland, Miss., where the two grew up together. But Scott learned from a newspaper article years ago that the most famous of the Muppets was named for him. ``I guess I made an impression on him,'' said Scott. ``We had gone our ways, and I have very fond memories of our time toegether,'' Scott said Wednesday. Named Theodore Kermit Scott Jr., he grew up being called Kermit because his father used the name Theodore. ``It was a bit of a burden. No one else was ever named that,'' he said, but added, ``Now it's a name everybody knows.'' Scott, a philosophy professor, says he often uses Muppets in his lectures. The Kermit character, he said, has ``that kind of ability to remain open to all of the possibilities, while at the same time dealing with all the hassles.'' He said he always has been flattered Henson used his name for the puppet known for singing, ``It ain't easy being green.'' ``I certainly felt there are a lot worse things my name could be associated with. I'm very happy and proud of what he accomplished,'' Scott said.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Voices Strong Support for United Germany
DOC.NOTE: EDs: Combines pvs; edits thruout to tighten; no pickup
DOC.TEXT: President Bush today voiced strong support for a united Germany with ``full control over all its territory'' and said reunification should completely end the allies' postwar rights in Germany. ``Forty five years after the end of the war, there is no reason that a unified Democratic Germany should be in any way singled out for some special status,'' Bush said after meeting with West Germany Chancellor Helmut Kohl. Britain, France and the United States support West Germany's call for a reunified Germany to be part of NATO. But the Soviet Union _ the fourth of the big World War II victors _ argues that the new Germany should be neutral, or a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. What's clear, Bush said, ``is that the United States and the Federal Republic of Germany share the same approach and have the same goals regarding German unification.'' ``We both want a united Germany which enjoys full sovereignty, a united Germany which is a full member of the Western community and of the NATO alliance, including participation in its integrated military structures,'' he said. Bush said that a reunified Germany should ``have full control over all of its territory without any new, discriminatory constraints on German sovereignty.'' He said he and Kohl agreed that U.S. forces should ``remain stationed in the united Germany and elsewhere in Europe to continue to promote stability and security.'' Kohl thanked Bush for the ``magnificent support'' he had given ``Germans on our path to German unity.'' Kohl said that a reunified Germany must remain a member of NATO _ but he urged that the alliance concentrate more on its political role than its military one. ``As the threat is decreasing appreciably, the alliance must keep the initiative in the field of disarmament and arms control and review its strategy and structure,'' he said. Earlier, at an Oval Office picture-taking session, Kohl said he could not say whether German unity would come before the end of the year _ even though he had said earlier that all-German elections could come as early as Dec. 2. ``Nobody knows that. We know that the people are shouting, `we are the people.' This is why nobody can fix an exact date. But everything's going very well. We can say that.'' Kohl's Christian Democratic Party lost two West German state elections on Sunday, which some analysts saw as a reflection of concern by voters over the cost and pace of reunification. Kohl said he intended to discuss the issue with Bush, although added that Bush is well versed on the issue already. ``I think it's been rare to find a president in the history of the United States who knows German history and German politics so well as this president. And European politics,'' said Kohl, speaking through a translator. ``And that of course is a lucky thing for us. And I think that you should write that,'' Kohl told reporters. ``So do I,'' Bush chimed in. Bush and Kohl were also expected to discuss arms control, troops in Europe and the situation in the rebellious Soviet republics of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia. It was Bush's final face-to-face meeting with the nation's key allies as he prepares for his summit in two weeks with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev, a superpower conference Bush says is strained by the Baltic standoff. Kohl recently joined French President Francois Mitterrand in urging Lithuanian leaders to lower some of their demands and seek a negotiated settlement with the Kremlin. Bush has urged restraint on both sides. But administration sources said Bush is frustrated at lack of progress toward a resolution of the Baltic issue, particularly with respect to Lithuania. The Kremlin maintains a partial economic blockade of the breakaway state. Bush told a news conference Wednesday that the pressure the Soviet Union is applying to the Baltic states ``has certainly put some tension on the summit'' between himself and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. They meet in Washington from May 30-June 3. ``We want to see negotiations or dialogue or whatever you call it _ discussions between Gorbachev and the Lithuanians get going. And then I'd like to see the release of that economic pressure on Lithuania. And that would clear the air fast,'' the president said. On Wednesday, Lithuania's parliament offered to suspend laws it has enacted since declaring the republic's independence if the Kremlin agrees to negotiate. However, the resolution did not involve rescinding the March 11 declaration of independence as the Kremlin demanded, a spokeswoman said. Today's session with Kohl was the president's concluding session with Western allied leaders before the summit. Last month he met with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher in Bermuda and Mitterrand in Key Largo, Fla. He also has met with Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney and Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Aide Admits Failure of Economic Reforms, Asks For Western Help
DOC.TEXT: A top economic adviser to Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Thursday all economic reforms in his country have failed, and he appealed to Western economists, businesses and governments for help. ``If the West would help, this would in fact make the whole difference,'' said Stanislav Shatalin. He spoke at a news conference called to discuss a new plan whereby Western experts review Soviet and Eastern European economic reform proposals. ``We have come to a very profound conclusion that without the cooperation of the West, we simply can't build a market economy,'' said Shatalin, who is the only economist on the Presidential Council that has been working on Gorbachev's reforms. ``I'm sure the president too shares this position,'' Shatalin said. Shatalin was not specific about the type of Western aid Moscow would like to see. Nor did he mention what political compromises, if any, Gorbachev might consider to secure Western support. However, friction over the Baltic republics' drive for independence and the Soviet refusal to consider a united Germany in NATO would likely block any massive governmental aid from the West now. Echoing similar comments by Gorbachev, Shatalin said many Soviets oppose a market economy, expected to bring price increases and unemployment. He cited an unspecified poll that he said showed 54 percent of Soviets supported market reforms, but 46 percent were firmly against them. Shatalin said, however, a market economy was the only choice. He said the Soviet Union has decided, along with other East European nations, to join a new plan uniting about 50 top experts to cull through reforms before they are implemented. The operation is being run by the International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis based outside Vienna. It has brought together Soviet, East European and Western economists and other academics since it was founded in 1972. The Soviet Union needs ``the import of the best possible brains'' to succeed in economic change, Shatalin said. He admitted that reforms introduced by Gorbachev, specifically in 1988 and 1989, had failed to improve the economy. ``If anything, the situation has deteriorated,'' he said. In 1988, state enterprises were supposed to gain greater independence from central planning authorities. But bureaucrats found ways around the new laws by introducing ``state orders'' the enterprises had to meet, and thus retained control over the bulk of their production. The economic deterioration is evident to Soviet consumers, who face shortages of food and other goods. Asked why the Soviet leadership had not acted earlier to move to a market economy, Shatalin again pointed to popular opposition. ``If you don't have real political support for the reforms, they die out,'' he said. Gorbachev's latest package of promised reforms has yet to be unveiled. The president told reporters Thursday the public was to blame for their failure so far. ``Changing people's minds is the most difficult thing,'' he said. ``Perestroika depends on public opinion, and it's conservative.'' Shatalin also blamed the relatively poor education of Soviet economists for the failures to date. ``For a long time, I've said the level of our education in economics is medieval,'' he said. ``The whole process of becoming more intelligent, more capable is moving more slowly than it should,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Andrew Dice Clay Not Ratings Champ
DOC.TEXT: The Dice Man didn't make last week's ``Saturday Night Live'' its most-watched show this season, despite heavy publicity before his appearance, Nielsen ratings showed Thursday The show, in which foul-mouth comic Andrew Dice Clay was host, was fourth-ranked. It had an 8.8 rating and a 26 percent share of the audience in its time period, according to the A.C. Nielsen Co. figures. The series' ratings champion this season remains the Feb. 24 show, when Fred Savage of ABC's ``The Wonder Years'' was host. It got a 10.7 rating and a 29 percent audience share. Each ratings point represents 921,000 homes. ``Saturday Night Live'' regular Nora Dunn and pop singer Sinead O'Connor boycotted last week's program because of Clay. He has been criticized for his coarse humor, which includes comments that disparage women and homsexuals. Although his appearance earned the show record ratings for this season in major cities like New York, Chicago and Los Angeles, ``it wasn't as big a draw in the smaller markets,'' an NBC spokeswoman said. This season's final ``Saturday Night Live'' broadcast, with Candice Bergen of CBS' ``Murphy Brown'' as host, will be shown Saturday. No decision has been made about whether the satirical late-night series will be renewed for a 16th season.

DOC.HEAD: Kennedy Center Chairman Seeks Repair Funds
DOC.TEXT: The 18-year-old John F. Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts needs $30.5 million to repair such things as a leaky marble roof and crumbling garage, the facility's top administrator said Thursday. James D. Wolfensohn told the House subcommittee on buildings and grounds that river and roof terraces, parapets, planters and building systems also need repairs. However, he said there was no danger to the estimated 4.9 million people who visit the 7,000-seat theater complex each year. ``If I thought it was unsafe we would close the building,'' Wolfensohn said. ``But we need to ensure the safety of the building continues.'' Wolfensohn, who has been chairman of the center for six weeks, said the sprawling structure overlooking the Potomac River had been poorly maintained and that fund-raising would not be able to meet high repair costs. Basic maintenance has not been done in five years, he said. The Kennedy Center is operating with bank loans and using advance ticket sales to pay bills and a $15.3 million deficit, Wolfensohn said. The National Park Service performs daily maintenance, but Wolfensohn wants Congress to consider who is ultimately responsible for all upkeep of the $750 million building. Wolfensohn said the five-theater facility was not in danger of closing. ``The performing arts is geerally a money loser,'' Wolfensohn said. Rep. Sidney R. Yates, D-Ill., praised the center for raising more than $50 million in the five years that ended in 1989 and fully paying operating costs.

DOC.HEAD: Woman Officially Alive Again After Computer Error Repair
DOC.TEXT: Rose Marie Posey is officially alive again after a computer error that declared her death was corrected. Now, she's ready for ``The Tonight Show'' and ``Nightline.'' The 73-year-old woman declared dead by U.S. Treasury Department and insurance company computers got word Wednesday that the errors had been fixed and her $871.13 monthly pension restored. And the local media darling is ready to go national. ``I'm happy, believe me,'' she said. ``I'll even get on an airplane if they ask me and go to talk to Ted Koppel or Johnny Carson _ and I hate to get on airplanes. ``I'm kind of liking the attention, you know.'' Mrs. Posey learned of her ``death'' in April when she didn't receive her monthly pension check from the Railroad Retirement Board. On May 10, Medicare refused to pay a $25 claim she'd submitted for minor foot surgery. The national health insurer told her in a letter that the surgery ``was reported to be after the date of death.'' After her story appeared this week in newspapers, Med Pay Inc., a Springfield third-party administrator of group health plan claims, stepped in and notified the government Mrs. Posey was indeed alive. ``It needed somebody who just knew which button to push,'' company president Gordon L. Kinne said. Travelers Medicare service representative Debbie Petersen called Mrs. Posey from Salt Lake City, Utah, on Wednesday to say she was once again alive in computer files, and the surgery claim would be paid.

DOC.HEAD: Security Increased Outside Parliament After Death Threats Reported
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police stepped up security outside East Germany's parliament Thursday after authorities reported death threats against the president of the chamber. A bloc of leftist East German lawmakers criticized the security measures, saying they were reminiscent of the policies of the ousted Communist regime. Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel said the dozens of extra police and roadblocks were needed around the People's Chamber were necessary because of ``numerous death threats'' against Parliament President Sabine Bergmann-Pohl. ``The threats that reached us are credible,'' he said. Diestel, in charge of police functions in East Germany, said authorities have also registered an increase in thefts of weapons and explosives recently. The interior minister refused to give further details about the case. In recent days, there has been increasing labor unrest as workers express fears that unification with West Germany will cost tens of thousands of jobs in East Germany. There was no word as to whether the death threats were connected to the labor woes. The leftist coalition called Alliance 90 criticized the extra police presence, saying it reminded them of ``the events of last year.'' Before his ouster October 18, hard-line Communist leader Erich Honecker ordered massive police forces into the streets to break up huge pro-democracy demonstrations.

DOC.HEAD: Gorbachev Says Conservative Public Holding Back Reforms
With AM-Soviet-Baltics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said Thursday that citizens' fear of change is holding back the economic and political changes that would give them a better life. ``In politics, the public doesn't accept pluralism, and it has complexes about ideological conceptions and cliches,'' he told reporters at a parliamentary session in Moscow. ``Take any sphere, everywhere we are hindered by complexes,'' Gorbachev added. ``People are saying `Chaos, chaos, collapse, collapse.' When Lenin watched a similar revolutionary process, he said, `You know, this chaos will crystallize a new form of life.' '' Some of Gorbachev's economic advisers in the past have said the public's conservative mood might hold back necessary economic reforms that could lead to higher prices and unemployment, but Gorbachev himself had not previously addressed the issue in such a forthright manner. ``Perestroika depends on public opinion, and it's conservative,'' he said. Gorbachev has delayed an economic reform plan over the past two months. Aides have backed away from suggestions that Polish-style ``shock therapy'' was in store for the Soviet economy. Radical measures in Poland brought sudden price increases and unemployment. Gorbachev has promised that nothing will be decided without discussion. He also indicated the reform program will not be discussed with his advisory Presidential Council until May 22. He spoke with reporters in the Kremlin's ornate St. George's Hall during a break at the Congress of the Russian Federation, where reformers forced his candidate for president into giving an accounting of his performance as premier. Radicals said that will be embarrassing, given the country's economic crisis. They hoped it could persuade Gorbachev to withdraw Russian Premier Alexander V. Vlasov from the race against political maverick Boris N. Yeltsin and substitute a more centrist candidate. Otherwise, Gorbachev risks having Russia, the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, taken over by Yeltsin, the silver-haired Siberian populist who is his most popular critic. Yet Gorbachev was off-hand when reporters asked him about the struggle between Vlasov and Yeltsin. ``I see no drama in this,'' he said. ``This is all normal. The (Communist) party has given up its monopoly.'' ``Tomorrow or the next day, new parties will appear with their own platforms and proposals, and this will be a normal process.'' Newly elected radicals at the Russian congress are trying to elect Yeltsin and wrest control of the republic's affairs away from the national government. Russia is the largest of the Soviet Union's 15 republics, with 52 percent of its people and three-quarters of its land mass. A radical takeover of the 1,059-member Russian parliament threatens Gorbachev's prestige. It could also undermine his authority, if radicals try to increase the Russian parliament's power by declaring that its laws take priority over national ones. Speaking to reporters, Gorbachev suggested that political groups favoring reform should work together. ``Confrontation could lead to bloodshed,'' he said. ``We were brought up differently. We think, `My opinion is right and the others are wrong.' As a result, nobody is listening to anybody.'' Many hard-liners are unhappy with Gorbachev's recent moves to end the Communist Party's monopoly on power, legalize private ownership of factories and otherwise upset basic laws of Marxism. ``In economics, they say you must not touch this and you must not touch that,'' Gorbachev said. Turning to Premier Nikolai I. Ryzhkov, who gave a television interview last week on economic reform proposals, Gorbachev said: ``Ryzhkov only said a few words and already there is great agitation in the country.'' But the deputy premier in charge of economic reform said in the Krasnoyarsk region of Siberia that reforms will not be painless. ``One model of the economy cannot be replaced by another without someone being hurt,'' said Deputy Premier Leonid Abalkin. In remarks carried by the official news agency Tass, he warned that ``the transition to the market is perhaps the last chance history gives to socialism. Only a market can heal our sick society and even bring prosperity.'' Abalkin said basic food prices will remain controlled and fixed incomes will rise to match expected inflation. In Vienna, Austria, a top economic adviser to Gorbachev said all economic reforms in the Soviet Union have failed, and he appealed to Western economists, businesses and governments for help. ``If the West would help, this would in fact make the whole difference,'' Stanislav Shatalin said at a news conference.

DOC.HEAD: Officer Leaves Keys in Ignition; Car Stolen
DOC.TEXT: A police officer who gives lectures on how to thwart car thieves had his cruiser stolen after he left the keys in the ignition. Lt. James Disanti left his car running early Wednesday in front of a donut shop in this southwestern Pennsylvania town. When he returned, the car was gone. State troopers spotted the car about an hour later at a gas station. When the troopers flashed their headlights as a greeting, the driver of the police car sped away, police said. After a short chase, troopers arrested David P. Sandrey, 22, of Charleroi, and charged him with theft, criminal mischief and fleeing police. Charleroi Police Chief Ed Hank said he probably won't take disciplinary action against Disanti. ``I might sit him down and talk to him, though,'' the chief said.

DOC.HEAD: Williams Seeks Arts Expertise on NEA Funding
DOC.TEXT: The sponsor of legislation to extend the life of the troubled National Endowment for the Arts said Thursday he was delaying the bill and asking arts experts to recommend changes in the way the NEA operates. Rep. Pat Williams, D-Mont., chairman of the House postesecondary education subcommittee, said he wants artists and representatives of at least 17 arts-related groups to meet next Tuesday and suggest NEA changes. The NEA has been criticized by conservatives, who have tried to place new limits on the way it awards grants. Williams, at a news conference, said he was convinced the NEA has broad support in Congress. But because of protests over the funding of recent controversial exhibits, Williams said, a bill to reauthorize the NEA for five years is unlikely to pass Congress without some amendments. Williams is sponsoring a bill backed by the Bush administration. A group of Republicans proposed an alternative that would give a portion of the NEA's money to the states for their distribution to the arts. Williams said he was cancelling a subcommittee vote on the bill that had been scheduled for next week until he meets with arts supporters. ``I'd be surprised if they came out with a recommendation that said all is well,'' Williams said.

DOC.HEAD: Radical Students Clash With Police on Eve of Aniniversary
DOC.TEXT: Radical students hurling rocks and firebombs fought police in Kwangju and a dozen other cities Thursday, the eve of the 10th anniversary of a bloody anti-government rebellion in Kwangju. Meanwhile, 27,000 workers at the nation's largest car plant continued a strike for a third day. The nation's 130,000-strong police force was on top alert after a major dissident coalition called for nationwide anti-government protests to mark the Kwangju anniversary Friday. At least 200 people died and more than 1,700 were injured when troops and tanks crushed a May 18, 1980 uprising in the southern city. The Munhwa Broadcasting Co. said 20,000 students joined in protests on 50 campuses Thursday. Police reported arrests and injuries but gave no figures. The national Yonhap News Agency said 10 people were injured in one clash south of Seoul. In Kwangju, 155 miles south of Seoul, tension mounted as radical students and dissidents prepared to mark the uprising. American residents and travelers in Kwangju said the U.S. Embassy in Seoul advised them to stay off certain streets. The dissident People's Alliance announced in Seoul that it would organize protests in several cities. The alliance was a major force behind nationwide protests on May 9 that were the largest and most violent since 1987. Radicals and dissidents want the ouster of President Roh Tae-woo. They say the merger of his governing party with two opposition groups into the new Democratic Liberal Party earlier this year was a political coup and marks a return to dictatorial rule in South Korea. In Kwangju, about 1,000 students clashed with riot police around Chonnam University, hurling rocks and firebombs. Police fired barrages of tear gas from two armored vans, sending clouds of the choking gas billowing over the school's main gate. ``Down with Roh Tae-woo!'' students shouted as they charged police in a steady rain. ``Drive out Yankees!'' During a campus rally before the clash, students charged that the United States took a bystander's role during the 10-day Kwangju revolt, thus condoning the crackdown by Korean soldiers. A huge placard showed a Korean student ripping apart a U.S. flag. An American flag was painted on a school's road so people could walk on it. About 7,500 combat-clad riot police were deployed in Kwangju. The massive show of force, along with steady downpours throughout Thursday, apparently kept protests down. In the southeastern industrial town of Ulsan, meanwhile, 27,000 assembly workers of the Hyundai Motor Co. stayed away again Thursday. They halted production at the nation's largest car marker on Tuesday. The plant, a subsidiary of the giant Hyundai group, makes 2,650 vehicles a day and sold 589,000 cars last year, including 200,000 in the United States and other nations. Hyundai workers went on strike after talks on a new contract failed to make progress. Union officials reported ``some progress'' in marathon talks but said both sides were still apart over some key issues, including a shorter work week and more benefits.

DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1st graf of 3rd item to fix typo in `is'
DOC.TEXT: Gerard Depardieu, star of the European blockbuster film ``Cyrano,'' will travel to Moscow next month to promote the movie featuring what some critics say is his best performance. ``Cyrano'' is vying for the coveted Gold Palm award at this year's Cannes Film Festival. It stars Depardieu as the long-nosed dreamer who breathes his passion and poetry into the empty head of a simple soldier to woo the beautiful Roxanne. At a cost of about $19 million, ``Cyrano'' is France's most expensive cinema production. It was Depardieu's 60th film role and has been called his strongest work by many critics. The film adapted from Edmond Rostand's theater classic was directed by Jean-Paul Rappeneau. Depardieu will be accompanied by Theirry de Beauce, secretary of state in the Foreign Affairs Ministry, and will also travel to Czechoslovakia and Hungary, where the movie was filmed.

DOC.HEAD: Panel Begins Close Look At FDA Operations
DOC.TEXT: A panel of medical, pharmaceutical and legal experts began Thursday examining the Food and Drug Administration with an eye toward revitalizing an agency often embroiled in controversy. Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan told the 15-member panel, which he appointed, to ``consider whether FDA's energies and resources are focused on the right objectives.'' Sullivan said the FDA, which regulates about 25 percent of products sold to consumers, has been under pressure in recent years ``to do more and more with less and less.'' ``Since 1979, Congress has passed 21 bills giving the agency more tasks, each of which added to the agency's mandate,'' he said. The FDA staffing level has fallen from 8,089 employees in 1980 to 7,877 this year. Also, 506 employees currently work solely on AIDS-related projects. None did 10 years ago. Staffing in the generic drug division, which had 120 employees a decade ago, has risen to 430. Most of the additional staff there was added because of the recent generic-drug corruption scandal. FDA Acting Commissioner James Benson said that because of the nature of the agency's work, ``We'll always be in the middle of some kind of controversy.'' The FDA regulates the quality of most of the nation's foods and food additives as well as prescription and over-the-counter drugs, medical devices and cosmetics. The agency's budget this year is $587 million and a $13 million supplemental appropriation is pending in Congress. The FDA ended up in the eye of the storm when it removed Chilean fruit from store shelves after a poisoning threat last year. It is often attacked by AIDS activists who claim the agency moves too slowly in approving new drugs. The FDA also has been under fire for its handling of generic drugs. The advisory committee's formation was announced last December, shortly after then-FDA Commissioner Frank Young left to become a deputy assistant secretary for health. Sources said at the time that Young was forced out, in part, because of the generic drug scandal that has resulted so far in 13 criminal convictions on charges ranging from bribery to racketeering. Those charged include generic drug companies, their executives and FDA employees. The FDA advisory committee is headed by Dr. Charles C. Edwards, a former FDA commissioner. Four other members of the panel are former FDA officials. Sullivan told the committee members to submit a preliminary report in four months and a final report one year from now.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Meets With Lithuanian Official
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to UPDATE with Gorbachev meeting with Lithuanian official. TRIMS to tighten. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: In a major breakthrough in the Baltic impasse, President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met today with an official of Lithuania's government for the first time since the republic declared independence. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene talked with Gorbachev for two hours in the Kremlin in what she called ``an introduction to coming negotiations,'' a Lithuanian spokesman said. The meeting was an unexpected breakthrough in the dispute between the Kremlin and Lithuania that flared on March 11 when the Baltic republic of 3.8 million people declared independence. Earlier today, Gorbachev lashed out at Lithuanian leaders, characterizing their actions as ``adventurism.'' Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania rescind the declaration. The Lithuanian government has refused, but on Wednesday its Supreme Council parliament offered to suspend laws passed since independence if the Kremlin will open talks on its declaration of secession. Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov, who also attended, told Mrs. Prunskiene the offer did not address their main concern: that the Lithuanian declaration of independence be suspended, the Tass news agency reported. ``K. Prunskiene's attention was drawn to the indispensable necessity that the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet cancel _ or as a minimum, suspend _ this act and all the legislative measures following it that contradict the Soviet Constitution,'' Tass reported. It said the leaders told Mrs. Prunskiene that concession was the only way to launch negotiations. But Tass said the leaders noted the Lithuanian offer showed that ``certain steps had been made toward the normalization of the situation,'' Tass said. Mrs. Prunskiene called the meeting ``an introduction to coming negotiations,'' Longinas Vasiliauskas, press attache of the Lithuanian representation in Moscow, said. He said the prime minister would not report in detail on the meeting until Friday. Tass said Mrs. Prunskiene promised to report what had been said to the Lithuanian Supreme Council parliament. Mrs. Prunskiene arrived in Moscow earlier today seeking to meet with Gorbachev, who has imposed a partial economic embargo on Lithuania in an effort to make it rescind independence laws it has passed. Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuania was willing to suspend its drive for independence and remain part of the Soviet security system. Shortly before her arrival, Gorbachev told Western reporters who questioned him about the Baltics: ``I believe that the Lithuanian leadership and some others cannot get rid of adventurism.'' Asked whether he was aware that Mrs. Prunskiene was in Moscow seeking to present new concessions, he said: ``I have received no such request.'' When Gorbachev was asked if he was willing to meet with leaders from the breakaway Baltic republics, he looked one reporter in the eye, then turned away and told his body guards, ``Let's move on.'' In an interview with Britain's Channel Four television, Gorbachev was highly critical of the Lithuanians. ``A constructive approach is needed. We will not permit any violation of the constitution or any division from the constitutional process,'' he said. Mrs. Prunskiene also said she was seeking to meet Secretary of State James A. Baker III. Baker, who is in Moscow for meetings with the Soviet leadership about the superpower summit at the end of the month. She told reporters she had a ``tentative'' appointment with Baker but had received no answer from Gorbachev. Baker said he would press Soviet leaders to explain why they have not begun talks with Baltic leaders. ``It's not encouraging to us to see the absence of a dialogue between leaders there and the Kremlin,'' said Baker. In Washington, President Bush said the standoff between Moscow and the Baltic republics ``certainly puts some tension'' on the planned summit.

DOC.HEAD: Shamirs Gets Three-Week Extension on Mandate to Form Government
DOC.TEXT: Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir received a 21-day extension Thursday on his mandate to form Israel's new government and immediately ran into trouble with potential coalition partners. Shamir, whose mandate was due to expire Friday, was granted the extension by President Chaim Herzog. ``I hope I would not need all that period and would finish with it before it expires. I don't want to name a date, but I hope it would be soon,'' Shamir told reporters outside Herzog's residence. Under Israeli law, a legislator entrusted by the president with forming a government is initially given three weeks and then may ask for an additional 21 days. No president has ever rejected a request for an extension. Shamir indicated he asked for extra time because of disputes with potential partners over the distribution of Cabinet posts as well as over the next government's guidelines. ``Each party has its aspirations and demands, and I have to worry about the overall picture,'' he said. Shamir, head of the hard-line Likud bloc, has tentative agreements that would give him a majority in the 120-member parliament. But he has been unable to sign pacts with three ultra-right parties and three Orthodox religious factions. The right-wing Tehiya party announced Thusday it would not join his government because of Likud's failure to meet party demands for government posts. The radical right-wing Moledet, meanwhile, said its ideological differences with Likud could not be bridged. The party advocates expulsion of Arabs from the occupied territories and opposes Shamir's plan of granting Palestinians limited autonomy. Israel has been governed by Shamir's 13-member transition Cabinet since March 15, when the left-leaning Labor Party engineered the collapse of Likud-Labor coalition over Shamir's refusal to accept U.S. proposals for an Israeli-Palestinian dialogue in Cairo. Herzog first asked Labor leader Shimon Peres to try to form a government. Peres failed after five weeks and was forced to hand the mandate to Shamir on April 26. At the time, Likud signed a coalition accord with a four-member faction headed by Yitzhak Modai, a former finance minister. The group had vacillated between the two rival camps for weeks. A second agreement was signed with Eliezer Mizrahi, a defector from the Agudat Israel ultra-Orthodox party which backs Labor but now appears willing to consider a partnership with Likud. Mizrahi's move to Likud robbed Peres of the majority he needed to form a government. Shamir still needs to pin down formal pledges of backing from three religious parties and three ultra-rightist factions, among them Tehiya and Moledet, to assure himself of a 61-seat majority. Despite the entangled coalition negotiations with small parties, Shamir ruled out a new alliance with Labor. ``I did not discuss this possibility with Mr. Peres and I think it is not realistic today,'' he said. In other developments, Labor announced it would delay by 10 days the publication of an internal report placing blame for the party's poor showing in the 1988 parliament elections and 1989 municipal balloting. The report, which reportedly criticizes Peres, was to have been published Thursday. It is expected to boost the campaign by former prime minister Yitzhak Rabin to oust Peres as party boss.

DOC.HEAD: The AP
Panel Calls For Excluder Devices On Trawlers To Save Endangered Sea Turtles
DOC.TEXT: A panel said Thursday that between 11,000 and 44,000 sea turtles drown annually in shrimp nets and recommended that virtually all trawlers be required to use turtle-excluder devices for most of each year. Incidental capture and drowning in shrimp trawler nets ``accounts for more deaths than all other human activities combined'' among the five endangered species of sea turtles that live in the U.S. waters of the Atlantic Ocean and Gulf of Mexico, the National Research Council committee said. Though many studies estimated that 11,000 loggerhead and Kemp's ridley turtles are killed annually by shrimp fishing, the report said that figure ``was judged by this committee to be an underestimate, possibly by as much as a factor of four.'' Other estimates by the committee put the number of turtles killed by shrimping each year at 55,000. A halt to shrimp trawling altogether could be required to preserve the sea turtle species, the report said, unless the industry takes vigorous measures to limit the number of turtles killed. ``The committee believes that shrimping with adequate controls is compatible with the recovery of turtle populations,'' the report said. ``Although prohibition of shrimp trawling might be required as a `last ditch' measure,'' the committee said the use of new technology could reduce turtle deaths ``to a level that the populations can tolerate.'' The committee said that the population Kemp's ridley turtles ``is dangerously small,'' about 1 percent of the abundance found in a 1947 study. Since 1978, the number of nesting females, the study said, has dropped from 700 to 350. Adult Kemp's ridley turtles live principally in the Gulf of Mexico and nest on beaches in Mexico. Loggerhead turtles nesting on South Carolina and Georgia beaches are in decline, the study said, but are stable or increasing in some Florida areas. Nestings of the other species, green turtles, hawksbills, and leatherbacks, seem to be stable or increasing slightly in some areas, the report said. The committee said that other human activity also kills many adult sea turtles, but nothing is as lethal to the species as shrimping. Other types of commercial fishing, the report, said kills about 550 turtles annually. An estimated 400 turtles die from collisions with boats, while others die from dredging and the removal of old oil rigs. An unknown number of turtles, the committee said, die from swallowing discarded plastic debris, which some turtles confuse with natural food. Environmental groups, which have been battling to protect sea turtles, hailed the report as a verification of the need to take strong measures. ``The report confirms what other studies and assessments have found in the past and what we have been arguing for the last 10 years,'' said Michael Weber of the Center for Marine Conservation. ``Capturing sea turtles in shrimp trawls is a major threat to their population in the United States.'' Congress requested the 1988 NRC study after passage of amendment to the Endangered Species Act. Some congressmen from Gulf states complained about federal regulations that required shrimpers to use net devices that are designed to prevent sea turtles from drowning. The report said the turtles drown when they are caught in a funnel-shaped net commonly dragged behind boats to capture shrimp that live near the ocean floor. Turtle excluder devices, or TEDs, are, in effect, trapdoors in the bottom of the nets that allow turtles to escape before they drown. Federal law now requires shrimpers to use TEDs while fishing from May 1 to Aug. 31 along the southern Atlantic Ocean coast, and from March 1 to Nov. 30 in the Gulf of Mexico. The NRS report said that the use of TEDs at all times in all areas could reduce the capture of turtles to about 3 percent of the rate that occurs without TEDs. The report said that turtle survival rates also would improve if nets were not towed for longer than 40 minutes in the summer and 60 minutes in the winter _ the approximate length of time a sea turtle can stay underwater without injury. The NRC also called for protection of turtle nesting areas and recommended that a small-scale captive breeding program continue for Kemp's ridley turtles.

DOC.HEAD: Senate Panel Hears Adams' Plan To Clean Up Nuclear Weapons Waste
DOC.TEXT: Congress should set up a special trust fund to guarantee availability of more than $100 billion for cleaning up radioactive wastes at nuclear weapons plants, a Senate panel was told Thursday. The Energy Department opposes the fund, proposed by Sen. Brock Adams and Rep. Norm Dicks, both Washington State Democrats. The department claims it would duplicate clean-up plans initiated by Energy Secretary James D. Watkins. But on Thursday, Sens. Tim Wirth, D-Colo., and Howard Metzenbaum, D-Ohio, joined an aide to Washington Gov. Booth Gardner in pleading for the fund before the Senate Environment and Public Works Committee. They said a permanent financing plan is necessary to guard against future administrations that may lack a commitment to health and environmental safety. ``We can't continue to push this problem off to future generations as it has been pushed off on us,'' said Dan Silver, a special assistant to Gardner. ``We're fooling ourselves if we think we can continue in a nickel-and-dime fashion to try to clean up these places without a long-term commitment,'' Wirth added. ``We are going to have to find a way of raising the ante significantly.'' Adams said Watkins had made great strides in launching the clean-up of waste sites, but he said the public remains skeptical about the commitment to provide the huge amounts of money necessary. ``We must create a program so we don't run the risk of a different secretary or a different administration deciding that we can let this go for awhile,'' he said. The trust fund would be created with an appropriation of about $6.2 billion over the next two years. The money would be in lieu of an approximately equal amount regularly appropriated to DOE for environmental activities, Adams said. The fund would be sustained by assessments to commercial users of DOE nuclear facilties and polluters. Leo Duffy, director of the Energy Department's Office of Environmental Restoration and Waste Management, said the proposal would ``complicate present budgeting requirements.''

DOC.HEAD: East German Rail Workers Strike For Higher Wages
DOC.TEXT: Rail workers nationwide stopped selling tickets and shuttling passengers Thursday to demand better wages and job protection in a united Germany, where socialist guarantees of jobs for all will not exist. The 30-minute strikes were the latest in a series of worker demonstrations in recent weeks fueled by frustration over the possible effects on jobs and prices of unification with West Germany. They came on the eve of the signing of a treaty by German leaders that will merge the countries' economies July 2, a major step to full unification. In Washington, President Bush met Thursday with West Germany Chancellor Helmut Kohl and voiced strong support for a united Germany with ``full control over all its territory.'' The East German government news service, ADN, said workers paralyzed main rail routes nationwide, stopping work at switching yards, ticket counters and on trains. The so-called ``warning strikes'' were staged to protest what workers said was the failure of the government railroad company to meet demands for higher wages and job protection. Train traffic, a principal form of daily transportation for many East Germans, was interrupted in the cities of Magdeburg, Rostock, Gera, Schwerin and others, ADN said. Last week, farmers, teachers and textile workers held nationwide strikes to protest unemployment expected as East Germany moves to a free market. Workers are seeking protection from joblessness and from the better-made Western imports already flooding the country. Many outmoded East German businesses are expected to fail in the first two years of economic unification. East Germans also are demanding higher wages to cope with the price increases expected when costs are set by the free market. The strikes were held during the weekly session of Parliament, which debated the draft of a new constitution that will take old Socialist laws off the books and establish East Germany legally as a democracy. It also would eliminate the old Communist guarantee of full unemployment. Liberal lawmakers pressed for some employment guarantees in the new democratic charter. Wolfgang Ullmann, a lawmaker from a left-leaning opposition coalition, called it a ``scandalous copy'' for ``would-be West German citizens.'' He called for a new constitution that guarantees workers' rights and warned of ``mass unemployment'' and a ``merciless economic war.'' Conservatives say the conversion to a free market and an increase in Western investment will eventually raise living standards and provide jobs. The economic treaty is to be signed Friday by Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere and Kohl. The parliaments of the two nations likely will consider it in June. A full political merger is not expected until next year. The centerpiece of the economic treaty is the circulation of West German marks as the official currency of East Germany. However, the treaty leaves out how to shift East Germany's publicly owned industries and property to the private sector, to be the subject of further talks. Some East Germans fear West German investors will buy up the nation. Kohl wants Western investors to have an incentive for investing in East Germany's moribund industrial sector, while de Maiziere wants some limits on how much property West Germans can own. Western businesses already are forging deals with East German enterprises, and Western products are increasingly available in East Germany. On Thursday, the West German subsidiary of the giant American cigarette maker, Philip Morris, agreed to buy a cigarette plant in the East German city of Dresden, according to a report by ADN. American cigarette makers have inundated East Germany with advertising in recent months in an effort to tap the market in this nation of heavy smokers. Also Thursday, the U.S.-based computer manufacturer International Business Machine and a government-run data processing enterprise announced a cooperative agreement, ADN said. The accord to develop software, sales and service will result in higher quality for the East German firm, ADN quoted Guenter Rose, head of the East German Data Processing Center, as saying. In Washington, meanwhile, Bush said a reunified Germany should ``have full control over all of its territory without any new, discriminatory constraints on German sovereignty.'' He also reiterated that a united Germany should be part of NATO. ``We both want a united Germany which enjoys full sovereignty, a united Germany which is a full member of the Western community and of the NATO alliance,'' he said. Although the United States, Britain and France say Germany should join the Western alliance, the Soviet Union, the fourth World War II victor, has said it should remain neutral or a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Pentagon Task Force Says $100 Million Should be Spent on HDTV
DOC.TEXT: A Pentagon task force is recommending that the government spend $100 million a year to develop advanced video systems such as high-definition TV, a published report said Thursday. That would be a 10-fold increase over what the Pentagon agency charged with HDTV development sought and received this year for advanced TV research. The High-Resolution Systems Task Force has forwarded the $100 million recommendation to the Defense Science Board, which will discuss the proposal next week, according to the Washington-based trade publication Communications Daily. A task force spokeswoman, Susan Hansen, said Thursday she could not confirm the $100 million figure. She said the task force recommendations were under review and would be considered by the board. The recommendations, she said, could be discussed at the board's quarterly meeting next week. The board _ made up chiefly of business executives, educators and retired military personnel _ reports to Defense Secretary Dick Cheney. Proponents of HDTV, which promises motion-picture-quality images and compact-disc-quality sound, say it could help re-energize the U.S. electronics and computer industries. But others say HDTV won't be a popular consumer item until well into the next century. The Pentagon foresees military applications in radar and other display-type technologies and has funded a modest research program through DAPRA, its Defense Advanced Projects Research Agency, which also funds the Sematech semicondutor consortium. White House officials such as Budget Director Richard Darman reportedly have opposed efforts to single out private industries for government aid. Concern over using federal funds to support so-called dual use _ military and civilian _ technologies led to the recent reassignment of DAPRA's director, Craig Fields, according to administration critics such as House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., and Rep. Mel Levine, D-Calif. An aide to Levine, Jon Cowan, said the task force recommendation was an ``important first step, but just a drop in the bucket'' compared with what the Europeans and Japanese already have spent on HDTV development. Europe Eureka consortium has spent between $300 million and $400 million on HDTV, while Japan has spent about $1 billion, Cowan said. ``It's upping the ante,'' Cowan said. DAPRA spent $5 million in 1989 to fund research into high-definition displays, spokeswoman Jan Bodanyi said Thursday. The agency requested and received $10 million for 1990 and has requested $12 million for 1991, she said. The agency has awarded several contracts to companies developing high-definition display technology, although some news reports have said the administration would not fund some of these awards. Congress appropriated an additional $20 million to DARPA for 1990, but the money can't be used until the agency tells Congress, among other things, how it intends to spend the funds. Cowan said the stipulation gives the administration an excuse not to spend the money. He said Levine and others were drafting a bill requiring that all programs funded through DARPA would be for military and civilian uses.

DOC.HEAD: Soviet Sculpture Unveiled in Citadel of Capitalism
DOC.TEXT: A sculpture by Soviet artist Zurab Tsereteli was unveiled on a busy corner in London's financial district Thursday, and the proud sculptor proclaimed: ``We have stormed the citadel of capitalism. His 6-foot-high bronze sculpture, titled ``Break the Wall of Distrust,'' depicts a young man breaching a wall. It was placed on Cannon Street, between St. Paul's Cathedral and the Bank of England. Tsereteli, from Tbilisi, Georgia is widely acknowledged as the leading Soviet sculptor. He said he sketched the design for the piece two weeks before the Berlin Wall was broken Nov. 9, 1989. ``I think people of talent and culture pick up a sense of what's in the air before the rest of us,'' said a beaming Trevor Osborne, chairman of developers Speyhawk PLC, who commissioned the work for the corner of a new office block rented to a Dutch bank. ``To see a sculpture by a Soviet artist in the heart of the City of London is a novel development and a sign of the times, a sign of the great and positive changes in Europe,'' Leonid Zamyatin, Soviet ambassador in London, told a small gathering. Zamyatin said he brought greetings to the ceremony from Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev and Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze, a Georgian like the sculptor. ``Shevardnadze said he hopes this will be called Tbilisi Corner,'' Zamyatin said with a smile. At the edge of the sidewalk, travelers in a red double-decker bus halted among taxis, trucks, vans and a Rolls-Royce, gazed out the windows at the crowd on the corner while messengers on motorcycles skittered in and out and a jack hammer drilled close by. Richard Luce, arts minister in Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher's business-oriented Conservative government, called it an honor and a privilege to unveil the sculpture. ``Millions of people sitting for hours in the London traffic will have the opportunity to look at it,'' he said. `I have been to Tbilisi, which is a wonderful city in a wonderful country. The timing by Speyhawk is quite brilliant. There are few better ways of developing better relations than through art and culture,'' Luce said. Osborne was looking for a sculptor to decorate his new building when he was introduced to Tsereteli by Connie Middleton, who had met the artist in Tbilisi while arranging the first British auction of contemporary Soviet art. ``I signed the contract with the sculptor in my house on October 27, 1989, and I was amazed when the Berlin Wall was knocked down two weeks later,'' Osborne said. The new sculpture is Tsereteli's first in Britain. His works are on show throughout his native Caucasus and on Soviet Embassy and consulate buildings in Japan, Brazil and the United States.

DOC.HEAD: Henson's Death Leaves Muppet Voice Void
DOC.TEXT: The death of Jim Henson left a chasm on Sesame Street and beyond. It also left questions about who would do the voices of Kermit the Frog and other beloved Muppet characters. Henson, 53, died Wednesday of multi-organ failure brought on by complications from galloping pneumonia, said Dr. David M. Gelmont, who treated Henson at New York Hospital. A memorial service was scheduled for Monday at the Cathedral of St. John the Divine, said Susan Berry, a spokeswoman for Jim Henson Productions. It was unclear what affect Henson's death would have on the program, which is produced by the Children's Television Workshop. After Mel Blanc died on July 10, 1989, his son, Noel, took over the voices of Daffy Duck, Bugs Bunny and other Warner Bros. characters. Henson and with his wife, Jane, had five children who range from age 19 to 30. Lisa Simon, who produces Sesame Street, said it wasn't immediately known what would become of the voices of Kermit; Ernie, the smiling humanoid devoted to his rubber duckie; and Guy Smiley, ``America's favorite game show host.'' Henson always did those voices and had no substitute. It also wasn't known whether Henson's death _ or any new voices for the characters _ would be explained to the children who watch the show. ``We're just dealing with shock of Jim's death,'' said Simon. In 1982, Will Lee, the actor who played the kindly shopkeeper Mr. Hooper, died at age 74. The next season, young viewers were told about Mr. Hooper's death. Viewers got the news on the Thanksgiving program, chosen because parents were likely to be with their children then to answer questions. In a four-minute segment, players on the program explained the death to Big Bird, who bought birdseed milkshakes from Mr. Hooper's store. ``Just because,'' he was told. Another human character, David, said he had taken over the store and would be providing Big Bird's beverages. At the end of the segment, Big Bird hung a drawing of Mr. Hooper over his nest _ and viewers were told that a baby had been born to a human couple on the program. ``That's the amazing thing about babies,'' said Big Bird. ``One minute they're not here, the next minute they are.'' ``Sesame Street'' reaches 11 million American households and is broadcast in 80 countries. It has been estimated that about half of all American children between ages 3 and 5 watch the show. The show is shot from September through January, and the 22nd season begins airing next January. ``That gives us the opportunity to catch our breath and see where we're going to go from here,'' said Simon. ``There are a lot of characters on the show other than Jim's characters.'' A Walt Disney Co. spokesman said despite Henson's death, Ponce D. Lion and other Muppets will still get a series on the Disney Television Channel, and a 3-D Muppet movie will be produced as planned. Under an agreement signed last summer, the company purchased rights to use Muppet characters in its theme parks, movies, TV shows and retail products.

DOC.HEAD: Nurses Say Short Their Supply Hurting Health Care
DOC.TEXT: A shortage of nurses is hurting the quality of care for patients in the nation's hospitals, according to a readership survey released Thursday by the Federation of Nurses and Health Professionals. Ninety percent of the 1,304 nurses who responded said the shortage is a problem where they work. Nearly three out of four said it has harmed the quality of patient care at their facility, federation officials said. ``They can't get into rooms to take care of patients as fast as they need to,'' because of their patient load and a growing number of non-nursing duties, said Candice Owley, federation vice president. ``They are more apt to make medication errors and other errors,'' in part because they are working long hours because of overtime demands, she said. Owley said she did not know of any deaths that had resulted directly from the shortage, but she said the possibility was there. ``If you are not able to see a change in a monitor or that a respirator is disconected, these patient's lives are on the line and you have to be concerned that this is happening,'' she said. The survey was based on 1,582 responses to a questionnaire that ran in the March issue of the federation's monthly newsletter, Healthwire. Of those responding, 84 percent said they were nurses registered nurses. The rest worked in other health-care jobs. The federation is a division of the American Federation of Teachers. It represents 40,000 health care workers across the country. Federation officials said they had no estimate on the number of nurses needed to alleviate the shortage. The American Hospital Association said more than 10 percent of the budgeted positions for registered nurses were vacant in December 1988. About 1.5 milion registered nurses are employed, said Jewell Gould, research director for the federation. He said Labor Department figures show that an additional 613,000 RNs will be needed by the turn of the century. The additional nurses will be needed because there will be more elderly Americans in the year 2000 than there are now, and they are more prone to needing health care.

DOC.HEAD: Worker Exposes Thumb to Radioactivity; Utility Fined $75,000
DOC.TEXT: Federal regulators said Thursday they have fined a New York utility $75,000, more than the usual amount, for inability to handle non-routine radioactivity brought to light when a worker irradiated his thumb. The fine was imposed by the staff of the Nuclear Regulatory Commission against the New York Power Authority for an incident March 8 at its J.A. Fitzpatrick nuclear plant in Oswego on the shore of Lake Ontario that exposed three workers to radiation. The authority will not contest the penalty, said spokesman Carl Patrick in New York City. The worker was using a radioactive tracer, sodium-24, to measure water flow in a piping system, according to a commission announcement. He became contaminated because he handled the cap on the tracer container with his gloved hand instead of tongs or tweezers, then took off the gloves. His left thumb touched the contaminated gloves, exposing it to an estimated 48.8 rem. Federal regulations limit the exposure of bodily extremities to 18.75 rem every three months. A rem is a unit of radiation dose to humans. Other workers became contaminated to an unspecified lesser extent as they helped decontaminate the first worker, the commission said. Plant managers did not adequately plan and supervise the job, the commission announcement said. The March 8 and earlier incidents ``represent a breakdown in the management control of the radiation safety program at your facility and demonstrate the need for improved planning and control of radiation protection activities, and particularly for those activities involving non-routine, radiologically significant tasks,'' Thomas T. Martin, the commission's regional administrator, said in a letter to the authority. Patrick said the authority has begun to retrain workers and is revising procedures for non-routine tasks. As for the other incidents, Patrick said another employee was contaminated about two years ago when workers were cutting radioactive materials underwater. A piece came out of the water and the worker picked it up, Patrick said. Another exposure occurred when workers failed to notice a piece of radioactive material had floated to the top of the fuel pool, he said.

DOC.HEAD: Social Security Chief Lashes Out at Critics
DOC.TEXT: Social Security Commissioner Gwendolyn King lashed out at congressional critics Thursday for unfairly depicting Social Security as a ``stumbling, inept agency down on its knees.'' ``It bothers me, and it's fair to say it bothers people at Social Security, that we always seem to get dumped on and nobody ever takes the time to say, `You know, that was a good job,''' Mrs. King said. Mrs. King said she welcomed constructive criticism, but worried that unfair reports would undermine confidence in Social Security. ``You're going to get people frightened and concerned about whether the system is going to be there to serve them,'' she said. ``The impression left of a stumbling, inept agency down on its knees is one that really does translate into a real problem for people in the field.'' She said she found it particularly galling that critics in Congress have been soliciting horror stories from Social Security caseworkers. ``You have to look at the big picture and not focus on all the anecdotes that you can muster,'' Mrs. King said. ``Social Security is, across the board, serving people, answering telephones, handling problems and it's amazing to me how well they're doing.'' Mrs. King's comments came in an interview with The Associated Press a day before she was scheduled to testify before the Special Senate Committee on Aging. It was to be another in a string of congressional hearings on service problems at the Social Security Administration. The agency, whose staff was slashed by 20 percent during the Reagan administration, has been faulted for declining service, providing inaccurate information and frequent busy signals on its 800-number telephone network. Mrs. King, who took over the agency in August, said her frustration was aimed not only at Congress. She alluded to negative media coverage of the agency and cited disgruntled employees who come in ``with gripes and criticims that may have been relevant a year ago.'' ``From every sector you will find people zeroing in on a microcosm of problems, anecdoctal in nature and certainly needing fixing,'' Mrs. King said. ``While we care about every single person ... I do have to keep the big picture in mind.'' Mrs. King said the agency had improved its operations over the past year, sharply reduced the busy signals on its 800-number and hired 500 workers to address staffing shortages. A study by the inspector general of the Department of Health and Human Services found a large majority of those surveyed found service helpful and accurate, she said. Mrs. King invited her critics ``to be a part of the solution and not just a part of the griping problem.'' She criticized several legislative proposals, including a bill to separate the Social Security Administration from the HHS. She said another proposal to require that local Social Security phone numbers, not just the 800-number, be listed in telephone books was ``specious'' and ``trite.'' ``Surely the U.S. Congress has more important business to get about,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Noriega Co-Defendant Sentenced to 30 Months
DOC.TEXT: The first of Manuel Noriega's co-defendants to be punished in the drug smuggling case was sentenced Thursday to 30 months in prison, but may only have to serve 15 months. Panamanian pilot Eduardo Pardo has cooperated with the U.S. attorney's office in its investigation of the deposed Panamanian leader, and will continue to do so, his attorney told U.S. District Judge William Hoeveler. Pardo, 44, pleaded guilty in February to one count of illegal travel for flying $800,000 in cocaine profits from Florida to Panama in 1983. Pardo had faced a maximum five-year federal prison sentence and a $10,000 fine. Assistant U.S. Attorney Michael Sullivan recommended leniency for Pardo. He said the defendant had turned over evidence that helped investigators track the movements of other co-defendants, including his flight log. ``We intend to talk to him more,'' Sullivan said. Tears ran down Pardo's face as his attorney, William Meadows, pleaded for probation. Pardo declined an opportunity to speak on his own behalf. He pleaded guilty ``because he knew that he did something wrong,'' Meadows said. ``He was deeply remorseful for it, and he said he has not done anything similar before or since.'' Meadows noted that Pardo had no previous criminal record and surrendered voluntarily to U.S. authorities in Panama City following the Dec. 20 invasion of Panama. Under sentencing guidelines, Pardo would be freed in 20 months, including five already served. But Hoeveler made a point of telling Meadows he would welcome a motion to reduce the sentence if Pardo continued cooperating with investigators. Outside the courtroom, Samuel Burstyn, attorney for co-defendant Luis del Cid, said the sentence would keep Pardo in the United States until after the Noriega trial planned for early next year. Burstyn said the sentence was ``obviously'' aimed at keeping Pardo available to the government. The attorney also revealed that his client, who'd been negotiating a plea bargain, has run into difficulties because Panamanian authorities have said they will not necessarily accept any agreement he makes with U.S. prosecutors. The attorney said he could not reach an agreement with federal prosecutors ``only to have the Panamanians in their zeal seek to extradite him.'' Del Cid, a former top aide to Noriega, is considered the highest-ranking defendant in custody after the former Panamanian leader himself. Noriega, del Cid and Pardo are among 16 people indicted in Miami in February 1988 on charges of taking part in a conspiracy that made Panama a way station and processing center for Colombia's Medellin drug cartel. Pardo and co-defendant Daniel Miranda flew a Lear jet fitted with secret compartments to hide the money, Sullivan told the court in February. Pardo received $40,000 for the flight and knew it was drug money, the prosecutor said. If Pardo testifies for the prosecution, the defendant most immediately threatened by Pardo would appear to be Miranda. Miranda's attorney, Michael O'Kane, has said his client didn't know the money came from drugs, and that Pardo's guilty plea didn't necessarily implicate his client. Noriega is accused of accepting $4.6 million in bribes from the cartel. The Panamanian leader surrendered to U.S. troops after the invasion of his country. He and three of the other defendants are being held in the Metropolitan Correctional Center south of Miami. Miranda and Brian Alden Davidow are out on bond.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Meets Kohl, Says Germany Must Decide Own Future
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, completing a series of pre-summit meetins with allied leaders, said Thursday a united Germany must exercise full control over its territory and not be ``singled out'' by the Soviet Union for special status. Bush, commenting after a meeting with West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl, voiced strong opposition to a Soviet proposal that a reunified Germany be neutral, or a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Kohl, too, said firmly that such matters were up to Germany alone, and he said his nation's choice ``is and will always be'' NATO. It was Bush's final meeting with Western leaders in advance of his May 31-June 3 summit with Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev. In recent weeks, Bush also met with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher, French President Francois Mitterrand and Canadian President Brian Mulroney. The issue of German reunification is expected to be high on the agenda at the Bush-Gorbachev talks. ``Forty-five years after the end of the war, there is no reason that a unified Democratic Germany should be in any way singled out for some special status,'' Bush said outside the White House as he bade farewell to Kohl. For his part, Kohl thanked Bush for the ``magnificent support'' he had given ``Germans on our path to German unity.'' In their formal remarks, neither Bush nor Kohl mentioned the delicate question of the pace of German reunification. At picture-taking session in the Oval Office, Kohl would not predict whether German unity would come before the end of the year _ even though earlier he suggested all-German elections could come as early as Dec. 2. ``Nobody knows that. We know that the people are shouting, `we are the people.' This is why nobody can fix an exact date. But everything's going very well. We can say that,'' he said through a translator. Losses by Kohl's Christian Democratic Party in two West German state elections on Sunday have seen as a reflection of voter uneasiness over his plans for speedy reunification.
