Bush administration officials say question of how quickly reunification proceeds is a matter to be left strictly up to the Germans. Bush said that he and Kohl both agreed that the rights of the four World War II victors _ the United States, the Soviet Union, France and Britain _ should be terminated at the time of German reunification. ``A united Germany should have full control over all of its territory without any new, discriminatory constraints on German sovereignty,'' Bush said. Britain, France and the United States support West Germany's call for a reunified Germany to be part of NATO. But the Soviet Union argues that the new Germany should be neutral, or a member of both NATO and the Warsaw Pact. Both the United States and West Germany ``want a united Germany which enjoys full sovereignty, a united Germany which is a full member of the Western community and of the NATO alliance, including participation in its integrated military structures,'' Bush said. A senior administration official, insisting upon anonymity, said of the West Germans at a White House briefing after the Kohl visit, ``It's absolutely critical ... that we keep in the closest possible touch with them and that was what this meeting was about _ especially immediately in advance of a U.S.-Soviet summit in which the future of Germany will figure prominently.'' In his remarks on the South Lawn of the White House, Bush said he and Kohl agreed that U.S. forces should ``remain stationed in the united Germany and elsewhere in Europe to continue to promote stability and security.'' Kohl said a reunified Germany must remain a member of NATO _ but he urged that the alliance concentrate more in the future on its political role rather than its military one. ``As the threat is decreasing appreciably, the alliance must keep the initiative in the field of disarmament and arms control and review its strategy and structure accordingly,'' he said. He said at a news conference later, ``We do not want a future Germany to have a diminished sovereignty. We do not want any singularization, neutralization or demilitarization of Germany. We do not want a united Germany to be nonaligned, to drift between the two camps.'' Bush and Kohl met privately for an hour, then for another two and a half hours with aides. During the Oval Office picture-taking session, Kohl praised Bush. ``I think it's been rare to find a president in the history of the United States who knows German history and German politics so well as this president. And European politics,'' he said. ``And that of course is a lucky thing for us. And I think that you should write that,'' Kohl told reporters. ``So do I,'' Bush chimed in. Bush and Kohl also discussed arms control, troops in Europe and the situation in the rebellious Soviet republics of Lithuania, Estonia and Latvia, aides said.

DOC.HEAD: Texas Lawmakers List Top 10 Reasons Letterman Should Come to Austin
DOC.TEXT: Borrowing a gimmick from David Letterman's late-night TV show, legislators adopted a resolution Thursday listing 10 reasons why he should broadcast live from Austin to celebrate a theater's 75th anniversary. A regular feature on ``Late Night with David Letterman'' is a top 10 list, read in reverse order, spoofing various topics. The Texas House list reads: ``10. The governor has promised that Mr. Letterman will not be executed during his visit to our state. ``9. No women in Austin currently claim to be married to or even a little bit interested in Mr. Letterman. ``8. No celebrity of Mr. Letterman's magnitude has visited Austin since 1966 when Burgess Meredith arrived in his private Penguin Plane for the world premier of the original Batman movie. ``7. We could have asked Katharine Hepburn to come, but she would have turned us down flat. ``6. A psychic channeler has determined that Mr. Letterman is the unwitting host for the spirit of our late President Lyndon Baines Johnson and that the oil bust will not be over until Dave brings Lyndon home. ``5. A cowboy hat is the only headgear that can fully conceal those pesky defects in Mr. Letterman's coiffure. ``4. The Texas National Guard has agreed to keep Cher and Shirley MacLaine outside the city limits during Mr. Letterman's stay, using excessive force if necessary. ``3. Mr. Letterman will not be required to participate in Spam-A-Rama, Austin's annual tribute to a certain nationally known pink rubberized food product. ``2. During his visit, the city's 750,000 resident bats will perform the world's largest stupid urban bat colony trick by recreating the astrological sign of Mr. Letterman's choice in the skies above Austin. ``1. Throughout his stay, Mr. Letterman will be officially addressed by all Texans as `The Great White Enchilada From Somewhere South of Poughkeepsie.''' The resolution by Rep. Terral Smith invites Letterman to be the Legislature's ``honored guest'' for the Paramount Theatre's 75th anniversary.

DOC.HEAD: Zumwalt Says Much More Defoliant Sprayed Than Recorded
DOC.TEXT: More Agent Orange was sprayed in Vietnam than official records show, a former commander said in a report Thursday that also suggests ``a discernible pattern, if not collaboration,'' to deny veterans compensation. Also, a Veterans Affairs Department panel issued a ruling that brings compensation closer to veterans exposed to the herbicide who suffer from soft-tissue sarcoma, a rare cancer. Admiral Elmo R. Zumwalt Jr., in his report to Veterans Secretary Edward J. Derwinski, said he was certain from his experience that more Agent Orange was spread than recorded. ``Combat units ... frequently conducted `unofficial' sprayings of Agent Orange obtained from out of channel, and thus unrecorded sources.'' said Zumwalt. ``Additionally, as commander, U.S. Naval Forces, Vietnam, I was aware that Agent Orange issued to Allied forces was frequently used on unrecorded missions,'' Zumwalt said in the report. The report, issued May 6, was released Thursday, a day after Zumwalt told an advisory panel to the VA he believes that 28 diseases are linked to Agent Orange exposure. Zumwalt, a special adviser to Derwinski, was recently named to the department's Advisory Committee on Environmental Hazards. The panel on Thursday determined it is as likely as not that a significant association exists between soft-tissue sarcoma and Agent Orange exposure. Derwinski is to decide by June whether to award disability payments to veterans with that disease. Derwinski decided in March that all Vietnam veterans with non-Hodgkin's lymphoma should be compensated. The advisory committee in August will examine studies relating dioxin and herbicide exposure to a skin disease known as chloracne, and a metabolic disorder known as porphyrea cutanea tarda. The two reports make it likely that veterans will be compensated for soft-tissue sarcoma. VA spokesman Bonner Day said the department had no figure on how many Agent Orange claimants said they have soft-tissue sarcoma. Zumwalt's report said the herbicide was used in strengths far in excess of that suggested by the manufacturers. The makers have settled a class-action lawsuit brought by afflicted veterans. He also criticizes government actions and studies on Agent Orange, including the activities of the advisory panel. His broadsides backed up claims by veterans who have been trying to get compensation for more than a decade and who claim the government has had to be pushed to move and has ignored evidence supporting links between Agent Orange and cancers. ``Were the faulty conclusions, faulty methodology and noticeable bias of the advisory committee an isolated problem, correcting the misdirection would be more manageable,'' Zumwalt wrote. ``But, experience with other governmental agencies responsible for ... analyzing and studying the effects of exposure to Agent Orange strongly hints at a discernible pattern, if not outright governmental collaboration, to deny compensation to Vietnam veterans for disabilities associated with exposure to dioxin.'' Committee chairman Oliver Meadows said he would not comment on the Zumwalt report. Zumwalt ordered the spraying of the defoliant in Vietnam and lost a son, a Vietnam veteran, to a cancer linked to Agent Orange exposure. About 12 million gallons of the herbicide, which contained cancer-causing dioxin, was sprayed from 1965 to 1970, according to records. Zumwalt said, however, ``a significant, if not major source of exposure was from non-recorded, non-Ranch Hand operations.'' Ranch Hand was the name for the aircraft spraying operation. ``Evidence readily suggests that at the time experts knew that Agent Orange was harmful to military personnel,'' he said. Zumwalt said that in addition to removing enemy cover and destroying crops, the herbicide was sprayed to clear vegetation around military installations, landing zones, fire base camps and trails.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Statehood Bill Introduced
DOC.TEXT: Sens. Edward Kennedy and Paul Simon introduced a bill Thursday that would grant statehood to the District of Columbia, beginning what Kennedy predicted would be ``a difficult uphill struggle.'' ``The measure we are introducing is not new, but it is overdue,'' said Kennedy, a Massachusetts Democrat who backed two previous statehood bills that died without votes being taken. ``No one doubts this will be a difficult uphill struggle, but we are committed to the effort,'' he said. Jesse Jackson, an ardent advocate of statehood, joined Kennedy and Simon, an Illinois Democrat, at a news conference announcing the bill. Mayor Marion Barry did not attend. Barry is scheduled to go on trial next month on charges of drug possession and perjury. Kennedy, referring to President Bush's recent suggestion that the city could be given the compromise benefit of voting rights in Congress, said statehood was the only acceptable goal. ``Part-way measures and half-hearted initiatives do not satisfy the basic principle of self-determination,'' Kennedy said. ``The people of the District of Columbia deserve their full rights.'' Del. Walter Fauntroy, who has introduced similar legislation in the House, said the city's negative image would hurt the statehood drive. ``Many members are concerned about letters they are receiving, complaining about the mayor and the crime rate,'' Fauntroy said. ``But they will not be an insurmountable obstacle.''

DOC.HEAD: Typhoon Leaves 9 Dead, $160 Million Damage in Eastern Siberia
DOC.TEXT: A typhoon swept through eastern Siberia, killing nine people and destroying about 700 homes, the official news agency Tass reported Thursday. The storm Wednesday ravaged hundreds of thousands of miles in the Irkutsk region about 2,500 miles east of Moscow, causing an estimated $160 million worth of damage, Tass said. The weather in the region had been extremely hot and dry for days beforehand, and high winds from the typhoon _ rare for the area _ destroyed buildings, left hundreds homeless and caused numerous fires, the news agency said. It did not specify where the typhoon originated or how and where the people died. Tass said firefighting teams managed to bring the blazes under control after several hours.

DOC.HEAD: Demonstrators Mob Bucharest During Last Official Campaigning
With AM-Romania-Politics, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: About 70,000 backers of interim President Ion Iliescu rallied Thursday on the last official day of the election campaign, but tens of thousands of demonstrators elsewhere branded him a ``neo-Communist.'' The pro-Iliescu crowd, some chanting ``We Love You, Iliescu,'' massed in north Bucharest. They heard their candidate pledge to keep Romania democratic. An estimated 30,000 anti-Iliescu demonstrators converged on University Square in downtown Bucharest. It was the largest crowd yet in a demonstration that has blocked the square and the capital's main central thoroughfare 24 hours a day since April 22. However, a feared mass confrontation between the two groups did not materialize. Police quickly broke up fistfights among about a dozen people from the rival groups. One government backer was detained. Iliescu and his National Salvation Front have dominated the government since the December revolution that deposed Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. They are heavily favored in Sunday's presidential and parliamentary elections, Romania's first free poll in 53 years. Iliescu and two challengers for the presidency _ the National Liberal Party's Radu Campeanu and the National Peasants Party's Ion Ratiu _ held the nation's first-ever televised debate between presidential candidates Thursday night. The two opposition candidates repeated their charges that the Front was responsible for violence that has plagued their campaigns. The Peasants Party claims 60 attacks against its supporters, including two fatal assaults. Iliescu said it was ``inconceivable that the Front, which led the government charged with maintaining a peaceful campaign, would also disrupt it.'' Asked about the possibility of a coalition government after the elections, Iliescu said it was ``not only possible but necessary.'' Campeanu called it ``a logical idea.'' The debate failed to generate heated exchanges between the candidates, who repeated campaign speeches they used in previous weeks. Addressing his supporters earlier Thursday at Aviators' Square in north Bucharest, Iliescu pledged to ``guarantee the future of democracy'' in Romania. The stage was surrounded by scores of guards who were barely able to keep the boisterous demonstrators from rushing the stage as they sang, ``May Ratiu and Campeanu Die of Sorrow.'' ``In five short months, we have presented a solid record of achievement,'' declared Premier Petre Roman, flashing the ``V'' sign that has become his trademark. The capital's anti-government protestors were joined by groups of students from western Timisoara and other cities. Timisoara is where the December revolution began. The anti-government demonstrators, who paralyzed traffic in the capital, vowed to stay put until election day, despite a ban on political rallies Friday and Saturday. Last Saturday, Iliescu said the square should be ``cleaned out'' after Thursday. But Roman said Wednesday the government had decided to allow the demonstrators to remain to avoid a ``provocation.'' The demonstrators charge that Iliescu and the Front still harbor Communist and totalitarian tendencies. Iliescu and some other members of the Front once held positions in the toppled Communist regime. The opposition backers also accuse the Front of manipulating state-run media to its political advantage.

DOC.HEAD: University Developing Walking Robot for NASA
LaserPhoto covering; LaserGraphic
DOC.TEXT: It doesn't think like C-3PO or R2D2, but this robot can amble along the rocky surfaces of Mars or the moon as well as any ``Star Wars'' machine did in a galaxy far, far away. Scientists at Carnegie Mellon University unveiled the prototype Thursday. Nicknamed the ``Ambler'' by the team that has been working on it since October 1987, the aluminum robot stands 12 feet tall and has paired stacks of three legs that enable it to traverse uneven terrain. ``A walking robot was needed as an alternative to the traditional line of wheeled rovers,'' said David B. Lavery, manager of the Planetary Rovers program at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. ``What we want to do is demonstrate that legged vehicles ... have an acceptable place,'' he said. ``I think the Ambler has successfully done that.'' William L. Whittaker, one of three Carnegie Mellon robotics experts heading the project, said the robot moves like a cross-country skier. ``A single leg reaches out in front of the others, places itself firmly on the ground like a ski pole and then pulls the machine forward,'' he said. Robots using Ambler technology are slated for use in a series of mechanized missions to Mars, Lavery said. He estimated walking robots could be on the Martian surface by the end of the decade. President Bush last week set a deadline of 2019 for Americans to walk on Mars. The date is 50 years after Neil Armstrong, Michael Collins and Buzz Aldrin first landed on the moon. The Ambler, which recently took its first steps, is one project being evaluated by the NASA rovers program, Lavery said. The other projects under consideration are all wheeled rovers, he said. ``The intent for the vehicles ... is for them to be capable of operating on their own with just a very general set of directions,'' he said. That objective has been met in the Ambler, according to Takeo Kanade, Whittaker's associate. ``Our goal is basically to demonstrate that actual exploration of planets is possible,'' Kanade said. The Ambler has the ability to assess its environment, make decisions, move and interact with or manipulate objects, he said. ``The Ambler is one of very few systems that embody all four capabilities,'' he said. Kanade, who serves as co-director of Carnegie Mellon's Robotics Institute, said the Ambler prototype will never go into space. But the robot's technology should be ready for space flight within a decade. Meantime, Kanade envisions other uses for the technology. ``It's not just the very narrow, kind of strange applications of space exploration. It has a very broad impact,'' he said. Independent walking robots designed to adapt to a variety of environments could be used for construction projects on the moon and to clean up hazardous waste on Earth, he said. ``These machines will have to contend with rugged and soft terrain, low temperatures, high winds, dust and equipment failure,'' Kanade said. ``These are robots that work in environments that are not traditionally designed for robots. ``The impact of this kind of program is phenomenal.'' Kanade said the university has spent $4.5 million in NASA grants to develop the Ambler.

DOC.HEAD: Nepal's King Orders Release of Political Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: King Birendra on Thursday announced a general amnesty for political prisoners in the Himalayan kingdom, most of whom were jailed for violating a ban on political parties. A statement from the palace said the king made the decision on the advice of Prime Minister Krishna Prasad Bhattarai, who took office last month after a two-month campaign for greater democracy. Political prisoners were arrested under the Association and Organization Control Act, a 1961 law that banned membership to political parties or any other political affiliation. The law was taken off the books last month in this nation of 17 million residents, a week before leaders of the pro-democracy movement formed the government. Chief government spokesman Radhey Shyam Bista said the number of prisoners detained under the act was ``being worked out.'' He declined to give a rough estimate. The pro-democracy movement broke the monarch's 29-year-old grip on power in Nepal. Previously, the Cabinet was chosen from a partyless National Assembly. One-fifth of the assembly's 140 members were nominated by the king and, political observers say, candidates for the other posts were screened by the palace before being allowed to stand for elections. The leaders of the pro-democracy movement have promised to hold free elections by next April and say they will reform the present constitution, which gives the king sweeping legislative, executive and judicial powers.

DOC.HEAD: African President Says Leaders Are Not Beggars
DOC.TEXT: President Abdou Diouf of Senegal said Thursday people should get rid of the idea that African leaders come to the United States begging for money. ``That is not my case,'' he told reporters. He was replying to a questioner who suggested he was leaving empty-handed after talking with President Bush and leaders of his administration. Diouf asked Bush for more help when he visited the White House Monday. White House press secretary Marlin Fitzwater reported Bush said he was sympathetic but could not promise anything beyond the $40 million a year Senegal has been getting. Diouf said he came to reaffirm links with the United States, the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund. And he said he had ample success and nothing to complain about. He said it would be better to have more help, but it was wrong to think that African presidents came to Washington just to pack their valises with aid. Diouf spoke at length of the monument to be erected at Almadies, Africa's westernmost point, in memory of slaves put aboard ships in Senegal for sale in North America in past centuries. He said the statue was not meant to show anger but as a symbol of a common desire to end violence and alienation among peoples.

DOC.HEAD: Baker to See Lithuanian Leader While Summit Arrangements Lag
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout with new quotes, background
DOC.TEXT: Secretary of State James A. Baker III, venturing into sensitive pre-summit diplomacy, said Thursday he would meet in Moscow Friday with the prime minister of the rebellious Soviet republic of Lithuania. Baker informed Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard A. Shevardnadze of the decision as they tried to break a deadlock on arms control issues less than two weeks before the Washington summit. ``There are gaps between us still. ... I can't tell you we are going to get there,'' a senior U.S. official said of Baker's attempt to forge an agreement on nuclear weapons cuts before President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev hold their May 31-June 3 talks. Bush said Wednesday that the Soviets' action against Lithuania ``certainly puts some tension'' on summit prospects, but he also said it would not stand in the way of any arms agreement. Gorbachev met Thursday with Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene in his first such meeting with a top Lithuanian official since the Baltic republic declared independence. Even so, the senior U.S. official insisted the Soviets had not fulfilled the Bush administration's call for them to take part in a dialogue with the Baltic leaders. ``It is not enough simply to talk about a need for dialogue,'' the official said. ``You have to do something that makes it happen. And they are continuing to stick to a position that accepts dialogue but only under certain conditions.'' Mrs. Prunskiene and other leaders of the republic have said they are willing to negotiate everything except their independence declaration. The senior U.S. official said Baker, who was planning to fly home at midday Saturday, would stay on for further talks with the Soviets if there was a chance of an accord on nuclear arms control. He is due to see Gorbachev Friday. ``The work is intense right now,'' said the official, who briefed reporters under rules guaranteeing him anonymity. Baker told Shevardnadze that he would see Mrs. Prunskiene and ``his reaction was a non-reaction,'' the official said. Gorbachev has demanded that Lithuania revoke its March 11 declaration of independence, but on Thursday asked merely for a suspension, Mrs. Prunskiene told reporters. Tensions in the Baltics and the stalemate on arms control issues were hindering Baker's effort to set a summit agenda with Shevardnadze. But symbolically, at least, they showed a spirit of cooperation. Shevardnadze took Baker on a tour of a Russian Orthodox church complex at Zagorsk, 45 miles northeast of the capital, and to the nearby village of Radonezh. The 24-car motorcade stopped at the modest home of a 76-year-old Russian woman who engaged Baker and Shevardnadze in a discussion of her pension, raised recently from 55 to 70 rubles a month _ the equivalent of about $40. ``It will be increased,'' Shevardnadze promised. Another elderly woman, wearing a purple scarf, told Baker the village church was closed ``and we have no place to pray.'' Appeals to authorities had not succeeded, she said. Shevardnadze told Baker afterward that the church would be reopened, a U.S. official said. When Baker arrived in Moscow Tuesday from Washington, the request from Mrs. Prunskiene for a meeting was given to him by U.S. Ambassador Jack F. Matlock Jr. ``We are not seeking to send any message by meeting with her,'' the senior U.S. official said. ``It obviously gives us a chance to hear more about her concerns.'' Mrs. Prunskiene has met in Washington with Bush. Still, the meeting with Baker here in Moscow, amid summit preparations, added a twist to the situation. Baker has already informed the Soviets that failure to resolve the dispute with the Baltics could interfere with an improvement in U.S.-Soviet relations at the summit. On the arms control front, meanwhile, Baker said Thursday he had not made much headway in bending the Soviet Union to U.S. positions on strategic weapons cuts. But Baker said he was still hopeful. He and Shevardnadze met twice during the day, for 45 minutes in the morning and for nearly five hours after their sightseeing venture. Baker's main goal is to bring the Soviets in line with the United States on air and sea-launched cruise missiles. That would break a stalemate and clear the way for a declaration at the superpower summit in Washington in two weeks. Asked if he had made headway, Baker told reporters: ``No, not a lot.'' But later, leaving the Trinity Monastery in Zagorsk, a monument to medieval Russia, Baker was a bit more upbeat. ``We hope we've made some progress. We'll know more when we get back,'' he said. The tour of the center of Russian Orthodoxy was arranged by Shevardnadze to give Baker some flavor of life outside Moscow. The church, even in stricter times, has enjoyed special privileges in a state that theoretically, at least, is atheistic. Baker and Shevardnadze met with church leaders, examined ornate icons, and weaved their way past mostly elderly women saying their prayers and lighting candles. While they motored back, Gennady Gerasimov, the spokesman for the Soviet Foreign Ministry, held a briefing in which he sidestepped questions about possible compromises in the U.S. and Soviet positions. Still, Gerasimov, to illustrate Soviet determination to reach an agreement, quoted Shevardnadze as jokingly telling his arms control negotiators: ``If you don't agree, you will be fired.''

DOC.HEAD: Sandinistas End Strike That Crippled Nicaragua
LaserPhoto MGA3
DOC.TEXT: An estimated 150,000 government employees returned to work Thursday, ending a weeklong strike that savaged Nicaragua's already crippled economy and hamstrung the new, U.S.-backed administration. The huge walkouts were a victory for the leftist Sandinista National Liberation Front, which engineered the strikes beginning Friday to press for job security and big pay increases. The 3-week-old government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro promised not to fire those who walked off their jobs and agreed to double salaries for the public employees as part of the strike settlement. That was about half what the Sandinista-dominated unions originally asked but higher than the 60 percent Mrs. Chamorro initially offered. She has devalued the cordoba, Nicaragua's currency, four times since she took office April 25; inflation however is averaging 70 percent monthly, in effect steadily reducing the real wages of workers in this nation of 3.5 million residents. ``Everything is returning to normal. Employees at the banking system cleared out the offices they had occupied and those at the ministries are following suit,'' presidential spokesman Danilo Lacayo said in a telephone interview. The international airport reopened and the bus system was getting back into gear. In Washington, President Bush complained that a procedural deadlock in Congress was holding up a $300 million aid package for Nicaragua and that he could not disburse $40 million in emergency help requested by Mrs. Chamorro until the package is approved. Alejandro Solorzano, a labor leader who supports Mrs. Chamorro, said the strike more resembled an attempt by the Sandinistas to bring down the new government than a job action. ``The strike was managed directly by a few leaders of the Sandinista Front. It was an attempted coup, carried out by adventurers and holdup men who checkmated the government,'' Solorzano said. ``The government will have to strengthen itself to prevent another coup attempt by the Sandinistas.'' Solorzano is secretary-general of the Federation of Independent Workers, a branch of the Socialist Party that forms part of Mrs. Chamorro's coalition. Barricada, the Sandinista party newspaper, ran an editorial calling the strike a triumph for the workers and for democracy. ``An attempt to overrun legality and flirting with totalitarianism almost set off a blood bath in the country and the conflict would have been aggravated if the government had resorted to repressive force,'' it said. The strike in Central America's largest country had been stepped up daily since May 10. Central Bank President Francisco Mayorga estimated it cost the government $10 million in lost production and revenues. The government budget had planned for eventual raises similar to those granted, but because of the strike they had to be granted sooner than planned, Mayorga said. The banker said Nicaragua is counting on the Conference of Donors for help. The organization of industrialized, mostly European nations aids Third World nations. It meets in Rome June 6-7. The country's cash crisis was deepened by U.S. failure to provide the emergency aid Mrs. Chamorro asked. The Chamorro administration inherited from the Sandinistas a paltry $3 million in cash at the treasury and a foreign debt of $11 billion. Inflation is chronic _ prices for consumer goods and services have been skyrocketing, changing in some cases daily. Public employees earn from as little as $10 to $12 a month for a cleaning woman to $350 a month for the deputy manager of a state-operated bank. U.S. officials said meanwhile the administration was getting ready to provide a month's worth of food for 14,000 rebels whose supplies are running out, taking $1 million to $1.5 million from aid programs to other countries. The United States supported the rebels, known as Contras, in their guerrilla war against the former Sandinista government, which came to power in 1979. Despite a plan to gradually disband the rebels, hostility remains strong between the Sandinistas and the Contras after 10 years of warfare. Nicaraguan and U.S. officials are worried about renewed conflict if the rebels leave the safety of security zones set up for them. Mrs. Chamorro overwhelmingly won elections on Feb. 25 for a six-year term. But her United National Opposition, a 14-party coalition, is fragmented and ranges from Communists to hard-line conservatives. Former President Daniel Ortega's Sandinistas, with 40 percent of the vote, remain Nicaragua's largest single party. Ortega said the Sandinistas will ``continue to govern from below.'' The Sandinista insist that the Contras disband by June 10 as they promised. Ortega's people continue their control of the military and demand that Mrs. Chamorro not touch their revolutionary reforms.

DOC.HEAD: Hungary Caretaker Gov't Ends Last Cabinet Session With Champagne
DOC.TEXT: Hungary's caretaker government of Premier Miklos Nemeth held its final Cabinet session Thursday, then invited reporters in for a farewell glass of champagne. Outgoing government spokesman Zsolt Bajnok said the Cabinet reviewed the country's economic peformance for the first three months of 1990, and concluded that generally positive trends have been dampened by rising unemployment. ``If the trend continues at this rate, we will have 100,000 unemployed by the end of the year,'' Bajnok said. Nemeth took over as Hungarian premier 16 months ago, when Hungary was still ruled by the Communist Party. He and his government oversaw a peaceful transition to multiparty democracy and free elections last March in which Nemeth and other reform communists united in a new Socialist party fared poorly, finishing fourth. ``The Nemeth team did what it had accepted to do with honor,'' Bajnok said. Nemeth, 42, and his team leave the incoming center-right government of Joszef Antall with 59 draft laws, the task of transforming Hungary's economy and repaying its large $20 billion foreign debt. The premier, who was elected to the new Parliament, told reporters he plans to rest over the summer before deciding whether to continue his career as a politician or pursue his trained profession of economist.

DOC.HEAD: Bright & Brief
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Restores AP logo in first item. The first item also moved on sports wires.
DOC.TEXT: Fans who pointed their binoculars in the right direction during the seventh inning of Tuesday's Toronto Blue Jays-Seattle Mariners game got an inside look at another event. Under the glare of ballpark lights, a naked man and towel-clad woman framed in the window of their darkened hotel room above the SkyDome scoreboard were clearly enjoying themselves. ``I never suspected in my wildest dreams that someone would be doing it right in front of the window,'' said Jays president Paul Beeston. We ``would take the position that it is a public place and that such behavior should not be condoned,'' Beeston said. SkyDome spokesman David Garrick said the couple should have been charged. But Police Det. Paul Feeney said that before a charge of public indecency can be laid there has to be evidence of intent to offend. ``In this case, they could argue that there was a reasonable expectation of privacy,'' said Feeney. Six weeks ago, a man who was caught performing an indecent act in front of a window at the hotel wasn't charged because he thought it was one-way glass and that he couldn't be seen. ``How our guests behave behind closed doors, unless they are committing a crime, is none of our business,'' said SkyDome Hotel manager Ray Thompson. However, Thompson said he is considering asking guests to sign a waiver of liability.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto MP2
DOC.TEXT: Local billboards are featuring a picture of Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev on an ad for a Minnesota-made vodka with the caption ``The Party's Over,'' an allusion to the loss of power by the Communist Party. But the party is just beginning for the Twin Cities, where Gorbachev plans to visit June 3 following his summit meeting with President Bush. Partner Gerry Schmitt of Minneapolis ad agency Schmitt & Sloan, which created the billboard ad, is elated over news of Gorbachev's impending visit. ``We think he's coming to see us,'' she said Tuesday. ``The stories say he's coming to see some undisclosed company. We think we're the one.'' Gorbachev may get to see his likeness on the 38 billboards promoting Karkov vodka. Scmitt said the billboards will stay up until mid-June. The company hopes Gorbachev sees one of them, said Felix Phillips, lawyer for U.S. Distilled Products Co., which makes the vodka in Princeton and markets it in several states. ``We'd be very happy if he climbed up and signed one,'' Phillips said. Ad agency partner Jeff Sloan said artists intentionally put the Soviet president's birthmark on the wrong side of his head in the ad to make it more noticeable from the viewer's perspective.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Gorbachev Receives Lithuanian in Major Break in Deadlock
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with quotes from Lithuanian Prime Minister; Baker to meet her Friday, other. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto VIL2
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev met with the Lithuanian prime minister on Thursday in a major breakthrough in the Baltic secession struggle, but he demanded the breakaway republic make further concessions. Lithuanian Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene said they met for one hour and 40 minutes in the Kremlin, and that Gorbachev told her ``the fact that we are meeting means we have moved from our initial positions. And this is a big step forward.'' She told reporters the discussion was ``difficult'' at first, but improved as it went along, though complete agreement was not reached. Gorbachev had refused to meet with the secessionist leaders of the three Baltics republics and earlier in the day accused them of adventurism. The Kremlin meeting, set by Gorbachev in a telephone call to Mrs. Prunskiene shortly after she arrived at Lithuania's mission in Moscow, broke the deadlock between Moscow and Lithuania over Lithuania's declaration of independence on March 11. Soviet authorities forcibly annexed Lithuania and its sister republics of Estonia and Latvia in 1940, and all three have declared moves toward independence this year. U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III, who had said that the Baltic impasse was casting a shadow over the May 30-June 3 superpower summit in Washington, told reporters he would meet with Mrs. Prunskiene on Friday. President Bush received her at the White House earlier this month. Gorbachev first demanded that Lithuania rescind its declaration, but on Thursday merely called for a suspension. The Lithuanian parliament has balked at revoking the declaration but on Wednesday voted to suspend post-independence laws if the Kremlin will open talks on independence. A compromise appeared to be emerging along the lines of a formula proposed last month by President Francois Mitterrand of France and Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany. In addition to suspending certain laws, Lithuanian concessions add a transition period before full independence and make concrete proposals on military cooperation, economic plans and other topics. Mrs. Prunskiene said Lithuanian President Vytautas Landsbergis would call the Supreme Council parliament into session on Saturday to formalize the offer. She said if Moscow finds parliament's action acceptable, the two sides could select negotiating teams. ``This does not mean we are returning to the situation of March 10,'' she told reporters, underlining Lithuania's determination to strive for independence. At the meeting, Gorbachev and Prime Minister Nikolai Ryzhkov told Mrs. Prunskiene the Lithuanian concessions did not meet their demand to suspend the Lithuanian declaration of independence, the official Tass news agency reported. ``K. Prunskiene's attention was drawn to the indispensable necessity that the Lithuanian Supreme Soviet cancel _ or at a minimum, suspend _ this act and all the legislative measures following it that contradict the Soviet constitution,'' Tass reported. The leaders told Mrs. Prunskiene that concession was the only way to launch negotiations, the report said. But Tass said the leaders noted that the Lithuanian offer showed ``certain steps had been made toward the normalization of the situation.'' ``Prunskiene called the meeting `an introduction to coming negotiations,''' said Longinas Vasiliauskas, press attache of the Lithuanian representation in Moscow. Earlier Thursday, Gorbachev lashed out at what he called the ``adventurism'' of Baltic independence leaders. ``A constructive approach is needed. We will not permit any violation of the constitution or any division from the constitutional process,'' Gorbachev told Britain's Channel 4 television at a Moscow parliamentary meeting. ``I believe that the Lithuanian leadership and some others cannot get rid of adventurism,'' he said in a separate session with foreign journalists. Mrs. Prunskiene came to the Soviet capital Thursday evening. She said her republic of 3.8 million people was willing to make another major concession, agreeing to remain part of the Soviet security system. Concessions approved by the Lithuanian parliament Wednesday would ``stop unilateral action for realizing the declaration of .. . independence for the Lithunian government, especially in those spheres most important to the Soviet Union, most of all, defense and borders,'' she told reporters. But she said Lithuania would stand fast on the declaration itself. ``The declaration of independence is active and is not a subject for discussion or negotiations,'' she said. Gorbachev has rejected Lithuania's declaration of independence and attempts at more gradual secession by Estonia and Latvia. He imposed an oil and natural gas embargo and other ecomomic sanctions on Lithuania, causing some businesses there to close and thousands of workers to be laid off. Soviet military officials are concerned by the refusal of Lithuanian youths to serve in the Soviet Armed Forces, and by prospects they would lose access to the Baltic ports of Klaipeda and Kaliningrad, accessible by land only across Lithuanian territory. Mrs. Prunskiene said the military compromise would involve ``participation of Lithuania in the defense system of the Soviet Union.'' She gave no details. Mrs. Prunskiene said negotiators must resolve hundreds of issues before a final deal is cut with Moscow. Latvian Deputy Prime Minister Ilmars Bisers said Wednesday that talks on Baltic independence would start next week with midlevel Kremlin officials. He said talks with Soviet officials would focus on ``the gaining of independence on the basis of a treaty with the Soviet Union.''

DOC.HEAD: Chinese Leader Says Tianamen Uproar `Much Ado About Nothing'
DOC.TEXT: The leader of China's Communist Party says the West's anger over last year's crackdown on the pro-democracy movement in his country was ``much ado about nothing.'' Jiang Zemin also told ABC-TV's ``20-20'' program that he had no regrets about the way the June demonstrations in Beijing's Tiananmen Square were handled. Troops opened fire, killing hundreds of protesters. But, he told Barbara Walters, Chinese leaders ``learn by our mistakes'' so similar demonstrations may be handled with non-lethal force. ``We have made adequate preparations in terms of strengthening the police force and storing of non-lethal weapons,'' he said. ``In this regard, I'm ready to learn from all the developed Western countries.'' The interview, to be aired Friday night, is apparently the first Jiang has granted a foreign television reporter since he was named general secretary of the Communist Party in June after the Tiananmen Square crackdown. Jiang also hold his government's top two military posts. He replaced Zhao Ziyang, who was deposed for supporting the pro-democracy movement, and was the handpicked successor of the country's supreme leader Deng Xiaoping, who resigned last year from all his official posts at the age of 84. Jiang agreed to the interview as the Bush administration neared a deadline on deciding whether to extend trade concessions to China. President Bush, who suspended military cooperation with China to protest Tiananmen, has until June 3 to decide whether to extend China's most-favored-nation status by one year. The status, granted to most U.S. trading partners, reduces tariffs significantly on imports. Bush told reporters Wednesday that while he didn't want to send a signal to Beijing that he approves of the government's human rights record, removing most-favored-nation status would adversely affect Hong Kong, the British colony that funnels 70 percent of China's exports to the United States. Jiang warned that revoking China's trade concessions would ``work against the interests of our two countries'' and those of the entire southeast Asian region. ``I hope that the U.S. government would consider this matter from a long-term perspective,'' he said. Jiang said that after last year's demonstrations, there was ``some kind of misunderstanding, lack of understanding, or even not-so-friendly attitudes'' toward China. ``Therefore, to give you a Chinese proverb, I would say it's like `much ado about nothing,''' he said. In a rare glimpse of the internal workings of China's secretive leadership, Jiang said ``there were different opinions within the top Chinese leadership, and that was the crucial point'' in the decision to resort to lethal force to quell the protest. Jiang said that if at the start of the student unrest in April 1989, ``we adopted resolute measures, for example by declaring a ban on assembly in Tiananmen Square, then it would have been easier for us to deal with the problem at a later stage.'' As mayor of Shanghai at the time, Jiang said, he had dealt with protesters there by persuasion rather than force. Jiang said no protesters were executed as a direct result of the Tiananmen events. China's official press reported 20 executions. He said 431 people, including 42 students, were still in detention. According to unofficial estimates, 10,000 to 15,000 people were detained after the protests. China announced last week that it had released 211 prisoners, including several prominent academics. Jiang said that despite the fall of communism in Eastern Europe, China would not tolerate any opposition to socialism and would combat ``bourgeois liberalization.'' But, he added, China is not opposed to everything about capitalism. ``We want to learn from the know-how and even buy know-how from Western countries,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Most State Charges Against Leona Helmsley Dropped
DOC.TEXT: A tax fraud indictment against Leona Helmsley was gutted Thursday by a judge who said state prosecutors were putting the self-styled hotel queen in double jeopardy. State Supreme Court Justice John Bradley said he dropped 180 of the 188 counts in the indictment because they are similar to those on which Mrs. Helmsley was tried in federal court last August. ``The court threw out the heart and soul of the state's case,'' said Alan Dershowitz, lead lawyer of Mrs. Helmsley's legal team. ``New evidence will demonstrate that Mrs. Helmsley did not evade taxes.'' ``I'm very happy,'' Mrs. Helmsley, 70, said tearfully as she left court after hearing Bradley's ruling. She suggested that the case against her was brought only because of her prominence. ``They're after my hide,'' she said. ``I'm Leona Helmsley.'' ``I hold my head high because I know that I am an innocent person falsely accused and terribly maligned,'' she said. The federal case related solely to Dunellen Hall, the Helmsley's mansion in Greenwich, Conn. The Helmsleys were charged with furnishing, renovating and operating the estate by charging its expenses to their businesses. Mrs. Helmsley was sentenced to four years in prison and fined $7.1 million in the federal case. She is appealing the conviction and sentence, maintaining that she in fact overpaid her taxes. Her husband, real estate billionaire Harry Helmsley, 80, was found incompetent to stand trial in the federal case. He is trying to avoid a state trial on on similar grounds. He has been examined by a psychiatrist, according to Leslie Gersing of the state attorney general's office, and a hearing on the exam results is scheduled for May 23 before Bradley. The dropped charges are counts of conspiracy, offering a false instrument for filing, falsifying business records, and scheme to defraud, all of which relate to Dunellen Hall and were dealt with in the federal case. The state charges involved Dunellen Hall as well as a condominium in North Hills, N.Y., and the Park Lane Hotel, the Helmsleys' New York City home. The judge let stand the eight counts that did not involve the Connecticut estate. He noted that the alleged state tax fraud conspiracy preceded and outlasted the federal conspiracy. Bradley refused a defense request to dismiss the remaining eight charges ``in the interest of justice.'' He said the impact of such an act on public confidence would be ``devastating.'' The charges that remain are counts of offering a false instrument for filing, a felony. Each count is punishable by up to four years in prison. Gersing, the state attorney general's spokeswoman, said one of the eight charges relate to Mrs. Helmsley's personal taxes and the others involve Helmsley businesses. She observed that Bradley dismissed the charges on principles of law, not on the merits of the allegations. Gersing said prosecutors were studying the Bradley decision and had not decided whether to appeal.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Demands Proof of Bodies Before Hostage Swap
DOC.TEXT: An Israeli defense official said Thursday that Israel is seeking proof a Lebanese Shiite militia is holding the bodies of two Israeli soldiers before considering swapping Moslem prisoners for the remains. Such an exchange with the mainstream Amal militia could encourage more releases of Western hostages held in Lebanon by pro-Iranian radicals. There are now 16 Western hostages, including six Americans. The Israeli official, who conveyed an official position though he spoke on condition of anonymity, was reacting to an Amal proposal reported by the Beirut daily Al Anwar on May 12. According to the report, Amal was ready to hand over the bodies of two Israeli servicemen killed in south Lebanon in exchange for the release of Shiite prisoners. After two U.S. hostages were freed last month, Iran and allied groups in Lebanon demanded a goodwill gesture, such as the release of prisoners held by the Israel-backed South Lebanon Army. The mostly Christian, 2,500-member militia holds more than 300 prisoners at al-Khiam prison in south Lebanon. Last week, South Lebanon Army commander Gen. Antoine Lahad rebuffed appeals to make prisoner releases solely to help Western hostages. He said three captured Israeli soldiers and missing militiamen from his army must be part of any deal. The Israeli official said Israel had no information about Amal holding any bodies of Israeli soldiers. Most of the seven Israeli servicemen missing in Lebanon are believed to be in the hands of radical Iranian-backed or Palestinian groups. ``If Amal believes the bodies are those of Israeli soldiers, let it first submit evidence to this effect. Only after we are convinced the bodies are in fact those of Israeli soldiers will there be room to negotiate the matter.'' Longest held of the 16 Western hostages is American Terry A. Anderson, chief Middle East correspondent for The Associated Press, kidnapped March 16, 1985.

DOC.HEAD: Marlon Brando's Eldest Son Arrested Following Shooting at Estate
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 2nd graf to UPDATE with police saying arraignment will take place Friday. CORRECTS victim's name to Drollet, sted Dorlett, throughout.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Brando Shooting-Turmoil
DOC.TEXT: Marlon Brando's eldest son told police he shot and killed his pregnant sister's boyfriend in a fit of rage because the man had beaten her, investigators said Thursday. Christian Brando, 32, was arrested in the actor's palatial Santa Monica Mountains estate Wednesday night and booked for investigation of murder, said Lt. Ron Hall. He was held without bail pending arraignment Friday. ``He admitted to the shooting,'' the lieutenant said. Dag Drollet, 26, died instantly from a .45-caliber bullet to the head, police said. An autopsy was planned for Friday, said coroner's office spokesman Bob Dambacher. Marlon Brando, 66, made a 911 emergency call to police at about 10:45 p.m. to report a shooting inside his estate, police said. Only one shot was fired. ``The dispute was over the victim's treatment of Cheyenne Brando, Marlon Brando's 20-year-old daughter,'' Hall said. ``There were allegations that there was physical abuse, a beating. There was an argument and he became angry.'' Tarita Cheyenne is the daughter of Brando and his current wife, Tarita Teriipia, a Tahitian actress who played his love in the 1962 remake of ``Mutiny on the Bounty.'' A Brando lawyer said the daughter was ``pretty well along'' in her pregnancy but declined to be more specific or identify the father. After police and paramedics arrived at the gated estate overlooking Beverly Hills, Drollet's body was found in what was described as an entertainment room. Hall said Christian Brando was alone with Drollet when the shooting occurred. The investigator said the Oscar-winning actor, his wife and daughter were in another wing of the home and didn't see the shooting. Brando's two other sons, Miko and Simon, weren't at the estate at the time. Officers recovered the gun used in the killing and several other weapons were confiscated, including a M14 carbine, a shotgun and an Uzi. Police and Brando lawyers wouldn't say who owned the guns. ``I don't want these guns here. Take these guns out of here,'' Marlon Brando was quoted as telling police. Drollet was a family friend from Tahiti who had been a house guest for 10 days, police said. Little was known about the man. ``There was no indication there had been a physical altrcation prior to the shooting,'' said Detective Steve Osti. Christian Brando was calm when police arrived. After a 45-minute jailhouse meeting with Christian, attorney Dan Stormer said the younger Brando was distraught. ``He's as upset as you'd expect him to be for someone in his position,'' said Stormer, who is working with the actor's attorney, William Kunstler. ``It's truly a tragic incident that's going to cause a lot of personal pain for him and his family.'' Christian Brando will plead innocent, Kunstler, an associate of the actor in civil rights struggles over the past 30 years, said from New York. Asked about the alleged confession, Kunstler partner Ronald Kuby said: ``We are engaged in an investigation and we aren't making any statements on the substance of the case.'' Christian Brando is the son of the actor and his first wife, Anna Kashfi. The couple divorced in 1960. There was little known about his adult years, other than he was once employed as a tree surgeon and most recently as a welder. Marlon Brando won best actor Oscars in 1954 for ``On the Waterfront'' and in 1972 for ``The Godfather.''

DOC.HEAD: NASA Sets Target Launch Date
DOC.TEXT: NASA said Thursday it is working toward a May 30 launch date for space shuttle Columbia, whose astronomy mission was delayed by work to replace a bad cooling valve. The so-called ``assessment dates'' are usually accurate, barring unforeseen problems, said NASA spokesman Bruce Buckingham. ``It gives the workers a date and target they're operating toward. It gives them a schedule deadline so they know what work needs to be done,'' he said. Mission managers are expected to set an official launch date at a flight readiness review teleconference on May 24. Columbia had been scheduled to lift off this week with seven astronauts and the $100 million Astro observatory, capable of probing sources of ultraviolet and X-ray radiation. But the National Aeronautics and Space Administration postponed the 36th shuttle mission two to three weeks in order to replace the valve at the launch pad. Technicians on Thursday finished soldering lines connected to a new valve. The bad valve, which was removed Tuesday, had a torn filter. The valve, which has a replacement value of $141,000, will be recertified and installed on the shuttle Endeavour, which is under construction in California and due to fly in early 1992, Buckingham said. Columbia's cooling system will be tested, then purged to remove excess moisture. It will be filled again with a refrigerant, probably on Monday.

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper Drops Columnist After Racial Slur
DOC.TEXT: The Oregonian has dropped Jimmy Breslin's syndicated column because of racial slurs he made about a co-worker, the newspaper announced Thursday. Breslin recently lambasted a Korean-American reporter with New York Newsday after she criticized one of his columns as sexist. In a newsroom tirade, Breslin called Ji-Yeon Yuh a ``yellow cur'' and ``slant-eyed.'' The reporter wasn't present during the obscenity-laced outburst. On May 8, Newsday suspended Breslin for two weeks. ``Breslin revealed attitudes that have no place in the newsroom or in a nation of people from all walks of life, of all colors, religions and ethnic and national backgrounds,'' said William A. Hilliard, editor of The Oregonian. ``And Breslin has no place in The Oregonian.'' Reached by telephone in New York, Breslin had little comment about The Oregonian's action. ``That's up to them. They run the paper,'' he said. Breslin will continue at Newsday. ``Jimmy Breslin has been writing about minorities with compassion, sensitivity and skill for more than a quarter of a century and we're looking forward to having him back at Newsday,'' the paper's editor Anthony Marro said Thursday. Marro said that since the suspension, Newsday has received about 100 telephone calls on the issue, the majority in favor of Breslin. The newspaper also has received about 80 letters that were about evenly split on the issue. Public reaction to the controversy hasn't influenced the newspaper's response, Marro said. ``I don't edit this paper by poll or by plebiscite,'' he said. Breslin's column is syndicated through the Los Angeles Times Syndicate. Doug Mayberry, vice president of sales for the syndicate, refused to say how many newspapers subscribed to the column and how many have dropped it since the controversy. Marro said he hasn't heard of any other cancellations. ``I suspect if anybody else had dropped the column, I would have heard about it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Maury Povich To Leave ``A Current Affair''
DOC.TEXT: Maury Povich, who since 1986 has anchored the syndicated ``A Current Affair,'' said Thursday he's leaving the weeknight TV series in June next year to co-produce and star in his own one-hour talk show. The as-yet untitled show, to premiere in the fall of 1991, will appear five nights a week from New York and be co-produced and syndicated by Paramount Domestic Television, said Povich. He said his ``Current Affair'' contract with Fox Broadcasting, which distributes that show, expires on June 1 next year. The craggy-faced anchorman, whose show was criticized as tabloid television during the program's early days, said he'll continue doing the show until his contract expires. He said ``A Current Affair'' is seen in 190 cities. In an interview, Povich said he hadn't been restless. ``It's just that over the last week or so, I began to think that it'll soon be five years here. That's 1,300 shows. I was here when it was a baby. ``It has grown into an institution and will be a hit long after I'm gone. And so I thought maybe it's time for the kid to leave the house _ even though the kid is 51.'' Povich is married to CBS anchorman Connie Chung.

DOC.HEAD: East German Premier Cautious on All-German Elections
With AM-Germany-Unification, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: East German Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere sought to rein in West Germany's push for quick unification by cautioning Thursday against holding all-German elections too soon. ``First we have to clear up the external and internal conditions for German unity,'' De Maiziere said. External issues deal notably with the strategic role of a united Germany. This is being discussed between the two Germanys and the victorious World War II allies France, Britain, the Soviet Union and the United States _ and must first be ``satisfactorily sorted out,'' De Maiziere told reporters. He spoke at the end of a two-day visit to Strasbourg during which he addressed members of the European Parliament and met with senior European Community officials. De Maiziere said also to be settled before all-German elections is the status of East Germany's treaties and relations with its partners in the 10-nation, Moscow-led Comecon trade bloc. ``East Germany's path into the European Community should not be a barrier to relations with Eastern Europe,'' he said. West German Chancellor Helmut Kohl has sought to accelerate German unification following his party's regional election losses last Sunday. Union of the two Germanys' currency into a powerful deutschmark is set for July 2. Kohl said Wednesday he wants the ``two-plus-four'' talks completed by fall and he and his coalition partners want West Germany's Dec. 2 elections to become all-German. Analysts say Kohl figures his Christian Democrats could lose to the opposition Social Democrats if voting was held only in West Germany, but might do better in all-German elections. De Maiziere, also a Christian Democrat, said he wants to wait with all-German elections until all questions about unification have been settled. In another development, King Michael, Romania's former monarch, told members of the European Parliament on Thursday that Sunday's elections in Romania must be postponed because the election campaign has been unfair. After debating the Romanian voting campaign, the parliament adopted a resolution telling Romania's ruling National Salvation Front to end ``their campaign of intimidation.'' Romanians vote for a two-chamber parliament in their first free elections in 50 years. Political experts predict the Front will win 60 percent of the vote. The Front has led Romania since the December ouster and execution of Communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu. It is said to shelter former members of Ceausescu's secret police. The election campaign has been marred by violence and charges that the Front has been intimidating opponents. Michael, who abdicated and left Romania in 1947, said Thursday: ``There can be no real democracy in a country where the government accuses the opposition of `destabilizing' the state, where peaceful demonstrators are called `a bunch of hooligans' .. . where the opposition cannot take public opinion polls, where candidates are regularly beaten, intimidated, persecuted and where television is a propaganda instrument used by the authorities.'' The former monarch, who lives in Switzerland, enjoys considerable popularity in Romania. In another resolution Thursday, the European Parliament unanimously asked the Soviet Union to reopen the case of Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg, who saved hundreds of Jews in Hungary during World War II. Wallenberg was arrested by Soviet troops in 1945 and vanished. The Soviets have claimed Wallenberg died in 1947, but witnesses said they saw him alive after this date.

DOC.HEAD: Bush Says He Won't Sign Civil Rights `Quota Bill'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: SUBS graf 3: ``But Sen.,'' and graf 8: ``The White,'' with corresponding grafs bgng: ``But the,'' and ``At the,''
DOC.TEXT: President Bush said Thursday he won't tolerate bias in hiring but also won't accept a civil rights bill that imposes quotas on employers. Sens. Edward M. Kennedy, D-Mass., and John Danforth, R-Mo., quickly unveiled a compromise amendment intended to deal with his objections to the bill that is at the top of many civil rights organizations' legislative lists for this year. But the White House and Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, both said it failed to remove their concerns about quotas. ``I want to sign a civil rights bill, but I will not sign a quota bill,'' Bush declared at a Rose Garden ceremony honoring the recently revived U.S. Commission on Civil Rights. The president, who met three times earlier this week with civil rights groups and other lobbyists to search for a compromise on the legislation, said before Kennedy and Danforth announced their new proposal, ``I think we can work it out.'' After unveiling the amended version, Danforth said, ``After weeks of negotiating over this change, we are now convinced that quotas will not be the unintended result of this bill.'' Danforth signed with five other senators as the newest sponsors of the bill, which now has 47 sponsors in the 100-member Senate. But Hatch said later, ``The Kennedy-Danforth amendment in no way solves the severe quota problem in the bill.'' Hatch, the top Republican on Kennedy's Labor and Human Resources Committee, said Bush and his advisers were ``too smart to be taken in by this new language.'' At the White House, deputy press secretary Alixe Glen said, ``It's a step in the right direction but it still does not eliminate our concern that employers would adopt quotas.'' There is no mention of quotas _ the hiring of a certain number or percentage of minority or other workers _ in the bill. But Attorney General Dick Thornburgh and other critics have said the earlier version's standard of proof for justifying exclusionary hiring practices was so tough that employers would use quotas as a way of avoiding lawsuits. The legislation would undo a series of 1989 Supreme Court decisions that made it harder for workers to prove they were victims of job discrimination. ``We will leave nothing to chance and no stone unturned as we work to advance America's civil rights agenda,'' Bush said to applause from the audience that included many civil rights leaders. ``We can and will make America open and equal to all,'' Bush said. ``We will tolerate no barriers, no bias, no inside tracks, no two-tiered system and no rungless ladders.'' Last month Thornburgh said he might recommend a veto of the pending bill, which is at the top of many civil rights organizations' legislative lists for this year. But after Bush's comments Thursday, Benjamin Hooks Jr., executive director of the NAACP, called it ``a very happy day.'' Hooks said Bush had moved ``right into the mainstream'' on the civil rights legislation, although ``a little conflict'' still remains. Bush said that the law must ``obliterate'' consideration of race, color, religion, sex or national origin from hiring, must protect ``against harassment in the workplace based on race, sex, religion or disability and should ensure a speedy end to such discriminatory practices.'' ``Our civil rights laws, however, should not be turned into some lawyer's bonanza, encouraging litigation at the expense of conciliation, mediation or settlement,'' the president said. The legislation would undo a Supreme Court decision that narrowed the ability of minorities to win monetary damages for job discrimination, and would restore the burden of proof to defendants in cases where hiring practices allegedly had a discriminatory impact. For 18 years, employers had the burden of proving a business necessity for any exclusionary hiring practices. The Supreme Court altered that in the 1989 Wards Cove case, involving hiring at an Alaskan salmon cannery. The original Senate bill said employers would have to prove discrimination was essential to job performance. The new version would require only proof that such practices had a ``substantial and demonstrable relationship to effective job performance.'' A similar change was made in the House version recently. Bush also named Charles Pei Wang, a New Yorker who is president of the China Institute in America, to the Civil Rights Commission.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Gallo Pleads `No Contest' To Manslaughter Charge, Gets Probation
DOC.TEXT: A remorseful Aileen Gallo, 77-year-old wife of multimillionaire winemaker Julio Gallo, pleaded no contest Thursday to a manslaughter charge in a fatal auto accident and drew probation and a fine. Mrs. Gallo, appearing in court with her husband and weeping as she faced Gilroy Municipal Court Judge Jerome Brock, was sentenced to three years' probation, 350 hours of community work, fined $2,400 and ordered to make restitution to the victim's family on all uninsured losses. Julio Gallo and his brother, Ernest, own the world's largest winery, headquartered in Modesto. Each brother is estimated to be worth $500 million. Gilroy is 70 miles south of San Franciso and 50 miles southwest of Modesto. Julio's arm was around his wife's shoulders as they faced the judge. Court clerk Lupe Dellanini said both wept. ``It was an emotional hearing,'' the judge told a reporter later. ``All the indications I have gotten throughout the case from the probation report and her statement to probation officers and in court (is) that the woman is pretty much devastated.'' The judge said he thought Mrs. Gallo would be haunted by the death of Sharon Kauk, 26. Mrs. Gallo's plea of nolo contendere was tantamount to a plea of guilty to the charge of misdemeanor manslaughter in the Jan. 2 accident. The maximum penalty was one year in prison. The judge said the victim's family asked that Mrs. Gallo not receive any jail time. ``I don't think we could come up with a more sympathetic defendant, as far as this type of thing goes,'' the judge said. ``She didn't have so much as a parking ticket and lives to do things for other people.''

DOC.NOTE: Eds: New thruout to show abortion provision dropped; CORRECTS language to show abortion financing from local tax dollars, sted federal money
DOC.TEXT: House-Senate negotiators smoothed the way for passage of a $720 million Central American aid bill Thursday by dropping controversial measures on abortions and the death penalty in the District of Columbia. President Bush threatened to veto the supplemental appropriations bill if it included the Democratic proposal to allow the District to use locally raised tax money for abortions for impoverished women. Negotiators also jettisoned a companion measure, pushed by Republicans, that would have permitted the death penalty in nation's capital. Sen. Brock Adams, D-Wash., said proponents of the abortion financing measure abandoned it because they didn't want to threaten the total money bill. But he vowed to bring the measure up again in the Senate. ``We will be back to pass pro-choice legislation,'' he said. ``We've got the votes.'' Negotiators cleared the abortion hurdle and made progress in other areas, but they didn't finish work on the 1990 supplemental appropriations bill. The money bill, loaded with pork-barrel items and extraneous provisions, totals about $3.3 billion. Still to be worked out are differences on defense spending. Key provisions in the measure are the $300 million in aid for Nicaragua and $420 million for Panama. Bush chided Congress this week for dallying on the Central American aid measure. Nicaraguan President Violeta Chamorro urgently needs the money because her country is bankrupt and is rocked with by anti-government strikes, Bush said. About 14,000 Nicaraguan Contras are staying in camps under a U.N. supervised peace agreement reached with Mrs. Chamorro after she defeated Sandinista President Daniel Ortega. The Bush administration, worried the rebels might run out of food, is expected to take between $1 million and $1.5 million from aid programs to other countries to help feed the Contras, said U.S. officials who asked not to be identified. Even former House Speaker Jim Wright of Texas joined the chorus calling for quick approval of money for Central America. ``In my considered view, it is extremely important for Congress to move as swiftly as possible to approve President Bush's emergency request for $720 million in desperately needed economic aid to Panama and Nicaragua,'' he said. Once negotiators have reached final agreement, the package must be approved by the full House and Senate. Money won't be spent to Central America until an authorization bill is passed by the House. Debate is set for Monday. The 1990 bill contains a host of big-ticket items, including $110 million for the census; about $162 million for the Head Start program for poor children; $400 million in housing loans for Israel to build houses for Soviet emigres; a total of $45 million for Peru and Bolivia; $705 million for the Agriculture Department's food stamp program; $10 million for natural disasters; $5 million for children in Cambodia, and roughly $60 million for flood control. Lawmakers removed a proposed $10 million for a U.S. Embassy in Lithuania. There was friction between the House and some senators over the amount of free mail House members have sent this year. The House postage account will be about $44 million in the red by the end of the year, lawmakers said. Rep. Vic Fazio, D-Calif., asked _ and senators conditionally agreed _ to let the House use $25 million in unspent funds from an operations fund to help make up the postage deficit. ``It now appears the House is going to spend twice as much money'' on mail as planned, said Sen. Don Nickles, R-Okla. Controversy has been brewing on the House mailings for some time, and Fazio told senators the House intends to take up proposed reforms. The House Administration Committee said one reason for the larger-than-expected deficit will be increased first-class mailings close to Election Day. Many members will turn to first class, at 25 cents per piece, because they will have used up the three third-class bulk mailings, at 10 cents each, allowed under the law, officials said.

DOC.HEAD: Croatia, Slovenia Reject Threat that Yugoslav Communism Must Be Saved
DOC.TEXT: The liberal, autonomy-minded republics of Croatia and Slovenia on Thursday rejected a threat from the federal presidency of ``urgent measures'' to save Communist rule and restore Yugoslavia's disintegrating unity. Slovenia said it would use all legal means to preserve its sovereignty. On Wednesday, Slovenia installed the country's first non-Communist regional government in nearly 50 years. Northern neighbor Croatia also held multiparty elections and is expected to install a center-right government at the end of May. Both governing parties want more regional autonomy. Thursday's rejection seemed certain to aggravate their deep split with the largest of Yugoslavia's six republics, Serbia, the only Yugoslav republic that has not scheduled multiparty elections. Yugoslavia's eight-member collective presidency, headed by Borisav Jovic, a Serb, said Wednesday ``the political and security situation ... is so unstable that Yugoslavia is currently going through its most critical phase.'' Jovic announced introduction of unspecified ``urgent measures'' to protect national integrity. Political, ethnic and economic differences have fueled a long row among the regions and within the disintegrating Communist party. The battle for power in the vacuum left by the 1980 death of Communist Yugoslavia's founder, Josip Tito, now seems headed for a climax. Jovic's remarks set off widespread speculation that martial law may be introduced in Slovenia and Croatia. The orthodox Communist leadership of Serbia opposes changes in the country's socialist system. It also wants a federal system with strong central authority in the Serbian and federal capital, Belgrade. Croatia and Slovenia say this constitutes an attempt by Serbian leader Slobodan Milosevic to retain single-party rule and ensure Serbian domination. Slovenia's collective presidency denounced Jovic on Thursday, saying he had spoken without consulting the republic. ``Democratic, free elections were carried out in Slovenia in which its citizens, expressing their will, elected a legitimate leadership,'' the Slovenian presidency said. It said the Slovenian developments had enhanced peace and stability, and called for an urgent conference of Yugoslav republics to chart a new relationship. In a statement carried by Tanjug news agency, Croatia's collective presidency said the ``realization of democratic strivings and the expressed will of the citizens of Croatia must and may not in any way be questioned.'' It termed Jovic's statements ``arbitrary and unacceptable'' and demanded more details. Yugoslavia's Communist Party and the presidency continue to formally run the country on the federal level. But the party has been effectively paralyzed since last January, when Slovenian and Croatian Communists broke with hard-liners.

DOC.HEAD: Mrs. Gorbachev to Wellesley With Mrs. Bush, Perhaps Williamsburg Too
DOC.NOTE: EDs: New throughout with quotes, added detail
DOC.TEXT: Raisa Gorbachev will join Barbara Bush in a summit-time trip to Wellesley College where both first ladies will address the graduating class, it was announced Thursday. Mrs. Bush is ``absolutely delighted'' that Mrs. Gorbachev has accepted her invitation, Anna Perez, the first lady's press secretary, said at the White House. The two first ladies will travel together to the women's college in Massachusetts on Friday June 1, the second day of their husbands' four-day summit. Mrs. Bush has also invited Mrs. Gorbachev to visit colonial Williamsburg, Va., while their husbands are occupied, but there is no word yet on whether the Soviet leader's spouse wants to go there, Ms. Perez said. Some 150 students at Wellesley signed a petition last month questioning the choice of Mrs. Bush as a commencement speaker, saying her prominence was based on whom she married. The petition signed by a quarter of the senior class said: ``To honor Barbara Bush as a commencement speaker is to honor a woman who has gained recognition through the achievements of her husband, which contradicts what we have been taught over our years at Wellesley.'' Mrs. Bush dropped out of Smith College after her freshman year in 1944 to marry Bush, then a Navy pilot. The couple was wed in January 1945, a few months after Bush survived the downing of his plane in the Pacific. Mrs. Bush, who turns 65 on June 8, has been a career homemaker and mother of six who moved dozens of time with her husband during his far-flung career through the oil business, politics and diplomacy. She has gained recognition in recent years for promoting literacy and other causes, including the care of babies with AIDS. Some feminists and others expressed outrage at the student's petition slighting Mrs. Bush's qualifications. But Ms. Perez said, ``She doesn't think it's a controversy, in her mind. She absolutely understands ... where the young women are coming from and she hopes they understand where she is coming from.'' Mrs. Gorbachev, 58, is a former university lecturer with a Ph.D. in philosophy from Moscow State University. She met the future Soviet leader in a ballroom dancing class while he was in law school and she was a graduate student in philosophy from Siberia. Asked if the Wellesley students might regard Mrs. Gorbachev as just a mother, Ms. Perez replied, ``Ph.D. in philosophy, party member _ I don't think so.'' The Gorbachevs arrive in Washington May 30. The two leaders will meet over the next four days at the White House and Camp David, the presidential retreat in Maryland's Catoctin Mountains. Ms. Perez said that on April 6, the day after the summit dates were announced, Mrs. Bush contacted Wellesley's president, Nannerl O. Keohane, and asked if they would like Mrs. Gorbachev to come as well. ``They responded they would be delighted. Very soon after that ... Mrs. Bush extended the invitation in writing to Mrs. Gorbachev,'' she said. Both women agreed to wait to fix their schedules until their husbands' were set, which was done Thursday. Mrs. Bush is not getting an honorary degree at Wellesley. Not all colleges bestow honorary degrees on commencement speakers.

DOC.HEAD: Health Coalition Asks New Research Priorities
DOC.TEXT: A coalition of 26 AIDS and health groups Thursday asked the National Institutes of Health to make major changes in its AIDS research priorities to expand clinical testing and improve coordination. The coalition sent to NIH an outline of the changes that could ``cut years off the time when we are finally able to manage'' AIDS, said Jean McGuire, executive director of the AIDS Action Council. The groups said NIH should: _Increase financial support of nongovernmental biomedical research proposals that have been approved by peer-review committees in the scientific community. _Join with the White House and the secretary of the Department of Health and Human Services to ``spearhead an effort to coordinate and facilitate AIDS research activities.'' Without such coordination and sharing of data, ``we never know which crucial areas of work are being overlooked.'' _Adopt the coalition's 13-point research program, which includes expanding clinical trials to include more women, children, intravenous drug users and blacks, all of whom are now underrepresented in AIDS studies. Other points in the research program include more testing of drugs to treat the opportunistic infections and diseases that kill people with AIDS, creation of a national AIDS database and relaxation of criteria for patients to enter clinical trials. Officials at NIH and the National Institute of Allergies and Infectious Diseases, which is the lead institute on AIDS research, said they had not seen the coalition's document and could not comment on it.

DOC.HEAD: Scientific Ship Runs Into Island off Tierra del Fuego
