DOC.TEXT: A scientific vessel leased by the U.S. National Geographic Foundation ran aground on a tiny island Thursday at the southern tip of South America, the Argentine Coast Guard said. It said there were no injuries among the 32 people aboard the Norwegian-flagged vessel, the polar ship Duke. The vessel, commanded by Carl Sanders, suffered damage to its bow, the Coast Guard said. It was towed to port at Ushuaia, Argentina's southermost city on the island of Tierra del Fuego. The Argentine news agency Diarios y Noticias quoted Coast Guard officer Alberto Irurita as saying a small amount of fuel spilled into the Beagle Channel, but it was surrounded by a floating barricade and cleaned up by shipboard pumps without damaging wildlife. The Coast Guard said the ship, which was carrying out studies in the channel, was headed west toward the Chilean port of Punta Arenas early Thursday when it hit the islet about 17 miles south of Ushuaia. The Beagle Channel is a 125-mile stretch of water that separates Tierra del Fuego from the more southerly Chilean islands of Navarino and Hoste. There was no word on how the scientific ship ran aground on the island. The vessel also performed support duties for the U.S. Palmer Base in Antarctica.

DOC.HEAD: Salvadoran Officials, Rebels Discuss Truce in Caracas
DOC.TEXT: Salvadoran government officials and guerrilla representatives negotiated over a proposed cease-fire Thursday during their second day of peace talks in Caracas, Venezuelan sources said. The talks came after the two sides agreed April 4 in Geneva to renew efforts to bring an end to their decade-long war. More than 70,000 people have been killed. U.N. envoy Alvaro de Soto was mediating the Caracas talks. The discussions, held in a school in a suburb of the capital, were kept secret behind a cordon of Venezuelan security forces. However, Venezuelan sources said on condition of anonymity that the discussions centered on a cease-fire, which the right-wing Salvadoran government considers essential to test the guerrillas' good faith. The leftist guerrillas have consistently rejected that proposal unless the government guarantees to fire elements of the armed forces allegedly involved in human rights violations. The obstacles at the talks were underlined Wednesday as Salvadoran President Alfredo Christiani sharply criticized the guerrillas of the Farabundo Marti National Liberation Front for leaking their position to the Salvadoran press. The guerrillas demand a demilitarization of Salvadoran society, full democratization of their country and a national economic pact.

DOC.HEAD: Budget Negotiators Told Huge Cuts Could Harm Economy
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS grafs 17-19: ``Darman provided,'' with White House examples of Gramm-Rudman cuts
DOC.TEXT: Negotiators for the White House and Congress were urged Thursday to seek deficit savings of $50 billion to $60 billion but avoid more drastic steps that might send the economy into a slowdown. Officials from the administration and the Congressional Budget Office gave the negotiators widely differing projections about the size of the growing federal deficit. But both sides agreed that cuts of $50 billion to $60 billion would not be enough to head off automatic spending cuts under the Gramm-Rudman budget balancing law. Some negotiators have said loosening the deficit targets in the law could be one way of dealing with that problem. ``We're still trying to find out what the facts are,'' House Majority Leader Richard Gephardt, D-Mo., said after Thursday's 90 minutes of closed-door talks. ``Then we'll set the goals we're trying to achieve, then we'll talk about ways to reach the goals.'' Congressional aides said it was likely to be several days before a detailed proposal for spending cuts or tax increases surfaced in the talks. The meetings began Tuesday after President Bush set aside his campaign pledge of no new taxes and said there would be no preconditions to the negotiations. Treasury Secretary Nicholas Brady, White House Chief of Staff John Sununu and Budget Director Richard Darman led the president's team into the negotiations. Participants at the talks heard differing projections about the likely size of the 1991 deficit without tax hikes or spending cuts. According to the non-partisan Congressional Budget Office, it will take $85 billion to $95 billion in savings to reach the $64 billion target in the Gramm-Rudman law. The White House's Office of Management and Budget presented figures showing that $59 billion to $74 billion would be needed. But Robert Reischauer, director of the Congressional Budget Office, and White House budget chief Richard Darman agreed that to cut next year's shortfall by more than $50 billion or $60 billion _ about 1 percent of the economy _ could contribute to an economic slowdown. A leading Democratic negotiator concurred. ``It is legitimate to ask the question, at what point do you begin to undermine the economy in terms of too many taxes and too many cuts,'' said Rep. Leon Panetta. Accepting the lower target presumably would make the work of the negotiators easier and lead to less politically painful remedies. Neither agency's figures included the costs of rescuing the nation's ailing savings and loan industry. CBO calculated that when those expenses are included, the amount of required deficit cuts could explode to $132 billion to $182 billion. The Gramm-Rudman law requires that the costs of the savings and loan bailout be included in calculations of the deficit. When Bush unveiled his budget in January, he said that just $37 billion in cuts would be needed to satisfy the Gramm-Rudman law. ``What we're seeing today is the administration abandoning their rosy scenario,'' said one of the Democratic negotiators, Senate Budget Committee Chairman James Sasser of Tennessee. Darman provided the negotiators with examples of the automatic spending cuts the Gramm-Rudman law would impose next year if a compromise deficit-reduction package was not worked out. He said that if $30 billion in cuts were required, defense spending would be cut by 7.6 percent and domestic programs by 10.4 percent. If $60 billion in reductions were necessary, the slice would be 15.2 percent for the military and 22.2 percent for domestic programs. As examples, he said that with $30 billion in Gramm-Rudman cuts, the FBI's $1.4 billion budget would be cut by $81 million. The Federal Aviation Administration's $6.5 billion budget would be reduced by $126 million and the Pentagon's $80.8 billion procurement efforts would be cut by $2.1 billion. For technical reasons, the Gramm-Rudman cuts are applied differently to various programs. The talks resumed as Democrats questioned Bush's willingness to embrace politically unpopular spending cuts. Bush has rejected Democratic calls for him to take the lead in proposing a solution, and lawmakers suggested before Thursday's negotiations began that the president might not be willing to accept deep spending cuts. ``It's premature to know that,'' said Gephardt, he top Democratic negotiator. Panetta said he believed Bush would be willing to support whatever proposal emerges. But he added, ``There's a lot of skepticism around this place whether or not they'll be willing to grab this tar baby in the end.'' Panetta, who also is among the negotiators, complained that partisan dueling is hindering negotiators and could jeopardize the talks' outcome. He said such pressures were likely to grow during the course of this election year. ``We're trying to walk through it, and you have the Hatfields and the McCoys firing shots over our heads,'' he said. Even House Speaker Thomas S. Foley, D-Wash., who normally avoids political finger-pointing, was drawn into the fray. On Wednesday, Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., had said Democratic calls for Bush to make a televised address on the deficit were an effort to force him to ``do a Jimmy Carter.'' That was a reference to the former president's unpopular penchant of reminding the nation of its problems. Asked about the remark, Foley responded, ``Does that mean exercising presidential leadership?'' The projected size of next year's deficit has grown because of unexpectedly high interest rates, growing costs of handling the savings and loan industry collapse, and lower-than-expected tax revenues.

DOC.HEAD: RETRANSMITTING a0739 to add 1st Ld-Writethru designation
Maoist Rebel Faction in Peru Says It Will Suspend Fighting
DOC.NOTE: Eds: This is a writethru to a0673 to add presidential poll result in Lima
DOC.TEXT: A Maoist rebel faction said Thursday it is suspending military actions while it reviews its anti-government struggle, but it vowed to resume its armed insurgency. In leaflets found in the Andean city of Ayacucho on Thursday, the 10th anniversary of the Shining Path uprising, rebels who claimed to represent a splinter faction of the group said it will lay down arms to ``evaluate all our brilliant actions of the decade and then return with new impulses and ideas.'' It said it would take up arms again ``soon.'' The leaflets were found near where a bomb exploded early Thursday. The bomb's target, the offices of presidential candidate Alberto Fujimori's Change 90 party, was slightly damaged, but no one was reported injured. A survey of Lima-area voters released Thursday showed Fujimori trailing novelist Mario Vargas Llosa by nearly 5 percentage points in the most recent survey of Lima-area voters. The center-right Vargas Llosa is favored by 46.3 percent of voters, to 41.7 percent who support the centrist Fujimori, according to a poll of 484 people made last weekend by the private firm Datum. The poll had a 4.6 percent margin of error. About one-third of Peru's 22 million people live in the Lima area. The runoff election is set for June 10. Vargas Llosa narrowly won the most votes, with Fujimori right behind him, in last month's primary but many thought his support had eroded in recent weeks. The winner must deal with Peru's poor economic situation and the continuing Shining Path insurgency. More than 18,000 people have been killed in political violence since the Shining Path took up arms 10 years ago. There have been reports in recent weeks in the Lima press of a schism within the Ayacucho branch of the Shining Path. The Andean city, 235 miles southeast of Lima, is the movement's birthplace and remains its stronghold. However, analysts who study the rebel movement say the division is unlikely to significantly weaken the guerrillas. In an indication of divisions within the movement, the rebel leaflets made no direct mention of the shadowy Shining Path leader Abimail Guzman. Instead, they called for an end to ``personality cults and ideological fundamentalism.'' Guzman, a former philosophy professor, is believed to advocate extreme violence. In past years, the rebel group has carried out numerous massacres of mountain peasants it viewed as traitors to its cause. The splinter group's leaflets criticized ``mass genocides, especially when they involve workers and peasants.'' It said such actions undercut grassroots support.

DOC.HEAD: Lights to Dim On Vegas Strip in Memory of Entertainer
With AM-Sammy Davis Jr
DOC.TEXT: Exterior lights and marquees at resorts along the Las Vegas Strip will go dark for 10 minutes Friday night in memory of Sammy Davis Jr., the star who entertained millions in this city over four decades. Davis died of cancer at his Beverly Hills, Calif., home Wednesday. Funeral services are scheduled Friday. Lights along the Strip were darkened after the assassinations of President John Kennedy and civil rights leader Martin Luther King Jr. Debbie Munch, a spokeswoman for Caesars Palace, said that resort would darken all non-essential exterior lights from 9 to 9:10 p.m. Friday in honor of Davis. ``He was the dearest song and dance man this city has ever seen,'' Ms. Munch said. ``We owe him this tribute.'' Don Payne, head of the Las Vegas News Bureau, said all hotels on the glittering Strip were being urged to join in the tribute. ``It's one way for this town to show the respect that we all owe Sammy Davis Jr.,'' Payne said Thursday. ``This city has particular reason to honor this man.'' ``Sammy Davis represented a significant part of the entertainment world for many decades and this is our way of thanking him,'' said Ira David Sternberg, a spokesman at the Tropicana Hotel. Davis was one of the city's top entertainers and was a member of the famed Rat Pack in the 1950s, joining Frank Sinatra, Dean Martin, Peter Lawford and Joey Bishop in appearances at the Sands Hotel. He last appeared here with comedian Jerry Lewis at Bally's Hotel in July of 1989, shortly before he quit performing because of throat cancer.

DOC.HEAD: AIDS Amendment Added to Bill
DOC.NOTE: Eds: TOP 17 grafs new with further comment from Hoyer, gay rights advocates; background; probability of conference; edits to tighten. ^By ROBERT GREENE
DOC.TEXT: The House approved an amendment Thursday permitting food service workers with AIDS to be assigned duties that would keep them away from hanbdling food. By a 199-187 vote, the House agreed to change the proposed Americans with Disabilities Act, a bill aimed at protecting the rights of the disabled, to allow employers to reassign workers with ``contagious diseases'' so they will not be allowed to handle food. Both sides agreed that ``contagious disease'' referred primarily to AIDS, which can be spread only by intimate sexual contact or by sharing hypodermic needles or blood. Among those voting for the amendment were 79 Democrats. Thirty-one Republicans opposed it. The amendment means the bill, once it passes the House, will have to go to a conference committee to work out differences. Backers of the measure had hoped to avoid having to submit the bill to such negotiations. ``I'm sure the Senate will now ask for a conference because this amendment will not be acceptable,'' said Rep. Steny H. Hoyer, D-Md., lead House sponsor. Hoyer called the provision the ``Jim Crow amendment of 1990.'' The analogy follows repeated descriptions of the bill as the most significant piece of civil rights legislation since the 1960s. ``The vote was a significant setback in the progress that has been made over the past several years'' in understanding AIDS, said spokesman Gregory King of the Human Rights Campaign Fund, a gay-rights group that lobbied against the amendment. The bill easily cleared the Senate last September on a 76-8 vote. That bill was the product of delicate negotiations with the White House. The House version nearly duplicated the Senate bill. The White House had endorsed the bill for its protection of AIDS victims along with other disabled people. However, its position on the amendment, whose existence was long known, was not clearly stated until Health and Human Services Secretary Louis Sullivan wrote a letter Thursday to House Speaker Thomas S. Foley. ``Food service workers infected with HIV need not be restricted from work unless they have other infections or illnesses for which any food service worker should be restricted,'' Sullivan said. ``Since the act limits coverage for persons who pose a direct threat to others, relaxing the anti-discrimination protection for food service workers is not needed or justified in terms of the protection of the public health.'' But the argument boiled down to public fears as opposed to scientific evidence. ``Perception is reality,'' said Rep. Chuck Douglas, R-N.H., arguing that restaurants which let AIDS victims handle food would be driven out of business. ``We need to look at reality as it exists today,'' said Rep. Steve Bartlett, R-Texas, ``not as we wish it to exist.'' ``In effect, it says there's a prejudice out there and let's pander to it,'' countered Frank McCloskey, D-Ind., invoking the memory of Ryan White, the Indiana youth who recently died as a result of AIDS acquired through a transfusion. Rep. Henry A. Waxman, D-Cali., said he believed the amendment stemmed from misunderstanding of the bill. The bill contains a provision that exempts any person whose condition or conduct poses a ``direct threat'' to others. The bill was hailed during opening debate as legislation ``whose time has come.'' The bill extends to people with AIDS, blindness, cerebral palsy and a number of other mental and physical impairments the protections accorded racial minorities and women. The House also passed a pair of amendments favoring business, including one giving small businesses temporary immunity from discrimination lawsuits. It rejected one giving a pay-based formula for determining whether businesses have spent enough to accommodate disabled employees. Backers say the legislation is necessary to push the estimated 43 million disabled Americans into the economic and social mainstream. The cost to the government is small, topping out at $31 million in 1994. The cost to business has not been calculated. Supporters say also that the cost will be offset by the addition of disabled people to the work force and the consumer economy. The bill prohibits discrimination in all phases of life: Employment, access to stores and services, transportation and telecommunications. Among key provisions: _Discrimination in hiring and on the job would be prohibited. The requirement would be phased in over two to four years, depending on the size of the company. Companies with fewer than 15 employers would be exempt. _Hotels, restaurants, shopping malls, drug stores, and business and professional offices, along with any other ``public accommodation,'' would have to make themselves accessible to disabled people. Accessibility includes structural adjustments, such as wheelchair ramps and widened doors, and services. _Transportation, public and private, would have to be made accessible. Fixed route bus systems would have to be accessible for people with wheelchairs. Special ``paratransit'' would be available for people with other disabilities who cannot use regular transit.'' Amtrak, Greyhound, and commuter rail systems are covered. Timetables for implementation vary according to system. _Speech- and hearing-impaired people would have access to telephone service by means of relay services. These services would have to be provided by phone companies within three years. The Federal Communications Commission would have jurisdiction.

DOC.HEAD: Two Game Shows Coming to Prime Time
DOC.TEXT: After a 20-year pause, game shows are returning in prime time to ABC, the network said Thursday. It said it would start showing ``Super Jeopardy!'' and ``Monopoly'' next month. The half-hour shows, hosted by Alex Trebek and Michael Reilly, respectively, will premiere on Saturday, June 16, starting with ``Super Jeopardy!'' at 8 p.m. EDT. ``Monopoly'' is based on the popular board game. The shows are produced by Merv Griffin Enterprises in association with King World, which produces the hit ``Wheel of Fortune'' and ``Oprah Winfrey'' series. King World said its ABC game shows will be on for 13 weeks, but a network spokewoman here said she couldn't confirm that. According to ABC, the programs are the first game shows on the network in prime time since ``Let's Make a Deal'' and ``The Newlywed Game'' in 1970. CBS briefly tried a game show in prime time later, airing ``The Price Is Right'' for two months in the summer of 1986.

DOC.HEAD: Church of Ireland Votes for Ordination of Women
DOC.TEXT: Leaders of the Anglican Church of Ireland gave final approval Thursday to the ordination of women as priests. Lay and clergy delegates to the church's general synod voted in favor of the change for the second time this week, approving the last stage of the bill. Anglicans in England, Scotland and Wales do not allow women to be priests. About 1,000 women have been ordained to the priesthood in one-quarter of the 27 Anglican churches, most of them in the United States, Canada and New Zealand. On Tuesday, clerical members of the church secured the necessary two-thirds majority by four votes, but there had been speculation Thursday's follow-up vote would reverse that decision. Delegates instead heeded a strongly worded request from Archbishop Robin Eames of Armagh, the leader of the church, to vote to ensure the bill's passage. The proposal was backed overwhelmingly by lay voters and by almost 70 percent of the clergy. The Church of Ireland has 410,000 members, most of them in the British province of Northern Ireland. Church officials said it will probably be months before any women become priests. There are six woman deacons and four in training. The majority of Ireland's population belong to the Roman Catholic Church, which opposes the ordination of women.

DOC.HEAD: Son Sought in Slayings of Parents, Grandmother
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note contents 8th graf.
DOC.TEXT: Police on Thursday sought a man whose elderly parents' bodies were found in the trunk of an abandoned car, along with that of his 93-year-old grandmother, authorities said. The bodies were discovered Wednesday in a car registered to one of the victims, Forest Janes, 78, officials said. Also killed were Janes' wife, Una, 72, and her mother, Ivy Welch. Illinois authorities requested an arrest warrant for investigation of murder for the Janes' 35-year-old son, Ronald J. Janes, who reportedly lived with his adoptive parents in rural Bradbury, Ill., about 100 miles west of Indianapolis. ``We regard him as a prime suspect in the case,'' Illinois State Police spokesman Bob Fletcher said in Springfield. ``The last time he was seen was on Sunday in Indianapolis with the car.'' The bodies were found after employees of a nearby restaurant told authorities a foul odor was coming from the black 1984 Lincoln Continental first seen in a downtown parking lot Monday, Indianapolis police Lt. William M. Reardon said. Autopsies conducted Thursday determined that all three victims died of severe head injuries suffered in a beating, said Marion County Coroner Dennis Nicholas. ``They all died very violent, brutal deaths,'' Nicholas said. He said the women were easily recognizable, but the man's head was severed and the victim was too badly beaten to be recognized. A pair of scissors was found sticking from Mrs. Janes' chest. Mrs. Welch's was found with a trash bag over her head and a hole in her abdomen. ``We found a pipe wrench and a 30-inch long piece of galvanized pipe, which were probably the murder weapons,'' said Nicholas. He said the victims probably died last Thursday or Friday. Relatives reported the victims missing Saturday, authorities said. Reardon said the evidence indicated the slayings occurred in Illinois, and said it was possible the bodies were put in the car and driven around for a few days. Police said they had no motive for the killings and were unsure why Ronald Janes might have traveled to Indianapolis. His ex-wife lives in the area, but Reardon said Janes had not contacted her for two years. Janes was thought to have been seen at a motel and a bar on Sunday, said Indianapolis police Detective Craig Converse. Janes has a criminal history that includes theft, forgery and battery dating from 1973, Illinois police said. He also is wanted on an arrest warrant for forgery in Illinois. ``His parents were aware of his problems with ... forged checks,'' said Special Agent Frederick J. Bray of the Illinois State Police.

DOC.HEAD: Mills Students Give Up Administration Buildings
DOC.TEXT: Mills College students, sensing victory over a decision to admit undergraduate men, ended a two-week barricade of administration buildings Thursday. Meanwhile, alumnae met secretly to discuss a financial rescue plan that would add millions of dollars to the college's coffers. The student protesters walked out of three administration buildings and held an afternoon rally on the Toyon Meadow, the main lawn of the campus. The college's alumnae organization has raised $3 million in a seven-day telephone fund drive, bolstering students' hopes that the college's board of trustees would reverse an earlier vote to admit men starting in the fall of 1991. The board is expected to meet Friday to decide whether to accept an alumnae rescue plan that includes adding $10 million to the college's endowment and doubling the association's yearly gift to the college.

DOC.HEAD: Humorist, Producer Seek Up to $14.6 Million in Movie Money
DOC.TEXT: Art Buchwald has attacked Paramount Pictures' claim that the hit Eddie Murphy movie ``Coming to America'' lost $18 million, contending in court papers that the movie actually made $39.8 million. Superior Court Judge Harvey Schneider ruled in January that Paramount must pay Buchwald $250,000 and 19 percent of the film's net profits. Paramount has said it will appeal the decision. Buchwald claimed the studio stole his script idea titled ``King For A Day,'' which dealt with an African prince who comes to live in the United States. The film's credits attributed the idea to Murphy. In papers filed Wednesday, the humorist's attorney Pierce O'Donnell said the share of the net profit due his client and producer Alan Bernheim should range between $6.9 million and $14.6 million. ``The studio's reaction is that their claims are baseless and unfounded,'' said Robert Schwartz, an attorney for Paramount. Paramount has claimed it lost $18 million on ``Coming to America,'' even though the 1988 film has grossed $275 million worldwide. Buchwald's audit, which covers the period up to December of last year, states that producing ``Coming to America'' cost Paramount $22.9 million. A Paramount audit put the figure at $58.5 million. Papers filed by O'Donnell said several items that Paramount listed in the cost of making the movie should not have been included. Among them were $1 million for Murphy's entourage; $900,000 for excessive fringe benefits and a 15 percent ``overhead'' charge that amounted to $8 million of the costs all by itself. The brief said $1.65 million of the $8 million overhead ``was merely for writing gross participation checks to Eddie Murphy and (director) John Landis.''

DOC.HEAD: North Carolina Marine From Pennsylvania Charged in Pentagon Theft
DOC.TEXT: A Marine Corps sergeant has been charged with stealing government property and accused of taking two computers and 60 floppy disks of secret data from the ``Star Wars'' office at the Pentagon, the Defense Department announced Thursday. A statement from the department's inspector general identified the suspect as Sgt. Robert Walter Rodgers, 27, originally from Upper Darby, Pa. and now based at Camp LeJeune, N.C. Rodgers was indicted by a federal grand jury in Alexandria, Va., on four counts charging theft of government and personal property, depredation (plundering) against government property and destruction of records, the IG said. The computers and disks have not been recovered. Investigators considered the possiblity that they had been turned over to a foreign power, but ``it is unlikely,'' said Michael J. Costello, head of the Washington office of the Defense Criminal Investigative Service. Costello said the disks contained ``some sensitive SDI information.'' According to the inspector general's account, Rodgers was a part-time employee of Polaris Corp., a contractor providing security services to the Strategic Defense Initiative Office in the Pentagon. On April 8, 1988, according to the statement, Rodgers ``crashed'' _ disabled _ the computer controlling access to the office, entered a storage room and removed the computers, one of them an officer's personal machine, and the disks. Investigators took the hard _ built-in _ disk of the disabled computer to its manufacturer and consulted writers of the programs it used to reconstruct events before the break-in, and thus were able to bring Rodgers under suspicion, Costello said. ``Rodgers apparently thought he could erase all incriminating activity. He is a very computer-literate person,'' Costello said.

DOC.HEAD: Undersea Earthquake Measuring 6.0 Rocks Southwestern Japan
DOC.TEXT: An undersea earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale rocked southwestern Japan early Friday, the Central Meteorological Agency said. There were no immediate reports of damage or injuries from the 8:28 a.m. (7:28 p.m. EDT Thursday) tremor, local police said. The agency said the quake was centered 30 miles under the ocean floor near Okinawa Island. There was no fear of a tsunami, the large tidal waves sometimes triggered by undersea earthquakes, meteorologists said. On Thursday, an earthquake logged at 5.7 on the Richter scale shook central Japan, but no damage or injuries resulted.

DOC.HEAD: Panamanian Found Innocent of Threatening to Kill President Bush
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 3rd graf, `Lakas, the ...' with 3 grafs to UPDATE with defendant's comment, prosecutors refusing to comment. Picks up 4th graf pvs: ``I am ...' Subs last graf, `But Secret ...' with 2 grafs to ADD further defendant's comment. No pickup. ^By CHIP BROWN
DOC.TEXT: The 21-year-old son of a former Panamanian president was found innocent Thursday of threatening to kill President Bush. Otto Lakas, an architecture student at Lubbock Christian University, could have faced a 5-year prison term had he been convicted in U.S. District Court. Lakas, the son of Demetrio B. Lakas, president of Panama from 1972-78, clenched his fists and looked toward the ceiling, tears rolling down his cheeks as the verdict was read. The jury deliberated only 15 minutes. ``I am very happy,'' Lakas said leaving the courthouse. ``I don't want to comment any more than that, but I am glad to go back home.'' Government prosecutors refused to comment about the decision. ``I am so relieved,'' said the elder Lakas, who testified Thursday that his son was on trial because of a misunderstanding of his people's culture. ``We always talk about killing someone. Even two or three times. Latins are fiery and outspoken,'' he told jurors. ``But it is not taken seriously. It's a way of expressing ourselves,'' he said under cross-examination. Demetrio Lakas had testified for the defense Wednesday that his son Otto grew up amid death threats in Panama. ``My life was threatened thousands of times,'' Lakas said. Otto Lakas was accused of threatening Bush in a discussion with the managers of a pawnshop where he was looking at a gun. Prior to the verdict, which came in the second day of the trial, family and friends testified about the non-aggressive nature of Lakas. They characterized the statements as a joke. But Secret Service agents took Lakas at his word and had jailed him without bond since April 17. When Lakas was asked if he had any regrets about the threat and his arrest, he replied: ``You bet, never again. I know the law now.''

DOC.HEAD: East, West Germans In Fuss over Spy Hiring
DOC.TEXT: East Germany's interior minister wants to hire former leading Communist spy Markus Wolf as a special adviser, but angry West German officials said Thursday that Wolf should be prosecuted instead. Wolf, 67, was purportedly the role model for the wily Communist spy Karla in John le Carre's espionage novels. Carl-Dieter Spranger, parliamentary state secretary in West Germany's Interior Ministry, said Wolf is ``not acceptable for office in a democracy.'' He said East German Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel's idea to hire him is ``unbearable.'' Before he retired in 1987, Wolf was chief of foreign intelligence within Communist East Germany's Ministry for State Security, which also contained the infamous ``Stasi'' domestic secret police. The ministry was dissolved last year in East Germany's quiet revolution that ended four decades of hard-line Communist leadership. During his 33-year career, Wolf earned a reputation in the West as one of the craftiest intelligence foes. He is wanted by West Germany. But Wolf was also one of the first senior Communist Party officials to call for democratic changes within his homeland. Wolf last year even joined activists in addressing pro-democracy street demonstrators. In a telefax to Western news media, Diestel defended his plan to hire Wolf, saying he would be invaluable in helping clear up the activities of the Stasi. Diestel said he wants to ensure that a Ministry for State Security can never arise again, and for that reason asked Wolf ``to lay open his knowledge and make it available to the new government.'' Eduard Lintner, a political expert for Chancellor Helmut Kohl's coalition government, urged ``serious consideration whether Diestel is still acceptable as interior minister, or must be let go,'' reported the newspaper Bild. The newspaper telexed to news agencies in advance an article that is to appear in Friday's editions. It quoted Volker Ruehe, head of Kohl's Christian Democrats, as saying Wolf is ``less suited as an adviser than anyone I can think of.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S Envoys Negotiate With Philippines on Bases
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 10 grafs to UPDATE with talks beginning Friday, grenade attack at U.S. library; pickup 7th pvs, `In 1988...'
DOC.TEXT: U.S. and Philippine negotiators met Friday for a fifth day of talks on the future of American bases in the Philippines after a late-night marathon session failed to produce a breakthrough. Early Friday, unknown assailants fired two grenades at a U.S government library in suburban Makati, one of which exploded, causing minor damage. The library had not yet opened, and there were no injuries, police said. The two sides disagree on whether the United States failed to make full aid payments, and on when the facilities would actually have to close if the two sides cannot reach a lease agreement. After this round of talks, which is to end Friday, the two sides could either begin formal negotiations on a new pact or start working on a schedule for closing the bases. Their lease expires in September 1991. The installations include Clark Air Base, the Subic Bay naval base and four smaller facilities. Police said three masked men dressed in black fired two grenades about 6 a.m. from a taxi at the Thomas Jefferson Cultural Center, operated by the U.S. Information Service. Police said the attack could have been timed to the bases talks. The two sides met into the evening Thursday to try to resolve a Philippine claim that the United States owes $222 million in back payments for use of the bases. U.S. officials said the talks resumed early Friday in hopes of a compromise before chief U.S. negotiator Richard Armitage leaves for Tokyo later in the day. ``We are trying to hammer out differences,'' said Philippine spokesman Rafael Alunan on Thursday. ``I believe that they are inching toward some sort of agreement'' on the payment issue. In 1988, the Reagan administration agreed to provide $962 million over two years in return for use of the bases through 1991. Congress subsequently cut the Bush administration's aid request by $96 million. U.S. officials insist they promised only ``best efforts'' to meet the target and that the aid cut was not a breach of faith. ``We have not conceded that there is a shortfall,'' said the spokesman for the U.S. delegation, Stanley Schrager. ``We have lived up to our commitment, and we have made our best effort.'' President Corazon Aquino suggested Thursday the United States could pay off the ``debt'' by providing medical equipment and other supplies to the Philippines. U.S. sources, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the United States was willing to provide additional equipment to the Philippines, but that it would not be designated as payment of any debt. A classified memorandum prepared in February by the Philippines' Department of Foreign Affairs suggested the government publicly demand full U.S. funding for the bases as well as other aid programs, while quietly agreeing to accept a lower aid figure. The memo, a copy of which was obtained by The Associated Press, also said the United States was reluctant to increase aid to the Philippines because of perceived weak leadership and mismanagement by the Aquino government. Mrs. Aquino said Thursday it was too early to say whether the two sides had reached an impasse. However, Philippine senators, who must ratify any new bases agreement, expressed renewed doubts any pact could win approval. Sen. John Osmena, the leading bases advocate in the Senate, told reporters Thursday: ``The ball is in the U.S. court. If they want to stay, they have to pay.'' Senate President Jovito Salonga said rather than trying to come to terms with the United States, the Philippines ``should now prepare for the next phase and try to effectuate a smooth turnover of the military bases.'' The Philippine government says the lease on the installations expires in September 1991, but the United States claims the bases could remain one year longer under the current agreement. President Bush has said he would study alternative locations for the bases if the negotiations fail.

DOC.HEAD: Thunderstorms Soak Much of U.S.; South Still Suffering from Flooding
DOC.TEXT: Severe thunderstorms soaked much of the nation Thursday, while the South and parts of the Plains still braced for the inundation of rising rivers. Tornado watches were posted Thursday night for central and eastern Pennsylvania, central and southeastern New York state, and much of New Jersey. Warnings of gale force winds stood through the night for the Great Lakes region and across the lower Great Lakes on Friday. Winds reached 61 mph at Buffalo, N.Y. Flood watches were in effect for New York state, Vermont and New Jersey. Heavy rain from strong thunderstorms could cause serious local flooding problems. Major flooding continued on the lower half of the middle Red River. The river is expected to stay at its crest at Coushatta, La., through Friday, about 6{ feet above flood stage. Flood warnings continued for the Little River near and below Rochelle, La., as well as along the Red River to where it joins the Black River. Flood warnings remained along the Sabine, Neches, and Angelina rivers in east Texas, as well as the Trinity and Leon rivers in north Texas. Warnings also continued along the Wabash River from Mount Carmel, Ill., to New Harmony, Ind. The river is expected to crest about the middle of next week, at its highest stage since March 1985. Flooding extended along the Sangamon River from near Lake Decatur, Ill., to the river's mouth. Recent heavy rains led to predictions of additional flooding on the Black River at Pocahontas and Black Rock, both in Arkansas, and on the St. Francis River at St. Francis, La. Flooding continued along the White River in eastern Arkansas and the ouachita river near the Arkansas-Louisiana border. The crest on the Missouri River was expected to be eight feet over flood stage at Booneville, Mo., on Friday. The Cuive River was seven feet over flood stage at Troy, Mo. Flooding has caused at least 13 deaths in Texas and one in Oklahoma in the past three weeks, and millions of dollars in damage. In Texas, 33 counties have been declared eligible for disaster aid due to storms and flooding. Showers and thunderstorms extended across much of New England, New York, Pennsylvania, New Jersey, Maryland, and parts of Virginia, West Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia and Alabama. Showers also reached along the Louisiana coast, the central Texas Gulf coast, and along the northern Pacific Coast. Rain was scattered from north-central Minnesota to west-central Wisconsin, and northern Lower Michigan. Casper, Wyo., reached 28 degrees Thursday morning and tied its low temperature record for the date, set in 1986. The nation's low temperature was 20 degrees at Gunnison, Colo. Temperatures at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 38 degrees at Warroad, Minn. to 95 at Avos Park, Fla.

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
Bosch, Losing in Balloting, Accuses Dominican President of Fraud
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 23 grafs to UPDATE with latest vote total, reaction from international observers, both sides claim victory, CORRECTS that Carter affirmed fairness of balloting, not vote count. Picks up 16th graf, `The election...'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5, SD4
DOC.TEXT: Former President Juan Bosch, falling behind in partial electoral returns, accused President Joaquin Balaguer of ``colossal fraud'' Thursday and threatened street demonstrations. Bosch, a leftist, told reporters he would lead the street protests on Friday ``no matter what the consequences.'' He called a news conference after results from Wednesday's general election announced by the electoral board showed Balaguer, a five-time president, had overtaken Bosch's narrow early lead. With nearly two-thirds of this Caribbean country's polling stations reporting results, the outcome remained uncertain, with the two rival candidates in a close race. Balaguer, 83 and blind from glaucoma, and Bosch, 80, who has moderated his leftist ideology in recent years, were opposing each other for the fifth time for the presidency of this nation of 7 million people. Balaguer won three of those previous elections. ``The Central Electoral Board and Dr. Balaguer committed a colossal fraud,'' Bosch said Thursday. ``We are announcing that PDL is going into the streets because the people have been cheated.'' PDL are the Spanish initials for Bosch's leftist Dominican Liberation Party. ``Tomorrow we will be ready to go with the people into the streets, no matter what the consequences,'' Bosch said. ``What remains of my life has no meaning if this fraud takes place.'' The electoral board later issued a statement saying election law prohibited such demonstrations while the vote count was still under way. Radio and television stations were barred from carrying newscasts during the election period, so Dominicans were not generally aware of his call for demonstrations. Officials of Bosch's party met Thursday with six of the 30 international observers monitoring the election. Oscar Ayerve of Ecuador said there was concern over the slow vote count, but he did not elaborate. Former President Jimmy Carter, one of the observers, was in the computer room at election headquarters and unavailable for comment. He said earlier the balloting was fair, but gave no assessment of the count. Bosch, who was overthrown in a 1963 military coup, held a narrow lead earlier. The electoral board announced results of Wednesday's election by party, rather than by candidate. With 3,914 the 6,663 polling stations reporting, Balaguer had 386,766 votes and Bosch 375,869, official returns showed. A former socialist mayor of Santo Domingo, Jose Francisco Pena Gomez, was third with 256,243 votes. The two leading parties both claimed victory. Bosch supporters celebrated at party headquarters early Thursday despite the uncertain outcome. Sen. Felix Jimenez, Bosch's campaign manager, said Balaguer should ``recognize his defeat at the polls.'' ``There is not doubt we have won the elections,'' said Balaguer's running mate, Vice President Carlos Morales Troncoso. He based his claim on results showing the Social Christian Reformist Party ahead in 18 of the country's 29 provinces and in the federal district of Santo Domingo. Balaguer's supporters held a vigil at his Santo Domingo residence. Soldiers patrolled the neighborhood. Most shops in the capital remained closed for a second day. No disturbances were reported. Returns from the capital of Santo Domingo, with a population of 2 million, were delayed by a computer problem, election officials said. Those results could strongly affect the outcome because Balaguer has done poorly in the capital in previous elections. About 3.2 million people were registered to vote nationwide. ``The election has been conducted in an adequate and honest manner,'' Carter said in a statement read on television. Eighteen parties contested Wednesday's general election, but only eight put forward their own presidential candidates. Among the 10 that did not, four declared in advance that all votes for their party would go to Balaguer and one committed its votes to Bosch. Bosch, an author and intellectual who describes himself as a Marxist but not a Communist, ran on a moderate platform. He pledged to work for good relations with the United States and endorsed capitalism as the best way to improve his country's economic plight. Bosch and the army hierarchy have been at odds since he was overthrown in a military coup 27 years ago. But military officers and Balaguer stated before the elections they would respect the outcome of the vote. An attempt by an army faction to restore the Bosch presidency after his ouster led to civil war in 1965. President Lyndon Johnson sent in 23,000 U.S. Marines to prevent a leftist takeover. Balaguer, founder and leader of the Social Christian Reformist Party, rose to power under dictator Gen. Rafael Trujillo, serving briefly as his figurehead president. Trujillo ruled for 31 years until his assassination in 1961. Balaguer was first elected president in 1966 and served three consecutive four-year terms before losing in 1978. He was re-elected in 1986. The president pinned his hopes in this election largely on a $2 billion public-works project to transform centuries-old Santo Domingo. He portrayed Bosch as a dangerous Marxist. Balaguer's public-works project has created thousands of jobs, but his popularity slumped as the country's economic problems deepened.

DOC.HEAD: Turner Says He Never Meant to Condone Slayings of Chinese Protesters
DOC.TEXT: Cable television magnate Ted Turner said Thursday he never meant to condone the massacre of pro-democracy demonstrators in China, and he hopes to meet with one of the student leaders who criticized his comments. Turner, creator of the international Cable News Network, told foreign journalists in Beijing last week that the Chinese government ``felt forced to'' call in troops to stop the mass demonstrations last year. He also said the students who occupied central Beijing's Tiananmen Square for weeks ``were breaking the law,'' and he said the United States was interfering in the business of another country when it disapproved of the Chinese government's actions. ``That statement was made in a question-and-answer format,'' Turner said Thursday after returning to Atlanta. ``In no way did I wish to condone the violence there. ``Everyone there knows I'm an advocate of peace. I was upset about it, too. It not only hurt the people involved, but the government as well.'' Turner commented following a brief news conference in which he signed 7-foot-7 wrestler Jorge Gonzalez to a contract with World Championship Wrestling Inc., a subsidiary of his Turner Broadcasting System. Shen Tong, a leader of China's student pro-democracy movement, who escaped the country after the massacre, told reporters during a visit to Atlanta last weekend that he was upset by Turner's remarks and wanted to meet with Turner personally. ``If I get a chance, I will meet with him,'' Turner said Thursday. ``I plan to see him.''

DOC.HEAD: Ex Northrop Plant Chief Gets Prison for Cruise Missile Fraud
DOC.TEXT: A former Northrop Corp. plant chief who pleaded guilty to conspiracy and fraud in supplying untested cruise missile guidance system parts was sentenced Thursday to three years in prison. Clarence Gonsalves, 62, also was fined $10,000 by U.S. District Judge Pamela Rymer. Gonsalves was once manager of Northrop's now-closed Western Services Department. Assistant U.S. Attorney William Fahey said Gonsalves' sentence could have been longer if he had not agreed to cooperate with U.S. authorities investigating the matter. About 1,700 flight data transmitters were made at Western Services for the air-launched cruise missile, which can carry either conventional or nuclear warheads. Many were delivered untested and below specifications. ``It's a very big and serious question mark'' over the performance of the missiles, said Fahey. Northrop and Boeing, the prime contractors in the cruise missile program, are testing missiles to see if their guidance system works. Fahey credited Gonsalves' cooperation with forcing Northrop to reach a plea agreement with prosecutors over the matter. The defense company pleaded guilty to 34 counts of fraud and agreed to pay $17 million to the government. Gonsalves also is cooperating in a parallel ``whistleblower'' civil case against Northrop over the cruise missile parts.

DOC.HEAD: `Show Me' _ Some Record Store Chains Demand ID's
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf to CORRECT to Rep., sted Sen. Also moved for PMs
DOC.TEXT: Teen-age customers of some record store chains now need more than money to buy certain hot LPs. They need ID. Bowing to pressure from politicians and parents over what they consider objectionable lyrics, some stores have begun to card youngsters. In some places, no one under 18 can buy products by rap and heavy metal acts that carry a warning label affixed by record companies. ``This stuff is addictive,'' says state Rep. Jean Dixon, a fan of Christian music whose attempt to force record companies to label albums with explicit material failed in committee. ``I had a kid write and tell me he's addicted to this bad music.'' Whether record companies and retailers agree with her premise or not, some are complying. Among them: Dallas-based Sound Warehouse Inc., which has 137 stores in 14 states, and Streetside Records, which has 19 stores in Missouri and Kansas. Camelot Music, the No. 2 company in the country, carded minors for several months before going to a money-back guarantee last month for dissatisfied parents. ``We've been carding kids for about two months, ever since Jean Dixon started her spiel,'' said Jim Varvaris, manager of a Streetside store in St. Louis County. ``Some of her comments show that she's kind of hogwash.'' Targets of the measure agree. ``It's a crock,'' said 17-year-old Matt Lauman of St. Louis, standing outside a Camelot outlet. ``We talk about this stuff in social studies all the time,'' said 14-year-old Megan Engbert of St. Louis. ``It's not fair.'' The number of albums and tapes that carry warning labels and necessitate carding is small. Varvaris said that of 75 new releases his store received Monday, only two needed stickers. Profanity and references to suicide, abortion and sex are on Dixon's hit list. ``I think that's an excellent move on the part of the retailer,'' said Dixon. ``I'm sure our efforts here had something to do with that. I'm very pleased with that and all parents should be, too _ that's fantastic.'' Four years ago, the Recording Industry Association of America, under pressure from the Parents' Music Resource Center headed by Tipper Gore, added warning stickers to certain albums. Mrs. Gore is the wife of U.S. Sen. Albert Gore, D-Tenn. That effort led to a wide variety of warnings, some smaller than a postage stamp, before the industry settled earlier this year on a standardized sticker. One popular rap album, ``Fear of a Black Planet'' by Public Enemy, is on the restricted list. Both albums by heavy metal act Guns N' Roses carry warning stickers that say they may contain objectionable material. Another rap group, 2 Live Crew, attempts to evade the censors with albums titled ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be'' and ``As Clean As They Wanna Be.'' Songs such as ``Me So Horny'' and ``Dirty Nursery Rhymes'' are gone from the G-rated version. Lawyers for the group have been in court in Broward County, Fla., where sheriff's deputies had threatened to prosecute store owners if they sell ``As Nasty As They Wanna Be.'' A federal judge earlier this week declined to rule immediately in a lawsuit brought by the group to restore the album to the shelves. Another rapper, Ice-T, touts his latest album, ``Freedom of Speech ... Just Watch What You Say,'' as X-rated. It carries the warning: ``Some material may be x-tra hype and inappropriate for squares and suckers.'' Minors, adept at skirting the law to purchase alcohol, still are getting their hands on albums by hanging around the parking lot and persuading an adult to buy it for them. ``Actually, it's kind of funny,'' Varvaris said. ``They'll come back in and say, `This is my brother, he's going to buy the tape for me.''' Record salesmen also wonder what's next. Is a ratings board, like that used for movies, inevitable? Will record labeling reach into the past and slap restrictions on albums from the 1960s like ``Blind Faith,'' which has a nude woman on the cover? ``Even the Beatles had explicit lyrics,'' salesman Stu Olson said. ``I mean, where do you draw the line?''
