DOC.HEAD: George Drzewiecki, Polish-born Plane Designer, Dead at 87
DOC.TEXT: George Drzewiecki, a Polish-born engineer who designed Poland's first plane to cross the Atlantic, has died in Ottawa. He was 87. Drzewiecki, who died Tuesday in a local hospital, moved to Ottawa after World War II. Cause of death was not given. Poland twice honored Drzewiecki after the war for his aircraft designs, said Anna Drzewiecki, his daughter. The British government recognized Drzewiecki's outstanding wartime service as an Allied ferry pilot when he was made a Member of the Order of the British Empire. ``Our father was an extremely humble man and would never tell us anything,'' said Anna Drzewiecki, chief of plastic surgery at the Children's Hospital of Eastern Ontario. In the 1930s, Drzewiecki designed more than 25 award-winning planes, including light, aerobatic and touring aircraft. His designs for a fighter and a bomber-trainer were destroyed when war broke out with the invasion of Poland by Germany in September 1939. His most famous plane, the single-engined RWD-5, was the first Polish aircraft to make a trans-Atlantic flight, his daughter said. As a ferry pilot in World WAR II, Drzewiecki flew damaged Allied planes back to Britain from Europe for repairs. After the war, Drzewiecki moved to Canada and worked at the National Research Council as a mechanical engineer until 1967. He specialized in the installation of radar stations. Some of the radar equipment he designed was used as backup for NORAD, the North American Air Defense command's northern warning system. Drzewiecki is survived by his wife Jozefa, and daughters Anna, Marta McDonald and Eva O'Grady.

DOC.HEAD: Outside Courthouse, Cheers and High-Fives
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes, color following Fama verdict; no pickup. Changes byline.
DOC.HEAD: With AM-Racial Attack
LaserPhoto NY58
DOC.TEXT: Demonstrators standing vigil at the Brooklyn courthouse erupted in cheers and high-fives following the first conviction in the Bensonhurst racial slaying, calling it a message to the nation. ``We got him!'' one man shouted after learning that Joseph Fama, a 19-year-old white man, had been convicted of second-degree murder and 12 of 14 other counts in the shooting death of 16-year-old Yusuf Hawkins, a black. Hawkins and three friends were attacked by a gang of whites as they walked through the mostly white Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn on Aug. 23. About 150 demonstrators gathered outside the courthouse Thursday, including many who'd been there throughout the racially charged trial and the 10 days of deliberations. Nearly all were black. Just before the verdict came in, a squall hit the neighborhood. But, as word of the decision arrived by bullhorn, skies cleared and a shaft of sunlight struck the courthouse. Activists, who'd warned of unrest in the event of an acquittal, greeted the verdict with glee. ``This will send a message,'' shouted Ron Jackson, a lawyer. ``It should cool the city this summer.'' About 150 police officers were on the street outside the courthouse and 150 on other streets nearby, with perhaps 150 news reporters. There have been incidents of minor violence involving demonstrators. Before word of the verdict arrived the mood was somber, but it quickly turned to joy. ``You can smile now,'' one demonstrator, Ronald Anthony, told a police chief who was standing before a line of officers. The chief smiled. ``It made me feel that we can get along,'' said Anthony. Alfred Mohammed, a Muslim minister, echoed Anthony, saying the verdict lessened tensions. Police Lt. Ray O'Donnell reported no trouble at the courthouse Thursday. ``Things were calm,'' he said. ``We are very pleased.'' As Hawkins' parents and supporters left the courthouse, the cheering intensified. A small group chanted ``Yusuf, Yusuf, Yusuf'' and ``Guilty, Guilty, Guilty.'' Hawkins' father, Moses Stewart, joined in the chants, pumping his fist in the air and smiling broadly before the family drove away. A group of about demonstrators marched 100 yards to Borough Hall and mounted the steps, carrying with them a makeshift coffin marked with the names of victims of racial slayings. Before the verdict, Fama's construction worker father, Rocco, said waiting for a decision had been tough and insisted again that his son was innocent. ``I feel sorry for the guy who died,'' said the elder Fama. ``I feel bad for the guy, I feel bad for my son.'' The wait was over for Fama, but not for the parents of 19-year-old Keith Mondello, the defendant in a parallel trial in the Bensonhurst case. The jury in Mondello's trial ended its deliberations Thursday without reaching a verdict. Six other white youths still face trial in the case. Since the beginning of Mondello's trial, parents Michael and Susan Mondello have avoided speaking with reporters. ``They have their moments when they are hopeful by the questions sent out by the jurors,'' said Mondello's lawyer, Stephen Murphy. ``The tendency is to try to read more into it than is really there.'' ``The wear and tear is much more than the trial,'' he added. ``I'm exhausted from this.''

DOC.HEAD: State Department Warns Americans Of Possible Terrorism In Peru
With AM-Peru
DOC.TEXT: The State Department warned Thursday that there may be bombings and kidnappings in Peru over the next couple of weeks in observance of the 10th anniversary of a Maoist rebel group. The warning said the bombings by the ``Shining Path'' group may be concentrated in Lima, the capital city, and in places frequented by tourists. In addition, the State Department cautioned Americans in Peru that the Tupac Amaru Revolutionary Movement may be planning to kidnap foreigners, especially Americans. The department said that information was obtained by the U.S. Embassy in Lima.

DOC.HEAD: Energy Department to Release Health Records
DOC.TEXT: The Energy Department has agreed to turn over health records of a large fraction of its nuclear weapons workers to a research group, the department said Thursday. The data had been sought in a lawsuit by the Three Mile Island Public Health Fund, a group formed to study the health effects of radioactivity after the 1979 accident at the Three Mile Island nuclear power plant near Harrisburg, Pa. Lawyers for the plaintiffs and the department will sign an agreement Friday to make the data available, said M.J. Jamison, a department spokeswoman. ``It's a done deal. DOE is virtually giving up all the data they were asked for,'' she said. The data were collected by department researchers at its installations at Oak Ridge, Tenn.; Richland, Wash. and Los Alamos, N.M., covering workers at those plants and at plants in Mound, Ohio and Rocky Flats, Colo. Just how many records are involved was not immediately clear. Ms. Jamison said she did not have a figure. She said 600,000 people had worked in the weapons plants of the department and its predecessors since the 1942 organization of the Manhattan Engineer District, the code name of the Army unit that built the first atomic bombs in World War II. Previous reports have said the fund was seeking data on 300,000 workers. The two sides have agreed that the department may withhold individual identifications such as names and social security numbers, she said. These identifications had been sought in the original lawsuit. The first release of records will be made 30 days after the signing of the agreement Friday. The department had long resisted making the data available, but last fall the Energy Secretary, Adm. James Watkins, hinted that he would do so after an advisory committee said it should be done. The panel called for a policy of ``maximum possible openness.''

DOC.HEAD: Quebec Tire Fire Forces Evacuation of About 100
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS throughout to UPDATE with evacuation proceeding of about 100, details. No pickup
DOC.TEXT: ST-AMABLE, Quebec (AP) _ The mayor of this farming center outside Montreal advised residents of houses closest to a burning tire dump to evacuate Thursday night, and about 100 people began the exodus. Mayor Jacques Doyon suggested the residents move to hotels because of a forecast change in the wind. Authorities said thick, choking smoke from 3 million burning tires may start drifting their way. ``We can't take chances so we are recommending evacuation,'' Doyon told a meeting of residents and journalists at the town hall in this community of 5,000 people, 18 miles southeast of Montreal and 50 miles from the U.S. border. He told residents the smoke was not toxic but contained irritants that could cause coughs, nausea, eye problems and headaches. He said elderly people and those who suffer from respiratory or cardiac conditions would be at greater risk. A Quebec provincial police spokesman said about 100 people were leaving their houses. Heavy rain poured down on the fire earlier Thursday, and authorities said their strategy will be to contain the tire dump blaze and then smother it with sand. The fire began Wednesday. It quickly spread over most of the dump, an area the size of seven football fields, and sent up a column of thick smoke more than 4,000 feet high. Dump trucks unloaded sand along the dump perimeter Thursday, to be bulldozed onto the tires once the intensity of the fire dies down. ``We're going to let it burn but at the same time control it,'' Richard Jette, a municipal councillor in the community. ``It has to burn for some time before we can get close to it and eventually smother it.'' The tires were stockpiled by St-Amable resident Jean-Paul Mireault over the last 20 years, fire authorities said. Heavy equipment dug trenches around the dump Thursday to collect the oily runoff from melting tires. The mass will be pumped into tanker trucks before it can seep into the water table.

DOC.HEAD: Investigation: Collusion Between British Soldiers, Terrorists
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS three grafs after 6th graf `The findings...' to UPDATE with reax to report; pickup 7th pvs, `Stevens was...'
DOC.TEXT: Members of the British army have passed intelligence papers to Protestant terrorists in Northern Ireland, according to a special investigator Thursday. ``Certain members of the Ulster Defense Regiment have been involved in collusion with loyalist paramilitaries,'' said John Stevens, an English officer assigned to investigate claims by loyalist gunmen they received police files. ``It would, however, be wrong to conclude that there is a significant proportion of Ulster Defense Regiment soldiers who are involved with paramilitaries. This is not the case,'' he said. Stevens said 94 people were arrested as a result of his investigation, and 59 were charged or reported for criminal offenses. He did not indicate how many of those were Ulster Defense Regiment members. The regiment is a locally recruited British army unit whose members are almost exclusively Protestant. No members of the provincial police force, the Royal Ulster Constabulary, were charged as a result of his inquiry, but two officers were under investigation, he said. The findings was met by different reactions. It was denounced as a ``whitewash'' by Sinn Fein, the political wing of the Irish Republican Army. Peter Robinson, deputy leader of the Protestant hard-line Democratic Unionist Party, dismissed the report as a ``cynical political exercise brought out to appease nationalists.'' Peter Brooke, the top British official in the province, told the House of Commons he was convinced the regiment was fundamentally sound but said the report ``has highlighted shortcomings and deficiencies in several important areas.'' Stevens was appointed in September by Royal Ulster Constabulary Chief Constable Hugh Annesley. The inquiry followed the murder of a Roman Catholic, Loughlin Maginn, by the Ulster Freedom Fighters, an illegal Protestant paramilitary group. When Maginn's relatives claimed he was not associated with any terrorist group, the Ulster Freedom Fighters released police documents that described him as a terrorist suspect. The Freedom Fighters' decision to publicize its possession of intelligence documents drew attention to fears within the Roman Catholic community that the security forces are not impartial. The Ulster Defense Regiment, which is 97 percent Protestant, has been a particular target of Catholic complaints of harassment and brutality, and 16 Regiment men have been convicted of murder. The Ulster Defense Regiment is widely disliked by Northern Ireland's Catholic minority, and the Irish government has called for the unit to be disbanded. The British government and local Protestant politicians have firmly defended the regiment. Stevens said the security forces had produced large quantities of documents necessary for anti-terrorist operations. ``There has, however, been a serious lack of control and adequate accounting procedures relating to the distribution of these documents,'' Stevens said. In some cases, Stevens said, people were recruited by the Ulster Defense Regiment against the recommendations of the Royal Ulster Constabulary. ``A small number of these went on to commit terrorist-related and criminal offenses whilst serving with the regiment,'' he said. Many potential recruits came from strongly loyalist neighborhoods and were subject to intense pressures, Stevens said. As members of the British army, Ulster Defense Regiment members are targeted by the Irish Republican Army and other paramilitary units opposed to British rule. Since 1970 when the unit was formed, 186 members have been killed. Stevens recommended forming a special anti-terrorist squad within the Royal Ulster Constabulary, but Annesley disagreed. Such a squad might work in Britain, where there were 23 terrorist incidents last year, Annesley said, but not in Northern Ireland were there were 1,655 incidents. Nearly 2,800 people have been killed in Northern Ireland since sectarian violence began in August 1969. The violence has declined in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: Shelby Seeks Pentagon Probe of Naval Academy Incident
DOC.NOTE: Eds; INSERTS grafs 5-8 with academy investigation announced Wednesday
DOC.TEXT: An Alabama senator called Thursday for a Pentagon investigation into the resignation of a female U.S. Naval Academy midshipman who was handcuffed to a men's room urinal and taunted by male classmates. Sen. Richard Shelby, D-Ala., a member of the Senate Armed Services Committee, wrote Defense Secretary Dick Cheney and Navy Secretary Lawrence Garrett III asking them to personally investigate the circumstances surrounding Gwen Marie Dreyer's resignation. ``Those responsible for the sexual harassment were only given demerits and a loss of leave time, while the victim has felt it necessary to resign from the Navy,'' Shelby wrote. ``I have also been led to believe that the victim was intimidated by classmates who warned her not to testify at a disciplinary hearing,'' he said. The academy superintendent, Rear Adm. Virgil L. Hill Jr., said Wednedsay he had asked the chairman of the academy's board of visitors to form a special subcommittee to report back this summer with ``an honest appraisal and a good set of recommendations.'' Hill said the panel would include Sen. Barbara Mikulski, D-Md., and three other members, and would work with a study group updating a 1987 study on how well women have been assimilated into the academy. Hill called the incident that led to Dreyer's resignation ``a very, very isolated one.'' ``Sexual harassment is something we try to deal with and try to fix,'' he said. Shelby said he found the incident ``reprehensible'' and he urged the Pentagon officials to ``make all efforts to determine whether there is an institutional bias against women in our military academies.'' ``I hope that this is just an isolated incident, that it is not reflective of a deep seated bias agaisnt women in our military,'' he said. Dreyer, of Encinitas, Calif., resigned from the Naval Academy last month after she became dissatisfied with the investigation of the Dec. 8 incident at the once all-male academy in Annapolis, Md. Midshipmen 2nd Class John Hindinger and Tom Rosson were punished with demerits and loss of leave time as a result of the incident. Six other midshipmen received written warnings for lesser roles in the incident. The academy ruled that the incident wasn't premediated and therefore could not be considered hazing, which can lead to dismissal. Hill described the incident as ``a good-natured exchange'' that ``got out of hand.'' He said it escalated from a snowball fight that had taken place minutes before. Dreyer was pulled from her dormitory room and dragged to the bathroom by male midshipmen. She was eventually freed from the urinal after her roommates shoved their way into the crowd and pleaded for the keys to the handcuffs. About 10 percent of the 3,000 midshipmen at the academy are women. A 1987 study of the assimilation of women into the academy since they first were admitted in 1976 found that 35 percent of the women who enrolled in the academy eventually left, compared with 22 percent of the men.

DOC.HEAD: Amnesty International Asks China to Account for 650 Prisoners
DOC.TEXT: Amnesty International on Wednesday demanded China account for the whereabouts of more than 650 prisoners arrested since the June crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators in Beijing. The London-based human rights group said many prisoners were reportedly beaten and tortured. ``One year after the killings in Beijing, the fate of those prisoners is still veiled in official secrecy _ but they are not forgotten,'' Amnesty said in a written statement. ``We know some of their names and we want to know what has happened to them.'' Amnesty has estimated at least 1,000 were killed and thousands injured when troops moved in on peaceful demonstrators in Tiananmen Square on June 3-4. The Chinese government has said nearly 300 people died during the action, including armed forces members. Amnesty said it had sent a list of more than 650 names of Chinese prisoners to Chinese Prime Minister Li Peng with a request for information on what has happened to them. China has said 6,000 people were arrested following weeks of pro-democracy demonstrations, which were crushed by the military in June. Amnesty International disputed that figure, saying a more accurate number is in the tens of thousands. Amnesty said: ``The killings and arrests last year are just the most recent, dramatic examples of sweeping and persistent persecution in China. Our message to the government is that these human rights violations are an international concern and that international pressure will not go away. ``Workers arrested since the June crackdown in Beijing are reported to have been particularly harshly treated by the martial law authorities, and many are reported to have been subjected to beatings and torture in detention during the weeks which followed the crackdown,'' it said. Amnesty released brief biographies of 16 prisoners, including religious leaders. The biographies also provided background on Tibetan monks and nuns who were arrested for taking part in Tibetan independence demonstrations in September. ``Sixteen nuns were among those arrested for participating in peaceful marches with some of them sent to labor camps without charge or trial and others imprisoned on counterrevolutionary charges,'' Amnesty International said. Another biography focuses on Long Xianping, a 35-year-old English teacher and mother of two boys, who was described to the rights organization as a quiet, apolitical person. She was arrested June 19, 1989, after making a political speech at a factory, Amnesty said. Amnesty said Ms. Long was deeply disturbed when she heard of the killings in Beijing. The political speech was her first. She was sentenced to two years' imprisonment in mid-December on charges of carrying out ``counterrevolutionary incitement,'' Amnesty said.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze at Kenneth Beauty Salon
DOC.TEXT: Six firefighters were injured early Wednesday in a fire at a midtown Manhattan hairdressing salon that caters to high-society clients such as Jacqueline Onassis, officials said. The fire broke out at 4:50 a.m. at the four-story brownstone building at 19 E. 54th St., which houses the Kenneth Beauty Salon on its second floor, said John Mulligan, Fire Department spokesman. Three firefighters were taken to New York Hospital suffering from smoke inhalation and other injuries, said Gail Richardson, a spokeswoman for the Emergency Medical Service. Three other firefighters were injured but refused medical attention, she said. Thirty fire trucks and 100 men responded, and were still battling the blaze at 7:15 a.m., Mulligan said. He said the salon is owned by Kenneth Battelle.

DOC.HEAD: Fed Nominee Confirmed
DOC.TEXT: The Senate on Wednesday confirmed President Bush's nomination of Assistant Treasury Secretary David W. Mullins Jr. to a seat on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board. Approval came on a voice vote without debate. Mullins, a former Harvard business school professor and one of the designers of Bush's savings and loan bailout plan last year, will fill the remaining six years of H. Robert Heller's term on the board. In his confirmation hearing in March, Mullins, 43, pledged that he would exercise his own judgment and would not blindly follow the administration's bidding in its desire to see lower interest rates. He said at the time there was ``no compelling evidence'' that the Fed's policies were unsound, and said he believed reports of a rift between the administration and the Fed were exaggerated. my

DOC.HEAD: Bill Downed By Legislator's 12-Year-Old Son Defeated Again
DOC.TEXT: A bill that would have passed if a legislator's son hadn't cast a ``no'' vote while sitting at his father's desk was defeated Wednesday when the House reconsidered it. State Rep. Mike Langton, a Democrat from Jacksonville, said his 12-year-old son Brian learned a valuable lesson. ``When you do something that you know you shouldn't, there are consequences to that act,'' Langston said. ``I'm not embarrassed. I think Brian was embarrassed.'' The boy was working as a page May 4 when the bill sponsored by Rep. Ron Glickman, D-Tampa, came up for a final vote. It would have created a comprehensive list of children waiting for help from the state Department of Health and Rehabilitative Services. Langton was out of the chamber making a telephone call during the roll call. Sitting at his father's desk and faced with a choice of punching the green ``yes'' button or the red ``no'' button, Brian chose red. The result was a 53-53 tie, which defeated the bill. ``Once he did it, he suddenly had all these legislators hulking over him saying, `Did your Dad tell you to do that?''' Langton said. When Langton returned to find out that his son had defeated the bill, he told Glickman he would have voted ``yes,'' and Rep. Fred Lippman, D-Hollywood, asked that the vote be reconsidered. On the House floor Wednesday, Langton joked that his son would vote differently if given a second chance. ``Over the weekend I had the opportunity to confer with my son Brian, and were it not for the pressures of his final exams in the sixth grade he would be here today. And he wanted you to know that he would vote in favor of Mr. Glickman's bill,'' Langton said. Despite Glickman's efforts to amend the bill and appease lawmakers worried about its cost and effectiveness, it was defated again, this time by a 60-52 count. Glickman said he held no grudge against Brian. ``I don't consider that event as something that fundamentally changed the course of history,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Mandela to Commonwealth: Keep Sanctions
DOC.TEXT: Appealing for continued sanctions, Nelson Mandela on Wednesday told foreign ministers of the British Commonwealth that South Africa's white government is still allowing police to murder blacks. ``We call upon you ... to impress upon your governments and those other governments you could influence to halt and reverse the efforts to untimely and wrongly lift sanctions,'' said Mandela, deputy president of the African National Congress. The ANC is the leading group fighting the apartheid system of racial separation in South Africa. Mandela was addressing a ministerial committee on South Africa of the 37-nation forum of Britain and its former colonies before leaving Wednesday night for Algeria. ``Calls for the lifting of sanctions against the government of South Africa are dangerous steps'' while blacks in the country continue to be killed daily by police with the clear sanction of the government, Mandela charged. ``Apartheid, the central problem that all of us are trying to put an end to, remains untouched, in place and intact,'' he said. South African President F.W. de Klerk freed Mandela from prison and announced a host of reforms in February. Mandela was in prison for 27 years after he was convicted of plotting to sabotage the government. De Klerk is holding talks with Mandela and other black leaders to clear obstacles for full-scale negotiations on bringing blacks into the political system. Mandela's appeal Wednesday was supported by Nigerian leader Gen. Ibrahim Babangida, who told the meeting the world should not be overly impressed with the ``tentative steps'' of de Klerk. De Klerk is now on a European tour. In another development, a Nigerian military spokesman was quoted Wednesday as saying civilians found guilty of helping to plot an April 22 coup attempt will face firing squads along with rebel soldiers. Lagos newspapers quoted Col. Fred Chijuka as saying a military tribunal will begin trying those accused next week. About 200 soldiers and more than 130 civilians have been detained for questioning in connection with the coup attempt. Last week, the military government released 127 detained soldiers. An unknown number of civilians have also been freed. No official casualty toll has been given from the fighting during the coup attempt. Middle-ranking army officers mounted the coup, saying they wanted to end Moslem domination of Nigerian politics.

DOC.HEAD: Jury in Bensonhurst Slaying Meets in Closed Courtroom with Judge
DOC.TEXT: A jury deciding the case of a white man accused of killing a black teen-ager met in a closed courtroom Wednesday with the trial judge as their deliberations crawled through a tenth day. Meanwhile, a separate jury considering charges against a second defendant, also charged with murder in the attack, was sequestered for the night after one juror reported feeling ill. Both juries were to resume deliberations Thursday morning. The first panel, weighing charges against Joseph Fama, wanted a private explanation of what constituted murder by depraved indifference, and state Supreme Court Justice Thaddeus Owens granted their request. Owens said the jurors asked for the closed-door session so they could ``speak openly and ask questions.'' When reporters objected, Owens replied, ``I'm not going to allow you in here because they don't want it.'' He then ordered the courtroom emptied. The jurors ``feel inhibited, they feel intimidated'' by the media, Owens said. Fama, his lawyer, David DePetris, and prosecutors were in the courtroom while the judge spoke with the jurors privately. Owens later opened the courtroom and defined murder by depraved indifference for the jury in the presence of reporters. ``If you find that he had mental culpability and he solicits, requests or aids others in the commission of this crime, he is guilty,'' he said. Outside the courtroom DePetris said he felt Owens' instruction was unfair. ``The judge gives the impression that very little is needed to convict on depraved indifference,'' he said. Fama, 19, is charged with fatally shooting Yusuf Hawkins in the predominantly white Bensonhurst neighborhood last Aug. 23. Co-defendant Mondello was the alleged ringleader of the white gang which attacked the black youth. The Mondello jury, which has twice sent out notes saying deliberations were at a standstill, ended its ninth day of discussions. Mondello's lawyer, Stephen Murphy, said outside the courtroom: ``I don't think the judge is going to force a verdict out of them.'' Mondello, 19, was charged in a 16-count indictment in connection with the Hawkins slaying. The major charges against Mondello are murder and manslaughter.

DOC.HEAD: Insurance Company Confused Man And Dog, Lawsuit Claims
DOC.TEXT: A man has sued an insurance company claiming it canceled his coverage after confusing his medical history with that of his cocker spaniel. Michael J. Niderberg of Murrysville is seeking in excess of $20,000 and a jury trial in Allegheny County court in a six-count lawsuit filed last week. According to the lawsuit, New York Life Insurance Co. revoked coverage because prescription drugs for the pet were listed in Niderberg's name. The dog, Pepper, suffers from occasional seizures, said Niderberg's attorney, Bruce Gelman. Niderberg's problems began after he had emergency surgery in August 1988 for a bleeding ulcer. He was hospitalized again in October 1988 for follow-up surgery. New York Life paid about $1,000 in medical bills before canceling coverage and refusing to pay the balance, which came to more than $50,000. The lawsuit claims New York Life's decision was based in part on a mistaken belief Niderberg had a seizure disorder he had not disclosed previously on the company's medical questionnaire. Gelman said his client told him the practice in Massachusetts, where he lived when the medications were prescribed, was to issue the drug in the name of the pet's owner. Attorney Daniel Lawson, who is representing New York Life, declined to comment on the case because it was in litigation. David Pomerantz, a spokesman for New York Life in New York, said company policy barred him from commenting on the case.

DOC.HEAD: 7 Killed, 32 Wounded in Lebanese Battles
DOC.TEXT: Rival Christian forces fought tank and artillery battles for an eighth day Wednesday but then called a cease-fire. Police said seven people were killed and 32 wounded. In south Lebanon, rival Shiite Moslem factions fought with rocket-propelled grenades and machine guns. Police said seven were wounded in those battles between one group loyal to Syria and another allied with Iran. The casualties from the Christian fighting in and around east Beirut raised the overall toll to 1,029 dead and 2,762 injured since that showdown began Jan. 30. Troops of rebel Gen. Michel Aoun are fighting Samir Geagea's Lebanese Forces militiamen. The thuds of exploding shells reverberated across Christian east Beirut from nightfall Tuesday to past sundown Wednesday. Thousands of residents were trapped in underground shelters. The cease-fire, brokered by the Maronite Catholic church, was called at 9 p.m. in east Beirut and surrounding Christian communities, radio stations of both warring factions reported. Scores of previous truces have collapsed. Police said the shelling duels dwindled shortly after the cease-fire proclamation but that intense sniping persisted. The conflict, the worst confrontation between Christians in the nation's 15-year-old civil war, has forced more than 400,000 of the Christian enclave's 1 million people to flee. Aoun on Wednesday was quoted by the conservative Ad-Diyar newspaper as denying an earlier report he had offered to step aside if the Maronite Catholic synod of archbishops under Patriarch Nasrallah Sfeir asked him to. ``I am staying at Baabda to welcome Geagea's fighters here,'' Aoun told Ad-Diyar in an interview, referring to the presidential palace where he has his headquarters. Both Aoun and Geagea are Maronites, the community that has dominated the political system since Lebanon's independence from France in 1943. In south Lebanon, morning clashes pitted the pro-Iranian Shiite fundamentalist Hezbollah, or Party of God, against the Syrian-backed secular Amal militia. Their battles shattered a 6-day-old truce in Iqlim al-Tuffah province. Since May 1987, the two factions have been struggling for leadership of the country's 1 million Shiites, Lebanon's largest sect. The latest casualties brought the overall toll to 1,041 killed and 3,081 wounded.

DOC.HEAD: Sisters Win Abuse Lawsuit Against Father, Still Deal With the Pain
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Note language in penultimate graf. Hometown of Hammond unavailable
DOC.TEXT: Two daughters of a former child-abuse expert won a multimillion-dollar award against their father on Wednesday for what they said was years of physical and sexual abuse. Sharon Simone, 45, of Boston, and her sister Susan Hammond, 44, of southern California, sued their 72-year-old father, Edward J. Rodgers, a former FBI agent and chief investigator for the El Paso County District Attorney's office, which employed him as a child-abuse expert. The sisters sought unspecified damages from their father for repeated physical and sexual abuse allegedly inflicted by Rodgers between 1944 and 1965. Neither Rodgers nor his attorney was present during the trial, and the proceedings were conducted by the sisters' female lawyers before an all-female jury hand-picked by the attorneys. Rodgers recently fired his attorney, Thomas D. Gresham, who said this week that he has been unable to locate his client. The jury began deliberations on Wednesday and returned after only a few hours with an award of $1.2 million for each sister. It awarded $600,000 to each sister for economic and non-economic damages and $600,000 for punitive damages; Colorado law does not allow punitive damages to exceed other damages. Hammond and Simone expressed remorse and regret at a news conference after the trial that Rodgers had not come forward to take responsibility for his actions and to hear the graphic testimony in the case. ``(The trial) was about truth and justice, and for me, compensation,'' said Hammond. ``I was angry at the thought of my father dying and meeting his God and getting justice that way. I wanted some justice in this world, and if it comes in the form of money, that's how I'll take it.'' The sisters said they didn't know if they would ever collect the award. Simone and Hammond, as well as their sisters Elizabeth ``Beanie'' Medlicott and Mary LaRocque, testified during two days of testimony about the physical, emotional and sexual trauma inflicted by Rodgers as they were growing up in Denver and Colorado Springs. Medlicott and LaRocque were not plaintiffs in the trial, but testified on behalf of their sisters. Edward Rodgers defended himself against the allegations in a deposition. He admitted that he hit his wife and may have hit his children, but didn't remember doing so. He described himself as a perfectionist who had fought alcoholism for years. ``I have thought of myself for years as a domineering son of a bitch who demanded strict obedience from my children,'' he said. ``I know that I have a terrible temper. I'm sure that I was harsh with them, but I don't know that it rose to the level of criminal abuse.'' The sisters have all undergone extensive counseling and psychiatric treatment, and Simone and Hammond say they are unable to have intimate sexual relationships.

DOC.HEAD: Murder Victim's Widower Sues Castro
DOC.TEXT: A man seeking justice for the 1984 murder of his wife is suing Cuban President Fidel Castro because the killer was a Mariel refugee. Leonardo Rodriguez, now 38, was convicted of killing Jean Ludwig as she jogged along a Key Largo bike path. ``At the time Fidel Castro and Cuba forced Rodriguez into the United States, both of them knew Rodriguez was a rapist and a murderer whom they had confined to prison in Cuba for those offenses,'' Gerald Ludwig's lawsuit says. In 1980, Rodriguez was among 125,000 Mariel refugees who crossed the Florida Straits, named for the port from which they left in a Castro-authorized exodus. ``Castro didn't know who the victim would be, but he knew the consequences of releasing violent criminals into the streets of Florida,'' James Lynch, Ludwig's attorney, said Tuesday. ``It's an outrageous act by a foreign government that had a direct impact on us,'' Lynch said, adding that Ludwig, a fisheries biologist who now lives in Louisiana, ``doesn't want it happening to anyone else.'' Lynch first filed the wrongful death suit in 1988, but a Dade Circuit judge dismissed the case because Castro had not been served with court papers within the 90-day limit set by the Supreme Court. Lynch refiled the suit in October. Late last month, another Circuit judge gave him 60 days to serve papers on Castro and his government. There is no indication yet that the papers have been received in Havana.

DOC.HEAD: Academy Honors E.L. Doctorow, Garrison Keillor and Others
DOC.TEXT: Novelist E. L. Doctorow, radio humorist Garrison Keillor and 43 other artists, writers, composers and architects were honored Wednesday by the American Academy and Institute of Arts and Letters. The academy bestowed $500,000 in awards, fellowships and scholarships on the winners at an annual ceremony at its Harlem headquarters. Doctorow won the Howells Medal, given once every five years for the best work of American fiction, for ``Billy Bathgate.'' The Medal for Spoken Language was given to Keillor, whose new radio series, ``American Radio Company of the Air,'' follows his successful ``A Prairie Home Companion'' series. The academy's gold medals for history and architecture, bestowed once every six years, went to historian C. Vann Woodward and architect Kevin Roche. The award for distinguished service to the arts went to Paul Engle, co-founder of Iowa's International Writing Program and founder of the Writer's Workshop. Steven Holl won the Arnold W. Brunner Memorial Prize in Architecture. The Witter Bynner Prize for Poetry, given to an outstanding young poet, was bestowed on Jacqueline Osherow. The Award of Merit in Sculpture was given to Joel Shapiro. The Sue Kaufman Prize for First Fiction went to Allan Gurganus for ``Oldest Living Confederate Widow Tells All.'' The institute and the academy were chartered separately by acts of Congress in 1913 and 1916, respectively. They merged in 1976. The ceremony also included the induction of five new members into the academy by novelist John Updike, chancellor of the academy. They are painter Helen Frankenthaler, novelist William Gaddis, novelist and literary critic Elizabeth Hardwick, literary critic Alfred Kazin and poet James Merrill. Academy membership is limited to 50 people elected from the 250-member Institute of Arts and Letters. Others honored Wednesday were Mel Bochner, Andrew Forge, Yvonne Jacquette, Catherine Murphy and Stephen DeStaebler, who won awards for art; M.H. Abrams, Rick DeMarinis, Rachel Hadas, Shelby Hearon, Debora Greger, Maxine Hong Kingston, David Lehman, Edmund S. Morgan, Eva Hoffman, Peter Brown and Paul Auster, who won awards for writing; and Samuel Adler, Gerald Levinson, Stanley Wolfe, David Evan Thomas and Lee Goldstein, who won awards in music. Painter Milton Resnick won the Jimmy Ernst Award in Art. Jeanette Winterson won the E.M. Forster Award, which is given to a young British writer. John Downey won the Walter Hinrichsen Award for music composition. Painter Nell Blaine won the Louise Nevelson Award in Art. The Richard and Hinda Rosenthal Foundation Awards, presented to a young painter who has not yet been widely recognized and to the author of a work of fiction that was a critical but not commercial success, went to painter Bryn Jayes and to Daniel Stern, author of ``Twice Told Tales.'' There also were nine scholarships and fellowships given to young composers.

DOC.HEAD: Soviets Halts Troop Withdrawal from East Germany
DOC.TEXT: The Soviet Union has suspended its withdrawal of troops from East Germany, officials of both Germanys said Wednesday. The Soviets gave no official explanation of their decision. A West German official said they were struggling with logistical problems, but an East German minister claimed the Soviets had political motivations. West German Defense Ministry spokesman Capt. Stefan Lang told The Associated Press the Soviets were having troubling reabsorbing troops pulled out of Eastern Europe. ``We don't see political motivations,'' he said. There has been widespread speculation housing shortages and economic troubles in the Soviet Union will create problems for Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev's plans to bring tens of thousands of soldiers home. But East Germany's defense minister, Rainer Eppelmann, said the Soviets made their latest decision because they fear the withdrawals from his country, Hungary and Czechoslovakia could leave NATO with a military advantage in Europe. In his interview with Deutschlandfunk radio, Eppelmann said the overall Soviet reductions would lead to a ``superiority of the West'' in military strength. In December 1988, Gorbachev promised a unilateral withdrawal from East Germany. According to Lang, the number was to be about 36,000 troops, nearly one-tenth the Soviet force estimated to be there. More than 10,000 Soviet troops are believed to have already returned home from East Germany, the West German spokesman said. U.S. and Soviet negotiators are working out plans to reduce the number of their troops to 195,000 each in central Europe.

DOC.HEAD: Blaze Burns Out of Control in Tire Dump Outside Montreal
DOC.TEXT: About 3 million used tires burned out of control Wednesday night at Quebec's largest tire dump, 12 miles east of Montreal. Work crews with bulldozers worked frantically to stop the fire from spreading to a nearby forest and trenches were dug to separate the 4-story-high mounds of tires. Residents of nearby St. Amable, a town of 5,000, were told there was no need to evacuate. Cause of the fire was unknown. On Feb. 12, a fire fed by 14 million tires burned for 17 days in Ontario, spewing toxic smoke into the air and forcing the evacuation of 600 people from their homes. Five teen-agers were arrested and charged with setting the fire at Tyre King Recycling in Hagersville, 12 miles north of Lake Erie and 60 miles north of Erie, Ohio.

The overwhelming Senate vote for a nearly $3 billion bill to help states and cities cope with AIDS expenses will encourage President Bush to find room for the spending in the federal budget, a key Republican backer says. Sen. Orrin Hatch, R-Utah, said he believe White House officials will drop any reservations about the bill's cost when they hold budget deliberations with congressional leaders, in part because of the breadth of the Senate's 95-4 vote Wednesday. ``I think basically they wanted to see how the bill would ultimately sift out. They now know, at least from the Senate standpoint,'' Hatch said. ``We're very hopeful ... that the White House will see the merits of it and will help to include it in the summit agreement. And I have no doubt that they will,'' he said.

Pro-Sandinista strikers agreed to end a walkout that crippled the new conservative government, but the country's cash crisis deepened while Washington officials haggled over an aid package. Under the settlement signed Wednesday night, public employees' salaries are doubled and the government promises not to fire those who walked off the job. Some workers remained in government buildings but were to formally end the protest and return to work today. The agreement was a victory for the Sandinista unions, which virtually shut down Managua and much of this Central American nation of 3.5 million residents since the walkout began Friday.

Hollywood's stars shed tears for Sammy Davis Jr., the exuberant song-and-dance man who started as a goggle-eyed child vaudevillian and battled to the glittery top of the entertainment world. The man who joked he was the nation's only ``black, one-eyed, Jewish entertainer'' died early Wednesday of throat cancer at age 64. ``A heaven with his magic gives me warmth,'' said Frank Sinatra. ``Sam was the best friend a man could have. He was a class act and I will miss him forever.'' Davis died at his Beverly Hills home, his wife, Altovise, and three of his four children at his side. He was diagnosed with throat cancer eight months ago and had returned home from the hospital March 13 after a two-month stay.

Teen-age customers of some record store chains now need more than money to buy certain hot LPs. They need ID. Bowing to pressure from politicians and parents over what they consider objectionable lyrics, some stores have begun to card youngsters. In some places, no one under 18 can buy products by rap and heavy metal acts that carry a warning label affixed by record companies. ``This stuff is addictive,'' says state Sen. Jean Dixon, a fan of Christian music whose attempt to force record companies to label albums with explicit material failed in committee. ``I had a kid write and tell me he's addicted to this bad music.''

Juan Bosch, a leftist ex-president, took an early lead over conservative President Joaquin Balaguer in Dominican elections, according to initial returns today. Bosch, who has moderated his positions in promising to lead the nation out of an economic crisis, had a narrow lead with about 10 percent of the polling stations reporting, the Electoral Board said before dawn. Vote-counting was being done by hand and was running way behind schedule. Balaguer, 83 and blind from glaucoma, and Bosch, 80, were locked in their fifth contest for the leadership of this Caribbean nation of 7 million people.

A Philadelphia businessman who asked his secretary to scout for good-looking women at a local pub and then call him on a beeper to tell him of his prospects is a dubious ``winner'' in a national bosses' contest. Other bad and ``downright unbelievable'' bosses named Wednesday included a New York supervisor who followed female employees to the restroom and stood outside to time them. A boss at a brokerage firm in Cleveland was awarded a special ``boss-felon'' award for holding ``forgery contests'' among secretaries to see who could best forge clients' signatures on stocks and bonds. A boss in Gaylord, Minn., ``won'' for discriminating against pregnant women. The contest, sponsored by a Cleveland support group for clerical workers called 9to5, National Association of Working Women, also honored ``good'' bosses.

DOC.HEAD: Mendes Murder Trial Test of Justice in Brazil
DOC.TEXT: Many Brazilians see the trial of three ranchers accused of killing Chico Mendes, a champion of rubber tappers and the rain forest, as a test of justice in a nation traditionally ruled by money. It is to begin next month, on a date not yet determined, in a tiny courtroom in the Amazon jungle town of Xapuri, where Mendes was shot down outside his home Dec. 11, 1988. At issue, in addition to the facts of the case, are a disregard for law that has penetrated all levels of Brazilian society, and the general belief that the rich and powerful can bribe their way out of anything. ``Morality in Brazil has hit such a low that ethical conduct is no longer regarded as practical,'' Rio sociologist Helio Jaguaribe said in an interview. Money always has been valued above the law in this nation of 150 million, which is suffering its worst economic crisis, but the Mendes case has highlighted what Brazilians call the ``impunity'' of the rich. It also has inspired demands for moral and judicial reform. Mendes, who was 44 when he died, led a rubber tappers' union and fought to save the Amazon from deforestation. He was killed despite warnings to Brazil's top justice officials that named his potential assassins. Internationally, he became a martyr to environmentalism. In Brazil, he is revered more as a man who died protecting the rights of peasants against powerful ranchers, who often hire gunmen to do their bidding in the jungle. The national and international outcry produced an initial flurry of activity. Police arrested a cattle rancher and his two sons a month after the killing and promised repeatedly that justice would be done. Judicial squabbling and red tape have put the trial on hold for 17 months, however, and the three suspects nearly escaped from the lightly guarded Acre state penitentiary in January. Because of the delay, some have begun to wonder whether the trial will occur. Amnesty International says only two of 1,000 killings linked to land conflicts between Brazilian peasants and landowners have gone to trial since 1980. Several assassination attempts were made last year on Julio Barbosa, who succeeded Mendes as leader of the Xapuri rubber tappers. Corruption took root under the military regimes of 1964-1985 and blossomed after five years of ineffectual government under civilian President Jose Sarney, who was replaced in March by Fernando Collor de Mello. During Sarney's term, nearly all the federal budget was spent on financing a bloated government. Fraud in financing a multimillion-dollar railroad project and a graft scandal involving a former planning minister went unpunished. Newspapers regularly carried reports of legislators paying for extravagant trips with public money. ``People have read so much about the dirty deals of corrupt congressmen and state officials that they think anything goes,'' said Radley Vigio, a Rio police officer. On New Year's Eve 1988, the tourist boat Bateau Mouche IV, built to carry 50, was jammed with 150 revelers and sank in front of Sugar Loaf Mountain, killing 54 people. Naval police had stopped the boat, but let it go, and there were accusations a bribe was paid. Last October, a clandestine landfill created by a private construction company collapsed on the Nova Republica slum in Sao Paulo. At least 14 people were known dead and about 75 were never found. No one has been arrested in either case. ``These inhuman things happen because the guilty often slip through the fingers of the justice system,'' said Lt. Eide Trindade, director of Rio's task force on organized crime. An outdated legal code, labyrinthine bureacracy and lack of resources discourage police, which prompts people to take the law into their own hands. A mob of 1,000 people raided a jail in the northeastern town of Santa Maria da Vitoria last year and lynched two men suspected of killing a 19-year-old woman. Violence continues in the Amazon. Leftist union leader Expeditor Ribeiro de Souza and two of his three sons were killed recently in the northern Amazon state of Para, despite warnings to the police that ranchers had hired gunmen to kill them.

DOC.HEAD: Moldavians Strive for Union Despite Border
DOC.TEXT: Moldavians are moving closer together despite the frontier Josef Stalin erected between them in 1940 when he seized Bessarabia from Romania and made it Soviet Moldavia. Early in April, Romanian peasants in the border area dismantled the wire fence on their side of the Prut River border and urged Soviet Moldavians do to the same. On Sunday, May 6, Soviet Moldavia opened the border for six hours so Romanians could cross and visit their ethnic brethren. Tens of thousands did so. Soviet citizens were not allowed to visit Romania, but some sneaked in. People on both sides call the area a cradle of Romanian culture. For centuries, Iasi was a center of Romanian learning and capital of a ``greater Moldavia'' that included Bessarabia and northern Bukovina, also annexed by Moscow in 1940 and now in the Ukraine. The city of 500,000, Romania's second-largest, is only 6 miles from the border. Despite the calls for reunion, some inhabitants do not appear eager to make Iasi the center of a newly reunified ``greater Moldavia.'' ``It's not exactly the right time,'' said Alexandru Pascu, a senior reporter with the cultural weekly Cronica. ``We should see first what happens with Lithuania, Latvia and Estonia, then ask that Bessarabia be returned to Romania.'' ``If we do it now, Gorbachev won't accept the breakup of his empire and will probably use force to prevent it.'' President Mikhail S. Gorbachev imposed economic sanctions on Lithuania after it proclaimed independence from the Soviet Union. Latvia and Estonia also have declared their intention to become independent, but have proceeded more cautiously. Stalin annexed all three Baltic republics, as he did Bessarabia and northern Bukovina, under a secret protocol of his 1939 non-agression pact with Hitler. Romulus Neagu, deputy foreign minister of Romania, told reporters in Bucharest: ``Romania has no territorial claims, but as a general principle, one should observe the right of every nation to self-determination.'' With political union a distant goal, Moldavia's new culture minister, Ion Ungureanu, has urged creation of a ``cultural confederation.'' In an interview with the Romanian newpaper Adevarul in March, he said that would allow Moldavians and Soviet Moldavians to receive each other's television programs. About 300 prominent authors, journalists and Orthodox priests from Bucharest and Kishinev, capital of Soviet Moldavia, met in Bucharest on March 27 and demanded that Soviet Moldavia, or Bessarabia, be allowed to rejoin Romania. The meeting was organized for the 72nd anniversary of the union of the province with Romania in 1918, after World War I. Gheorghe Ghimpu, head of the Moldavian People's Front of Soviet Moldavia, declared at the conference: ``The tragedy of Moldavians started with the Hitler-Stalin pact, when unjust frontiers were imposed.'' Nicolae Stoicescu, religious affairs minister of Romania, appealed for ``the strengthening of cultural and spiritual unity'' between Romania and Soviet Moldavia as a ``first step toward political union.'' Other speakers demanded the ``amputated'' territory be returned to Romania. Yevgeny Tyazhelnikov, then Soviet ambassador to Romania, acknowledged late in March that ``there are tendencies aiming at the greater independence'' of Moldavia, but ruled out returning Bessarabia to Romania. Stoicescu met with Moldavians who advocate increased cultural cooperation, including deliveries of religious books in Romanian to the Soviet side of the border. Soviet Moldavians requested Romanian assistance and experts for restoration of churches in the republic. Millions of Romanians and Moldavians now can receive Sunday broadcasts of Orthodox Mass by Radio Iasi, which resumed operation after communist dictator Nicolae Ceausescu was deposed and executed in December. Ceausescu closed the station in 1985. It now broadcasts religious, historical and other news to ethnic Moldavians, who make up 70 percent of Soviet Moldavia's population. Revival of the radio station and growing border contacts are among the strongest indications to date of Romania's desire for some control over Soviet Moldavia. Soviet Moldavians began pressing for greater autonomy two years ago. In September, Soviet officials agreed to replace the Cyrillic alphabet imposed by Stalin with the Latin alphabet Romanians use.

DOC.HEAD: Fernandez Takes on Corrupt School Boards and Messy Desks
DOC.TEXT: Schools are crumbling, the administration is rife with bunglers, kids are failing tests and dropping out at a colossal rate _ and Board of Education bureaucrats are writing memos, telling teachers how to wash their hands. ``Apply soap, lather well,'' advised step No. 3. This is what Joseph A. Fernandez found when he arrived five months ago at 110 Livingston St., headquarters of the nation's largest school system. But since he took office as schools chancellor, Fernandez has shaken the system of its lethargy; he envisions a lean, mean education machine. ``I'm sure some people view me as the outsider, coming in and stirring this whole system up,'' Fernandez said. ``The bottom line on this is how does it impact kids,'' he said. ``I'm not concerned with how it impacts everybody else.'' Fernandez moved quickly to strengthen his authority. He dismissed several local school officials and took over the board governing one of the system's 32 local districts. The staff of 5,200 at 110 Livingston was cut by 400. By Fernandez' edict, top aides must be in the office by 7:30 a.m. And while there, they and the rest of the staff must follow rules on such things as office neatness, how to dress and proper telephone etiquette. ``He wants things done and he wants them done properly,'' said his spokesman, James Vlasto. ``Probably for the veterans here, it's taken them somewhat aback.'' The number of teachers and students in the system, almost 1.1 million combined, is larger than the population of Dallas, the nation's seventh-largest city. And its $7 billion budget is bigger than that of 15 states. The problems are just as big. More than 35 percent of the 950,000 students read below minimum standards. There is a backlog of 33,000 repair requests for the system's 1,000 buildings. In the 1988-89 school year, 1,854 weapons were confiscated from students and 9,000 reports of violence were recorded. Fernandez, a 53-year-old native New Yorker who spent his entire career outside the city, seems unfazed. Sitting behind a massive oak desk, classical music playing softly in the background, he gives the impression of a man firmly in control. Practicing what he preaches, everything on the desk _ and there's not much _ is piled neatly. A computer terminal sits to one side; he is the first schools chancellor to ask for one. He admits he has stepped on a few toes with his direct style, and angered some local school board members who feel he is overstepping his authority under the 20-year-old state law that decentralized the city schools. Some examples: _He appointed trustees to take over a long-troubled Brooklyn school district where auditors found $2 million was misspent and children were deprived of remedial reading, drug education and other services. _He ordered the suspension or removal of two district school superintendents and three principals. _He overturned a local school board's selection of a superintendent, issuing new rules in the process setting minimum standards for the job. Another school board was ordered to fire an untenured principal. _He is seeking to have each of the city's 1,000 schools publish an annual budget for public scrutiny. Fernandez' entire educational career had been in Florida, where he started as a math teacher in 1962. Within 10 years, he became Miami's first Hispanic principal and was named superintendent of schools there in 1987. He already has managed feats in New York that his predecessors were unable to accomplish. Gov. Mario Cuomo signed an act giving him the power to transfer principals, who had been granted ``building tenure'' by law. The bill passed after Fernandez hammered out a deal with the principals' union. He also has support in Albany, the state capital, to eliminate the city Board of Examiners, a teacher licensing board that critics say duplicates the state licensing apparatus and discourages teachers from working in New York City. But Fernandez' biggest innovation is one that he pioneered as head of schools in Miami _ one that, if successful, could free schools from such Board of Education dictates as last year's seven-step hand-washing memo. The plan, called school-based management and shared decision-making, would allow teachers, parents and principals to identify problems in their own schools _ problems like reading levels, poor attendance or drugs _ and develop solutions. Fernandez said he expects about 200 schools to participate in the first year. Officials at each school will receive $20,000 to use as they see fit _ for training or to hire consultants, for example. ``It's their plan, their strategy, their dollars,'' he said. ``As you get ownership, my experience has been people try a little bit harder to make the thing work.'' The chancellor's office will provide technical assistance and check progress toward the goals, ``having the ability to step in when the thing's not working right and fixing it,'' Fernandez said. ``There's a lot of people, not just here in the city watching, but nationally,'' he said. ``If it plays in New York, it can play anywhere.'' Fernandez has more innovations in mind. He is talking about increasing the high-school math requirement their plans. ``The association will never stop trying to broadcast,'' Nick said. ``Never, never, never.'' The ship is named after the statue erected by demonstrators in Tiananmen Square in Beijing in May 1989. It was destroyed during the June 4 military crackdown that left hundreds, perhaps thousands, of civilians dead. Exiled Chinese dissident leaders have expressed support for the project but none were expected to be on board for the broadcasts because of threats from Beijing that it would arrest Chinese aboard. The Nationalists retreated to Taiwan in 1949 after losing a civil war to Communist forces in mainland China. While the two sides remain technically at war, indirect trade and civilian contacts have increased in recent years.

DOC.HEAD: HBO's ``By Dawn's Early Light'' A Little Dim
DOC.TEXT: Early in the show, a couple drunkenly staggers into their motel room at night. At dawn, she gets mad when he suggests in crude terms it'd be no good for either of them if others knew of their affair. ``Ah, what I mean is, we function professionally first,'' he says, trying to mollify her. He worsens matters by saying they need to ``keep an official distance.'' This tends to undermine ``By Dawn's Early Light,'' an HBO movie premiering Saturday that concerns the prospect of doom thanks to Soviet military dissidents trying to provoke nuclear war with the United States. You see, the man in the motel (Powers Boothe) is an Air Force major, a B-52 bomber pilot. The woman (Rebecca De Mornay) is his co-pilot. It just does not do for B-52 bomber pilots to have love affairs. Sure as heck, they'll have a tiff at an awkward moment _ like while en route to a Soviet target. Suppose she sees one of the plane's bombs go off? Suppose she realizes the end of humanity is likely and refuses orders to drop another Big One? Well, she might be considered sane. But her beau might pull rank, give her a bottle of cyanide pills and say, ``You are relieved, captain. Get the hell out of here.'' And then relent, and gently plead, ``Don't leave me now.'' Alas, these things happen. And they sandbag what might otherwise be an interesting film about how the end of the Cold War doesn't necessarily mean the possibility of nuclear war is gone, too. Written by Bruce Gilbert, the film's trip to the edge of Armageddon begins when Soviet dissidents launch a nuclear missile against one of their own cities. This triggers an automatic nuclear attack on U.S. military bases and Andrews Air Force base near Washington, then the start of the U.S. counterattack, of which Boothe's five-member B-52 crew is part. The Soviet president, learning the truth of the first strike on his nation, desperately tries to turn off the war, pleading with his American counterpart (Martin Landau) to do likewise. The American wants to believe him and orders only an attack similar in scope to that of the Soviets, despite recommendations of massive retaliation. But the war escalates because of an error; U.S. computers don't initially realize a second Soviet launch is directed at China, not the United States. The crisis worsens when the U.S. president is thought killed in a nuclear blast. His immediate successors all are dead, and leadership of the nation passes to the Secretary of the Interior (Darren McGavin). In a welcome switch for this kind of movie, not all top U.S. military officers are portrayed as bomb-crazed, kill-the-commies lunatics. In fact, two senior officers _ James Earl Jones as the general commanding an airborne command post and Jeffrey De Munn as the new president's military adviser _ are the ones who repeatedly urge restraint. But it's to no avail, since the new, inexperienced president succumbs to the let's-go-boom blandishments of an Army colonel (Rip Torn). If that's not bad enough, one of Boothe's crew members, in anguish over the deaths of his family in the Soviet attack, goes mad. That has a terrible impact on most of the crew in his B-52. But the movie's in-flight attempt to heighten the drama just doesn't work. The film would have been far better without a B-52 crew lurking in it. For starters, this crew's cockpit discipline is plumb awful. And it's very hard to believe that not only is a woman flying the bomber (women in the U.S. military still are barred from combat slots), but that she and the command pilot are bunkmates. Boothe, as a flier of the good-old-boy school, turns in a masterful performance, despite dialogue so clunky it constitutes a lethal weapon. And the larger issues of doom raised by the movie do get one to thinking. But by shoehorning in amour and turning its B-52 into the Love Bomber, ``By Dawn's Early Light'' proves a lot more dim than it should have been.

Elsewhere in television ... OSGOOD AT THE MIGHTY STEINWAY: It isn't widely known that Charles Osgood, the poet laureate of CBS News, also is a pianist. But on Monday, he'll be playing such fine old standards as ``A Foggy Day'' at Carnegie Hall. The occasion is a seventh-birthday celebration for Skitch Henderson's New York Pops Orchestra. Osgood isn't the only musician at ``CBS This Morning.'' Co-host Paula Zahn is a cellist. They should get together with Gene Shalit of NBC's ``Today'' show, even though his weapon of choice is the bassoon.

DOC.HEAD: 1992 New Hampshire Primary Stuck in Starting Blocks
With PM-Quiet in Iowa
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: New Hampshire's first-in-the-nation presidential primary was beginning to rev up at this time four years ago. This time around, it's stuck in the garage. Presidential hopefuls including Democrats Richard Gephardt and Bruce Babbitt were campaigning actively in the state in May 1986. Republican George Bush and other candidates had campaign people at work there. This year, no potential candidates have visited in the past six months and no campaign people are soliciting support for would-be presidents. Democratic political activists in the state aren't lamenting the lack of attention. ``A long campaign focuses attention much too early and it takes away from things we need to be doing at the state and local levels,'' said state House Minority Leader Mary Chambers, who ran Michael Dukakis' 1988 campaign in New Hampshire. ``I don't believe the first-in-the-nation primary is beneficial for the state,'' said Dennis Murphy, who ran Illinois Sen. Paul Simon's 1988 presidential campaign in the state. ``It takes away from state politics.'' In the 1988 race, Gephardt campaigned for more than two years in Iowa and New Hampshire. The Missouri congressman won the Iowa caucus and finished second to Dukakis in New Hampshire, but ended up withdrawing before the national convention. Jean Wallin, co-chair of Gephardt's 1988 New Hampshire campaign, said ``there isn't any reason for them to be here now. You can accomplish as much in one year as in two, and you won't be burned out at election time.'' Murphy agreed. ``The joke in New Hampshire in 1980 was people would be asked, `Are you going to vote for Ronald Reagan?' and they would answer, `I don't know. I've only met him twice,''' he said. ``I don't think it's necessary for each person to meet a candidate four times before making a decision.'' With Reagan's retirement on the horizon, candidates and workers from both parties began descending on New Hampshire two years before the 1988 primary. This time, President Bush is expected to seek another term and Republican candidates are non-existent. Several prominent Democrats have visited the state, including Gephardt, West Virginia Sen. Jay Rockefeller, Ohio Gov. Richard Celeste and Colorado Rep. Patricia Schroeder, but none recently. Ned Helms, New Hampshire Democratic Party chairman, said many top Democrats have turned down invitations to speak in New Hampshire because they fear a visit would be misconstrued. Those who have stayed away include Texas Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley and New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, he said. ``People are reluctant to come to New Hampshire because the minute they get here people say, `Aha, you're running,''' Helms said. Other possible factors keeping Democrats from jumping into the campaign are Bush's high approval rating and the thrashing Dukakis took in 1988, activists said. ``I guess the Democrats may be thinking that Bush is a shoo-in,'' Wallin said. ``I certainly hope that's not the case.'' State GOP chairwoman Rhona Charbonneau and others said Massachusetts' swift economic decline, which began while Dukakis was campaigning for the presidency, has made candidates wary of starting too early. Many potential Democratic candidates also are concerned with re-election and don't want to risk leaving their states to start a presidential campaign, activists said. So when might candidates begin arriving in New Hampshire? Most political observers predict the stream of potential presidents will begin sometime after the November elections and most likely early next year. ``People should check their Christmas cards so they'll know who's going to be here in January,'' Wallin said. End Adv PM Mon May 21

DOC.HEAD: Iowa's Campaign Machinery Equipped With Everything But Candidates
With PM-Quiet in New Hampshire
DOC.TEXT: Iowa's perpetual campaign machinery is running short on one key component _ presidential candidates. ``It's a national question: Who are the candidates?'' said Democratic activist John Cacciatore. The 1990 midterm elections still are months away but thoughts already are turning toward the 1992 race for the White House. In Iowa, whose precinct caucuses are the nation's first test of presidential strength, things have been quiet but few are surprised. Not that there haven't been any visitors. The day after the 1988 election, Jesse Jackson courted farm activists in Des Moines, and he returned the following year. Texas Sen. Lloyd Bentsen keynoted a Democratic Party fund-raiser last fall, and lectured activists on the lessons to be learned from the party's latest loss. New Jersey Sen. Bill Bradley raised some money for local candidates, and Hawaii Sen. Daniel Inouye even joked about accepting the party's nomination during an event this year. Colorado Rep. Pat Schroeder has given a couple of policy speeches. All in all, activists say, things are about on track. ``At this point in the last cycle, you would have not seen anybody a lot,'' said Barry Piatt, who worked for Missouri Rep. Richard Gephardt's 1988 presidential campaign. Gephardt won the Iowa caucus but withdrew before the national convention. This year the story is a Democratic one, since President Bush is expected to seek a second term. There's been intense speculation about who the Democrats will field, and some have worried that none are making early moves. Iowa Democratic Party spokesman Joe Shannahan rejected those concerns, and pointed to campaign records from previous election cycles. The first candidate to put staffers in the field the last time around was former Arizona Gov. Bruce Babbitt, who dispatched two aides to work for local candidates in the summer of 1986, he said. In the 1984 election cycle, records show only token campaign appearances by this point. Florida Gov. Reubin Askew made one appearance in the spring of 1982, as did California Sen. Alan Cranston. Colorado Sen. Gary Hart made a single foray in May 1982, while Ohio Sen. John Glenn didn't visit Iowa until June of that year. Only the eventual 1984 Democratic nominee, Walter F. Mondale, had made multiple appearances by this point, the records show. Further, Shannahan said, the last election cycle was an intensely active one because there was no incumbent on the ballot. U.S. Rep. David Nagle, a former state Democratic chairman, said the timing of this year's campaign is logical. Bentsen, he said, generated wide name identification when he ran on the 1988 ticket with Massachusetts Gov. Michael Dukakis, and would benefit by the shortest possible campaign. Others have what's known as the ``1990 problem.'' ``The reason you don't have presidential candidates in Iowa this year is because the potential presidential candidates are running for re-election in their home states,'' Nagle said. Bradley, Gephardt, Tennessee Sen. Albert Gore Jr., New York Gov. Mario Cuomo, Illinois Sen. Paul Simon and Ms. Schroeder all are on the ballot this year, he noted. While many see the early presidential contests as an endurance contest, that's not always the case. Dukakis won his party's nomination, and finished a respectable third in Iowa. His first campaign appearance in the state came in January 1987, roughly a year before the precinct caucuses. ``You can come reasonably late to Iowa and still get a fair shake,'' Nagle said.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Mon May 21

DOC.SECOND: PM-Another Look: Lester Maddox, Adv 21, 1st Ld-Writethru,
DOC.NOTE: $Adv21
For Release Monday PMs, May 21, and Thereafter
DOC.HEAD: Maddox Still Outspoken, But Says Race Not His Issue Now
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 18th graf, ``A hearty ... you, friend?'' to CORRECT location of courthouse from Forest Park to Jonesboro; PICKS UP 19th graf, ``Jurors, deputies ... a typhoon.''
DOC.HEAD: An AP Extra
LaserPhoto AX3 of May 16
DOC.TEXT: Former Gov. Lester Maddox, whose name became synonymous with Southern segregationist defiance in the 1960s, is back campaigning for his old job and outrageously outspoken as ever. But he says good government _ not race _ is his issue now. Let there be no mistake: Maddox, who closed his Pickrick fried chicken restaurant in Atlanta in the '60s rather than serve blacks, still disapproves of desegregation. ``As well as a constitutional human right to associate with whomever you please, there should be a corresponding right to disassociate if you please,'' he said recently. But he prefers to colorfully expound on his contention that he's the only hope of freeing Georgia from the grip of wasteful political insiders. ``I want to be your Ex Lax in state government,'' was a frequent quip one warm spring day as he pounded the sidewalks and shopping centers in the southern suburbs of Atlanta, popping in on unsuspecting merchants and their customers and, momentarily, taking center stage. Spry at age 74 despite a bout with cancer, Maddox is one of five candidates seeking the Democratic gubernatorial nomination in the state's July 17 primary. A 16-year absence from state office has taken its toll. A recent newspaper poll showed Maddox in last place in the five-man Democratic field with 3 percent. Former Atlanta Mayor Andrew Young led with 29 percent in his bid to become the nation's second black elected governor and Georgia's first. Maddox sees it differently: ``Either me or Andy Young is going to be the next governor.'' A public school dropout who later took a correspondence course and opened a restaurant, Maddox became Georgia's governor in 1967 because of a fluke in state law. Nationally known for opposing integration, including an incident in which customers at his restaurant armed themselves with pick handles, Maddox won the Democratic nomination in 1966 but got fewer votes in the general election than Republican Howard ``Bo'' Callaway. Write-in votes for other candidates kept Callaway from receiving a majority. The election thus was thrown to the heavily Democratic Legislature, which chose Maddox. Despite his advance billing, Maddox said in his inaugural address he would not tolerate extremism in Georgia, and he proceeded to appoint more blacks to state office than any of his predecessors. Maddox also initiated a twice-monthly affair called ``Little People's Day,'' opening the doors of his office to anyone with a problem. The law at that time did not allow governors to seek consecutive terms, so at the end of four years, Maddox ran for and won the office of lieutenant governor, ousting the incumbent. But his popularity waned as he and Jimmy Carter, who succeeded him as governor, wrangled bitterly for four years, and Maddox lost a bid in 1974 to regain the governorship. Sixteen years later, time seems to have done little to dull his exuberant personality, sense of timing or love of one-liners. A hearty handshake that pulls the other party off-balance long has been a Maddox trademark. It still was in force as he grabbed hands in the Clayton County Courthouse in suburban Jonesboro, often with a ``How you, friend?'' Jurors, deputies, clerks, lawyers searching deed titles _ all were fair game as he moved through the building like a typhoon. Several asked ``Old Lester'' how he was doing. A typical reply: ``I'm praying and loving and living, and if you aren't doing the first two, you aren't doing much of the third.'' Some asked if he brought his bicycle, referring to his gimmick of riding a bicycle backwards. Not this time, he told them. The campaigning this day was in friendly territory, places that 16 years ago likely would have sported campaign signs proclaiming, ``This is Maddox Country.'' Many remembered Maddox, including Guy Roundtree of Riverdale. ``He's a fine man,'' Roundtree said. ``I voted for him when he was governor.'' But there were a lot of blank stares, too. With 3.6 million of Georgia's estimated 6.4 million residents under the age of 34, that means 56 percent of the population wasn't even of voting age when Maddox left office. But he insisted he has a chance. ``The people seem to be more unhappy, more dissatisfied now .. . than I have ever imagined or experienced. They feel like they're being left out, and there's nobody fighting for them. I think that's one of the strong things going for my candidacy,'' he said. Maddox contended he is the only candidate with government experience ``who knows what to do with dollars _ how to spend 'em and how to use 'em _ and how to speak on behalf of outsiders. ... There's no candidate likely to be elected governor, other than myself, who isn't a captive of the political establishment.''
DOC.NOTE: End Adv for Mon PMs, May 21
