DOC.HEAD: Engineers Say Martial Arts Protective Gear Inadequate
DOC.TEXT: Engineers who practice the Korean martial art tae kwon do used a mechanical leg and videotapes of sparring sessions to conclude that currently accepted protective gear is inadequate. The study found that a tae kwon do kick can carry the same energy as a major league fastball racing at 90 mph, and can cave in a person's chest by as much as two inches, creating a high risk of internal injuries. The study was conducted by University of California, Berkeley, mechanical engineering Professor Dennis Lieu, who twice needed hospital attention after keeling over from tae kwon do blows even though he was wearing protective gear. His co-author was engineering student and 1989 National Collegiate Taekwondo Champion Elaine Serina. Tae kwon do originally was taught for warfare, self-defense and fitness. It has gained wide popularity as a competitive sport and was introduced as a demonstration event at the 1988 Olympics in South Korea. Lieu and Serina used high-speed videotape to record a sparring session between them, then analyzed the tapes at slow speed. ``I remember asking her to kick me so we could have it on tape,'' Lieu recalled. ``She did, and I bent over in pain and wound up on the floor.'' The engineers then developed a mechanical leg to recreate tae kwon do kicks under laboratory conditions, using torso models similar to those used in automobile crash experiments. They concluded existing protective gear is much too soft, and needs to be more rigid in critical areas to adequately protect against internal injuries.
DOC.HEAD: Anti-Smoking Campaigns Are Effective, Study Finds
DOC.TEXT: Cigarette smoking dropped 2{ percent during the first year of an anti-tobacco advertising campaign in two Australian cities, suggesting a similar effort in California will succeed, a researcher says. That ``may not sound like a tremendous drop, but it is,'' said John P. Pierce, an associate professor of community and family medicine at the University of California, San Diego. The same reduction in the United States would mean hundreds of thousands fewer smokers, said Pierce, who studied the effectiveness of the Australian television advertising blitz while working at the University of Sydney. Pierce's study was published in the May issue of the American Journal of Public Health. He presented the unpublished findings to California's Legislature last August, helping persuade lawmakers to spend cigarette tax money for a $28.6 million media campaign that was launched April 10. ``The Australian campaign is the prototype for the California campaign,'' Pierce said. ``If the campaign can achieve similar results here, it means there would be 660,000 fewer smokers in California by mid-1991.'' TV commercials that focused on the health hazards of smoking aired during prime time for six to eight weeks each year, starting in 1983 in Sydney and 1984 in Melbourne. Pierce and his colleagues surveyed 20,000 residents of Sydney and Melbourne. They found the 2{ percent drop in smoking one year after the campaign started. In subsequent years, smoking among Australian men dropped an additional 1{ percent per year, but didn't drop further among women _ a difference Pierce said isn't yet understood. Before joining UCSD in January, Pierce worked at the U.S. Centers for Disease Control as chief epidemiologist in the Office on Smoking and Health.
DOC.HEAD: Breasts Can Be Rebuilt Using Thigh Tissue
DOC.TEXT: Doctors are starting to use thigh tissue to rebuild breasts for women who underwent mastectomy due to breast cancer. Silicone implants now are the most common form of breast reconstruction, followed by the transplant of skin, fat and muscle taken from the abdomen and buttocks. But three Atlanta plastic surgeons say ``thigh flaps'' _ or tissue taken from the thighs _ also can be used. Some women would prefer to have excess tissue removed from their thighs than from their abdomen or buttocks. Others might need to use the thigh tissue method, said L. Franklyn Elliott, one of the surgeons who reported on the new method earlier this year in the journal Plastic and Reconstructive Surgery. Some women may be unable to have their abdominal tissue used either because they don't have enough or because they have abdominal scars from previous surgery, Elliott said. The thighs have longer veins and arteries than buttock tissue, providing better blood flow to the reconstructed breast, he added. Dr. William Shaw, head of plastic surgery at the University of California, Los Angeles, cautions that use of thigh flaps has drawbacks. Fatty tissue isn't as consistently plentiful in the thighs as in the buttocks, so the use of thigh flaps poses a risk of creating deformities in the thighs, or of making one thigh appear smaller than the other, he said. Elliott replied that as surgeons become more experienced using thigh flaps, they will become more skilled in using liposuction and other methods to minimize disfigurement and to match the two thighs. ``Generally, my patients who have chosen breast reconstruction using thigh flaps have preferred the resulting deformity to the `saddlebags' they had before,'' he said.
DOC.NOTE: End advance for May 21

DOC.TEXT: A steep hike in health care costs led a modest rise in inflation last month, the government said. Overall, consumers received their first break since a cold snap sent prices soaring at the beginning of the year. The government said Wednesday that declines in the cost of vegetables, fuel oil and women's clothing offset higher health care costs to restrain the overall increase. The rise in the Consumer Price Index was held to a seasonally adjuted 0.2 percent in April, the most modest gain in seven months.

Troubled Circle K Corp. said it sought federal bankruptcy court protection after it failed to reach agreement with creditors on a plan to work out of its massive debt problems. The company, owner of the nation's second-largest convenience store chain after Southland Corp.'s 7-Eleven, filed for Chapter 11 protection from creditors late Tuesday. Circle K listed $1.94 billion in assets and $1.58 billion in liabilities, including $993.2 million in secured and unsecured debts to 711 creditors.

Housing starts fell in April to their lowest level since the last recession in 1982, the government said. The Commerce Department said Wednesday that starts of new homes and apartments fell 5.8 percent in April to a seasonally adjusted annual rate of 1.25 million units, the smallest number since an annual rate of 1.17 million units in the recession month of October 1982.

British media baron Robert Maxwell said his Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd. has agreed to buy the gossipy tabloids Globe, National Examiner and Sun in the latest ownership shakeup among the publishers of magazines sold mainly in grocery checkout aisles. Terms were not disclosed. Maxwell said Wednesday he hoped to complete the purchase from Globe International Publishing Inc. by mid-June. Globe International said the combined circulation of the three weekly magazines exceeds 2.5 million.

Mobil Corp., one of the major producers of plastic grocery bags, said it will begin collecting and recycling used bags from supermarkets across the country. The oil giant's Mobil Chemical Co. unit annually manufactures over 5 billion of the 23 billion bags used by the nation's grocery stores. Mobil said Wednesday it will recycle the bags into plastic sacks and other products made of polyethylene, such as plastic garbage cans. The first stores to participate in the program will be 244 Safeway markets in California, Nevada and Hawaii, which will begin collecting bags sometime next month.

West Germany said it was creating a $70 billion fund to help rebuild East Germany's shattered economy. The opposition said the move raised new questions about unification's real costs. Details of the plan Wednesday were outlined by West Germany's finance minister, who said costs of the program would be borne by the government and the 11 West German states.

Earnings for the nation's 500 largest service companies dropped 12.3 percent in 1989, but it still was their second most profitable year ever, Fortune magazine said in an annual ranking released. The report Wednesday attributed the decline for the Fortune Service 500 to drops in profitability among the biggest commercial banking, thrift and retailing businesses. Fortune said the 500 biggest service companies earned a combined $69.7 billion in 1989, down from a revised $79.5 billion a year earlier.

The bankruptcy trustee for the Delaware & Hudson Railway has accepted a $25 million bid for the carrier from Canadian Pacific Ltd. Under the agreement, Canadian Pacific either will run the Delaware & Hudson or underwrite its operation by a trustee. The freight line runs from Montreal to Washington and from Albany, N.Y., to Buffalo, N.Y. The Delaware & Hudson, the nation's oldest continuously operated railroad, filed in June 1988 for Chapter 11 protection from its creditors. It is about $100 million in debt.

Instant photography came to the Soviet Union with the opening of a retail shop in Moscow that will sell Polaroid cameras to Soviets for rubles. The cameras, assembled at a Soviet plant from Polaroid components, will sell for 250 rubles, or about $405, while 10-exposure instant film packs will sell for 30 rubles, or $48, a company spokesman said Wednesday. The new shop is a joint venture formed by Polaroid Corp. and the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Energy and Industries.

The stock market backed off Wednesday from record highs of recent sessions while traders assessed the latest inflation statistics. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 2.77 to 2,819.68. The dollar closed mostly lower. The bond market lost ground despite more evidence that inflation is slowing. Pork futures prices soared after a report showed an unexpected drop in pork belly stocks; cattle futures advanced; cocoa and coffee futures surged; precious metals retreated; oil futures were mixed; and grains and soybeans were mixed.

DOC.HEAD: Maxwell's Mirror Group Agrees to Buy Globe, Two Other Supermarket Tabs
DOC.TEXT: The supermarket tabloids are being devoured! The Globe, National Examiner and Sun are the latest gossipy weeklies about to fall under new ownership. The much-larger National Enquirer and its sister publication Weekly World News were bought out last year. Star magazine is in the process of changing owners. Industry analysts were hard-pressed to find a common link among the sales, however. The National Enquirer was sold after its founder died. Star no longer fit the strategic plans of Rupert Murdoch's News Corp. The latest acquisition would give British media baron Robert Maxwell a chance to put his experience with tabloids in Europe to work in the United States. Maxwell said Wednesday his Mirror Group Newspapers Ltd. has agreed to buy the Globe, National Examiner and Sun from Globe International Publishing Inc. Terms were not disclosed but industry executives said the three magazines could command somewhere between $100 million and $200 million. Globe International, a privately-held publishing concern based in Montreal, said the combined circulation of the three magazines exceeds 2.5 million. Only last year, the much larger National Enquirer and Weekly World News were sold for $412.5 million to a group that included Macfadden Holdings Inc., a media investment firm, and Boston Ventures Management. The new owners of that company, known as G.P. Group Inc. of Lantana, Fla., subsequently agreed in late March to buy Star from News Corp. for $400 million in cash and stock. The National Enquirer has a circulation of more than 4.1 million while Star ranks second among supermarket tabloids at 3.6 million. Weekly World News sells nearly 850,000 copies a week. The Globe International tabloids, whcih are published in Boca Raton, Fla., would be Maxwell's first magazines in the United States, where his main interest has been book publishing and information services. But his Mirror Group PLC publishes the Daily Mirror, the United Kingdom's second largest newspaper. Its other British newspapers include Sporting Life and the Daily Record and the Sunday Mail in Scotland. Mirror Group also recently launched The European, an English-language weekend newspaper for Europe. Maxwell reportedly lost out in bidding for the National Enquirer. The Globe and the National Examiner each have been published for about 35 years. The Globe originated as a local entertainment magazine in Montreal called Midnight while the National Examiner had its roots in the Midwest, according to Globe International spokesman Dean Heine. He said Mike Rosenbloom, the owner of Globe International, acquired both the Globe and National Examiner about 20 years ago. Rosenbloom started Sun about nine years ago. The Audit Bureau of Circulations said Globe had an average circulation of 1.33 million in the six months ended Dec. 31, down 12.9 percent from a year earlier, while National Examiner averaged nearly 894,000, down 20.2 percent. The Bureau does not audit circulation figures for Sun, but Heine said its circulation is about 450,000 a week. Heine said the three magazines emphasize entertainment and generally have moved away from the gruesome stories that once characterized the supermarket tabloids. In the current edition of Globe, the cover features photos of actresses Vanna White and Linda Evans to accompany a featured story alleging they are ``in a bitter battle for the same man.'' The National Examiner has cover stories claiming that former evangelist Jim Bakker is going insane and describing the plight of a tourist whose prosthetic plastic nose melted in the Florida heat. ``Jesus back on earth, say scholars'' reads another cover headline. David Adler, a spokesman for Maxwell, said it is too early to say what Maxwell's plans are for the three tabloids. The sale will leave Globe International with several publications distributed mainly in supermarkets and convenience stores, including so-called mini-mags that feature calorie counters or horoscopes. It also publishes Bridal Guide, the humor magazine Cracked and Your Health magazine as well as detective magazines and puzzle books.

DOC.HEAD: Northrop to Eliminate 3,000 Jobs in Latest Blow to California Aerospace
DOC.TEXT: Northrop Corp. added to the litany of woes for California's aerospace industry by announcing it would trim its workforce by 7 percent because of defense spending cuts on its B-2 bomber. The company said it would eliminate 3,000 jobs by the end of the year, including 2,700 in Southern California, through layoffs and attrition. The cuts followed similar moves by McDonnell Douglas Corp. and Lockheed Corp. and are expected to reverberate through thousands of smaller firms in the industry. ``World events, government decisions, economic conditions, are all evolving at a rapid rate _ at an unprecedented rate,'' Chief Executive Kent Kresa said in announcing the layoffs. ``Questions are being asked about fundamental assumptions that have not been questioned since many of us here were children,'' he said in remarks prepared for Northrop's annual meeting Wednesday. The radar-dodging, bat-winged stealth bomber made up 58 percent of Northrop's $1.28 billion in first-quarter sales this year. But because of easing world tensions, Defense Secretary Dick Cheney has proposed cutting purchases of the bomber from 132 to 75. Peak production would fall from 36 planes a year to 12. ``The party's over. There's going to be some pain,'' said Jack Kyser, a Chamber of Commerce economist. Last week McDonnell Douglas said it would cut 4,000 jobs, mostly in Long Beach, and Lockheed announced it would shut down in Burbank, eliminating 4,500 local jobs over the next few years. Kyser said Northrop may have decided it was best to announce its layoffs on the heels of bad news from the other companies. ``It may be the idea that the rain is already falling,'' he said. ``They're in sort of a batten down the hatches, survival mode anyway.'' The layoffs could create a ripple effect through the aerospace industry, the greatest source of manufacturing jobs in the region. Kyser said 70 percent of the area's aerospace companies employ 50 or fewer workers. Kresa noted that Northrop has 6,000 subcontractors and suppliers in the region. ``On our major programs today, Northrop as prime contractor is responsible for only 30 or 40 percent of the work; 60 to 70 percent is done by our subcontractors and suppliers,'' Kresa said. ``They also will be among the first to feel the effects of budget reductions and stretchouts.'' Northrop's employment peaked at 48,200 at the end of 1987. It has cut 2,500 employees during the past year and now has about 41,000 workers. Kresa also said Northrop can eliminate its $1 billion in debt by the mid-1990s through cost-cutting and sale of assets. He cited the recent sale and partial leaseback of its corporate headquarters complex, which produced an after-tax gain of $90 million and cut the company's short-term debt by $218 million. Kresa also set a goal for Northrop, which lost $63.5 million last year, or returning to the 20 percent return-on-equity level it achieved in the mid-'80s. ``I was impressed by his comments,'' said Lawrence Harris, a securities analyst with Bateman Eichler, Hill Richards in Los Angeles. ``The 20 percent return-on-equity goal is certainly ambitious, but it's the kind of target the Street would be looking for on a long-term basis.'' Kresa said the slowdown in the B-2 program would allow Northrop to proceed with full-scale development of the advanced tactical fighter at its ultramodern Pico Rivera plant next year if the company wins the contract on the next-generation fighter. A Northrop-led team is competing with a Lockheed-led team. Harris said that statement suggests Northrop is studying the possible sale of all or part of its Hawthorne facility, where it does subcontracting work on Boeing 747s. He estimated the 218 acres of land there is worth $114 million and the buildings another $296 million. Another possible target is a Ventura County plant that produces targets and drones and has worked to develop the Tacit Rainbow missile, Harris said. The missile will be produced in Georgia and many engineering tasks already have been moved to Hawthorne. He estimated the Ventura land and buildings could fetch $130 million.

DOC.HEAD: Convenience Store Chain Files for Chapter 11 Protection
DOC.TEXT: Circle K Corp. has become the nation's latest retailer to seek bankruptcy court protection after being unable to pay off a huge debt incurred during a rapid expansion program. The nation's second-largest convenience store chain said Wednesday it resorted to a Chapter 11 filing after failing to reach agreement with creditors on a plan to work out its debt problems. The filing surprised some analysts because Circle K last month halted interest payments to bondholders under a tentative debt-restructuring agreement with senior creditors and its largest shareholder, American Financial Corp. The agreement included a moratorium on senior debt payments through Oct. 31 But Circle K spokesman Ray Cox said some senior creditors balked at signing the standstill agreement. He declined to say which lenders threw the company into bankruptcy but said American Financial was not among them. The Cincinnati-based company owns 38.3 percent of Circle K's stock. ``I think most people felt that since they had been given until October by their short-term creditors, they would put together a restructuring plan and come out of it,'' said Dennis Telzrow, an analyst with Eppler, Guerin & Turner of Dallas. Circle K listed $1.94 billion in assets and $1.58 billion in liabilities, including $993.2 million in secured and unsecured debts to 711 creditors. The other liabilities were claims by about 47,000 creditors, mostly suppliers to Circle K stores. The company isn't alone with its debt woes. Ames Department Stores and the department stores owned by Campeau Corp. are reorganizing under Chapter 11, struggling with debt taken on through takeovers. Debt problems forced Southland, which has about 7,000 7-Eleven stores, to agree to sell a controlling interest to Japan's 7-Eleven franchiser. Telzrow said investors' faith in management may have been shaken during five years of unrelenting expansion under former chairman Karl Eller, who resigned eight days before the Chapter 11 filing late Tuesday. He said it is possible creditors might ask U.S. Bankruptcy Judge George B. Nielsen Jr. to appoint a trustee to run the company. When Eller took over in mid-1983, Circle K had 1,200 stores in 11 states with annual sales of $750 million. By last November, it had grown to a peak of 4,685 stores in 33 states and 1,386 licensed or joint-venture stores in 13 foreign countries. Revenues last year totaled $3.5 billion. The company incurred about $1.3 billion in debt to finance its expansion, mainly high-interest junk bonds. Annual interest payments exceeded $100 million. Eller tried to sell Circle K last summer but got nowhere, and he came up short in his attempt at a leveraged buyout. Two months ago Circle K announced a $42 million operating loss in the quarter ended Jan. 31. Company attorneys met Wednesday with the bankruptcy judge, but Cox said he could not comment on the talks. He said company attorneys didn't know when they would have a reorganization plan ready. President Robert Dearth Jr. said Circle K stores and warehouses would operate as usual. He said the company was optimistic about receiving cooperation from its vendors. Circle K has announced plans to sell 350 stores in the Pacific Northwest and another 25 in Hawaii, but neither sale has closed. Those sales now would need the approval of the bankruptcy court to proceed. Circle K now operates about 4,641 stores in 32 states, plus the foreign stores.

DOC.HEAD: Settlement Reached in Suit Challenging Lucky-Alpha Beta Merger
DOC.TEXT: The state claimed victory in its fight to maintain competition at the grocery counter after California's largest supermarket chain agreed to sell most of its Alpha Beta stores to settle antitrust charges. Wednesday's decision by American Stores Co. of Salt Lake City ended a 1{-year legal battle with California authorities over its $2.5 billion acquisition of the Lucky supermarket chain. It also follows a key U.S. Supreme Court ruling last month that allowed the state to sue the company to overturn the merger. Previously, it had been widely assumed states and citizens could not interfere with deals once they were completed. American Stores did not admit that the takeover was anti-competitive and said it agreed to the settlement to avoid any more costly legal battles. ``It is evident the time required and disruption caused by further litigation with the attorney general would only serve to create great confusion and uncertainty for employees, shareholders and lenders,'' said J.L. Scott, chief executive of American Stores. Attorney General John Van de Kamp, who had contended the merger would hurt competition in the supermarket business, hailed the agreement. ``This is wonderful news for California consumers struggling to stretch their grocery dollar,'' said Van de Kamp. Under the terms of a consent decree, American Stores will continue to operate Lucky but, within the next five years, must sell 152 of Alpha Beta's 175 stores in Southern California. It also will convert nine Alpha Betas into Lucky stores and sell nine Lucky stores. Van de Kamp said American's operation of the remaining 14 Alpha Beta stores would not hurt competition. American Stores also agreed to pay $550,000 to the Attorney General's office to cover a portion of the attorneys fees and other costs. The agreement was approved by U.S. District Judge David W. Kenyon in Los Angeles, who would have presided over a trial. The deal puts no restrictions on American Store's future growth in California and doesn't require the attorney general to approve of the buyer, price or terms of the sale of the stores. Scott said American Stores expected to receive full value for the Alpha Beta stores. In 1989, the 161 stores subject to divesture earned $32.5 million on sales of $1.8 billion. American Stores completed the purchase of Dublin, Calif.-based Lucky Stores Inc. in May 1988 to create the state's largest grocery store chain with more than 500 stores and annual sales of more than $20 billion. Four months later, Van de Kamp sued to block the merger on grounds it was anti-competitive. American had contended the deal would ultimately help consumers because Alpha Beta stores would adopt Lucky's low-price policies. But a federal court forbade the joint operation of Lucky and Alpha Beta until the matter could be resolved in court. In April, the U.S. Supreme Court voted 9-0 to empower Van de Kamp to sue to undo the merger. Wednesday's agreement marked a political victory for Van de Kamp, who is running against former San Francisco Mayor Dianne Feinstein for the Democratic gubernatorial nomination. The deal only affects Alpha Beta stores in Southern California. In an earlier deal between American Stores and the state. American Stores agreed to sell 13 of Alpha Betas Northern California stores and integrate the other 23 into Lucky's chain.

DOC.HEAD: Another Test Coming for the Art Market
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto NY43 of May 16
DOC.TEXT: The sale of a van Gogh for a record $82.5 million bodes well for tonight's auction of a renowned Renoir painting, but collectors aren't spending so freely for less significant works, art experts said. Renoir's depiction of an open-air dance hall in Montmartre, ``Au Moulin dela Galette,'' is to be auctioned at Sotheby's. On Tuesday night, van Gogh's ``Portrait of Dr. Gachet'' was the highlight of a contemporary art sale at Christie's, drawing a record bid from a Japanese gallery. ``When you have a tremendous painting, like the van Gogh or the Renoir that's coming up Thursday night, you're going to get extraordinary prices,'' said Milton Esterow, editor and publisher of ARTnews. Buyers are being selective, however, and only the most highly prized works inspire frenzied bidding. Even with the van Gogh, Christie's entire sale brought a total of $269.4 million. Although that was only $67,000 under the record for an art auction held by Sotheby's, 24 of the 81 offerings did not sell and some that did went for significantly less than their pre-sale estimate. ``I think (Tuesday) night showed that the market is correcting to a more realistic level,'' Esterow said. The Renoir is estimated by Sotheby's to sell for $40 to $50 million, the same presale estimate as the van Gogh. Its owner is Betsey Cushing Whitney, the widow of John Hay Whitney, the financier, publisher, sportsman and former ambassador to Britain. The large canvas captures an afternoon crowd of revelers beneath a lush canopy of acacia trees at an open-air dance hall in Montmartre that was popular in the artist's day. ``With the van Gogh taking such an unprecedented leap into $82 million that perhaps the other collectors will have to follow suit and put their estimates a little bit higher as far as the Whitney picture is concerned,'' said Harry Brooks, director of the Wildenstein Gallery in Manhattan. The winning bid for ``Dr. Gachet'' was placed by Hideto Kobayashi of the Gallery of Kobayashi of Tokyo. The gallery won a heated bidding contest with an unidentified European buyer, represented by Charles Allsopp, chairman of Christie's in London. The Japanese play a major role in the impressionist and post-impressionist art market and accounted for a third of the activity in the auction room, said Michael J. Findlay, who heads the impressionist and modern art sales for Christie's. Americans and Europeans represented the other two thirds, he said. Five of the 11 most expensive paintings sold at auction have been bought by Japanese collectors, including Pablo Picasso's ``Pierrette's Wedding,'' purchased in 1987 for $51.3 million, and van Gogh's ``Sunflowers,'' bought in 1987 for $39.9 million. The strong Japanese presence is attributed by art experts to the wealth in Japan, bolstered the yen's rise against the dollar in recent years. Also, Japan has a tradition since the 1930s of collecting impressionist art. ``Van Gogh was an artist who was unabashedly an admirer of Japanese art and prints,'' said Findlay. Many of the impressionists' notions of composition _ like the flattened perspective _ and color come directly from Japan, he said. David Nash, senior vice president in charge of fine arts at Sotheby's in New York, said Japanese collectors had made inquiries about ``Au Moulin de la Galette.'' ``I have no predictions to make about what will happen to the Renoir,'' Nash said. ``Obviously, it is encouraging to see that a major 19th century painting can bring such a high price,'' he said of the van Gogh. Renoir paintings have not fetched the top prices that van Gogh's works have. The highest price paid for a Renoir was $17.7 million in April 1989 for ``La Promenade''; it was bought by the J. Paul Getty Museum. Until Tuesday night, the highest price ever paid for a painting at auction was $53.9 million for van Gogh's ``Irises.'' Esterow noted that substantially more Renoirs have been on the market and that their quality is less consistent. But Findlay of Christie's said ``Au Moulin de la Galette'' was special. ``There hasn't been a Renoir of that quality so we don't know what the market will say about it,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Bosses Range From Good to Bad to `Downright Unbelievable'
DOC.NOTE: EDs: 9to5 correct in grafs 5, The contest, and 13, `Common themes' Also moving on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: A Philadelphia businessman who asked his secretary to scout for good-looking women at a local pub and then call him on a beeper to tell him of his prospects is a dubious ``winner'' in a national bosses' contest. Other bad and ``downright unbelievable'' bosses named Wednesday included a New York supervisor who followed female employees to the restroom and stood outside to time them. A boss at a brokerage firm in Cleveland was awarded a special ``boss-felon'' award for holding ``forgery contests'' among secretaries to see who could best forge clients' signatures on stocks and bonds. A boss in Gaylord, Minn., ``won'' for discriminating against pregnant women. The contest, sponsored by a Cleveland support group for clerical workers called 9to5, National Association of Working Women, also honored ``good'' bosses. Those included the president of a computer services firm in Birmingham, Ala., for progressive family leave policies; a department chairman at Hofstra University in Hempstead, N.Y., for advocating pay raises; and the chairman of Northwest Airlines for making company employees ``feel like an asset to the airline.'' Identities of the unbelievable and bad bosses were not released. A Philadelphia secretary who nominated her boss said she was asked ``to go to a `beef & beer' to check out girls before he entered. ``He told me to beep him if there was anyone good-looking in the bar so he wouldn't waste his time,'' the woman wrote. Another bad boss was nominated by a state worker in Madison, Wis., whose mother had to be rushed to the hospital. The next day, the worker asked for the afternoon off to visit her. ``Well ... go ahead. But next time you should plan these things better,'' the boss responded. The manager of an insurance company in Boulder, Colo., also ``won'' for yelling at a female worker to bring coffee and adding, ``You squaw; me chief.'' ``Common themes emerged in both the good and bad boss stories,'' said Ellen Bravo, associate director of 9to5. ``People want to be appreciated and to be treated like human beings _ not like machines or peons. And businesses that show regard for their employees inspire loyalty and prosper as a result.'' Judges who reviewed hundreds of entries submitted by office workers nationwide included Rep. Patricia Schroeder, D-Colo.; Washington Post columnist Bob Levey; and Roberta McKay, who heads the Labor Department's women's bureau.

DOC.HEAD: Dollar Higher, Stocks Bounce Back
DOC.TEXT: The dollar edged up against the Japanese yen today, and the Tokyo Stock Exchange's key index rebounded moderately. The dollar closed at 152.00 yen, up 0.05 yen from Wednesday's close of 151.95 yen. It opened at 152.08 yen and ranged between 151.73 yen and 152.55 yen. When it reached 152.55, the dollar was sold for profit-taking and position adjustments, said Takeshi Nagata, a dealer with Chemical Bank in Tokyo. ``Ahead of the release of the U.S. trade figures later today, market players tried to keep their dollar positions neutral,'' he said. But Nagata said the dollar was unlikely to fall below 150 yen ``unless the U.S. trade figure has more than a 10 billion dollar deficit.'' The market expects the U.S. March trade deficit to be around $9.1 billion, up from $6.5 billion the previous month. ``Expectations for a slowdown in the U.S. economy have been gradually factored into the market and are no longer a strong incentive to sell the dollar,'' Nagata said. Some $11.4 billion changed hands in spot trading. On the stock market, the 225-share Nikkei Stock Average rose 93.98 points, or 0.29 percent, closing at 32,061.60. It lost 29.42 points on Wednesday. The index rose slowly as market players became cautious after the yen's lower opening in Tokyo this morning, traders said. Kazuhiro Nomura, a trader with New Japan Securities Co., said the Nikkei began rising in late morning as investors started buying shares in companies that have been performing well. ``Gains in the Nikkei's futures market also prompted buying in the spot market,'' he said. ``But investors' targets tended to shift from one issue to another, and trading was directionless.'' Trading was thin, with first section volume estimated at 580 million shares, down from Wednesday's 750 million. In the bond market, the price of the benchmark No. 119 10-year Japanese government bonds fell to 87.70 points at 4 p.m. (3 a.m. EDT) from Wednesday's close of 87.90. The yield stood at 7.020 percent, up from 6.780 percent the previous day.

DOC.HEAD: Democrats Say Bush Fails to Show Leadership on Budget Deficit
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Meeting resumes 2 p.m. EDT; lead prospects uncertain; also moved on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: Capitol Hill Democrats say President Bush lacks leadership and could doom the budget summit because of his refusal to outline publicly the severity of the nation's budget problems. ``This Congress won't be able to act unless the American people feel there's a crisis,'' said Rep. Charles Schumer, D-N.Y. ``There's only one person who can show the American people how bad the crisis is.'' ``This country is crying for leadership,'' said Rep. Marty Russo, D-Ill., calling on Bush to cash in some of his popularity for the good of the nation. ``You don't get to be great by making no decisions,'' he said. The president said Wednesday he turned down a Democratic suggestion that he make a nationally televised address to explain why he called the summit on the budget deficit. The Democrats are campaigning to make sure he shares the blame for any tax increase that results. ``I don't want to inadvertently send the wrong signals to the markets,'' Bush said Wednesday. He said he would wait to make such an address later, when he could present a bipartisan solution to the problem. Rep. Bill Frenzel, R-Minn., said Democrats were merely pushing Bush to ``do a Jimmy Carter,'' referring to the former president's unpopular penchant of reminding the nation of its problems. ``It's not a crisis. It's a manageable problem,'' Frenzel said Wednesday after a meeting with White House budget director Richard Darman and other members of the House Budget Committee. In the closed-door session, Darman continued his effort to convince lawmakers that strong action must be taken to reduce the deficit. Darman refused to appear before the committee in open session. The budget summit talks were scheduled to resume this afternoon with more discussion of the fiscal forecast for 1991. Under the Gramm-Rudman law, the deficit for the fiscal year beginning Oct. 1 must be cut to no more than $74 billion or automatic spending cuts will be imposed to make up the difference. The projected deficit, which the administration put near $100 billion four months ago, could be twice that if costs for the bailout of the savings and loan industry are included. Not counting the S&L capital _ and the administration doesn't want it counted _ the deficit still would be $123 to $138 billion. So to avoid the huge automatic cuts, Congress and the president must agree on around $50 billion in spending cuts and tax increases. The president is the only one who can build public acceptance of the necessary sacrifices, and he has to start soon, Democrats said. ``He has to start now to sell the dimensions of the problem and go before the people to talk about the seriousness of it,'' said Sen. Lloyd Bentsen, D-Texas, chairman of the Senate Finance Committee. ``It should be a major address to the American people ... the longer he waits, the more difficult it will be. ``He can't wait to do that the night before the vote in a fireside chat,'' said Rep. Dale Kildee, D-Mich. ``He has to lead. He has to govern.'' Kildee said he understood the president was already feeling pressure from his own Republicans because of his wavering on the ``no new taxes'' pledge. ``I think he's torn between the politics and the governance,'' he said. ``And I hope he leans more toward governance.'' The president's news conference Wednesday was aimed at pressuring Congress to approve aid for Central America. ``The president's priorities are out of skew when he's focusing on Nicaragua and Panama but will not use the same public media in order to try to describe what the problems are with our own economy,'' said Rep. David Obey, D-Wis.

DOC.HEAD: Instant Photography On Sale in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Hundreds of Muscovites gathered for the opening of the first Soviet retail shop selling Polaroid cameras for rubles. Many had their picture taken and were delighted as their portraits developed instantly. The cameras, assembled at a Soviet plant from Polaroid components, will sell for $405 in rubles, a company spokesman said. The new shop is a joint business venture formed by Polaroid and the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Energy and Industries. Initial sales were expected to be about 10,000 cameras in the first year, according to a Polaroid official. The joint venture, called Svetozor, will generate hard currency by manufacturing printed circuit boards used in the electronics of the Polaroid camera and exporting them to other Polaroid plants in the West. Previously, Polaroid products were only available at special shops or foreigners and only for hard currency _ dollars or other cash traded on the international market.

DOC.HEAD: London Stocks Soar on European Monetary System Rumors
DOC.TEXT: Stock prices soared on unconfirmed rumors that Britain would soon join the currency-stabilizing mechanism of the European Monetary System. Dealers said cash-heavy institutions were spurred by what was seen as a more positive stance by the government toward the EMS. Prices also were boosted by a shortage of stock in some sectors. One trader said stocks considered undervalued were being bought and many investors felt they had to buy into the market for fear of missing out on any rally that might accompany Britain's long-awaited entry into the full EMS. At midday, the Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-stock index was up 50 points, or 2.2 percent, at 2,271.1. Volume came to 458.2 million shares.

The stock market advanced broadly today, bidding to extend the rally that carried it to record highs earlier in the week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 16.89 to 2,836.57 in the first half hour of trading. Gainers outnumbered losers by nearly 2 to 1 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 622 up, 341 down and 509 unchanged. Volume on the Big Board came to 25.29 million shares as of 10 a.m. on Wall Street. Analysts said the market benefited from lingering hopes for lower interest rates. In the credit markets today, prices of long-term government bonds rose slightly, lowering their yields to the 8.61 percent-8.65 percent range. The dip in rates came in spite of news that the nation's trade deficit increased to $8.45 billion in March from a 6{-year low of $6.10 billion the month before. Brokers said the latest figure, though larger than expected, didn't significantly discourage the belief that the United States has been gradually improving its competitive position of late in world markets. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up \ at 44}; International Business Machines, up | at 116; General Electric, up ] at 68{, and Bristol Myers-Squibb, up ] at 58~. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .88 to 194.02. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.14 at 354.82. On Wednesday the Dow Jones industrial average dropped 2.77 to 2,819.68. Declining issues outnumbered advances by about 8 to 7 on the NYSE, with 703 up, 792 down and 520 unchanged. Big Board volume totaled 159.81 million shares, against 165.73 million in the previous session.

DOC.HEAD: Trade Deficit Jumped 38.5 Percent in March
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Inserts graf with Mosbacher reaction after 2nd graf: Despite the.
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. trade deficit jumped 38.5 percent to $8.45 billion in March as record exports were offset by the second highest level of imports, the government reported today. Despite the widened gap in March, the deficit still was below the average $9.0 billion monthly imbalance in 1989. And many economists say the gap, which has improved each year since peaking in 1987, should continue to narrow this year. Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher, noting that the $23.9 billion first-quarter trade deficit was the lowest in more than six years, said in a statement he expects the gap to total less than $100 billion this year. It was $109 billion in 1989. The Commerce Department said a 4.6 percent increase in exports in March, to $33.28 billion, was offset by a 10 percent gain in imports, to $41.7 billion, second only to the record $41.9 billion set last October. The trade deficit is the difference between what America imports and what it sells abroad. The imbalance had narrowed to a revised $6.1 billion in February, the smallest deficit in six years, and was down 34.6 percent from a $9.32 billion gap January. The February gap first was reported to have been $6.49 billion. Many analysts had been expecting a deficit of about $7.8 billion in March, up from the February level but still well below the $9 billion monthly average last year. The news was sure to attract attention at the White House and on Capitol Hill, where negotiators were studying compromise spending cuts and possible tax hikes to reduce the budget deficit. Trade improvements are seen as an essential part of any effort to spur economic growth and stem the widening gap between what the government receives and what it spends. The jump in exports from $31.8 billion was led by automobiles, industrial supplies, and foods, feeds and beverages. It was pulled down by a decline in aircraft shipments which had boosted the February export level. Imports were up from $37.9 billion in February, led by automobiles, capital goods, consumer goods and industrial supplies. The 10 percent gain was the largest since a 21.8 percent advance in September 1985. Oil imports totaled 261 million barrels, up 7.4 percent from February. But prices fell from $19.39 a barrel to $18.18 a barrel in March, making the $4.7 billion import bill virtually the same as the previous month. As usual, the deficit with Japan was the largest of any country. It totaled $3.6 billion; followed by China and Taiwan, $600 million each; Mexico and Brazil, $300 million each, and Canada, $100 million. The United States posted a $700 million surplus with the countries of Western Europe. The trade deficit hit $152.12 billion in 1987 and then dropped to $118.53 billion the following year. The 1989 deficit slid further to $109 billion. ``I think the deficit for '90 will show a significant improvement over 1989,'' said senior economist Bruce Steinberg of Merrill Lynch Capital Markets in New York. ``It will get down to about $95 billion or so, maybe even better than that.'' Economists at Fuji Securities Inc. in Chicago also forecast continued improvement. They expect the average monthly gap in the first quarter to total about $7.6 billion, down from $9.1 billion during January-March 1989. ``Stepped-up export demand stemming from vibrant economic growth abroad, plus reduced import demand caused by sluggish domestic growth, should assure further reductions in the deficit in coming quarters,'' they say. Elias Bikhazi, money market economist at Security Pacific National Bank in Los Angeles, said ``softer import growth'' should help cut the deficit to ``a bit below $100 billion'' this year. Oil imports, however, remain troubling. Domestic oil production now is at a 25-year low and many analysts expect both foreign oil shipments and prices to rise in coming months. The administration is counting on further trade improvements to dampen growing protectionist pressures in Congress as well as to bolster economic growth. A sluggish economy already has cut government tax receipts and, together with high interest rates, is threatening to drive up further the already raging federal budget deficit. As a result, President Bush and congressional leaders began negotiations earlier this week on a package of spending cuts and revenue increases to forestall the automatic spending cuts for fiscal 1991 under the Gramm-Rudman balanced budget law.
The NASDAQ Composite Index at 11am was 444.45 up 2.52 from the previous day's close.

In the credit markets today, prices of long-term government bonds rose slightly, lowering their yields to the 8.61 percent-8.65 percent range. The dip in rates came in spite of news that the nation's trade deficit increased to $8.45 billion in March from a 6{-year low of $6.10 billion the month before. Brokers said the latest figure, though larger than expected, didn't significantly discourage the belief that the United States has been gradually improving its competitive position of late in world markets. Gainers among the blue chips included Philip Morris, up \ at 44}; International Business Machines, up { at 115~; General Electric, up ] at 68{, and Bristol Myers-Squibb, up ~ at 59]. Federal National Mortgage rose 1[ to 39\. A gauge of what the company pays on its debt against what it earns on its mortgage assets improved in April. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.22 to 194.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.65 at 355.33.

DOC.HEAD: Crop Futures Turn Mostly Higher On Weather, Exports
DOC.TEXT: Grain and soybean futures prices were mostly higher in early trading today on the Chicago Board of Trade amid talk of new export sales and prospects for a resumption of wet weather in key growing areas. Soybean futures showed the greatest strength this morning after settling mostly higher Wednesday. Some of this morning's buying interest was was fueled by reports of firmer soybean meal markets in Europe and indications that Mexico bought more than 300,000 metric tons of U.S. corn overnight. Further support stemmed from the National Weather Service's latest six-to-10-day outlook, issued Wednesday, which predicts cooler- and wetter-than-normal conditions in the Midwest during the latter half of next week. Heavy rains in the Midwest already have slowed corn and soybean planting, a supportive factor in the futures markets. Rain also is expected to return to the Southern Plains this weekend, posing the threat of further damage to the winter wheat crop. In early trading, wheat futures were unchanged to 2{ cents higher with the contract for delivery in May at $3.90 a bushel; corn futures were } cent lower to 1 cent higher with May at $2.83{ a bushel; oats were unchanged to 1 cent lower with May at $1.53{ a bushel; soybeans were 1 cent lower to 5{ cents higher with May at $6.16{ a bushel. Livestock futures were mixed in early trading on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange while pork-belly futures were up sharply following sharp gains yesterday. Live cattle futures were .05 cent lower to .15 cent higher with June at 74.37 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .05 cent higher with May at 84.80 cents a pound; live hogs were .15 cent lower to .40 cent higher with June at 65.40 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .15 cent lower to 1.38 cent higher with May at 65.55 cents a pound.

DOC.HEAD: Narrowing of Japan's Trade Surplus Resumes
DOC.TEXT: The narrowing of Japan's trade surplus, interrupted in March after an 11-month stretch, resumed in April, the Finance Ministry announced Thursday. The ministry said Japan's exports exceeded its imports by $3.54 billion in April, compared with $7.29 billion a year earlier. In trade with the United States, the surplus shrank from $4.54 billion to $2.45 billion. The surplus, measured when goods pass through customs, had expanded in March from year-earlier levels because of unusually high imports in March 1989, just before imposition of a new 3 percent sales tax. The amount of the surplus' narrowing in April was exaggerated by the particularly large surplus in April last year, when imports fell sharply after the tax was imposed. The ministry said the basic trend of declining surpluses was continuing, regardless of the distorting effects of the tax on comparisons with 1989. Japan has been under pressure from the United States and other trading partners to shrink its large surpluses. In various negotiations this year, Japan has agreed to open its market wider to U.S. satellites, supercomputers and forest products, and to boost public works spending, tighten antimonopoly rules, reform its distribution system and combat corporate groups' exclusionary trade practices. Japan's global exports in April totaled $21.87 billion, down 5.8 percent from a year earlier. Imports rose 15 percent to $18.33 billion. Japan's exports to the United States amounted to $6.72 billion in April, down 14.9 percent from April 1989, while imports from the United States increased by 26.8 percent to $4.27 billion. Exports of automobiles, meanwhile, dropped 19.1 percent in April to $3.71 billion. Japanese automakers have been boosting their production overseas.

DOC.HEAD: Burger King Names Chief Operating Officer for U.S. Restaurants
DOC.TEXT: Robert J. Stetson, Burger King Corp.'s chief financial officer since February 1989, was named the fast-food company's chief operating officer Thursday. Stetson, 39, will be responsible for the operation of the more than 5,400 Burger King restaurants in the United States and report to Barry J. Gibbons, Burger King's chief executive officer, the company said. No one has been named to replace Stetson as CFO. Before joining Burger King, Stetson was a top-level executive with Pearle Optical, which has more than 1,300 outlets. Like Miami-based Burger King, Pearle is a subsidiary of the British conglomerate Grand Metropolitan PLC. The economics and business-administration Harvard graduate began his career as chief financial officer with Pepsico Food Service International in 1972. He left to become president of Magna Photo of Chicago in 1982, rejoined Pepsico as Pizza Hut senior vice president in 1986 and later joined Pearle. Burger King, which has 6,000 outlets worldwide and had systemwide sales of $5.7 billion in 1989, was acquired by Grand Metropolitan in January 1989 when the British company bought Pillsbury Co.

The stock market gained ground today, bidding to extend the rally that carried it to record highs earlier in the week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 12.03 to 2,831.71 by noontime on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 7 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 761 up, 543 down and 546 unchanged. Analysts said the market benefited from lingering hopes for lower interest rates. In the credit markets today, prices of long-term government bonds rose slightly, reducing their yields to the 8.61 percent-8.65 percent range. The dip in rates came in spite of news that the nation's trade deficit increased to $8.45 billion in March from a 6{-year low of $6.10 billion the month before. Brokers said the latest figure, though larger than expected, didn't significantly discourage the belief that the United States has been gradually improving its competitive position of late in world markets. Gainers among the blue chips included General Motors, up ] at 48}; American Telephone & Telegraph, up | at 43]; DuPont, up { at 40}, and Woolworth, up 1 at 64[. Hewlett-Packard fell 1] to 44} on top of a 1~-point drop Wednesday, when the company reported lower quarterly earnings. Federal National Mortgage rose } to 38~ in heavy trading. A gauge of what the company pays on its debt against what it earns on its mortgage assets improved in April. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose 1.22 to 194.36. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.65 at 355.33. Volume on the Big Board came to 90.97 million shares at noontime, against 79.23 million at the same point Wednesday.

DOC.HEAD: Pair Convicted of Insider Trading by Getting Preview of Magazine Column
DOC.TEXT: A judge froze the assets of a former print shop worker and a stock broker after their convictions on insider trading charges for scooping tips from Business Week before the magazine hit the newsstands. U.S. District Judge Stephen V. Wilson ordered the assets frozen after a jury on Wednesday convicted William N. Jackson, 34, of Long Beach and Brian Callahan, 30, of Anaheim. Jackson, a former quality control analyst at a printing firm, could be fined up to $80,000 for his part in the insider trading scheme, while Callahan, a former Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. broker, faces a maximum fine of $110,000, prosecutors said. The two men traded in 53 stocks between 1987 and 1988 using information gleaned from Business Week. Jackson made more than $19,000 for himself and two brothers, and Callahan made the same amount for himself and his clients plus $8,000 in commissions, the government alleged. Jackson reviewed a freshly printed copy of Business Week each Wednesday night, then phoned Callahan the next morning to buy stocks recommended in the ``Inside Wall Street'' column, prosecutors said. The magazine, printed on Wednesday nights, does not reach newsstands until Thursday evening. The Securities and Exchange Commission said it would seek all profits, plus interest, and triple that amount in penalties. The men's attorney, Joseph Connolly, argued the SEC was ``stretching the securities laws almost beyond recognition'' and called the violations marginal. ``These are a couple of guys who lost their jobs,' he said. ``They're not wealthy, either of them.'' Jackson acknowledged he bought stock, but testified he did not realize he was breaking the law or confidentiality requirements of his company, R.R. Donnelley & Sons Co. Callahan testified he believed Jackson got his tips from a computer program. Neither the printing company nor Business Week were charged in the case.

DOC.HEAD: GM to Shut Lakewood Plant in Atlanta Aug. 6
DOC.TEXT: General Motors Corp. will shut its Lakewood car assembly plant in Atlanta Aug. 6, a GM spokeswoman said Thursday. Sharon Hines said 2,200 employees will be laid off when the automaker stops making 1990 versions of the Chevrolet Caprice. Production of the 1991 Caprice began in March at Willow Run, Mich. The Lakewood plant will be the fourth assembly plant GM has shut down since 1987, when it signed its current contract with the United Auto Workers union. The agreement allows an assembly plant closing only when sales of its products slump. The other closed plants were in Leeds, Mo.; Pontiac, Mich.; and Framingham, Mass.

DOC.HEAD: Parent Company of Long John Silver's Thrives After Leveraged Buyout
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: Decked out in a light blue shirt and navy pants, Leonard Harlan, financier, was a regular member of the fast-food crew. He cut fish, prepared salads, did some frying and assisted at the front counter during a six-hour shift at a Long John Silver's Seafood Shoppe in south Lexington. But it wasn't a regular work day for Harlan. As president of one of the investment firms that took the fast-food company private last September, Harlan was working in the trenches as part of the company's plan for keeping in touch with the troops. ``I'm impressed with the way the team operates,'' said Harlan, 53, who wore a Seaman Apprentice nametag with ``Len'' printed on it. ``It gives me an appreciation into what you do in one of these shops.'' Castle Harlan Inc. is one of two New York investment firms involved in the management-led leveraged buyout of Jerrico Inc., the parent company of Long John Silver's. The other owner is DJS-Inverness and Co. In contrast to other takeovers that have succumbed to heavy debts, Lexington-based Jerrico has thrived since its $620 million buyout. ``We take fundamentally sound companies and expand from that base,'' said Harlan, who added that operating cash flow is up 20 percent over last year. ``Our philosophy is we build companies. We get the energy released inside the company. We take the lid off.'' Harlan Castle also owns Peasant Restaurants of Atlanta and Morton's of Chicago, Ethan Allen furniture company, Delaware Management Co., a money-management firm; and Reagan Outdoor, a billboard company. Jerrico has streamlined operation, reducing costs by $16 million in corporate administration and $14 million at the restaurants since the buyout. It also eliminated about 200 regional and corporate jobs. ``We didn't look for the quick buck,'' Jerrico president John E. Tobe, who also worked a shift at a Long John Silver's in Atlanta. ``We had long-term planning. I think that's what made this LBO a success.'' LBOs work best when operations are trimmed to the best performers and other assets are sold off to cover financing costs. In Jerrico's case, the company recently announced agreements to sell two restaurant chains, Jerry's to Great American Restaurants, Inc. of Atlanta and Fazoli's to Seed Restaurant Group Inc., a Japanese-owned firm. The prices were not disclosed. Jerrico also owns two family-style Italian restaurants called Florenz, which it plans to sell. ``We want to focus solely on Long John Silver's,'' said Tobe, who has been with Jerrico for 16 years, the past six as president and chief executive officer. Long John Silver's has about 62 percent of the $1.2 billion quick-service seafood restaurant business. Jerrico owns about two-thirds of the 1,500 restaurants, and the rest are franchised. The chain operates in 35 states, the District of Columbia, Canada and Singapore. Since the buyout, there has been an aggressive management campaign to give Long John Silver's a more contemporary image. Television ads began Feb. 26 to promote the restaurants as ``Makin' a Splash'' with its seafood products. ``It is a theme that employed the upbeat nature of the business,'' said Harlan. ``We are an upbeat business.'' The restaurants are being remodeled, giving the buildings fresh appearances with bright yellow on dark blue paint and large cupolas with beacons to attract customers. ``The buildings were historically gray like (Kentucky) state police cruisers,'' said Tobe. ``State police cruisers are gray so they can go unnoticed. Our buildings ended up doing the same. We want to have the units pop out at you.'' The menu has been expanded to include baked and broiled seafood for the health-conscious consumer and finger foods. Several items will be introduced for a limited time this summer. The company also plans to increase the percentage of its restaurants with drive-through service from the current 35 percent to 65 percent; install large, bright menu boards and improve plates and packaging. ``The company went from very traditional, very methodical to one, overnight, of innovation,'' said Bill Mahony, executive vice president, operations. Jerrico recently sold four Long John Silver's in Phoenix to American Seafood Partners, one of its largest franchisees. The agreement also calls for the buyer to develop 16 new franchised units in the Phoenix area within the next three years, and another 16 in markets yet to be chosen. The company also is looking to add 200 franchised units within five years in established markets and expand into the Northeast and Northwest, where it has almost no presence, Tobe said. ``We're aggressively going after new franchisees,'' he said. ``We also hope company employees can become franchisees.'' The company recently offered stock appreciation rights to 3,000 employees, starting with assistant managers, which will let them benefit from the appreciation of the value of Jerrico's stock, now held by senior managers and investors in the buyout. ``The company is theirs,'' said Harlan. ``We want an entrepreneurial spirit. We want to produce independent thought.'' In 1989, before the buyout, Jerrico had a different focus in remembering the 20th year of Long John Silver's. ``On the 20th anniversary, we celebrated our age,'' said Anthony M. Lavely, executive vice president for marketing. ``Now, eight months later, we're celebrating our future, our youth and our desire to do new things.''
DOC.NOTE: End adv for Monday May 21

DOC.HEAD: PacifiCorp Raises Offer For Pinnacle West
DOC.TEXT: PacifiCorp, the Portland, Ore.-based utility giant, today increased to $1.82 billion its offer to acquire Arizona's largest utility, Pinnacle West Capital Corp. PacificCorp also agreed to assume all of the debt of Pinnacle West and its subsidiary Arizona Public Service Co. as part of the offer. Steve Carr, a Pinnacle West spokesman, said the company's board of directors would ``seriously consider'' the offer. Pinnacle West's board rejected three previous offers from PacifiCorp.The last offer, worth about $1.7 billion, was rejected in March as inadequate. Under the new offer, Pinnacle West shareholders would received $21 in cash for each share of stock they hold at the time of the acquisition. Pinnacle West stock sold for $12.75 at the close of trading Wednesday. ``We think it is time to bring to a conclusion PacifiCorp's expressions of interest to you ...,'' PacifiCorp President and Chief Executive Officer A.M. Gleason said in a letter delivered Thursday to Richard Snell, chairman of Pinnacle West. ``Our offer remains the same with regard to customers of Arizona Public Service: Rate increases limited to 2 percent per year for four years. ``This is significantly less than the rate relief requested in APS's most recent filing with the Arizona Corporation Commission: Rate increases of 6.5 percent per year for three years.'' PacifiCorp has said it wants the Arizona utility so that it could conduct seasonal transfers of excess power between Arizona, where power use peaks in the summer, and the Pacific Northwest, where power use peaks in the winter. Gleason said the deal would delay into the next decade any need for PacifiCorp to build additional power plants to meet peak demands. PacifiCorp has electric utility operations in seven Western states. Prior to receiving the offer Snell was not enthusiastic about a deal. ``If there's another offer, we'll take a look at it,'' Snell said. ``But our position is that this is not a good time to sell, and the company is not for sale. ``On the other hand, we've given serious consideration to the other offers, and we will again if one comes our way.''

DOC.HEAD: Production Goes Up This Week
DOC.TEXT: Domestic automakers were scheduled to produce 234,512 cars and light trucks this week, up from last week's 232,762, Ward's Automotive Reports said Thursday. This week's production is lower than the same week a year ago, in which 248,552 cars and light trucks were produced, the trade journal said. U.S. automakers were scheduled to make 138,967 cars this week, compared with 140,799 a week ago and 159,479 in the same week in 1989. Light truck production for the week was scheduled at 95,545, compared with last week's 91,963 and last year's 89,073. Canadian automakers were to build 23,665 cars this week, down from 28,289 a week ago but up from last year's 18,001. Canadian light truck production was scheduled at 18,952, compared with 21,948 a week ago and 16,905 in the same week last year.

DOC.HEAD: London Shares Finish at Highest Levels Since November 1987
DOC.TEXT: Share prices on London's stock exchange closed sharply higher across the board in active trading Thursday as a variety of influences sent them rocketing to post their biggest daily gains since November 1987. ``It's very impressive, to say the least,'' said Tony Rebello, chief dealer for the London brokerage Credit Suisse First Boston. The Financial Times-Stock Exchange 100-share index finished up 63.3 points, or 2.85 percent, at 2,284.4, its high for the day. That figure was well above the low of 2,227.7, posted when official trading began. The narrower Financial Times 30-share index closed up 55.9 points at 1,795.7. The Financial Times 500 index closed up 31.01 at 1,229.85. Volume was 645.4 million shares, the healthiest showing in months and markedly better than the 460.4 million shares that changed hands Wednesday. In the futures market, the June Financial Times 100 index contract closed at 2,329.0, up from 2,258.0 a day ago. Strength in stock-index futures contracts and unconfirmed rumors early in the session that Britain could join the European Monetary System's exchange-rate mechanism as early as this weekend sent prices soaring. The market ``really never looked back'' from the opening, Rebello said. Dealers said strong buying to cover short positions buoyed the market, and some institutional investors jumped on the bandwagon amid a shortage of stock, committing to fresh positions so they wouldn't miss out on the rally. ``People sitting on the sidelines decided that they at least better get their toes wet,'' Rebello said. Also, British traders said strength on Wall Street, sustained throughout the London session, provided a good backbone of support for movement on the 100-share index. Most agreed that fluctuations in the key Dow Jones industrial average on Wall Street will determine the fate of the market in London in the short term. ``If Wall Street goes higher, I think the bull will prevail,'' Rebello said. Conversely, he added, if the Dow average eases, it will most likely drag the 100-share index with it as investors realize that Britain's gloomy economic situation has not fundamentally changed. Although a slew of British economic data were released during the session, the market largely ignored them and payed virtually no attention to U.S. trade data that showed a wider-than-expected trade gap for March. Among British indicators, the public sector borrowing requirement, or budget deficit, came in at 2.12 billion pounds for April, higher than market forecasts of 1.25 billion pounds. Unemployment was unchanged in April from the month before at a seasonally adjusted 5.6 percent of the work force.

The stock market showed a small gain today, bidding to extend the rally that carried it to record highs earlier in the week. The Dow Jones average of 30 industrials climbed 9.95 to 2,829.63 by 2 p.m. on Wall Street. Gainers outnumbered losers by about 6 to 5 in nationwide trading of New York Stock Exchange-listed issues, with 774 up, 628 down and 516 unchanged. Most of the gains came early in the session, encouraged by a brief drop in open-market interest rates. As the session passed, however, rates turned higher. Yields on long-term government bonds climbed to the 8.65 percent-8.69 percent range. In the economic news, the Commere Department reported that the nation's trade deficit increased to $8.45 billion in March from a 6{-year low of $6.10 billion the month before. Brokers said the latest figure, though larger than expected, didn't significantly discourage the belief that the United States has been gradually improving its competitive position of late in world markets. Hewlett-Packard fell ~ to 45\ in active trading on top of a 1~-point drop Wednesday, when the company reported lower quarterly earnings. Federal National Mortgage rose ~ to 39. A gauge of what the company pays on its debt against what it earns on its mortgage assets improved in April. The NYSE's composite index of all its listed common stocks rose .34 to 193.48. At the American Stock Exchange, the market value index was up 1.22 at 354.90. Volume on the Big Board came to 123.48 million shares with two hours to go.

DOC.HEAD: Iacocca Urges Shareholders To Take Long View
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca pleaded with stockholders today to stick with the automaker despite falling profits and stock price, saying it is poised to take on Japanese and American competitors in the 1990s. Iacocca, addressing the company's annual meeting, acknowledged that earnings have been very disappointing, but counseled them to take a long view. He noted that the yearly dividend of $1.20 per share was about a 7 percent yield at the stock price of about $17 today. ``Barring a disaster, maybe a nuclear disaster, we don't anticipate cutting your dividends,'' the flamboyant Chrysler leader said. Iacocca also was in Los Angeles to concludeda six-city promotional tour linked to an aggressive advertising campaign touting Chrysler quality. He reiterated his claims that the quality of Chrysler cars now equals Japanese models and that they are the safest on the road. Now, he said, the task is convincing Americans of that, and ``we're going to get better.'' He said the whole industry has suffered of late, Chrysler included, from over-capacity and economic declines at the beginning and end of the 1980s. ``You might say this is starting to look a lot like the Chrysler of the 1980s _ a Chrysler in trouble,'' Iacocca said. However, he said, Chrysler today has far less debt, more than 10 times the cash on hand, can borrow $2.6 billion without asking Washington for help as it did in 1980, and has 13.3 percent of the U.S. car and truck market compared with 10.3 percent in 1980. He said that after 44 years in the industry he was convinced it would make more sense to report sales results every 10 years rather than every 10 days because planning is done that far in advance. He said he realized, of course, that shareholders would not allow him to do that. But, he said, ``taking the long view is the only way to keep your sanity in this business.'' He also denied that his latest ad campaign constituted Japan-bashing, saying he never said a word against the Japanese people or the high-quality products they produce, but only against their trade practices and the U.S. government for allowing them. ``One thing we've learned is that the competition will not necessarily be a fair competition,'' Iacocca said.

DOC.HEAD: The Tax Impact of Putting Bart to Work
DOC.TEXT: If Homer Simpson sent underachieving son Bart out to get a job this summer, he might keep the punk out of his hair for a couple of months but Bart could get an unexpected bill from Uncle Sam. Mowing lawns or peddling papers isn't the cartoon Bart's idea of fun, but it's a way of life for millions of real-life youngsters who try to make some money when school is out. The earning power of summer job-holders can have an impact on family tax returns. Probably not too much, tax experts say, although mom and pop could face additional IRS forms and extra confusion. Jobholders over age 14 may have to pay taxes, or at least file returns, depending upon how much money they earn. The so-called ``kiddie tax'' _ an offspring of the 1986 tax reform laws _ presents a problem for those under 14. That tax is applied to unearned, or passive income, such as dividends or interest on savings accounts. All children pay no taxes on the first $500 of passive earnings, and the next $500 is taxed at the child's own rate, usually 15 percent. But for those under age 14, unearned income over $1,000 is taxed at the parent's top rate, usually 28 percent to 33 percent. The purpose of this rule is to curtail the popular practice of shifting income to children and other dependents to reduce taxes. Many young dependents aged 14 or older likely won't have to have any state or federal taxes deducted from their paychecks, provided their total annual earnings remain under the standard deduction of $3,250, experts say. They will, however, have to file returns or be included in their parents' returns if they have both passive and earned income. ``For the youngster who starts a summer job and has no passive income the operative number is $3,250,'' said Frank Keith, a spokesman for the Internal Revenue Service. Even more income could be sheltered for a child if he qualifies to take a personal exemption, which is $2,050 for 1990. But parents couldn't also claim the child as a dependent on their return, and in order to qualify, the child must prove he provides more than half his total support, experts say. Regardless of their earnings, youngsters still have to pay the 7.65 percent Social Security tax. Staying below the standard deduction shouldn't be much of a problem for most children job-holders. Someone working 20 hours a week at minimum wage during July and August could only expect to gross about $685. Before they'd have to start worrying about taxes, they would have to be making around $7 an hour, 40 hours a week for the entire summer. It's a different story for children under 14. Although these youngsters are barred from most jobs, with a few exception such as certain farm work or paper routes, the kiddie tax could penalize an especially enterprising youth. Vincent Vaccaro, a tax partner at the accounting firm Coopers & Lybrand, said the standard deduction on earned income could be reduced if a child under 14 also has passive income. He gives the following example: A 13-year-old old makes $3,000 a year from a paper route, plus has $1,000 in unearned income. The first $500 in unearned income would be exempt from taxes but that also would reduce the youngster's standard deduction by the same amount, to $2,750, making him liable for taxes on his earned income. ``It can be very cumbersome for families. It's a clear case of overkill,'' said Judy Walsh, director of executive financial counseling for the accounting firm Deloitte & Touche. ``It's a complicated system ... for something very simple, like children trying to earn money for college.'' Vaccaro agreed, saying the kiddie tax has ``made it a lot more fun'' for accountants.
DOC.NOTE: End Adv PMs Thursday, May 17

DOC.HEAD: Philip Morris To Acquire East German Cigarette Company
DOC.TEXT: The West German subsidiary of Philip Morris Cos. has agreed to acquire the East German cigarette manufacturer VEB Kombinat Tabak, it was announced Thursday. Terms were not disclosed. The proposed acquisition between VEB Kombinat Tabak and Philip Morris GmbH will allow the New York-based food and tobacco giant to expand further in Eastern Europe, where trade barriers have been broken down recently following the move away from communism. George Knox, a spokesman for Philip Morris in New York, said the two companies have signed a letter of intent to merge, and the deal is expected to close at the end of June. ``It's a good strategic move for us in the market, but it's fairly small,'' he said. Knox said Philip Morris sells about 6 billion cigarettes in Eastern Europe a year. VEB Kombinat Tabak produces about 10 billion cigarettes in East Germany annually under the brand names F-6, Karo and Juwel, he said. According to the official East German news agency ADN, the proposed takeover was approved by a majority of the Dresden-based company's employees. Philip Morris promised there would be no layoffs through 1992, the news agency said. It also promised to raise the workers' gross salaries by about $90 a month and apply the more generous West German benefits, it said. Sales and marketing will be directed by Philip Morris' West German headquarters in Munich, while sales offices will be set up in Berlin and Dresden, ADN said. The Dresden plant, which employs about 1,000 workers, will produce brands made by Philip Morris GmbH as well as its own brands, ADN said. ADN said experts were studying what investments were needed to modernize production in the Dresden plant and raise the quality of the cigarettes.
