DOC.HEAD: John Mulheren: Enigmatic and Successful Boesky Associate on Trial
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Subs 5th graf to recast; subs 22nd graf to restore dropped words.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY27 of May 15
DOC.TEXT: Wearing pastel tennis shirts and moccasins without socks, John A. Mulheren Jr. cuts an odd figure in federal court, where he is on trial for securities fraud. During a lull in jury selection, Mulheren playfully grabbed an open microphone and sang. When the judge asked prospective jurors if a six-week trial would pose problems, Mulheren joined a dozen who raised hands. Mulheren's irreverence in the face of prison is consistent with an iconoclastic image earned as one of the most aggressive and successful speculators of the 1980s. The 6-foot-2 Wall Streeter trained to ride the luge in the Winter Olympics, palled around with Bruce Springsteen, wore chinos as a Merrill Lynch & Co. Wunderkind, once brought a roller-skating chimp to work as a gag, rode a helicopter to work and executed daring trades that awed his peers. He also is a diagnosed manic depressive who allegedly schemed to shoot Ivan Boesky after learning his former friend sought to implicate him in market cheating. ``He's a very colorful, unusual, talented guy somewhere between charming and crazy,'' said a Wall Street executive for whom Mulheren managed capital in the mid-1980s. Mulheren, 40, looks like a happy bulldog. That's the way friends describe him, volatile yet gentle, known for mood swings incited by his medical condition, an abrupt hot-to-cold that in some ways mirrors Wall Street itself. He reaped millions in gambles with other people's money and his own that flouted conventional wisdom. He threw lavish parties at the Rumson, N.J., mansion where he lives with his wife and five adopted children. It came apart in February 1988 when Mulheren was arrested toting an assault rifle and Army fatigues. Police said he was en route to get Boesky, the speculator who named names for leniency in settling insider trading charges. Last June, Mulheren was charged with manipulating Gulf & Western Inc. stock and concealing ownership of large blocks of shares in concert with Boesky. His trial began last week in Manhattan federal court. Mulheren faces five years imprisonment and a $250,000 fine on each of 41 counts. ``He had a reputation as a very savvy trader,'' said Robert Seijas, a New York Stock Exchange market-maker. ``The respect for his ability was practically universal. Whatever else he did, that was true.'' Mulheren arrived on Wall Street in the early 1970s from Roanoke College in Virginia as an assistant trader at G.A. Saxton, a now-defunct brokerage. He was hired by former Treasury Secretary Donald T. Regan at Merrill Lynch while in his mid-20s and ran the risk arbitrage department, where traders bet enormous sums on potentially hot stocks. His casual dress rankled superiors, particularly as young Mulheren made a personal fortune and generated $99 million for Merrill in three years, associates say. Confronted about his attire, Mulheren told executives, ``I can wear a coat and tie or I can make money.'' The khakis stayed. ``He was 26 and looked upon by Don Regan as the most valuable human asset in that firm. It's kind of remarkable,'' said Mulheren acquaintance Michael Aronstein, president of the New York investment firm Comstock Partners. Mulheren later left Merrill to open Mulheren & Co., which folded, partly because he was a careless manager. ``He can't handle the administrative stuff or any of the nonsense that goes along,'' Aronstein said. ``He's not going to score 46 points in the game and then clean up the concession stand. Unfortunately, in this business, when you're running a business, somebody's got to clean up.'' Mulheren later traded stocks for the Wall Street firm Spear, Leeds & Kellogg. Friends said he left in 1984 to be with his family after one of his children nearly drowned in the backyard pool while Mulheren was preoccupied with a business call. About six months later, Mulheren founded Jamie Securities. It became one of the most powerful traders in takeover stocks. In a move typical of his style, Mulheren would dump stock to send it down then repurchase at the lower price. Friends recall complex trading strategies that required vast market knowledge. ``He was a guy who would initiate market moves by thundering in and thundering out,'' said a top speculator who knew Mulheren, speaking on condition of anonymity. ``He would often fake left and move right.'' Mulheren's skill was matched by eccentricity. His antics at Merrill Lynch ranged from inviting Dixieland bands onto the trading floor to renting a live chimp on roller skates named ``Mr. Zip.'' He kept a large portrait of John Belushi by his Merrill desk. A large stuffed toy bear sat by his desk at Jamie, where he also installed a Nautilus machine. He'd take breaks to work out. ``John is his own person. He doesn't make excuses or explain himself to anybody,'' said Mulheren friend Charlie Sweeney, a Merrill senior vice president. He said Mulheren's trading ability shone through ``whether he dressed in a blue jumpsuit or a beanie with a propeller on top.'' Mulheren snubbed golf and tennis, drawn instead to sports that matched his love of risk. Hoping to qualify for luge racing at the 1988 Olympics in Calgary, Alberta, he hired a German trainer, bought the best gear and zoomed down the ice at Lake Placid, N.Y. ``He wanted to bring the fun back into the Olympics. He tried to bring fun back onto the trading desk on Wall Street too,'' said friend Charles Minter, a partner in Comstock Partners. Known for generosity, Mulheren hosted huge parties and children's competitions at his riverfront home. He once ordered a hail of pingpong balls to fall from the sky. He threw a ``This Is Your Life'' party for wife Nancy. Boesky was Mulheren's Achilles heel. They were so close Boesky made him a family trustee. When Boesky's firm faced a jam in 1982, Mulheren helped bail him out. They talked almost daily. In 1986, Mulheren had no hint of Boesky's impending fall. Mulheren subsequently cooperated with regulators but became increasingly frazzled when it appeared he would be indicted. In early 1988 Mulheren stopped taking lithium prescribed for his depression. On Feb. 18, he loaded some of his weapons collection into his Mercedes. His wife called police, who stopped him in the driveway. They said Mulheren planned to kill Boesky and Boesky's chief trader, Michael Davidoff. Two months later, Jamie Securities folded because of Mulheren's legal problems. Weapons charges in New Jersey later were dropped and Mulheren was placed on probation. He recently returned to Wall Street as a partner in another firm, J&B Specialists. Friends praise him for going to trial, unlike other Wall Street figures who have copped guilty pleas. ``He's got that trader's mentality _ he sees a good trade here,'' Sweeney said. ``Dollars and cents, I'd think he'd be smarter settling, but it's not a matter of dollars and cents. He wants to be completely exonerated.'' Boesky is the main prosecution witness. ``I wish he had never made any contact with Ivan Boesky,'' Minter said. ``But you can't go back. I just hope the evidence presented will exonerate him.''

DOC.HEAD: Space Center Gives Houston Economy Basis For Future
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: The Lyndon B. Johnson Space Center has poured billions of dollars into the Houston area since 1962 but its true economic value has only recently been recognized, and now the center is viewed as a key to prosperity. Stripped of 225,000 jobs when the energy industry collapsed, the nation's fourth biggest metropolitan area suddenly found itself without an economic anchor and sought another. What it found in part was aerospace, most of it connected somehow to the space center 25 miles southeast of town. ``We frankly have never really focused on it until five or six years ago,'' said John Brock, president of economic development for the Greater Houston Partnership. The space center has pumped almost $40 billion directly into Houston, and even with a reduced space program, the center spends about $3.7 million each working day. ``The impact might be 10 _ maybe even 20-fold _ on the general economy in Houston,'' Brock said. Economist Robert Hodgin of the University of Houston-Clear Lake, said the space center, while an important contributor to the region's economy, provided only a piece of the recovery. ``What it did do, however, was to serve as ray of optimism, served as a magnet for other endeavors and served as a PR (public relations) tool for city leaders,'' Hodgin said. The National Aeronautics and Space Administration officially opened the facility on 1,620 acres of donated land in 1963 as the Manned Spacecraft Center, directing the Gemini, Apollo, Skylab, space shuttle and other programs. It was renamed in 1973 to honor Johnson, who as vice president had a lot to do with its location in Houston. The space center has served as both an employer of thousands: there are 3,250 federal employees on the payroll, plus another 9,650 contractor personnel work at the center or support its operations. The center also spent $16.1 million last fiscal year on public utilities. Besides the basic operations, however, Brock said the center has been a draw to other aerospace companies such as Grumman Corp. and McDonnell-Douglas Corp., both of which have major aerospace operations nearby. Grumman came to Houston in the early 1970s to build the lunar module for the Apollo program, but in 1986 brought in its civil space operations because ``Houston was still in the woes of the oil and real estate slump, so that made it very, very favorable for business coming in,'' said Grumman spokeswoman Miriam Reed. Plus, ``there's a terrific local labor force. Because of NASA and the universities, there are lots of high-tech people there in terms of engineering and technical personnel.'' The slump, NASA and labor benefits helped Houston beat out metropolitan Washington, southern California and Colorado for the facility, Ms. Reed said. Grumman had hoped to land the main contract for the Freedom space station, but stayed in Houston when it failed, and now is a subcontractor on the project, working on the crew quarters and a ``space tug.'' McDonnell-Douglas also set up shop in Houston a few years to supply parts for the Freedom space station. Brock said Houston is hoping to land an aircraft maintenance base being planned by Continental Airlines Inc. Houston also is home to Space Services Inc., which earlier this month sent its second commercially launched rocket into space and plans to launch 12 more this year. SSI is headed by Donald K. ``Deke'' Slayton, one of the original seven Mercury astronauts. ``The Fortune 500 20 years from now is going to have a number of companies that do business in space,'' said Art Dula, a self-described ``space lawyer'' who has helped incorporate several space-related businesses including SSI. ``Houston, since it has a very strong energy industry _ which is high-tech and R&D (research and development) oriented _ has the kind of technical expertise'' to be home to those companies, some of which have yet to be founded, he said. While the oil collapse pitched many workers out of a job, Brock and Dula said their skills _ from sheet metal working to computer programming _ easily can be used in the aerospace industry. ``And as a result, we are trying to take the Johnson Space Center and the activities based there and let that whole industry blossom,'' he said. NASA pitched in three years ago as it helped establish a program called Partners In Space to aid companies in learning how to do business with the space agency and benefit from its presence. ``Partners ... believe that the center must be integrated into the business, educational, research and technology goal of the state,'' states a Partners publication. ``As such, Partners work in their respective communities to ensure that America's space program, and especially the portion that could come to Texas, enjoys broad support.'' Houston's plans could be undermined, however, by problems with Texas's educational system. At a recent symposium sponsored by Partners in Space, every speaker worried about those shortcomings. ``Space travel and technology ... is a highly sophisticated business,'' said Thomas M. Stauffer, president of the University of Houston-Clear Lake. ``It requires, indeed demands, a significant fraction of the nation's technical manpower in order for the space shuttle to fulfill its mission. ``With the upcoming space station project, moon and Mars missions, that fraction will grow,'' he said. ``The perfect U.S. space program is dependent upon a steady supply of highly educated individuals.'' But Stauffer and others said the Texas schools are not producing enough of those individuals. Arguments over court-ordered education funding show ``education leadership does not appear to be high on the agenda in Austin,'' the state capital, he said. While recruiters have focused on aerospace, Daniel Nebrig, an associate director of the center, says future space explorations mean more than just a one-industry impact. Projects such as the space shuttle and the space station require specialized knowledge best found at NASA, Nebrig said. But to figure out how to live on the Moon, or mine Mars, Nebrig said, ``We need new technology. ... We need people who are used to making concrete, mining, agriculture.'' ``Houston plays into that hand very well,'' Brock said. ``Somewhere we will be involved with, if not space exploration, then space engineering as it continues to advance.''

DOC.HEAD: Royal Dutch-Shell Income Down
DOC.TEXT: Royal Dutch-Shell Group of Companies reported Thursday that net income dropped 40 percent in the first quarter of 1990, reflecting a weak performance by its chemical group and a one-time gain from property sales a year ago. The Anglo-Dutch oil giant, based in The Hague, Netherland, said its net income for the three months ended March 31 totaled $1.35 billion, compared with $2.16 billion in 1989. The company does not report consolidated per-share earnings. Sales totaled $29.12 billion, up from $25.02 billion. The company's financial statements are based on British accounting methods and cannot be directly compared to those of most American companies. Inventories are valued on the basis of first in first out (FIFO), or on a historic cost basis, instead of the typical American system of last in first out (LIFO), or on a current cost basis. Shell said higher crude oil prices, increased oil production and improved gas sales bolstered exploration and production earnings. But it also noted that net income for 1989 was buoyed by a $412.4 million gain from property sales. Shell said its chemicals business was weak during the latest first quarter, mainly from ``sharply lower prices for commodity petrochemicals.'' Refining and marketing profits also declined, with U.S. operations showing a slight loss for the quarter, it said. In the United States, chemicals sales declined and several plants were damaged by extremely cold weather, Shell said. ``Demand for chemicals remains strong and plant capacity utilization high, although petrochemical margins are likely to continue to be well down from the high levels experienced in late 1988 and early 1989,'' the company said. Shell also said it had higher tax and interest charges, as well as adverse currency movement during the first quarter of 1990. Royal-Dutch Shell is the world's second largest oil company behind Exxon Corp.

DOC.HEAD: Eight Saatchi Account Directors Leave To Form New Agency
DOC.TEXT: Saatchi and Saatchi, the troubled British advertising giant, said Thursday that eight account directors at its London agency have resigned to form an independent company. The departure of the directors, who worked at Saatchi and Saatchi Advertising Ltd., was unrelated to a recent management shakeup and decline in the parent's financial performance, a spokesman for the company said. The spokesman said the directors are among about 100 at the agency and dismissed suggestions it represented a major defection. ``It's part and parcel of having a people business,'' he said. ``People come and go.'' The departures follow unconfirmed speculation of a possible sell-off of Saatchi's core advertising businesses and the resignations earlier this month of directors Roy Warman and Terry Bannister, formerly joint chief operating officers of Saatchi's core communications division. Paul Cowan, one of the directors who resigned, told the Evening Standard newspaper that Saatchi and Saatchi had changed from being a young, dynamic agency to a multinational conglomerate. ``We are the keepers of the agency's creative flame,'' he was quoted as saying. ``We hope to recreate the thriving agency culture which Saatchis used to have.'' In the year ended September 1989, the company reported a 48 percent drop in pretax profit to 61.3 million pounds, or about $103.6 million, from 117.0 million pounds, or $197.8 million, in 1988. Saatchi last year named former IMS International Inc. chief executive Robert Louis-Dreyfuss as chief executive of the company in hopes of redeeming losses relating to the purchase of consulting businesses, bought for about 250 million pounds, or $422.6 million, mostly in 1986. Louis-Dreyfuss' appointment followed considerable speculation over a possible breakup or buyout of the company. Carl Spielvogel, head of Spielvogel Bates Worldwide Inc., Saatchi's unit in the United States, last year was rebuffed in an attempt to launch a management buyout.

DOC.HEAD: Equitable Chairman Elected to President, CEO
DOC.TEXT: Equitable Life Assurance Society said Thursday its chairman, Richard H. Jenrette, has been elected to the additional posts of president and chief executive officer. Jenrette succeeds John B. Carter in those posts. Carter has announced his retirement. Jenrette, 61, joined the Equitable in 1985 after the company bought Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corp. Jenrette was one of the founders of the Wall Street investment house and served as its chairman and chief executive. He was elected Equitable chairman in 1987. New York-based Equitable is the nation's third-largest life insurance company.

DOC.HEAD: Oil Slips, Products Gain
DOC.TEXT: The energy futures market closed narrowly mixed Thursday in lackluster trading. On the New York Mercantile Exchange, the June contract for West Texas Intermediate, the benchmark grade of U.S. crude, fell 16 cents to settle at $18.87 a 42-gallon barrel, after losing 56 cents Wednesday. Other contract months, however, gained as much as 10 cents a barrel. Andrew Lebow, an analyst at E.D.&F. Man International Inc., said a Department of Energy announcement confirming earlier reports of a sharp rise in crude stocks put selling pressure on the near-term crude contract. The June contract expires Tuesday. Among refined petroleum products traded on the New York Merc, wholesale unleaded gasoline for June delivery rose 0.04 cent to settle at 64.21 cents a gallon. The contract gained 0.66 cent Wednesday. Although there was no significant movement in unleaded gas contracts, Lebow noted that traders will be watching gas futures carefully as Memorial Day approaches and kicks off the summer driving season. ``We'll see if buying in preparation for the holidays is enough to lift gas out'' of the current narrow price level, he said. June wholesale heating oil, which declined 0.09 cent on Wednesday, gained 0.33 cent to settle at 51.96 cents a gallon. Natural gas for June delivery was unchanged at $1.570 per 1,000 cubic feet.

DOC.HEAD: Highest Closes in Dow Jones Industrials Average
With AM-Wall Street
Dollar Mostly Firmer, Gold Ends Higher
DOC.TEXT: The dollar ended firmer Thursday against all key currencies except the British pound and Canadian dollar, even though the government reported the U.S. trade deficit widened sharply in March. Gold prices rose slightly after declining overseas. On the Commodity Exchange in New York, gold bullion for current delivery settled at $369.50 a troy ounce, up 50 cents from late Wednesday. Republic National Bank in New York quoted a late bid for gold at $369.10 an ounce, up 5 cents. Dealers and analysts said the currency market generally shrugged off Thursday's Commerce Department report, which showed the trade shortfall totaled a wider-than-expected $8.45 billion in March, up from a revised $6.1 billion gap in February. ``The trade number wasn't that far out of expectations to be a big enough deal,'' said Craig Sloane, a currency analyst with Smith Barney, Harris, Upham & Co. ``We're not talking about anything that shocking.'' Sloane said technical factors helped push up the dollar. Traders said the bigger spotlight in foreign exchange Thursday was on the British pound. Sterling was boosted by speculation that Britain would soon be joining the European Monetary System, said Robert Ryan, corporate foreign exchange manager for the Bank of New York. Chancellor of the Exchequer John Major indicated in an interview with the European Wall Street Journal that government opposition to Britain's participation in the EMS had softened considerably. Market speculation is that British entry into the system could be announced as early as this week, traders said. In London, sterling traded at $1.6905, up from $1.6805 Wednesday. It rose in New York to $1.6920 from $1.6805. Other late dollar rates in New York, compared with late Wednesday's quotes, included: 1.6498 West German marks, up from 1.6450; 1.4045 Swiss francs, up from 1.4005; 5.5570 French francs, up from 5.5460; 1,212.50 Italian lire, up from 1,210.00; and 1.17475 Canadian dollars, down from 1.17505. Late dollar rates in Europe, compared with late Wednesday, included: 1.6474 West German marks, up from 1.6431; 1.4049 Swiss francs, up from 1.3990; 5.5510 French francs, up from 5.5410; 1.8430 Dutch guilders, down from 1.8505; 1210.50 Italian lire, up from 1208.50; and 1.1738 Canadian dollars, down from 1.1756. In Tokyo, where the global trading day begins, the dollar closed at 152.00 yen, up from 151.95 yen Wednesday. It traded at 151.90 yen in London, and at 152.15 yen in New York, up from 151.665 yen Wednesdsay. Gold fell in London to a late bid price of $369.25 an ounce from $370 Wednesday. In Zurich, gold fell to $369 an ounce from $369.85. Earlier, in Hong Kong, gold declined 85 cents to close at a bid $369.15 an ounce. Silver prices were mixed. On New York's Comex, silver bullion for current delivery settled at $5.026 a troy ounce, up from $5.010 Wednesday. Silver closed in London at $5.05 an ounce, unchanged.

DOC.HEAD: Fall For Eighth Straight Week
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Interest rate figures reported by Donoghue's Money Fund Report are for week ended Tuesday. All other figures are for the week ended Wednesday.
DOC.TEXT: Assets of the nation's 507 money market mutual funds fell $1.78 billion in the latest week to $381.71 billion, the Investment Company Institute said Thursday. The decline in the seven-day period ended Wednesday marked the eighth straight weekly drop in fund assets, the Washington-based mutual fund trade group said. The previous weekly drop was $2.22 billion. Fund assets hit a record high $392.14 billion in the week ended March 21. The institute said that in the latest week, assets of 245 general purpose funds fell $640.3 million to $131.53 billion, assets of 102 broker-dealer funds dropped $1.41 billion to $158.43 billion, and assets of 160 institutional funds rose $270.1 million to $91.75 billion. The seven-day average yield on money market mutual funds rose in the week ended Tuesday to 7.70 percent from 7.66 percent the previous week, said Donoghue's Money Fund Report, a trade journal based in Holliston, Mass. The 30-day average yield remained unchanged at 7.68 percent, Donoghue's said. The average maturity of the portfolios held by money funds was unchanged at 44 days, Donoghue's said. The newsletter Bank Rate Monitor said its survey of 100 leading commercial banks, savings and loan associations and savings banks in the nation's 10 largest markets showed the effective annual yield available on money market accounts fell to 6.22 percent as of Wednesday from 6.23 percent a week earlier. The North Palm Beach, Fla.-based newsletter said the effective annual yield available on special savings accounts, called Super NOW accounts, rose to 5.05 percent from 5.04 percent. Bank Rate Monitor said the effective annual yield was 7.99 percent on six-month certificates of deposit, down from 8.01 percent the previous week. Yields were 8.17 percent on 1-year CDs, down from 8.18 percent; 8.20 percent on 2{-year CDs, unchanged; and 8.21 percent on 5-year CDs, down from 8.24 percent.

DOC.HEAD: May Earnings Rise 27 Percent in First Quarter; Gap Income Up 40 Percent
DOC.TEXT: May Department Stores Co. said Thursday its first-quarter earnings rose 27 percent, while specialty apparel retailer Gap Inc. reported its income rose 40 percent during the period. May, based in St. Louis, said it earned $80 million, or 58 cents a share, in the quarter ended May 5, up from $63 million, or 45 cents a share, a year earlier. Sales rose 10 percent to $2.19 billion from $1.98 billion in the first quarter of 1989. May operates 14 department store chains, including Lord & Taylor, Foley's and Filene's, along with its Volume and Payless shoe store chains. The company expects to spin off its Venture discount stores later this year. During the first quarter, May opened nine new department stores: two Lord & Taylor stores, five Hecht's stores, one Kaufmann's store and one G. Fox store. The company plans to open 14 more department stores this year. Meanwhile, Gap said it earned $21.2 million, or 60 cents a share, up from $15.1 million, or 43 cents a share, a year earlier. First-quarter sales totaled $402.4 million, up from $309.9 million. San Francisco-based Gap said it chalked up the gain despite higher promotional activity, or price markdowns, that brought in sales but put some pressure on profit margins. Company Chairman Donald Fisher said heavier markdowns also are being taken in the second quarter, but said this has been typical of Gap's performance in previous years. Gap operates 998 stores, including its Banana Republic chain.

DOC.HEAD: Morgan Stanley Chairman To Retire
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of Morgan Stanley Group Inc., S. Parker Gilbert, will retire from the investment firm at the end of the year, the company announced Thursday. Gilbert, 56, said in a statement he had recommended to the Morgan Stanley board that company president Richard B. Fisher succeed him, and that vice chairman Robert F. Greenhill become president. Gilbert, who has been with Morgan Stanley for 30 years, will remain a director of the company and chairman of its advisory board, the statement said. Peter Roche, a Morgan Stanley spokesman, said in a telephone interview that Gilbert was retiring to pursue outside personal interests, but also would maintain close ties to the investment firm. Fisher, 53, has been Morgan Stanley's president since 1984, and before that was head of its capital markets division. He joined Morgan Stanley in 1962 and became a managing director in 1970. Greenhill, also 53, directs Morgan Stanley's investment banking division. He also joined the company in 1962 and became a managing director in 1970. Greenhill was elected vice chairman last year.

DOC.HEAD: Platinum Futures Surge On South African Violence
DOC.TEXT: Platinum futures prices rose sharply Thursday amid reports of increased racial violence in South Africa, the world's largest platinum-producing country. On other commodity markets, gold and silver futures also advanced; copper futures were mixed; pork futures rose to the daily limit for the second straight day; soybeans rebounded from recent losses; and energy futures were mixed. Platinum futures settled $5.30 to $5.40 higher on the New York Mercantile Exchange, with the contract for delivery in July at $492.90 a troy ounce. The rally was based largely on news that South Africa's bigest mining company shut part of a gold mine Thursday following a racial clash that left two whites dead and several blacks injured. The victims were among 12 people killed in five separate incidents Wednesday in South Africa, which last year produced about 77 percent of the platinum supplied to non-socialist countries. The mining-related violence occurred at an Anglo-American Corp. gold mine, not a platinum mine. But because South Africa plays a key role in the delicately balanced platinum market, any sign of escalating racial tension makes traders nervous. ``If the situation in South Africa were to reach dangerous levels where they would have to close a few of those platinum mines, you could see a strong rally develop,'' said Petr Cardillo, a commodity trading adviser with Josephthal & Co. in New York. Analyst Bette Ratopoulos of Prudential-Bache Securities Inc. said the platinum market has been trying to rally lately but has been reigned in by indications of gold selling by the Soviet Union. The gold market tends to set the pace for the other precious metals. But she said there were no signs of Soviet gold sales Thursday, leaving platinum free to respond to its own fundamentals. Gold futures settled 30 cents to 60 cents higher on New York's Commodity Exchange with June at $370.60 a troy ounce; silver was 1.5 cents to 1.6 cents higher with May at $5.026 a troy ounce. Copper futures finished narrowly mixed on the Commodity Exchange despite the threat of another strike next week at three Southern Peru Copper Co. mines where workers returned to work just two weeks ago after a seven-week walkout. Analysts said traders were focusing on the sluggish U.S. economy and expectations of a corresponding decline in copper consumption. Copper futures ended .50 cent lower to .50 cent higher with May at $1.212 a pound. Pork-belly futures rose the permitted daily limit of 2 cents a pound on the Chicago Mercantile Exchange for the second straight day in reaction to an exchange report on Tuesday showing an unexpected drop in frozen belly supplies. Cattle futures settled narrowly mixed in Chicago ahead of the Agriculture Department's monthly cattle-on-feed report covering the seven largest cattle states. The report showed a slightly smaller number of feedlot cattle as of May 1 than traders had expected, mainly due to an unexpectedly small number of feedlot placements last month. Live cattle futures settled .22 cent lower to .12 cent higher with June at 74.20 cents a pound; feeder cattle were .10 cent lower to .07 cent higher with May at 84.82 cents a pound; hog futures settled .20 cent lower to 1.10 cents higher with June at 66.10 cents a pound; frozen pork bellies were .10 cent lower to 2 cents higher with May at 66.22 cents a pound. Soybean futures prices rose strongly on the Chicago Board of Trade, rebounding from recent steep losses amid signs of stronger demand and increasing concern about rain-delayed planting. Corn futures also closed higher while wheat and oats were narrowly mixed. Wheat futures settled } cent lower to { cent higher with May at $3.89{ a bushel; corn futures were 1 cent to 4\ cents higher with May at $2.86} a bushel; oats were 1 cent lower to 1 cent higher with May at $1.54{ a bushel; soybeans were 4 cents to 9{ cents higher with May at $6.17 a bushel. Oil futures finished narrowly mixed in lackluster trading on the New York Merc. West Texas Intermediate crude oil settled 16 cents lower to 14 cents higher with June at $18.87 a barrel; heating oil was .12 cent to .33 cent higher with June at 51.96 cents a gallon; unleaded gasoline was .05 cent lower to .10 cent higher with June at 64.21 cents a gallon.

DOC.HEAD: Broadest Money Supply Measures Higher In Latest Week
DOC.TEXT: The two broadest measures of the nation's money supply rose in the week ended May 7, the Federal Reserve Board reported Thursday. The Fed said the measure known as M2 rose to a seasonally adjusted $3,271.6 billion from $3,269.2 billion the previous week. An even broader measure, M3, rose to a seasonally adjusted $4,067.7 billion from $4,060.5 billion. The narrowest measure of the money supply, M1, fell to a seasonally adjusted $805.5 billion from $805.7 billion. M1 includes cash in circulation, deposits in checking accounts and non-bank travelers checks. M2 is M1 plus accounts like savings deposits and money-market mutual funds. M3 is M2 plus less-liquid accounts, such as certificates of deposit in minimum denominations of $100,000. In judging its monetary policy, the Fed has indicated it is monitoring the value of the dollar, commodity prices and the difference between short- and long-term interest rates. It also has shifted its attention from M1 to the two broader money supply measures. The annual growth rate in M2 so far this year is 4.8 percent, which is within the Fed's target range of 3 percent to 7 percent. The annual growth rate in M3 is 2.1 percent, which is below the Fed's target range of 3.5 percent to 7.5 percent. The Fed has not set a target for M1 growth since early 1987. For the latest 13 weeks, M2 averaged $3,265.6 billion, a 5.6 percent seasonally adjusted annual rate of gain from the previous 13 weeks. M3 averaged $4,065.5 billion, up 2.4 percent, while M1 rose 5.7 percent to an average of $805.0 billion. In other reports: _The Federal Reserve Bank of New York reported commercial and industrial loans at major New York City banks fell $4.51 billion in the week ended May 9. _The Federal Reserve said bank borrowings from the Federal Reserve System at the discount window, excluding extended credit, averaged $319 million a day in the week ended Wednesday, up from $286 million the previous week. _The Federal Reserve said net free reserves averaged $559 million in the two weeks ended May 16, down from $842 million in the previous two-week period. _The Federal Reserve Bank of St. Louis reported that the monetary base, the seasonally adjusted total of member bank reserves held at Federal Reserve banks and cash in bank vaults and in circulation, was $306.1 billion in the two-week period ended May 16, up from $305.9 billion two weeks earlier.

DOC.HEAD: Networks Seek New Ways of Counting Viewers
DOC.TEXT: A group representing the three networks has asked the Nielsen ratings company to consider studying new ways of counting viewers, a proposal that could change the industry's standard ``people meter'' system, the company said Thursday. The request disclosed by Nielsen Media Research came from the Committee on National Television Audience Measurement (CONTAM), representing CBS, NBC, ABC and the National Association of Broadcasters. The research company said it would consider the request. If a decision is made to proceed with a study, test results would not be available before the end of this year at the earliest. Nielsen also said its regular national service, which is based on people-meter data, ``will remain in place at least through the 1990-91 season.'' ABC, CBS and NBC annually pay Nielsen a total of $20 million for its research data, according to a network official who spoke on condition of anonymity. CONTAM's request comes at a time the networks are sharply questioning data from Nielsen's people-meter system, which is in 4,000 homes. Among other things, the data for the first three months of this year showed daytime viewing levels had taken their sharpest dive _ 5.5 percent _ in recent memory. In a May 3 meeting here with about 300 network and advertising exectives, Nielsen officials said they had found no flaws in Nielsen's ratings system, but that they were studying it and willing to work with the industry to improve it. The people-meter devices require participating viewers to log on when they watch TV, thus telling Nielsen who is watching TV as well as how many. The system now under fire by the networks became the industry standard in 1987, replacing passive devices called audimeters that only recorded TV set use, and gave raw numbers but not instant demographic information. ``The people meter is supposed to do both, and obviously can't do both,'' said Nicholas Schiavone, an NBC vice president for marketing and sales research who is president of CONTAM. Uncertainty over the data could have an impact next month when advertisers begin their so-called ``upfront'' buying of commercial network time, which this year is estimated to be worth $9 billion to $10 billion. The next step apparently is up to Schiavone's group. Jo LaVerde, a Nielsen spokeswoman, said the company still was waiting for a concrete proposal for a study from CONTAM. Proposals outlining the scope of the study then will have to be exchanged and an agreement reached, ``because a proposal will not a test make,'' she said.

DOC.HEAD: Chrysler Chief Begs Shareholders To Have Patience
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 10th graf, `Asked if ...' to CORRECT Viper launch to 1992 model year sted 1993.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto LA10
DOC.TEXT: Chrysler Corp. Chairman Lee Iacocca urged shareholders Thursday to hang on despite falling profits and a slumping stock price, saying things will look better by the time its Viper sports car goes into production in late 1992. At the company's annual meeting, Iacocca acknowledged that last year's earnings were disappointing and sales have been slow. But he counseled shareholders to take a long view, saying Chrysler has prepared for strong performance in the 1990s. ``Nobody in this room is more frustrated than I am at our stock sitting there at about $17 a share today,'' Iacocca said. ``Hell, that means the stock is less than half the book value of the company. And it's half a billion less than the cash we have in the bank.'' But he said that despite recent woes, the company is far better off than a decade ago, when it survived only because the government co-signed its loans. And he said that anyone who bought Chrysler shares then would have earned a fine return. ``If you'd rushed out after our shareholder's meeting 10 years ago and bought $1,000 worth of Chrysler stock and reinvested all the dividends it would be worth $9,500 as you're sitting here today. So yeah, I'm not too happy about that stock price right now. But take the long view for a minute.'' He also pledged to continue a yearly dividend of $1.20 per share ``barring a disaster.' He said a series of plant closures were regrettable, but unavoidable, given U.S. car-building overcapacity. And he described a $15.6 billion, five-year product development plan and $1 billion research and development center as untouchable. On Friday, Iacocca is scheduled to reveal details of the company's planned 10-cylinder Viper, which will compete with the Chevrolet Corvette. The news conference will cap a six-city tour promoting an ad campaign that claims the quality of Chrysler cars now equals Japanese models and that they are the safest on the road. Briefly answering a few questions after the meeting, he said, ``I think we've got a good program. We'll come back in the next six months.'' Asked if it is appropriate to introduce an expensive, limited-appeal car like the Viper at a time when car sales and profits are falling, he implied things would be better when it is introduced for the 1992 model year. ``It's going to take a year and a half yet,'' Iacocca said. Chrysler also is working on a new line of sleek, mid-size cars and an additional model for its profitable Jeep line, among other vehicles. Compared to 1980, Chrysler today has only one-tenth the debt ratio, $4.3 billion in the bank versus $300 million, a $2.6 billion credit line not dependent on Washington, a profitable credit division, and a car market share about 3 percentage points higher, at 13 percent, he said. He denied that his latest ad campaign constituted Japan-bashing, saying he never said a word against the Japanese people or the high-quality products they produce, but only against their trade practices and the U.S. government for allowing them. ``One thing we've learned is that the competition will not necessarily be a fair competition,'' Iacocca said. Questioned by shareholders, Iacocca acknowledged that service at dealerships could be improved and that top Chrysler management could benefit from more direct contact with people who buy and build the vehicles. He also said he's hopeful that the U.S. auto industry will be able to wean itself from heavy rebates, with the accompanying artificially high sticker prices, although he wouldn't predict when that would happen. ``I'd like to do away with them,'' Iacocca said. ``We're all sort of on dope. We got onto it 10 years ago, and now we can't get off it.''

DOC.HEAD: Say Phone Giant Breaking the Rules with New Credit Card
DOC.TEXT: Four major banks accused American Telephone & Telegraph Co. on Thursday of violating federal telephone and banking regulations with its new Visa and MasterCard credit card. The banks, in a filing with the Federal Communications Commission and other regulatory agencies, said that by offering 10 percent long-distance discounts to holders of its AT&T Universal Card, the telephone giant was illegally discriminating against other AT&T customers. The discount was provided ``simply to promote AT&T's entrance into the general purpose consumer credit card market,'' the banks told the FCC. AT&T said the allegations of illegal behavior were ``absolutely without merit.'' The FCC filing cited published reports estimating that AT&T could have 5 million customers for its credit card by the end of this year. Credit card industry officials have said that consumers loaded down with bulging wallets full of plastic probably would find a combined credit card attractive _ and put big pressure on traditional bank cards. The banks _ BankAmerica Corp., Chase Manhattan Corp., Citicorp. and MBNA America Bank _ also made filings with the Federal Deposit Insurance Corp. and the Federal Reserve, said Doug Jones, the FDIC's deputy general counsel. ``They're alleging banking violations,'' Jones said. He didn't elaborate. FDIC spokesman David Barr said the banks had sent a 53-page petition to the agency on Tuesday, with a 10-page cover letter to FDIC Chairman L. William Seidman. AT&T spokesman Jim McGann said the banks also filed a complaint with the Georgia state banking commission. The banks said AT&T was charging discriminatory phone rates; had failed to have the 10 percent discount approved; failed to file tariffs for finance charges and late charges imposed on the card users; and discriminated against other credit card holders in access to phone service. Peter Gallagher, senior vice president for corporate and consumer affairs at AT&T Universal Card Services Corp., said AT&T was not violating telephone rules. The card is issued through Universal Bank in Georgia. ``I'm absolutely confident we are in total compliance with the appropriate laws, rules and regulations,'' Gallagher said. He also rejected the banks' assertion that Universal Bank was acting as a reseller of phone services, which also would fall under FCC regulation, and that the Universal Card discriminated against non-AT&T credit card holders who try to use AT&T coinless pay phones. ``We are not going to be deterred by any diversionary tactics,'' Gallagher said. ``We're committed to the credit card business. We're here to stay.'' He declined to disclose how many people had signed up for the card but said the response ``has been wonderful.''

DOC.HEAD: PacifiCorp Again Raises Offer For Pinnacle West
DOC.TEXT: PacifiCorp on Thursday increased its bid for Pinnacle West Capital Corp. to $1.82 billion, the fourth offer in six months by the Portland, Ore.-based utility giant for Arizona's largest power company or its parent. David F. Bolender, president of PacifiCorp's electric operations, said it would be the last offer. Pressed by reporters at a news conference here, Bolender added that the bid would be withdrawn if there was no progress within a few weeks. Pinnacle West, which went from the robust holding company for Arizona Public Service Co. to the brink of reorganization after buying MeraBank in 1984, will hold its annual meeting Wednesday. Last month, some stockholders of Pinnacle West urged management, including new Chairman Richard Snell, to accept PacifiCorp's next offer. Pinnacle West spokesman Steve Carr said the company's directors would seriously consider the takeover package. Under the offer, Pinnacle West shareholders would receive $21 in cash for each share of stock. Wall Street cheered the offer. Pinnacle West shares jumped $3.62{ to close at $16.37{ in New York Stock Exchange trading. Kathleen A. Lally, an analyst with County NatWest Securities in New York, called the offer ``very attractive'' and said that if Pinnacle West ignored it, the company could face lawsuits by angry shareholders. In November, PacifiCorp offered $1.7 billion for Arizona Public Service. Pinnacle West, then controlled by Chairman Keith Turley, rejected that bid. In December, it rejected another offer, this time for all of Pinnacle West and its subsidiaries but MeraBank, which lost more than $400 million in the last two years. In early March, Pinnacle West rejected a third offer that its directors said was equivalent to $16 per share. That offer was for a common-stock swap valued at $1.7 billion and an exchange of Arizona Public Service preferred stock, worth $372 million, plus assumption of debt. Federal regulators took control of MeraBank Jan. 31, but the holding company was forced to borrow $450 million to bring the failed thrift up to capital requirements, increasing its debt to $1.1 billion. Pinnacle West, which has suspended its dividends, made $4.2 million in 1988 and reported a $551.4 million loss for 1989. In its latest offer, PacifiCorp also agreed to assume all debt of Pinnacle West and Arizona Public Service. In addition, Bolender said PacifiCorp would retain an offer to limit Arizona Public Service rate increases to 2 percent per year for four years, which is less than a 6{ percent-per-year, three-year proposal filed by the utility with state regulators.

DOC.HEAD: Drivers Rally Outside Financial Backers
DOC.TEXT: Striking Greyhound drivers took their picket lines to the company's financial backers Thursday and urged them to pressure the financially strapped bus line back to the bargaining table. ``If Greyhound goes under, they go under,'' Ellis B. Franklin, vice president of the Amalgamated Transit Uniont, said as about 60 supporters of the 11-week-old strike rallied outside the offices of PaineWebber Inc. Franklin said the investment bank owns 16 percent of the closely held bus company's parent firm. Similar rallies were held outside brokerages and other financial institutions in seven other cities. A call to PaineWebber was not immediately returned. Greyhound spokesman George Gravley said he expected the rallies to have no effect on lenders. ``Companies that put up millions of dollars are not going to make decisions based on some rally,'' Gravley said. Greyhound is continuing to operate reduced services with about 3,000 strikebreakers. The firm lost $56 million in the first three months of this year and has missed payments on its debt obligations. Earlier this week Standard & Poor's, a leading credit rating agency, lowered Greyhound's rating to D, denoting a default on its debt. In Washington, strikers chanted ``Contract'' and ``Negotiate Now'' as they walked in a circle on a busy downtown street at noontime. Cheers went up when Franklin announced the credit rating drop. Gravley dismissed the credit rating drop as a ``technicality.'' The company expected the move after announcing its first quarter loss and plans to miss a $9.75 million interest payment that was due on Tuesday, he said. For weeks, Greyhound refused to resume negotiations with the union because of dozens of shootings and bomb threats. When talks finally resumed two weeks ago, the union called the company's offer an ``insult.'' Last week, Greyhound Chairman Fred Currey claimed victory and dismissed the strike as irrelevant. ``Regardless of what Mr. Currey says, the ATU is not going anywhere. We'll be here forever,'' Franklin told the picket line.

DOC.HEAD: AT&T Says It Will Lower Evening Rates 2.5 Percent
DOC.NOTE: EDS: ADDS 6 grafs of background on reductions and price caps.
DOC.TEXT: American Telephone & Telegraph Co. said Thursday it planned to lower its interstate and international rates by about $160 million annually, effective July 1. In a filing with the Federal Communications Commission, AT&T said it would reduce by $100 million its prices for direct-dialed interstate calls during evening hours. That represents a reduction of about 2.5 percent. An additional $60 million reduction would take place in other long-distance and operator services, the company added. But it also plans to eliminate the free call to interstate directory service now offered each month. The company said its research showed that only one in four residential customers uses that directory assistance over a three-month period. The changes require FCC approval. The company said that during evening calling hours, 5 p.m. to 11 p.m., Sunday through Friday, the price of a 10-minute direct-dialed call to anywhere in the continental United States will cost $1.53 or less. Today such a call costs $1.58 or less. The decrease is AT&T's 11th since 1984 following the breakup of the old Bell system. The decrease would bring the company's total long-distance reductions to 42 percent during that period. AT&T's main competitors, MCI and US Sprint, have tended to drop their prices in line with AT&T. AT&T spokesman Jim McGann said the $60 million portion of the reduction was in anticipation of an expected adjustment by the FCC in what long-distance carriers pay to connect with local phone networks. Much of the post-1984 reductions in long-distance rates has been because of FCC-ordered reductions in so-called access charges. When the long-distance carriers paid less, they were required to pass those savings along to customers. But in July 1989, the FCC imposed a new regulatory structure that caps the prices AT&T charges instead of its profits. As a result, AT&T doesn't automatically pass through its savings to customers. ``We're not required anymore to directly, dollar for dollar, pass through reductions to us, for instance in access,'' McGann said. ``What we're required to do is stay below the cap.'' In fact, last November AT&T raised interstate night and weekend calling rates by 1.3 percent _ a $34 million annual increase. McGann said competition and increased productivity was the best guarantee of lower prices. He said AT&T's evening prices already were below the price caps, and the new reduction will drop them even farther below.

DOC.HEAD: Exxon Exploration Reorganization Cuts Jobs In Midland, Denver
DOC.TEXT: Exxon Co. USA has announced a realignment of its exploration operations that will result in about 200 layoffs. The company said Thursday it would combine its western and eastern divisions into one operation to find oil and gas in the 48 contiguous states. The job cuts will be divided evenly between Midland, Texas, and Denver. ``This change is designed to improve the efficiency of conducting our business in today's highly competitive business environment,'' said S.M. Cassiani, vice president of exploration for Exxon USA, the domestic subsidiary of Exxon Corp. Exxon said it would combine the western exploration division, with offices in Midland and Denver, with the Houston-based eastern exploration division. The changes will be completed by late summer, Exxon said. Exxon said a small complement of people will remain in Denver doing project acquisition and the southwestern production division will retain its Midland operations.

DOC.HEAD: Pratt & Whitney to Enter Soviet Aviation Market
DOC.TEXT: Pratt & Whitney said it is entering the developing Soviet aviation market through a three-way pact with the Soviet government and a West German engine maker. Although the agreement is short on specifics, Pratt officials said it opens the door to cooperative ventures on small- to medium-sized commercial aviation engines. Pratt spokeswoman Peggy Ford said the agreement could involve the co-development of a new engine. Soviet participation in production of engines made by Pratt and Motoren und Turbinen Union also will be considered, she said. The cooperation is likely to involve the use of engines with up to 40,000 pounds of thrust _ about equal to most recent outgrowths of Pratt's PW2000 series, Pratt spokesman Mark Sullivan said. The engines likely would be used on Soviet-built airframes, Sullivan said, although he said the agreement does not exclude the possibility of engines powering Western-built aircraft. Sullivan said the agreement takes into account a suit Pratt rival General Electric Co. filed against MTU recently. That suit seeks to stop a new MTU-Pratt partnership to develop larger versions of Pratt's PW4000 engine. The suit charges that permitting MTU to collaborate with Pratt would jeopardize technology GE has shared with the West German company. Pratt's announcement boosts the East Hartford-based jet-engine maker into the Soviet engine arena at a time when GE has been touting its early successes there. Most recently, GE, based in Fairfield, landed a $150 million deal to supply as many as 10 of its CF6-80C2 engines to the Soviets to power Airbus Industrie A310-300s. The planes by the France-based European consortium will be the country's first western-built aircraft.

DOC.HEAD: Reports 77 Percent Drop In Quarterly Net
DOC.TEXT: Navistar International Corp. said net income plunged 77 percent in its fiscal second quarter because of an industry-wide decline in retail truck sales. Chicago-based Navistar, the country's biggest manufacturer of medium- and heavy-duty trucks, said net income in the three months ended April 30 was $8 million or 1 cent a share, compared with $35 million or 11 cents a share in the same period a year ago. Sales fell 10 percent to $1 billion from $1.1 billion. Chairman James C. Cotting said industry-wide sales of medium and heavy trucks in North America fell 12 percent in the first three months of 1990 to 71,000 units. Navistar's fiscal second-quarter deliveries of 22,200 units were 10 percent below the same quarter a year earlier, Cotting said in a statement. For the first half of fiscal 1990, Navistar lost $10 million or 10 cents a share on sales of $1.9 billion. In the comparable 1989 period, the company earned $72 million or 23 cents a share on sales of $2.2 billion.

DOC.HEAD: Investor Group Holds 59 Percent of AI's Junior Debt
DOC.TEXT: A New York-based investor group seeking control of Allegheny International Inc. said Thursday it had acquired 59 percent of the troubled appliance maker's junior debt through a public tender offer. The offer by Japonica Partners expired Wednesday. Control of the debt could put Japonica in a strong position to get its reorganization proposal approved by creditors of the company, which sells the Sunbeam and Oster brands. A preliminary count showed Japonica received tenders for $69.5 million of the $111.5 million principal value outstanding of three series of Allegheny International subordinated debt, Japonica said in a statement. It offered to buy those bonds at prices ranging from 27.7 cents to 41 cents on the dollar. It also received $6 million out of $17.3 million principal amount of subordinated debt of Chemetron Corp., an Allegheny International subsidiary, by offering 83.8 cents on the dollar. Japonica previously purchased significant percentages of the company's secured bank and senior unsecured claims and used its voting power to ensure a company-sponsored reorganization plan was defeated in a creditors' vote. Allegheny International has been in Chapter 11 reorganization since February 1988. The company is seeking to get its reorganization plan confirmed by U.S. Bankruptcy Court. It has asked the court to nullify Japonica's votes. Company spokesman Edward Romanoff declined comment on the Japonica offer Thursday. Japonica's $655 million reorganization proposal would pay cash to all of Allegheny International's creditors and shareholders. The company's plan would repay most claims other than trade debt in new stock. Allegheny International values its plan at $687 million, but Japonica has claimed that figure is inflated. Allegheny International's unsecured creditors' committee said in a letter last week that it judged the value of the two plans to be about equal.

DOC.HEAD: FBI Agent Defends His Abilities on Trading Floor
DOC.TEXT: An undercover FBI agent told jurors Thursday he traded thousands of commodities contracts for customers while secretely recording pit traders' conversations during an unprecedented sting operation. FBI Agent Randall Jannett took the witness stand to defend his ability to spot illegal trading during a wide-ranging federal probe of corruption at the Chicago Mercantile Exchange and the Chicago Board of Trade. Forty-seven traders and a clerk in the world's two largest commodity exchanges were indicted last year as a result of the investigation. Prosecutors contend that traders diverted customer profits into their own accounts. Sixteen of those charged have pleaded guilty to reduced charges and agreed to cooperate with federal prosecutors. Jannett specialized in Swiss franc futures during 1988. A Swiss franc future is a contract to buy or sell that currency at a future date at a price agreed upon in advance. Jannett and another FBI agent, posing as inexperienced commodities traders investing family money, passed all the tests required to trade on the exchange floor. They bought seats on the exchange and opened their own trading company. Defense attorneys for the first three traders to go to trial _ Danny L. Scheck, Robert D. Mosky and David Zatz _ told jurors last week that Jannett was so confused by the frantic pace of activity on the floor that he mistook legal transactions for attempts to defraud customers. Jannett's testimony Thursday was devoted to establishing his credentials as a commodities trader and showing jurors how he hid a tape recorder inside his red trading jacket. The three traders are being tried before U.S. District Court Judge Ann C. Williams. The government's case rests partly on those taped conversations. Defense attorneys contend the recordings are incomprehensible because of the harried shouting typical of the trading floor. They also contend that Jannett was so inexperienced that he mistook traders' attempts to verify transactions for schemes to steal customers profits. Prosecutors are expected to begin playing hours of recorded trading floor action when trial resumes Friday.
